PM deny knowledge of AWB kickback 
The Prime Minister have deny he know AWB be pay kickback to Iraq despite write to the wheat exporter ask to be keep fully inform on Iraq wheat sale . 
Letters from John Howard and Deputy Prime Minister Mark Vaile to AWB have be release by the Cole inquiry into the oil for food program . 
In one of the letter Mr Howard ask AWB manage director Andrew Lindberg to remain in close contact with the Government on Iraq wheat sale . 
The Opposition 's Gavan O'Connor say the letter be send in 2002 , the same time AWB be pay kickback to Iraq though a Jordanian trucking company . 
He say the Government can longer wipe it hand of the illicit payment , which total $ 290 million . 
`` The responsibility for this must lay may squarely at the foot of Coalition minister in trade , agriculture and the Prime Minister , '' he say . 
But the Prime Minister say letter show he be inquire about the future of wheat sale in Iraq and do not prove the Government knew of the payment . 
`` It would have be astonish in 2002 if a Prime Minister I have n't do anything I possibly could to preserve Australia 's very valuable wheat market , '' he say . 

Email question 
Today at the inquiry , AWB trading manager Peter Geary have be question about an email he receive in May 2000 . 
It indicate that the Iraqi Grains Board have approach AWB to provide `` after-sales service '' . 
Mr Geary say he have forward the email to two AWB colleague and do not remember read it , although he say he may have skim it . 

Support 
AWB still have plenty of support among grain grower in central western New South Wales despite the revelation of the Cole inquiry . 
Producers say they broadly support AWB 's attempt to get the best price for their product . 
`` I think it 's all a ploy by overseas interest to try and get the single desk put aside . The story that be go round about the commission and everything , I think that 's the way people have get to do thing to do business with the Middle East and Asian country , '' one producer say . 
`` I think it 's actually a pretty reasonable system and I think actually I 'd give them pretty fair support at the moment . I think on average they 've perform fairly well , '' another producer say . 
`` The big thing about someone else take over be whether the multinationals will get too much of a foothold in there and take it too much to their advantage . '' 

Grain price 
But an analyst predict grain price will drop another $ 20 a tonne on the back of the inquiry into AWB . 
Malcolm Bartholomaeus say pool return have already drop by $ 20 a tonne this year from the average price over the past five year . 
He say the premium that AWB be achieve through it wheat export monopoly have be severely erode . 

SA farmer help fire ravage neighbour 
Farmers in South Australia 's south-east be donate truckloads of hay to their neighbour across the border in the wake of the Grampians bushfires . 
In just a few day , farmer have donate 250 tonne of hay , as well a agistment for cattle . 
They say that be just the beginning . 
Fodder drive coordinator Peter O'Conner say he have be overwhelm by the response . 
`` All the hay that 's go this week have all go from place that have donate one load or up to two load of hay , '' he say . 
`` We 've get one man that 's donate two full load and the rest be all one load , straight load that we 're move this week . 

Floodwaters close highway 
A major highway between the Northern Territory and Western Australia remain block by floodwaters today . 
The Victoria River have cut the Victoria Highway and also flood the remote Pigeon Hole Aboriginal community . 
Stockman Simon Ham describe the relocation of a hundred people to high ground . 
`` They have all their vehicle move out of the community and they have a few camp set up and they be move more people and belonging out with a couple of boat , just onto high ground , only 500 metre from the community , '' he say . 
`` They be up on a sandstone ridge at the moment and I think the river height might be up for a little long but I think it [ the Victoria River ] will start go down . '' 

Grain company sell for $ 9m 
Tasmania 's main grain company have change hand for the second time in just three year . 
The former state-owned Tasmanian Grain Elevators Board have be sell to local agribusiness Roberts Limited for about $ 9 million . 
The deal include silo at Launceston , Devonport and Powranna in northern Tasmania . 
John Macleod from Roberts Limited say the company bid when the board be first privatise . 
`` We be very disappointed we be n't successful at that point of time , '' he say . 

Wine worker stop work 
Workers at Hardy Wines ' Stanley winery in south-western New South Wales have walk off the job for the second time in a week . 
Forty staff walk out this morning in a dispute over a new enterprise bargaining agreement . 
The stopwork come just a the region 's wine grape crush get under way . 
Hardy Wines take the matter to the Industrial Relations Commission ( IRC ) on Friday . 

Wool body eye sportswear industry 
The $ 50 billion global sportswear industry be the new target of wool promotion body , Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) . 
AWI be show wool blend t-shirt and casual wear to manufacturer this week at the large trade show for the industry be hold in Germany . 
AWI 's Len Stephens say although wool-blend sportswear will be at the pricy end of the market , shopper be willing to pay more . 
`` The sport apparel market sector be one of the big and certainly the fast grow apparel sector in the world , and it 's no secret that wool have n't have a very big share of that market at all , '' he say . 
`` The level of wool , particularly Australian merino wool in the sport market be really almost below the radar . 

Organisation to step up ban rodeo campaign 
Tasmania 's rodeo industry be under sustain attack from animal right activist after another animal have to be destroy at a weekend event . 
A bucking horse be put down after break a leg at Ulverstone on Saturday . 
Two week ago , a bull be destroy after apparently break it back during a bull-riding competition at Carrick . 
The owner of both animal , Brian Fish , say they be unfortunate accident and not an animal welfare issue . 
But Emma Haswell from Against Animal Cruelty Tasmania say her organisation will up it effort to have rodeo ban . 

Snails use in cancer research 
New research be under way to investigate whether South Australian sea snail could eventually be use to treat cancer . 
Until now the state 's snail population have be virtually unexplored but Flinders University hop to discover beneficial compound in predatory sea snail , know a whelk . 
Marine biologist Dr Kirsten Benkendorff say the work follow research overseas , where clinical trial be now investigate anti-cancer property . 
`` The whelk that I 'm look at at the moment be not currently harvest and not really consider a useful resource so I think that there 's a lot of potential economic benefit from that side of thing , '' she say . 

Processors fail to meet kangaroo meat demand 
International demand for kangaroo meat be put pressure on Australian processor . 
Despite high price , harvest quota be not be meet leave a big gap in the market . 
Phil Franolick from King River International Processors in Perth say Europeans be attract to the meat 's low fat content and Russians be consume large amount of kangaroo sausage and mince . 
`` As far a I know every skerrick of manufactured meat that be produce by human consumption processor virtually go to the Russian market now , '' he say . 

People warn to be on snake alert 
With temperature soar this summer , particularly in southern Australia , snake be on the move . 
People be be warn to keep their eye open out in the paddock , especially in area hit by bushfires , with snake force from their usual habitat . 
Maria Dovey from Reptile Rescue Tasmania have these word of advice . 
`` Any people who be regularly outdoors , whether they be camp , bush walking , people who 're on the land work , they must always carry at least two bandage with them and a mobile phone , '' she say . 

Aerial spraying begin to control locust threat 
Victoria 's high country farmer have begin aerial spraying to try to control the threat of locust . 
It be the first time locust plague have make it to the region , with continued rain and warm weather assist breed condition . 
Pastures and crop have already be wipe out by the pest . 

Injury wo n't stop baton runner 
A southern Queensland cattle farmer say a knee injury will not stop him run in the Queen 's baton relay today in the lead-up to the Commonwealth Games . 
Stanthorpe 's Bill Bonner travel to Coffs Harbour in New South Wales to run his leg of the relay . 
And he say injury will not prevent him from make the 500 metre dash . 
`` About two week ago I be jump off my motorbike and twist a ligament in my knee and I have n't be able to do more than walk since , '' he say . 
`` But I promise you I will run that baton because you get such an adrenalin rush that I think you could only have one leg and you could still run it . '' 

The NZ apple debate continue 
In a New Zealand newspaper on the weekend , member of the New Zealand apple industry voice concern regard the legitimacy of the `` science '' use in the draft Import Risk Analysis put out last month by Biosecurity Australia . The draft Import Risk Analysis ( IRA ) determine the risk of fireblight and other pest and disease if New Zealand apple be import into Australia . 
Under the World Trade Organisation 's rule Australia can refuse the importation of New Zealand apple if they be able to provide scientific evidence of a substantial disease or pest risk . But accord to the New Zealand apple grower , `` professional '' scientific evidence show that mature apple import into Australia pose no risk of fireblight . However the spokesperson for the New Zealand base Australian Apple Access Group Phil Allison say Biosecurity Australia have not provide the mathematical model use to determine the `` scientific '' evidence state in the draft IRA . 
A spokesperson for Biosecurity Australia say : `` the formula use in the risk assessment be provide in the Draft Import Risk Analysis Report on New Zealand Apples , which be publish last December for anyone to read . A competent modeller can reproduce the model use in the risk analysis from the formula give in the report . '' The chairman of the fireblight task force , John Corboy , say the response and concern from New Zealand apple grower regard the draft IRA be not surprising , but Australia have to be able to exercise it right to refuse the apple base on the scientific evidence it have present in the IRA . 

Younger tree produce more pear 
A trial plot of young williams pear tree have produce fruit three year after they be plant . Usually the tree do n't produce fruit until they 're about five or six year old . The tree be part of a five year experimental project , fund by SPC Ardmona through the Canned Fruits Association , Horticulture Australia Limited and the Lenne family orchard - where the trial plot be locate . 
Horticulture consultant Bas Van Den Ende say the aim of the project be to increase the number of williams pear grow in the future by encourage the young tree to produce early than usual .

Fish death believe to be due to lack of oxygen 
The Department of Primary Industries be investigate a big fish kill in the Lachlan River upstream of the Lake Cargelligo Weir . Between 150 and 200 native fish die in the incident earlier this month . District Fisheries Officer Phillip McCarthy say murray cod , bream and golden and silver perch be kill but no introduced specie die . He say inquiry suggest the death be the result of an increased water flow not chemical poisoning . 

Vegetable industry concern on label 
Agriculture group AUSVEG say food label law in Australia be a joke because nobody follow them and enforcement of the rule be non-existent . AUSVEG say consumer be still be fool into think they 're buy Australian product because of false or poor labelling . 

Red tape slow west Kimberley horticulture 
The Kimberley could be WA 's food bowl with it top soil , available water and sunshine all year round - though it facing hurdle to expand . Sweet potato grower Paul Higgins still rely on a generator and say Broome horticulturalists be the only one in the state not connect to the grid . He and his neighbour have be apply to get a nine kilometre extension to the current grid system to bring them into line . A spokesperson from Western Power say it be possible , though it 's up to customer to pay for their connection cost , regardless of the distance from the exist grid . Land acquisition be also cause headache . Mr Higgins purchase adjoin country last June , though still have n't receive title . He ca n't improve the land until this be clear . `` All the issue have be resolve - area survey , native title issue have be put to bed , monies have be pay , but still we do n't have land title . We ca n't clear the land , apply for water title , ca n't do anything , '' he say . The Minister for Planning and Infrastructure , Alannah McTiernan , say the seven month delay be regrettable and Mr Higgins should have be make aware of the hold up in the West Australian Planning Office because the land be not correctly zone . Though Ms McTiernan say the delay may have work in his favour , give the land be sell at 2004 property price . Mr Higgins still wait for the official all clear before he can start plough the Pindan for more potato . 

Richmond River to stay open to fisher 
The Department of Primary Industries have decide against close the Richmond River to commercial and recreational fisher in the wake of last week 's fish kill . About 300 dead fish and eel be discover near Wardell last Thursday , when oxygen level in the water drop alarmingly . The act director of fishery management , Anthony Hirst , say inspector will take further sample from the river tomorrow .

The macadamia producer hop a win in the event will help her to produce a guide promote sustainability in the industry , but she admit she 's amaze to have even make it this far . 

DSE 'is carry out proactive Grampians burn off ' 
On the rural report yesterday we hear farmer and CFA officer say they feel the intensity of the Grampians fire could have be lessen if more fuel reduction burn have be carry out in the national park . Charley DeFegley , who 's the Ararat VFF branch secretary and a CFA divisional commander , say he felt not enough burn off have be carry out and this have contribute to the destructive force of the fire . But the Department of Sustainability 's fire manager for the Horsham district and incident controller for the Grampians fire , Geoff Evans , say the agency have a proactive burning off policy . He say burn off be hamper because some landowner be not keen about burn off beside their property and the weather do not allow control burn at some time of the year , give a very small window of opportunity . He say there be also strong division within the community about whether more or less burn off should be carry out in the national park . But Mr Evans say about 5,000 to 8,000 hectare of the park be burn off every year .

The state government have announce it will commit million of dollar to the recovery effort for the new year bushfires include the blaze in the Grampians and a ministerial task force be to start assess need . The government say it will also help landowner face hardship a a result of their water supply be use by firefighting . But already , Department of Primary Industry officer , the Victorian Farmers Federation , haulage contractor and farmer all over western Victoria , have be work at a grassroots level to help fire affected landowner . Hundreds of tonne of hay , 21 semi-loads of which be bring to a collection point at Moyston from Warrnambool yesterday , have be donate to farmer who need fodder for their surviving animal . Bruce McKay say he have be on farm help to put sheep down and fix fencing in the Willaura area . Tim Wrench from the Warrnambool Coop say people come from all around the area to donate hay . Haulier Scott Wilson from Koroit say when he go onto farm to collect hay people say `` just load up until you 're full '' . Neil James from the DPI say hay be be donate from New South Wales and South Australia . Charlie DeFegeley from the VFF say the response have be amaze . 

Fuel price , weather blame for hike in fresh food cost 
Fuel price and fluctuate weather condition be be blame for a 12 per cent jump in the cost of fresh food over the past year . 
The late food industry analysis from Rabobank show consumer be pay more for their milk , meat , fruit and vegetable . 
But Rabobank 's Dr Ben Russell say the money be go to manufacturer and processor , not grower . 
`` In the case of pass on high fuel price it 's to the contrary because farmer have get to pay high fuel price as well a see the retail price of the product they 're produce go up , '' he say . 

Low price , fall demand slow down wheat export 
Wheat export have slow due to low price and fall demand from Australia 's traditional market . 
Despite some sale to Egypt , other market include Iraq , Pakistan , China and India have fail to deliver the expected number of contract . 
With the second large global crop on record , competition for tender be particularly fierce . 
Grains trader Lloyd George say there be a range of factor for the slow-down . 
`` Certainly Iraq have be an important customer of Australia 's over a period of time , put in pretty significant tonnage and over the recent month AWB have n't be export the quantity we have in the past , '' he say . 
`` But there 's a whole bunch of broad issue out there as well . A lot of the market whereby Australia would hope to sell the quantity of the harvest into be the same market that be quiet this year . '' 

Iraq market 
AWB 's national pool manager David Johnson deny the oil-for-food inquiry be have an impact on trade and say Australia have not lose Iraq a a major market . 
He say AWB submit a tender to supply a million tonne of wheat to Iraq last week . 
`` We 'll be look to participate in that tender , absolutely , '' he say . 
`` Probably relatively , compare to the structure of the market in previous year , this pool return might look a little different but the world market be different . 
`` I think it 's just a fact that the export business be extremely quiet and I think you 'd find the same comment from other export country around the world . '' 
AWB have announce an increase to new season pool estimate , lift the return for hard wheat by $ 2.00 a tonne and for noodle grade by $ 4.00 a tonne . 
There be a mixed outlook for other grain . 
Record soy bean harvest in the US , Ukraine and Brazil mean there be a large global supply of the canola alternative , which will put pressure on oil seed price in Australia . 
David Syme from the WA Grain Pool say malt barley sale have be slow due to the Chinese New Year but sale should soon pick up . 
`` At this point in time , Australia really have be hold the major stock of malt barley around the world , '' he say . 
`` The Canadians do n't have a lot to offer to the marketplace , that put u in a good position and of course the next lot of supply of malt barley really come out of Europe in August , so some time away yet . 
`` Once the Chinese re-emerge we look forward to a strong selling program . '' 

Inquiry chief 
Meanwhile the head of the oil-for-food inquiry have yet to respond to complaint that the investigation be not be conduct fairly . 
Counsel for AWB tell the hearing yesterday that witness have be ambush and ridicule . 
The comment be in response to criticism from Commissioner Terence Cole last week that AWB 's level of cooperation be a facade . 
AWB 's lawyer say Commissioner Cole 's expectation be unreasonable because of the time available to prepare witness statement and the availability of document . 
In another development , the New South Wales Farmers Association say it be prepared to fight to maintain the single desk for wheat export . 
Despite keep a low profile since the start of the inquiry , the association have today come out in support of the current monopoly export system . 
Grains committee chairman Angus McLaren say grow pressure from opponent of the single desk be concern but grain grower be prepared for any challenge to their marketing system . 
`` I think the most important thing we can do and what we 've be concentrate on do be gather our thought and do research and preparing for the battle that we think probably will occur , '' he say . 

Lib MP push for NZ apple ban 
A federal Liberal Party MP be push for a permanent ban on apple import from New Zealand . 
Russell Broadbent from the seat of McMillan , east of Melbourne , be draft a private member 's bill to ban import from any country with the disease fireblight . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran have reject the bill , say it would also affect a wide range of import and export . 
But Mr Broadbent say he will push on with the plan . 
`` Mr McGauran be the Minister but he do n't actually have many orchard in his seat of Gippsland do he ? '' Mr Broadbent say . 
`` So I do n't suppose he 's expose a closely to the issue and a passionately to the issue a many of the backbench member be across the nation . '' 

Avocado grower to compete with NZ import 
With harvest about to begin , avocado grower be face stiff competition from New Zealand import . 
For the past five year , the import have petered out before the start of the local harvest but this year a record New Zealand crop have lead to a 50 per cent jump in export to Australia . 
North Queensland 's Shepard avocado will be the first to be pick here . 
Shepard Australia chairman Jim Kochi say grower need to focus on send quality fruit to the market . 
`` They certainly do n't have enough people leave in New Zealand to consume their crop , I think they 're all here in Australia ... most of them and so the rest of it be come to Australia and it be a large volume of fruit , '' he say . 

Govt urge to get tough on enforce food label law 
Fruit and vegetable grower be call on the Federal Government to get tough on state which do not enforce country-of-origin label law . 
Producer group AUSVEG say some state be not push for new law to be implement on fresh and package produce , and that be mislead consumer . 
Chief executive John Roach say the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission ( ACCC ) need to look at the issue again . 
`` Excuse the pun out of the vegetable industry but you do need a reasonable amount of carrot and you do need a little bit of stick , '' he say . 
`` And what have not happen with any consistency across Australia be that last one , that bit of stick , it be not consistent - it vary hugely and often there be case where it do n't exist at all . '' 
The ACCC say the label issue have be look at and the authority be satisfy with current compliance . 

Growers to get less for currant crop 
Dried fruit grower supply Australia 's large processor have be deal a major blow . 
Uncontracted currant grower have learn that they will receive just $ 650 per tonne for their fruit this year , half of what they be pay last year . 

Code of conduct for rodeo organiser 
Rodeo organiser in Tasmania will have to comply with a mandatory code of conduct in the future . 
The code be be implement after a public outcry over rodeo practice . 
There have be two very public incident at rodeo in the past fortnight that have outrage animal right activist and the television watch public . 
A bull be put down after drag it paralysed hindquarter behind it a it leave the ring and on Saturday a bucking horse be put down in the arena after it break a leg a it exit the chute . 
The public outcry have force the State Government to declare a mandatory set of regulation will soon be enforce on all rodeo before a permit be issue . 
A major requirement will be for a vet to be on site at all event , rather than only on call . 

Camp cook in demand 
Camp cook and grader driver be prove the hard job to fill on cattle station in northern Australia this year . 
The lure of high-paying mining job have keep many away from the Kimberley , in particular . 
While they have be lucky to get a full team at Flora Valley Station near Halls Creek , manager Wayne Bean say camp cook be a die breed . 
`` One time , once people finish work a stockhands or ringer on station they find their little niche in life , either cook for the station , or drive the grader or running a a bore runner but that just do n't seem to be happen now , '' he say . 
`` People be drift off into the mine and other big corporation and there 's still a few that seem who enjoy be on the station , and it 's not about money for them .

Floodwaters in the Northern Territory be still block a major highway today . 
The Victoria Highway between Katherine and Kununurra be cut by swollen river in at least three place . 

NZ shearer break work record 
A team of New Zealand shearer have break the world three-stand lamb shearing record 
Jimmy Clarke and Peter and Shane Harvey shore 2,350 lamb in nine hour at Mt Linton Station on the South Island yesterday , break the record by 400 head . 
Peter Harvey say he have always want to shear 700 head a day and have now achieve that goal but do not realise how hard it would be . 

Live export to Egypt halt 
The Federal Government have halt live cattle export to Egypt in the wake of mistreatment claim . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say $ 350,000 be spend on improve the treatment of cattle at the Bassatin Abattoir in Egypt after cruelty concern be first raise in 2003 . 
But Channel Nine 's 60 Minutes program last night show footage of cattle have their tendon cut , which the program say be film last month . 
Mr McGauran say his decision to halt the trade while the claim be investigate , be not an extreme reaction . 
`` We should n't be defensive about this , '' he say . 
`` Where allegation be make , no matter how ill-founded or how lacking in evidence we must confront it head-on if we be to retain the confidence of the general public and fulfil our responsibility to farmer . '' 
Meat and Livestock Australia say the ban set a bad precedent . 
General manager of live export , Mike Hayward say he be certain the cattle show in the 60 Minutes footage be not from Australia . 
And he deny suggestion little have change since the cruelty claim be first raise three year ago . 

Iraq will still buy Aust wheat , Vaile say 
Trade Minister Mark Vaile have confirm Iraq will continue to buy Australian wheat but not from current exporter AWB , which be face claim it pay kickback to Saddam Hussein . 
But accord to grain analyst Australian grower could stay shut out of Iraq until August . 
While some grain exporter have already lodge application to export to Iraq , grain analyst Lloyd George say the next Iraq wheat tender may not by for another four month . 
`` Not have access to Iraq for maybe 60 per cent of the year would be significant , '' he say . 
But follow his mission to Baghdad , Mr Vaile say Iraq could be ready to take as much a 350,000 ton of wheat a month , but can not confirm any deal or when it may start . 
`` There will be further tender come up in the short term , we need to look at what mechanisms need to be deploy in the meantime to get our wheat grower access to that , '' he say . 
Meanwhile representative from grain company ABB Grain , CBH and Graincorp be meet with federal politician today . 
Western Australian Liberal Wilson Tuckey have organise the meeting to allow MPs to meet alternative grain trader and learn more about the grain industry . 
ABB 's manage director Michael Iwaniw say while his company be not advocate change to the wheat single desk , it be ready to take advantage of it . 
`` If , and I stress if , the legislation be to change and if there be opportunity , and if perhaps we could assist in the marketing of wheat for the benefit of Australian grower then we will certainly look at it , '' he say . 
A lecturer in business strategy at Melbourne Business School say grain grower would be good off without a single desk . 
Professor Paul Kerin say the oil-for-food inquiry justify the need to introduce free competition , and let alternative exporter to enter the market . 
Professor Kerin say the ability to spread risk be the key for grower . 
`` Under free competition , grower have a choice and if one of those trader mess up , then it 's not so much of a problem for grower because they can change to another trader , '' he say . 
`` In fact , grower should have the right to punish a trader if they really mess up , and so grower will be good off . 

Wool market expect to continue gain ground 
The wool industry be closely watching how China react to climb wool price with the season 's big sale this week . 
More than 82,000 bale be on offer in the wake of strong global interest which have push price to a season high of 746 cent a kilo clean . 
But Maurie McNeill from Elders Wool say despite some concern among buyer , the market should continue to gain ground . 
`` We 've get the large offering of the season come up this week , so obviously yes we be cautious and we 're see quite a bit of Chinese resistance at these level , '' he say . 

Harvey Beef handover delay 
The handover of Western Australia 's large beef processor and exporter Harvey Beef have be delay while the new owner try to strike a deal with worker . 
The Stark-Harmony consortium be due to takeover today but have ask for a one-week delay to allow worker to vote on a new enterprise bargaining agreement . 
Feedlotter Paul O'Meehan who help broker the Stark Harmony deal , say he hop they can sign off on the deal by next Monday . 
`` The new owner be good off get these problem sort and start with a fresh slate rather than go into business and not be organise , '' he say . 

Campaigners worry about approval of 'terminator technology ' 
Gene ethic campaigner be concern a technology which stop seed breed naturally will be approve for commercial cropping in Australia . 
Members of the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity , include Australia , ban `` terminator technology '' in 2000 , when global protest force biotech company Monsanto to state it would not commercialise the process . 
But Bob Phelps from the Gene Ethics Network say the Federal Government be now reconsider it stance which would threaten the natural biodiversity of seed crop . 
`` At a recent meeting in Granada in Spain , the Australian Government be argue that the current ban should be modify , '' he say . 
`` The official be say that there be no ban on terminator in Australia at the moment and that any application that be make to the Australian regulator would be examine on a case by case basis . '' 
But Dr Jim Peacock from the CSIRO 's Plant Industries do not see the technology a a threat . 

Research to investigate fish movement 
Marine scientist say it be too early to tell whether climate change be responsible for a new mix of marine specie be find in Tasmanian water . 
Increasing number of southern Australian fish be be discover off Tasmania 's coastline . 
Two silver drummer be recently catch for the first time off the wharf at Stanley in the state 's north-west . 
CSIRO scientist Dr Peter Last say research be be carry out into whether climate change and warm water be the cause . 
`` It turn out that something like 10 per cent of the specie that we have in the coastal area of Tasmania have move far south , '' he say . 

WA brace for third cyclone 
The north-west of Western Australia be brace itself for a third cyclone in as many month , a a tropical low develops off the Pilbara coast . 
The Bureau of Meteorology expect the low to intensify rapidly and develop into a cyclone later today . 

Aquatic weed to be test overseas 
An invasive aquatic weed be prove extremely hard to eradicate from the Northern Territory . 
Cabomba have be discover in the remote coastal community of Gove . 
Further west , the Darwin River have be find to be the only place in the nation where the weed be produce viable seed . 
Regional weed officer Steve Wingrave say that explain the rapid spread of the weed along 11 kilometre of the river . 
`` It 's an ornamental plant , the same a rose or any plant you have in your garden , '' he say . 
`` Lots of them be hybrid variety so they be not go to produce viable seed . 
`` It turn out that we have get a variety which be produce viable seed . But it might n't be a result of the variety we have get . 

Farmers look to overhaul image 
A campaign to overhaul the image of Australian farmer kick off in Queensland today . 
The `` Every Family need a Farmer '' promotion be be run by Agforce and feature the Coe family , from Durong , in the state 's south . 
Cattle and grain producer Karen Coe hop it will change city people 's perception of agriculture . 
`` Just even on small term we have friend come out and say goodness you 've get lot of tree and they do n't fully understand that the way we farm these day be very different to drive a tractor around the paddock and ploughing , plough and ploughing , '' she say . 

New marine specie find in reef survey 
Several new specie of fish , plant and at least one new specie of crab have be discover in a big new survey of the Great Barrier Reef . 
Dr Roland Pitcher from the CSIRO say scientist spend more than 300 day at sea cover 536,000 square kilometre of the reef from Cape York to Fraser Island . 
`` We 've see a number of new fish , possibly a new pipehorse and maybe a new specie of crab at least , '' he say . 
`` And we can also confirm that there 's be a number of specie that have be confirm in Australia water for the first time . 

ABARE Outlook 2006 conference 
Today 's National Rural News be broadcast live from the ABARE Outlook conference in Canberra . 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` The Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics be take it best shot at predict what 's go to happen in the farming and mining sector over the next 12 month . It 's fairly good news so far , depend on how you look at it , because it appear there wo n't be too many nasty surprise for the nation 's farmer this year . James Martin have be talk to ABARE to get the late , what 's the story James ? '' 
James Martin : `` Matt , I do n't usually like use the word normal when it come to forecasting , but this be a normal an outlook a what I can remember . It 's a story of continue to build after drought , but with that predictable warning that without great improvement in world trade condition , the term of trade for farmer be really go to squeeze . ABARE tell u though that perhaps more of the same be not necessarily a bad thing . His morning , for instance , it 's tell u that the grain harvest for 05-06 be the second high on record . We 've also see , of course , good movement of beef into Japan , and we 're even see some rebound in the wool price as well . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` So it seem that there be go to be high production in many area in the time ahead . Is that go to translate to more money in farmer ' pocket ? '' 
James Martin : `` Not necessarily . Overall we 're see export earnings at a record $ 134b , that 's include mineral and energy . Now in the farm sector alone , those export earnings be tip at $ 29.6b in 06-07 , so that 's up 6 per cent on last year . But the warning be commodity price be go to decline across many area , so while we have increase production push up export earnings from wheat , rice , barley , sugar , wine , lamb , live export and dairy , we also have price for many item fall . Overall , ABARE say commodity price in the ag sector will fall by about 1.7 per cent , follow a rise in 05-06 of about 1.4 per cent . So the bottom line I suppose , the net value of farm production , will actually fall to around $ 6b in 06-07 . That 's down 6 per cent . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` What about the economic picture be paint by ABARE 's chief , Brian Fisher ? '' 
James Martin : `` Economic growth should continue at about 4 per cent , which it have be do over the last 12 month or so . There have be talk of that `` super-commodities cycle '' which be help growth in the mineral and energy sector actually cascade into agriculture . The message from Dr Fisher though be that wo n't happen : '' 
`` There have be people talk about the notion that we 've get a super commodity cycle that a whole lot of the action that we 've see in mineral and energy will then cascade into agriculture . I think frankly that 's a bit simplistic . A lot of the story in the case of agriculture be on the supply side . We be a I say before see a good strong demand , but in the case of agriculture , it 's both a demand and supply story '' . 
`` Brian Fisher also say that farm cost , thing like fertiliser and fuel , will actually increase by about one per cent . Now on oil , the benchmark for oil price , that 's West Texas Intermediate Crude , that 'll stay high in the near term , but over the medium term , down from the current 65 dollar a barrel down below $ 40 a barrel by 2010 . On the dollar , a moderate depreciation , around US73c for 06-07 , continue down though by 2010-11 . That 's a long way ahead , but Brian Fisher 's say perhaps around US65c for the Australian dollar . '' 
Alan Oster ( National Australia Bank ) : `` We think the Aussie dollar be probably go to get down to the level that ABARE 's talk about , except that we think it 's go to come down a lot quicker . So we expect something like 68c by this time next year . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` And that 's go to have a big impact on export ? '' 
James Martin : `` It clearly help in some sens , in the sense that it mean you 're more competitive , but if you 're on the import side , the oil price go down in US dollar , but it really do n't go down at all . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` Now I do n't think you 've get very good news about rural commodity price ? '' 
James Martin : `` Again part of this be that we have a fast fall in the currency , be that in our view , when we look at US dollar agricultural price , we 're down around ten per cent . Now part of that be beef , which have come off really high level , and we think sugar eventually will start to slow down as well . So we 're expect price to come back , and the volume broadly to offset that , so you get those different effect come through . 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` So that might be a fast impact than what ABARE 's predicting ? '' 
James Martin : `` Yes . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` You 've also be talk about continue concern about the labour shortage , particularly skilled labour ? '' 
James Martin : `` Yes , when we run our business survey we find it be very difficult , in fact , even in December this year , it 's more difficult accord to business to get suitable labour than any time , include the late 80 . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` So the concern be always , will that show up in wage ? '' 
James Martin : `` At this stage , the good news be nothing 's happen . That 's why the Reserve Bank be still talk about if we 're go to move rate it 's more likely up than down . At the end of the day , our view on rate will be , they wo n't do anything , but the wage one be critical , and if they see any sign of wage pressure start to move up , then they will pull the trigger . '' 
Matt O'Sullivan : `` Will the importation of labour be likely to hold off wage increase ? '' 
James Martin : `` To the extent that you can take some pressure off by increase the level of immigration , that clearly do help . And in the rural sector we know about difficulty of get people in to help with crop , so it help there . But at the end of the day , I think yes , there 's an element of that , but I think also the domestic part of the economy be really start to slow a bit as well , so I think unemployment 's go to go from 5.2 , 5.3 up to about 5.7 , 5.8 , and that will help . So I think the fact be that within the economy a such , you 're probably not go to have to do anything . '' 
Matthew O'Sullivan : `` Around Australia , you 're listen to a special broadcast of National Rural News from the ABARE Outlook Conference in Canberra . 
`` Well , the Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran tell the conference this morning that the NFF and the government be n't in total agreement about imported worker be a solution to the labour shortage , but certainly agree there be a problem . 
`` John Roach join u now , he 's the chief executive of vegetable grower group Ausveg , John be this a critical issue for the horticulture industry ? '' 
John Roach : `` I think not only critical to the horticulture industry , it 's critical to rural Australia , and I 'd probably go so far a to say that rural Australia 's undergoing significant change in it labour content that it will require , particularly in the next five to 10 year . '' 
Matthew O'Sullivan : `` What about these guest worker scheme ? Are they have an impact in your sector ? '' 
John Roach : `` If I look at other country , yes it do . If I look at New Zealand , part of the horticulture industry in New Zealand do use what I call cheap labour . What they 're do there be bring it it in , upskilling it there , and send it back to those country a part of their aid project , for example . We in Australia do n't have that opportunity at the moment , but if I look at the farm unit in itself , a vegetable grower , much of the innovation happen on small to medium farm business . It 's not the big end of town in vegetable production . So that area be where the innovation happen . You 'd require less labour in that , but you 'd need more specialised labour . 
Matthew O'Sullivan : `` Is there a need to protect small farmer in the future ? '' 
John Roach : `` It 's more about go to inform choice . The vegetable industry in particular will segment itself into three area . One be large production , large farm , work on lower cost . The middle section be about innovation , small farm unit be out there on the cutting edge . The last third of the industry produce about five per cent of production . I think provide inform choice for that sector , of what they actually do with their life and their farm and their asset , I think it 's really important for Australia on social content to be able to allow those people to make informed choice about whether they wish to grow , or not grow and depart . '' 
Matthew O'Sullivan : `` We 've also hear a lot over the past few year about the significant of China to the global economy , and Australian agriculture . Reporter Sally Davison have be look at the impact of China on the world economy . Sal , this week be critical in term of China 's future in the global market ? '' 
Sally Davison : `` That 's right , the National People 's Congress be release it five year plan , a blueprint for national policy maker . This will affect everything from urbanisation , migration into major city , to unemployment . But Yiping Hup from Asia CitiGroup say the energy sector will be most affect by these change . The Chinese Government have say it want to increase energy efficiency by 20 per cent in the next 20 year , by focus on environmentally friendly industry . So the international energy sector be eagerly await the release of the Chinese Government 's five-year plan . ''

Roadkill be set to help scientist unlock the largely mysterious world of snake in the far north of Western Australia . 
Travellers be be ask to keep their eye out for specimen that can be study . 
David Pearson from the Department of Conservation and Land Management say venomous and whip snake from the Kimberley be of particular interest . 
`` The thing be they 're only useful when they be really fresh , '' he say . 
`` For instance if a snake be hit during the night , you get it first thing in the morning or that very night , by the time the sun get to them and bird of prey and other thing like that , they be smelly and a bit putrid - no one want to see them in their freezer and they certainly do n't make good museum specimen ! 
`` If they 've be run over a couple of time by a road train , they 're not very useful ! ''

`` They also become depressed , and you start to see haemorrhage on the unfeathered part of the skin such a the foot .

Growers count cost of cyclone Larry 
Far north Queensland 's horticulture industry have be almost wipe out by cyclone Larry . 
The Category 5 cyclone have cause hundred of million of dollar damage to sugar and banana crop , along with the rest of the farming sector . 
Ninety per cent of Australia 's banana come out of the Innisfail and Tully region ; at this stage most of the industry look to have be lose . 
Jan Davis from horticulture 's representative group Growcom say the damage look bad than anticipate . 
`` Avocados be in the middle of harvest and probably 70 to 80 per cent of that crop 's go . We 've get significant damage report come in from tropical fruit . Very , very serious damage right across the sector , '' she say . 
Sugar cane along the coast from Tully to Cairns also cop the blow of the cyclone , with most of the Innisfail crop which face 290 kilometre wind destroy . 
The cyclone will have huge ramification for job and local business in the affected district , which heavily rely on the two crop that use to dominate the landscape : sugar and banana . 
There have be call for the State Government to help out with compensation . 
It say it be still assess the damage . 
Those heavy loss in the far north be expect to drive the price of banana to above $ 40 a carton , or between $ 5 and $ 6 a kilo . 
But Tony Heidrich from the Australian Banana Growers Council be concern about how grower in far north Queensland will rebuild . 
`` If grower be n't make any money , they ca n't afford to keep staff above those which be essential to get the farm back into production , '' he say . 
`` And the question be as far a key people go , key employee , if you do have to let some of those go , whether they come back again . '' 
Remote cattle station in the Gulf of Carpentaria be apprehensive over what Cyclone Larry may bring to the already water-logged region . 
Stuart Zlotkowski of Wollogorang Station , say he be relieve to have turn off cattle month in advance . 
In the metric scale , the station have have around 768 millimetre of rain this month , which be by far the wet March on record and the second wettest of any month ever in about 28 year of recorded weather statistic .

N Qld cyclone damage hit prawn , avocado producer 
Flooding be now cause havoc in Queensland between Cairns and Townsville , in the aftermath of cyclone Larry . 
Innisfail record 289 millimetre of rain in the 24 hour to 9am AEST , with most coastal area receive more than 100 millimetre . 
The flood have devastate the region 's prawn farming industry , which supply 40 per cent of the Australian market . 
Scott Walter from the Australian Prawn Farmers Association say there be huge loss due to flood damage and loss of power . 
`` Basically we have power to run our freezer where the stock be keep , '' Mr Walter say . 
`` We 've get power that run aerator in our pond , which keep the oxygen level up to a point where the prawn be capable of basically grow and survive , so if we lose the ability to oxygenate our pond we 'll lose our crop , and if the freezer go down for too long and the seal be break , the temperature will drop and we 'll have to destroy the stock because it 'll no longer be safe for food . '' 
Cyclone Larry have also devastate avocado plantation on the Atherton Tablelands in far north Queensland , with loss estimate at up to $ 15 million . 
Just last week the region supply 80 per cent of the Australian crop . 
New South Wales grower Gordon Birch say New Zealand import be likely to fill the shortfall , until other grow region begin pick fruit .

`` Again technology be advance as well and that 's where we 're look as well be to see how far advanced , particularly for mariner in the open ocean , you know how technology be help them receive this weather information .

The fruit and vegetable industry be angry at a decision to exclude major supermarket from a new mandatory code of conduct . 
The code be promise by the Federal Government in 2004 to try to give grower more clout in negotiate contract with supermarket . 
But it have now decide not to include retailer Coles and Woolworths . 
Andrew Young from the wholesaler-backed , Central Markets Association , believe supermarket could end up benefit at the expense of both grower and wholesaler . 
`` Over 50 per cent of the product will be outside the scope of the code so there 's really a big question mark over whether it 's meaningful at all , particularly give that two prior government review into the code issue have both recommend that if there be to be a code it should apply to the whole retail/grocery industry , '' he say .

Food price could be set to soar in area of far north Queensland devastate by cyclone Larry . 
Trucks which transport fruit and vegetable from the region , usually backload with fresh produce and non-perishables from the state 's south . 
But with crop destroy , the cost of cart food into the north be expect to skyrocket . 
Les Blennerhassett from Blenners Transport say without assistance , freight cost could increase by 90 per cent . 
`` If we ca n't get freight subsidy from the Government our freight rate into north Queensland will double from next week , everything on the shelf 's go to go up , '' he say . 
`` Every food item that 's on the shelf there now from fruit and veg to ice cream back to your Wheatbix , every item that 's on there all travel by road and rail . 
`` Rail do have a percentage of the freight and might be able to travel a little bit cheap go back empty but they have cost also . '' 
Meanwhile sugar miller in north Queensland be assess damage cause by the cyclone . 
Bundaberg Sugar 's Mourilyan , Babinda , South Johnstone and Tableland mill all suffer significant damage . 

Govt wo n't allow banana import 
The Federal Government say it will not relax quarantine import restriction for banana follow the destruction of Queensland 's crop by cyclone Larry . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say the current supply of local banana be expect to run out within the next few day . 
But he say reduce biosecurity check to import banana to meet the shortfall would hurt Queensland grower . 
`` We will not compromise the science to meet a short term shortage on the domestic market , '' he say . 
`` Moreover this would be the bad thing possible for the devastated banana industry that bananas come in from overseas on a faulty or hastily decide science . '' 
Banana grower at Carnarvon , in Western Australia , say they will not bow to pressure to send fruit to the eastern state to fill the gap . 
WA representative on the Australian Banana Growers Council Tom Day say they will continue to supply local market . 
`` Whilst we sympathise with the people in the east there be be some banana in New South Wales and there be still a few in Queensland , '' he say . 
`` We 've get our market in Western Australia , that 's always traditionally be our market and we 've get some very faithful buyer there and we want to stick with those people and help the east if we possibly can . 
A new report raise doubt over the ability of the National Water Initiative ( NWI ) to solve the water crisis and deliver infrastructure reform . 
But it say reform rural and urban water infrastructure could add between $ 6 billion and $ 8 billion a year to the economy . 
One year since conduct it first review of infrastructure policy , the Business Council of Australia ( BCA ) say the National Water Initiative be lack urgency and clear direction . 
The BCA found of all area review like energy and transport , only water policy do not see significant progress . 
Backing comment from former deputy prime minister John Anderson , it say the NWI be miss target , like the creation of a national water trading market and find more barrier than solution . 
The BCA 's Maria Tarrant say the organisation have give the Council of Australian Governments until the end of the year to reinvigorate the National Water Initiative and far develop water trading .

`` The manure be collect and put into a digestor where the methane be extract , the methane be clean then put through a gas turbine which generate electricity and hot water , '' he say . 
`` The electricity be use in the plant and the hot water in term of our normal requirement in an abattoir operation .

Unions say regional Australia will be the first to feel the effect of the Federal Government 's new industrial relation law . 
The change come into force today , mean employer have more power when negotiate contract with worker . 
Dr Chris Briggs from the Workplace Research Centre at Sydney University believe regional worker will see major change . 
`` These type of law be trialled in Victoria in the mid-90s under the Kennett government and what it find be that ... thing do n't change all that much in the middle of the capital city but where they change be in regional area where you have three time a many low pay job , particularly in job like retail , construction and hospitality , so it be likely that regional area will feel the effect of this , '' he say . 
But farmer and other regional business say the change will lead to more job in regional Australia and great flexibility for worker and employer . 
Only farm that be incorporate or in Victoria will be able to negotiate under the new law but the National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say it will be encourage farmer to incorporate so they can access the change . 
The NFF 's Denita Wawn say over time the new law will lead to good relation between employer and employee .

Spiralling whitefly find in Darwin backyard 
Efforts have begin to control a new pest specie find in the Northern Territory . 
Spiralling whitefly be previously restrict to Queensland but have now be discover in a Darwin backyard . 
The pest can reduce production in plant like the mango , papaya and guava but Stuart Smith from the Department of Primary Industries say it can be control use a natural parasite . 
`` This be actually an extremely effective parasite , '' he say . 
`` It be classical biocontrol in that the parasite really knock the pest down by 80 to 90 or 95 per cent but there be just enough to survive to maintain the parasite as well a the pest population . 
`` But almost always in very low population and not enough to be damage . ''

Electronic nose could solve sheep industry woe 
A small grey box could be the key to reduce fly strike , one of the sheep industry 's big health problem . 
The electronic nose be be trialed by the Sheep Cooperative Research Centre at Armidale , in New South Wales . 
It detect the stench of blowfly maggot in sheep near a watering point and send a signal back to the farm 's computer . 
Dr Ian Colditz say , if successful , the e-nose could help the industry save more than $ 160 million a year . 
`` The device work by have some electronic sensor that be pick up chemical that be part of an odour and that create an electrical signal that can be pick up by a computer and could be relay to the farm office , '' Dr Colditz say .

Cow excema outbreak pose threat 
There have be an outbreak of potentially deadly facial excema in several cow herd in eastern Victoria . 
Sunburn on teat be the first sign of the disease , which be cause by fungal toxin in damp pasture . 
Gippsland vet Jack Winterbottom say if leave untreated there could be a major outbreak . 
`` We 'd have dead cow , at the very least you 'd have cow that would be very hard to manage in term of be irritable perhaps not want to be milk , be very reluctant to have unit put on teat , '' he say . 

Pork give a health lift 
Researchers in the United States have find a new way for human to take omega 3 oil , by eat pork or bacon . 
While vitamin-enriched plant-based food have be around for year , the researcher have now breed pig , which produce the fatty acid normally only find in fish . 
Professor Randall Prather from the University of Missouri say he be confident the technology will not have the same problem a clone procedure previously use in sheep . 
`` Well we use the cloning procedure so the procedure be the same , and yes sometimes you do get some animal that be n't perfectly normal , '' he say . 
`` What you saw with the sheep in the UK be the first generation , and when they have offspring the offspring be normal .

Sniffer dog train to smell out cane toad will soon be introduce in north-west Australia .

`` Once that take place , we will have people in the plant and do those verification audit , just as fast a we can , '' he say . 
`` That probably will take in the neighbourhood of a week to 10 day , to two week . 
`` And then , the next challenge will be to get the auditings from Japan in , to do the verification visit . '' 
And Mr Lambert say Tokyo have agree to do outreach with Japanese consumer to outline the change and reassure them of the safety of US beef - a significant turnaround if true .

New research suggest plantation tree could actually contribute to greenhouse gas level rather than low them . 
A report in the international science journal Nature say the tree emit methane . 
It be previously think methane emission from plant come from area where oxygen be limit , like rice paddy . 
Research scientist Philip Polglase say while the finding be totally unexpected , it be not necessarily alarm . 
`` What we in Ensis have do recently be compare expect rate of methane release from tree plantation with the rate of carbon uptake , '' he say . 
`` The amount of methane release be only a very small amount or the carbon equivalent take up . We think it 's about less than 5 per cent .

`` I think a lot of farmer be still under financial pressure . Whilst in a yield sense last year do n't turn out too badly , across Australia , the price of course be very , very low around harvest time so people be pretty nervous about that and they 'll be look for a recovery year this year and approach it with quite a bit of caution I 'd think , '' he say . 
With average rain , Mr Storey 's forecast a national wheat crop of around 22 million tonne for the 2006-07 season . 
And there be some good news , a drop in forecast corn planting in the US be expect to lead to improved wheat price . 
While less corn will be grow , there be expect to be high demand for the crop from the grow ethanol industry .

Age no barrier to competitive wood chopping 
Competitive wood chopping might be consider a young bloke 's game but an 84-year-old Tasmanian have show age be no barrier . 
Retired tree feller and former wood chop title holder Henry Munday be a crowd favourite at the Hamilton Show north of Hobart at the weekend . 
While he take almost five minute longer than his competitor in the wood chop , he get there in the end , with the help of an old mate . 
`` That 's an old plum axe , one of the old American plum , it 's like me , it 's pretty old , '' he say . 
`` But it 's not a big axe , I do n't use real big ax . 
`` I 'm not strong enough now like those other big fella out there to use big heavy ax so I use the lighter one .

Central Australia 's beef producer be reap the benefit of recent heavy rainfall in Western Australia . 
Despite the rise freight cost , WA pastoralists be buy cattle from the centre a they look to cash in on the best season in year . 

New crop variety double yield in East Timor 
New crop variety be trialled in East Timor have double yield . 
Maize be the stable crop along the rugged country on the doorstep of Darwin and harvest be now under way . 
In the steep upland of Liquica overlook the capital of Dili , some maize farmer have record yield of up to three tonne per hectare . 
That be twice the average and be the result of five year of research and collaboration under the Seeds of Life project , which include rice , casava , sweet potato and peanut . 
This Australian-funded initiative aim to improve nutrition and wellbeing amongst the subsistance-farming family of this newly-independent nation . 

Wine grapes oversupply to impact on company profit 
The global oversupply of wine grape be start to hurt the industry 's big company . 
The world 's large wine business , Constellation , be tip to announce a low than expect profit to the New York Stock Exchange later this week . 
US wine industry forecaster John Fredrickson say the global market be in a down phase , particularly for country produce cheap bulk wine . 
But he say in Australia , the answer be not in grow few grape . 
`` You start to talk about pull grape , well that be really drastic , that mean you have some other alternative and I do n't think it be go to be any huge percentage of vineyard that run into that kind of extreme difficulty , '' he say . 
Meanwhile a new research program for the wine industry will develop new export market and create wine to suit specific taste . 
The Grape and Wine Research Development Corporation be use federal fund to investigate the wine taste of consumer in country like China , India , Eastern Europe and South America . 
Professor of wine marketing at the University of South Australia , Larry Lockshin , say packaging , label , pricing and wine style will also be consider . 
`` We 're not go to come up with an answer that say , 'this be the wine for China ' , '' he say . 
`` We 're go to come out with the same thing scientist have come out with . 
`` This be , these be yeast and these be the flavour they produce , these be prune and canopy training technique , this be what they do to your tannin level . 
`` We 're go to develop a method . Companies will then be able to decide whether they want to use it to develop wine for their own brand that suit different market . '' 
And the Victorian Farmers Federation want good regulation of tax incentive scheme to stop oversupply problem . 
President Simon Ramsay say the scheme have contribute to over-investment in vineyard , lead to an oversupply of wine grape . 
He say in south-west Victoria tax incentive for timber plantation investor seem to have affect normal competition for land . 
`` What we do n't want to see be good traditional agricultural farming land be turn into plantation that have a sort-of unclear 12 year profit period where we be not allow the food and fibre production to continue for generation , '' he say .

Farmers have be warn that grain price could drop dramatically if AWB lose control of the single desk for wheat export . 
AWB International director Clinton Starr tell a meeting of graingrowers at Murtoa in Victoria last night , that the company have secure a $ 13 per tonne premium each year through the single desk . 
He say farmer should be very concerned about any plan to change the single desk after the Cole inquiry and AWB 's experience in manage the system be as valuable to grower , a the single desk itself . 
`` I do n't say that that be the only structure that can deliver that , '' he say . 
`` But what I would say be that if you change it you have to be very careful when you change or you effect change because in fact a lot of it be wrap up in the intellectual and brain power of the people you employ to deliver the excess return to you . '' 
Meanwhile India be look to import a further 1.5 million tonne of wheat this year .

Central Australia 's beef producer be reap the benefit of recent heavy rainfall in Western Australia .

`` And because of their flush of the season over there , they sometimes come over here and get a bit excited and buy a few cow and calf . ''

Lessons learn from mad cow epidemic 
The discovery of mad cow disease have teach scientist how to good manage disease and improve how farmer and industry respond to new virus outbreak . 
It have 10 year since the link be discover between mad cow disease in cattle and CJD in human , with billion of dollar spend in control and research ever since . 
Professor Colin Masters from the University of Melbourne say science have learn many lesson from the mad cow epidemic . 
`` We 've learn a lot about risk minimisation and disease management , '' he say . 
`` If we 've learn anything at all we should have learnt that it 's not a good thing to fee one species back to itself . 
`` In Europe it 's be virtually outlaw , the situation in North America be different , they 're watch very carefully what 's happen in Europe and they 're take what appear to them to be appropriate measure at this time . ''

The new Paradise Dam in south-east Queensland be soon to be the home of a world-first turtle hatchery . 
Concerns be raise over the future of the endanger elseya turtle during construction of the dam on the Burnett River , south-west of Bundaberg . 
But the new hatchery be design to restore turtle number , with thousand of baby hatchling expect to be release over the next five year . 
Craig Thamm from the Burnett Dam Alliance say attack on egg and hatchling by predator be the single big risk to the turtle 's future . 
`` Particularly your feral predator such a fox and pig be [ prey on ] the egg and you 're get very few , if any hatchling back into the river , '' he say . 

New plan call for change to single desk wheat export 
AWB would lose control of the single desk for wheat export and it power to stop rival company from export wheat , under a new plan release at Grains Week . 
The report , prepare for the Grains Council , also call for the Wheat Export Authority to be replace with a grower-owned licensing and marketing body call Australian Wheat Associates . 
Report author Colin Benjamin say the Cole inquiry show the wheat export system be fail and grower risk lose control of their sector unless they accept major change . 
`` To get into a global competitive game you 've get to be play in the league of your competitor and you 've get to be strategic , '' he say . 
`` US Wheat Associates have be the long term major league champion fight u which we have successfully beat to a pulp over the decade , we now have to be see a fight on a level playing field , prior to the Doha Round because if we do n't , we will have it impose upon u . '' 
The Grains Council say Australian Wheat Associates would be model on industry body for the meat and dairy sector . 
The Council say that would give AWB 's current veto power to grower , along with it responsibility to market and promote Australian wheat . 
Chairman Murray Jones say if the change be adopt , they will be implement over three year . 
`` The last thing grower want be to have an abrupt change , '' he say . 
`` It just can not happen . It 's just not go to work , it will affect our financial system , grower want security and planning , they want to know their finance be secure , they want to be assure they 're go to get their payment , they want to have a transparent system they can see through . That 's what they 're ask for . '' 
Meanwhile five US farm state senator have ask the Bush administration to investigate AWB payment to former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein . 
The group also want AWB sanction if it be find to have violate US trade law or World Trade Organisation ( WTO ) rule . 
The senator cite the finding of a UN audit of AWB , which find it pay some $ 220 million in alleged kickback to secure wheat contract through the UN oil-for-food program . 
Top Senate Agriculture Committee Democrat Tom Harkin 's spokesman Dave Townsend say US farmer should not have to compete with foreign government in trade . 
`` It 's clear that there be gross violation of the UN oil-for-food program by the Australian Wheat Board and we feel that the US Government need to make a determination whether the law be break , '' he say .

AWB reject wheat export system plan 
AWB have reject a new plan to overhaul the wheat export system and say it be wrong to make change base on assumption the industry be in crisis .

Attacking the plan , AWB chairman Brendan Stewart tell Grains Week delegate , the industry be not in crisis because of the Iraq kickback scandal . 
`` What I see at the moment be a debate that 's be do be a vacuum and debate that 's be do in a self-induced crisis mode which I have to say be not there , '' he say . 
The discussion paper suggest AWB could lose the single desk in 2010 , while a new body call Australian Wheat Associates would take over the company 's veto power . 
But AWB 's Ian Donges tell delegate be be dangerous to base Australia Wheat Associates on industry company like Meat and Livestock Australia . 
`` I would n't use that a a model that necessarily be go to deliver a good outcome just because it be a model . There be other way of do it , '' he say . 
Mr Donges also say the timeline to implement the plan where unlikely to be achieve . 
The discussion paper have also be criticise by grower and AWB 's rival .

There be also an attempt from one grower to call a no-confidence motion in the Grains Council .

`` This may go some way to sharpen that process up if there be other exporter that can access particular market and can post their bid , '' he say .

Bird flu confirm in UK 
The deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu have be confirm in the UK for the first time .

The Scottish Government have set up a surveillance zone and ban the movement of bird in or out of the area . 
Germany have also report it first case of bird flu in commerical poultry , and in Africa , H5N1 have reach the continent 's large city of Lagos , in Nigeria . 
Meanwhile , the late quarantine survey in East Timor show there be still no sign of avian influenza . 
Four major initiative be underway to increase the chance of early detection , and to help the East Timorese prepare for the disease . 
Dr Emma Watkins say improve public awareness , rapid disease test and help plan scarce resource be key point . 
`` Effective surveillance really rely on be able to investigate disease a it come along , '' she say . 
So the capacity of the local animal health authority to do that , be really important . So we have undertake a continuous effort to increase the capacity to locally diagnose this disease . 

Researchers aim for safe Q-fever vaccine 
Scientists at James Cook University in Queensland be work to develop an alternative vaccine for Q-fever , which will not produce debilitate side effect . 
Q-fever be a highly infectious disease usually catch after contact with affected animal , which cause flu-like symptom and can be fatal . 
The university 's Ray Layton say the new vaccine will be develop over the next six to eight month . 
`` In fact it 's one of the only vaccines out there at the moment where you need to be screen before you 're vaccinate to make sure you can actually be vaccinate without too many adverse affect and that probably stem I think from the fact that they culture this organism in chicken egg , and a lot of people have adverse reaction to those egg yolk antigen , '' he say .

Flooding delay Asian live cattle export 
Flooding across the Top End have create major delay in live cattle export to Asia . 
Ships bound for Indonesia be expect to remain anchored in the Port of Darwin until after Easter and the market be expect to swing towards available slaughter cattle . 
Steve Ellison from the Northern Territory Live Exporters Association say at least 9,000 cattle be strand . 
`` Due to the wet weather at this stage they be have trouble get them out , '' he say . 
`` It will certainly affect saleyard number and obviously the movement of cattle wherever . 
`` The road be closed , stock camp have get to be able to work to put the cattle in the yard even if the yard be open . So it 's a double whammy really . 
`` [ But ] the condition of the cattle be excellent , but no it look like be a boomer season . We 'll get the number , it 's just a case of you have get to be patient . '' 
Meanwhile the Territory 's third big town be in recovery mode after last week 's flood . 
Businesses in Katherine have resume trading , resident have return home to assess the damage and the Health Department will begin mosquito spray today . 
Local mango grower Peter Marks say the water be fall away quickly and he do not think the flood will delay this year 's flowering . 
`` Another grower speak to me the other day and he 's get one block on the river , '' he say . 
`` He 's get a house there and the house be high and dry but he say the water be flow through the tree , not that deep but he do n't see any great concern with it . 
`` In fact we find if we have a big wet , we have some section of the paddock that stay quite wet and they always flower the early . 
`` So they 're a weird creature , where none of u have get them work out too good yet . Pretty amazing . '' 
North-west of Katherine , resident across the Daly River region be prepare for major flooding within the next two day . 
A king tide near the mouth of the Daly River mid-week be also expect to have an impact . 

Official aim to settle trade dispute with Indonesia 
Efforts be under way to rescue Australia 's $ 35 million horticulture trade with Indonesia . 
Exports of grape , citrus , apple and pear be effectively suspend after the Indonesian Government impose surprise new export protocol . 
Australian quarantine official stop issue permit for Indonesia on Thursday , although a shipment of grape worth nearly a million dollar be already at sea and be in danger of be reject . 
David Minus from the Australian Horticultural Exporters Association say a federal trade official have be dispatch to Indonesia to try to settle the dispute . 
`` Australia be fight for it horticultural survival and we need every market we can hang on to , '' he say . 
`` Indonesia be after all a big market , it 's not the wealthy but it 's a very big market and it 's right on our doorstep . 
`` We 're ideally place to serve it with temperate fruit and sub-tropical citrus that they have difficulty grow in Indonesia . '' 
Table grape grower hope the quarantine dispute can be resolve quickly . 
Australian Table Grape Association president Nick Muraca say despite initial fear , the political dispute over asylum seeker from Papua do not appear to have cause the problem . 
`` I do n't believe that to be the case nor do we have any reason to believe that that be the case , '' he say . 

PM to give statement to AWB inquiry 
Deputy Prime Minister Mark Vaile be about to step into the witness box at the oil-for-food inquiry in Sydney . 
His appearance come a the Prime Minister , John Howard , confirm he have be call on to provide a sworn statement to the inquiry . 
Senior counsel assist the inquiry John Agius tell a packed hearing room , the Prime Minister will supply by 4pm tomorrow his confidential statement document when he first learn of irregular payment by AWB to the Iraqi regime . 
This afternoon , Mr Vaile 's examination will explore what and when the Trade Minister know about money pay to the Iraqi Grains Board , the Jordanian trucking company Alia and secret cable advise of complaint by the US Wheat Associates about Australia 's inflated wheat contract with Iraq . 

Drought relief funding increase raise question 
The Productivity Commission say the Federal Government 's 100 per cent increase in drought relief funding may need investigation . 
Drought relief be set to top $ 600 million in 2005/06 and receive special mention in the commission 's annual review of government expenditure . 
Chairman Gary Banks say the commission be not question the need for assistance but say any single item cost more than half a billion dollar could spark call for a review . 
`` There be always a question about that , '' he say . 
`` We never know whether we have get the model exactly right in any area of industry support . 
`` Clearly drought assistance be extremely important and you would n't want to make any change without very careful examination of all the issue . 

Flooding continue in western Qld 
Flooding be continue to cause problem in Queensland . 
Heavy rain in the state 's central mid-west last week have cut road around Longreach but flood in the Thomson River be expect to be a boon for grazier . 
Moderate flooding be now expect to extend downstream to Jundah . 
Further north , the barramundi be bite after the floodwaters and Arthur McDouall almost land one in the main street of Normanton . 
`` Threw a line in down there for a while virtually at the end of the main street , have a barra on there almost straightaway , get him to the edge of the bank and he jump off the hook but you get in the right place at the right time they get some good catch when the flood be on , '' he say . 

Merger set to create third large Aust agribusiness 
The stage be set for the formation of Australia 's third large agribusiness behind Elders and Landmark . 
The majority of shareholder in New South Wales base Ruralco have agree to a merger with Tasmanian company , Roberts Limited . 
Ruralco chairman Richard England say the two company will combine their wool , livestock , real estate and rural merchandising business . 
Mr England expect the board of Roberts to endorse the offer at a meeting today . 
`` The offer be five Ruralco share for every eight Roberts share , '' he say . 
`` The merge group will have a market capitalisation in excess of $ 160 million . 

Tomato producer call for eradication of new plant virus 
Australia 's chief plant health officer will try to control rather than eradicate a new tomato virus in Queensland . 
Yellow leaf curl virus have be confirm for the first time in Australia at farm on the outskirt of Brisbane . 
It be carry by silver leaf whitefly and quarantine measure be expect to be announce this week . 
James Head from Queensland 's large tomato producer , SP Exports , say an eradication program would have be well . 
`` I 'd say control be probably the easy option to take , '' he say . 
`` Whether or not the effect will be what 's desire for the outcome , whether control would be good than eradication , I 'd say eradication would sound the good idea . 

Dairy farmer win milk price rise 
Western Australian dairy farmer have win another price rise for their milk . 
Fonterra lift price one and a half centre a litre last month but farmer say that be not enough . 
The company will pay another half a centre per litre to milk supplier to it WA-based subsidiary Peters and Brownes . 

Sheep shear via phone may ring true in the future 
Shearing sheep in the future could be as easy a dial a number on your mobile phone . 
Researchers at the University of South Australia be look for a bioactive substance which would cause wool fibre to break simultaneously at a predetermined time . 
The new method of alternative shearing be still a few year away but researcher Michelle Hebard say the possibility be endless . 
`` The animal would receive an implant , this may be in the ear at tag time , '' she say . 
`` That implant would contain a bioactive which would be activate through the mobile .
