The country have come to the big smoke for the Sydney Royal Easter Show - Australia 's big . 
The Royal Easter Show be an event on an amazing scale - 15,000 animal compete for over half a million dollar in prizemoney over the two week and 900,00 people be expect to come to watch them do it . 

Good turnout for district fundraiser 
Around 200 people turn up in the tiny WA town of Yuna for the district 's big fundraiser at the weekend . 
The Whelarra Regatta start around five year ago and involve small team row handmade raft across a 170 metre dam . 
People crowd the bank to see the team race . 
Carisa Grylls of Chapman Valley be in the UDL team and say it be a great day to show off the community . 
`` Well we do n't really think that we be go to win the race , so we kind of thought that we 'll head towards the bar , '' she say . 

US corner Iraqi wheat market 
As the oil-for-food inquiry drag on , new figure show US wheat export to Iraq over the past year have grow almost five-fold . 
The US export about 500,000 metric tone of wheat to Iraq last marketing year before the UN Volker report on alleged AWB kickback to Iraq lead to a cut-off of AWB shipment and a surge in US export . 
`` For the past year , we 've capture almost three-quarters of the Iraqi wheat market , which be quite large , which be well over 3 million tonne and we 've gain a very large share of the Iraqi rice market , '' Bob Riemenschneider , grain and feed director at the US Foreign Agricultural Services , say . 
The US have export about 2.4 million tonne of wheat to Iraq so far this marketing year and Mr Riemenschneider expect that to increase gradually in coming year . 
Meanwhile the US be ramp up pressure on Australia 's single desk for wheat export , a Federal Government minister begin appear before the Cole inquiry . 
Key member of the US Agricultural Committee Senator Tom Harkin say Australia agree to rein-in trading monopoly in it free trade agreement and the single desk go against world trade rule . 
Spokesman for Senator Harkin , Dave Townsend , say the US be ready to respond to the Cole inquiry 's recommendation . 
`` Keep in mind this be in the context of the WTO negotiation and I think it 's fair to say that everyone be look to have more transparent and open market through any reform in the WTO and have a monopoly in charge of wheat export prevents that from happen , '' he say . 

US dry spell look positive for Aust wheat grower 
A continue dry spell in the United States be look positive for wheat grower here in Australia . 
Monthly supply and demand estimate be release by the United States Department of Agriculture overnight and be largely unchanged . 
But national pool manager for AWB Limited David Johnson say the dry condition be expect to have an impact on America 's hard red winter wheat crop , which be in direct competition with Australia . 
`` We 've already see downgrade in their production forecast in Texas and Oklahoma in the southern state , '' he say . 

Govt know of new Indonesian fruit and veg protocol 
The Federal Government say it have know for almost a year that Indonesia be plan new import protocol for Australian fruit and vegetable . 
The condition be impose last week and grower say the $ 35 million export trade be effectively at a standstill . 
The Federal Government believe Indonesia put in the protocol aim at protect it from fruit fly after receive an infected fruit shipment from another country . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say Australia lodge submission on the protocol last year but do not hear back from Indonesia until the condition be impose on April 4 . 
`` Indonesia do not respond to the submission of Australia and the various other country before decide on a new decree , '' he say . 

Centre to make sure biosecurity expert up to the job 
Making sure the expert be up to scratch will be one of the task of a new biosecurity risk analysis centre in Victoria . 
The Federal Government have commission the University of Melbourne to investigate how Australia assess biosecurity threat and whether it be be do well enough . 
Professor Mark Burgman say part of his job be work out the best way to keep Australia free of disease like foot and mouth or bird flu . 
`` Initially our focus be biosecurity and we will develop tool to help people do that job well , '' he say . 

US beef processor ban from export to Hong Kong 
US meat export to Asia have be deal another blow , with a major processor ban from export beef to Hong Kong . 
A shipment of Cargill beef be find to contain fragment of bone in contravention of export regulation design to prevent the spread of mad cow disease . 
Chief market analyst at Meat and Livestock Australia Peter Weeks say the news will not affect Japan but the late controversy could delay the resumption of US export to Korea . 
`` But outside of Hong Kong be far more significant particularly in Korea where they have link their reopening , the timing of their reopening to instance , to the previous instance as well a the third BSE case in the US and the circumstance surround that , '' he say . 

Brazil beef export no threat to Australian market : producer 
There be claim today that Australia will not have to compete with the world 's big beef export country in our key market for at least a decade . 
Beef producer Chris Ward have be work in Brazil for 20 year and say the country be struggle to increase it 174 million head herd due to a poor currency , lack of infrastructure and low commodity price . 
Mr Ward say the major inhibitor be the presence of foot and mouth disease , which will continue to lock Brazil out of Australia 's major market of Japan , Korea and the US . 
`` In term of compete with Australia in the premium market that Australia play in , I do n't see that , '' he say . 

Resources industry staff problem expect to worsen 
Finding and retain staff be one of the big issue face Australia 's booming resource industry , accord to a new study . 
The People at Work report , publish by the Chamber of Minerals and Energy , say the issue be only go to get bad . 
Author Bernard Salt say the problem in hang onto staff have a lot to do with different value between the generation . 
`` We have always assume that we 're the best country in the world and everyone will automatically want to come to Australia to work , '' he say . 

Pastoralists expect to double cattle production 
Northern Territory pastoralists expect to increase cattle production by 50 per cent within the next 10 year , accord to the first comprehensive survey since the early 1980s . 
Better fencing and water point in central Australia , and improved pasture in the north would result in the increased carrying capacity 
Pastoral extension officer Trudi Oxley say improved weaning rate also mean more production . 
`` We come up with a weaning percentage across the NT a be 71 per cent , so for every hundred cow there be 71 weaners pull off them when they be muster and a mortality rate around 3 per cent , '' she say . 

Leather business suffers from impact of drought , cyclone 
A leather tan business in south-east Queensland have be deal a double blow . 
Murgon Leather have be force to impose water restriction due to the drought , while it main supplier of hide close in the wake of cyclone Larry . 
The Innisfail Meatworks will remain shut until the end of the month . 
General manager James Barbeler say the leather tan business have be force to cut back on staff and production . 

Sheep 's temperament have impact on reproductive rate 
'Crazy ' sheep be more than just a nuisance in the yard - research have find they be be also less fertile and less productive . 
Dr Alex Ball of Sheep Genetics Australia be look at the impact of temperament in trial on his property at Armidale in New South Wales and elsewhere across Australia . 
He say a nervous temperament can have an impact on how well sheep reproduce . 
`` We have just be basically tag animal be they crazy or calm and what it have have be impact on reproductive rate , '' he say . 
`` So we know our own crazy ewe they be probably rear 20 to 30 per cent le lambs and that 's mirror by some very good research in Western Australia .

A 24-year-old Victorian auctioneer have win the National Young Auctioneers Championship . 
Adam Mountjoy from Mansfield in Victoria 's Alpine region receive the high score after be judge on diction , presentation and manner during a sale of four steer at the Sydney Royal Easter Show . 
He say it be very rewarding after work so hard to prepare for the competition .

Farming grant to aid environmental project 
The Federal Government want to give farmer cash incentive to encourage them to carry out environmental improvement on their land . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran have set a deadline of 2008 to implement the scheme , which he say will improve the environment and lift farm productivity . 
Mr McGauran will not say how much the plan will cost but say the National Farmers Federation 's call for a billion dollar in compensation be well off the mark . 
`` No where near in the ball park but before we lock ourselves into position why do n't we find a way forward , '' he say . 
`` We 'll fund some pilot project and I 'm glad to say the state be show some interest and a number be show strong support . 
`` If we work cooperatively we 'll find a way to strike the balance between conservation or environment and production . '' 
The NFF have welcome the announcement , and say the scheme should not be view a a cash handout or production subsidy . 
President Peter Corish say farmer manage 60 per cent of Australia 's land and deserve to be reward for their environmental work . 
`` Farmers be ask to manage that native vegetation at their own cost and we believe firmly if the community want to maintain that native vegetation , certainly that farmer should be reward for manage that , '' he say . 

Court postpone decision on AWB 'apology ' document 
A decision on whether AWB 's so-called 'apology ' document should be make public have be postpone until late April . 
This morning the Federal Court rule it would allow further evidence from AWB support it claim of legal professional privilege . 
The document be initially provide to the Cole inquiry along with other evidence prepare by AWB company secretary Dr Richard Fuller . 
A draft apology , it be write by former manage director Andrew Lindberg , after a US-based public relation specialist advise AWB to over-apologise , to try to counter any corporate scandal relate to the oil-for-food program . 
At this morning 's hearing , the Federal Court hear AWB would provide a second witness statement testify the apology be prepare a part of lawyer-client meeting and a such should remain confidential . 
AWB also question the power of Commissioner Terence Cole to make any ruling around lawyer-client confidentiality , an issue dispute by lawyer act on behalf of the commission . 
A full hearing have be adjourn until April 24 . 
Meanwhile another two senior staff member have resign from AWB . 

Yellow leaf curl virus outbreak hit tomato grow region 
There have be a confirmed outbreak of the tomato yellow leaf curl virus in one of Australia 's major tomato grow region . 
Plant biosecurity officer be in Bundaberg in south-east Queensland to increase surveillance and identify the spread of the virus , discover in a backyard garden . 
The disease be only recently detect in Australia , near Brisbane and can stunt plant growth and slash production . 
Hydroponic grower David Da Tra say grower need to keep the virus carrier at bay . 
`` Just hop we can control or minimise the vector which be the silverleaf greenhouse , '' he say . 

Horticulture industry supplier on notice to cut cost 
Suppliers of material , machinery and other good to the horticulture sector have be place on notice to cut cost to grower . 
Fruit and vegetable grower have launch a class action against cardboard box maker , Amcor , seek up to $ 300 million compensation over alleged price fix on packaging . 
They claim 17,000 grower and some major food manufacturer be overcharge more than $ 700 million for box and pallet . 
Mike Badcock from grower group Ausveg say grower be now look at cost across the sector . 
`` It seem quite suspicious do n't it . America , the fuel price be only half what we pay in Australia , to put a pivot irrigator up in America , it cost you between a third and half what it cost to put one up in Australia , fertiliser be a lot cheap in new Zealand , '' he say . 
`` We 've really get to get to the bottom of a lot of these thing in Australia and find out why it 's cost u more to farm in Australia . '' 
Despite claim farmer be lose bargain power , a new report say sell produce under contract do not place grower at the mercy of big business . 
The report , commission by the Australian Farm Institute , say there have be substantial growth in the level of farm produce sell on the contract system and price be not necessarily fall . 
Report author Mark Barber say it depend on the farmer . 
`` It open up all sort of new opportunity and some farmer will benefit more than others from this , '' he say . 

Riverland citrus grower lock out of Indonesian trade 
Citrus grower in South Australia 's Riverland have be lock out of sell fruit to Indonesia despite be free of fruit fly . 
Australia 's $ 35 million fruit and vegetable trade with Indonesia be at a standstill because of new import protocol design to address fruit fly concern . 
The Riverland 's fruit fly-free status be recognise by other Asian market like Japan and Taiwan but not by Indonesia 's newly impose quarantine protocol . 
Judith Damiani from Australian Citrus Growers say it be an important market . 
`` It 's not one of our large market in term of volume or value but we do send quite a significant amount of mandarin and valencia as well , '' she say . 

Dairy Farmers restructure go ahead despite profit 
Despite post a half-year profit of $ 4.7 million , the Dairy Farmers Co-operative will push on with a restructure involve the closure of four plant . 
The Bomaderry factory , in the south-east of New South Wales , shut down today , while the Toowoomba plant , in southern Queensland , will close by the end of this month with the loss of 12 full and part-time job . 
Chief executive Rob Gordon say change across the business be expect to save $ 42 million a year . 

Locusts swarm across WA wheatbelt 
Locust plague be emerge a a big concern for winter crop in Western Australia this season . 
Locusts have make their way from the wet pastoral region into agricultural area , with farmer now report locust swarm across the wheatbelt . 
Senior entomologist with the Department of Agriculture Kevin Walden say the green feed in the agricultural region could help locust survive for week . 
`` We 're likely to see these locust survive into May but by the time the female be complete their cycle , then number will drop off very quickly , '' he say . 
`` But , a I say , if the break of the season 's early , then there may be a bit of an overlap between crop emerge and locust still fly around .

Pastoralists and researcher from around the country have take the first step towards create a new arid zone research group . 
The group will work independently of state and territory organisation , focus on problem that affect pastoral production in all desert area . 
Mark Ashley from the 21st Century Pastoral Program say initial research will focus on reduce input cost and improve technology for the wool and beef industry . 
`` As it stand at the moment most of the state agency be focus with their particular industry , '' he say . 
`` A lot of these issue be big issue , they go across state boundary . 

Weather blame for hike in fish price 
Fish price in Melbourne have jump by up to 20 per cent in the lead-up to Easter . 
An unusually high number of low pressure system with high wind have keep many small fishing boat off the water . 
Ross McGowan from Seafood Industry Victoria say the small boat catch most of the fish buy by restaurant and which be also popular at Easter . 
`` They generally catch the fish that end up in restaurant and the Victoria market for example , '' he say . 
`` Whiting , flathead , mullet , the whole range of snapper of course . 
`` They 're the sort of fish the bay and inlet fisherman catch , include calamari . 

Pasture shortage limit cattle feedlot expansion 
A shortage of pasture in some province of Indonesia be limit the expansion of small community cattle feedlot . 
Rather than fee grain , villager rely on leucaena , legumes , kapok and even banana stem and leaf . 
It can take up to 12 month to fatten cattle in this way for the lucrative Jakarta market . 
Researcher Maximilian Kapa say one feedlot can support up to 15 remote family in West Timor . 
`` It be a very good market , especially the Jakarta market , '' he say . 
`` Actually the farmer here can not fulfil the market demand because there be a trend that the population of Bali cattle decline here every year due to uncontrolled breeding and minimised management like that . 

I do n't see rorts cable : Howard 
Prime Minister John Howard have tell the Cole inquiry he do not believe he receive or read any cable that warn AWB be involve in sanctions-busting . 
Mr Howard be under tight security when he arrive at the commission to explain when he first know about AWB 's improper payment to the Iraqi regime . 
Blocked-off street , bag search and sniffer dog greet those who enter court two on level five of the building ahead of the Prime Minister 's long-awaited appearance at the Cole inquiry . 
The Prime Minister spend a brisk 42 minute in the witness box . 
When senior counsel assisting , John Agius , ask him to put a date on his knowledge that the Iraqis be rorting the oil-for-food program , Mr Howard say it be probably a year before a speech he give on Iraq to the National Press Club in March , 2003 . 
When ask if he know AWB be involve in that rorting , Mr Howard reply : `` No , I do n't . I have always believe the best of that company . It would never have cross my mind it would have behave corruptly . '' 
Commissioner Cole refuse any cross-examination of the Prime Minister , say it be outside the term of reference . 

Petition 
Meanwhile a petition support by some of the lead light in the legal profession be call for a widening of the inquiry 's term of reference . 
Lawyers , barrister and academic from the University of New South Wales say AWB and the Federal Government may have violate international law by allow bribe to be pay to Saddam Hussein .

Tens of thousand of tonne of Riverland wine grape will be dump on the ground or leave to rot on the vine this season because of the national oversupply . 
The South Australian grower have be leave with no market for their fruit after some have contract suspend , while others be not able to renew their agreement with winery . 
The region 's lost income could total $ 65 million . 
Loxton grower Glenn Arnold say the situation be desperate . 
`` We 're just try to survive , '' he say . 
`` Everybody say there 's swing and roundabout and you know good time be follow by bad time , bad time be usually follow by good time ... we 've just get to hang in there .

Palandri wine of Margaret River in Western Australia have just secure the state 's single large export ever into the United Kingdom .

He say the contract be significant for bulk producer of generic wine .

Farmers environmental grant 'pork barrel ' 
The Federal Government 's plan to pay farmer to good manage the land have be label a `` veiled production subsidy '' and a `` pork barrel '' by a Canberra think tank . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran want to give farmer cash payment to well protect the land and lift their productivity . 
He believe farmer be carry an unfair share of the cost of manage the environment and should be reward for carry out project which benefit the entire community . 
But the Australia Institute 's Andrew Macintosh say the Government have a poor record of deliver environmental project and in allocate funding to regional area . 
`` What we 've see with the Natural Heritage Trust be that the program 's turn into a massive pork barrel that 's dress up in green clothing and that 's my big fear with this , '' he say . 
Mr McGauran say the program will not become a spending black hole and deny the proposed payment would become production subsidy .

`` A van will go out into a farm community and child can come there but they might only get one day a fortnight of a program . 

Easter gift may post disease risk : AQIS 
The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service ( AQIS ) be warn that Easter gift from overseas , such a paint or blow egg , could spread bird flu to human and bird . 
Carson Creagh from AQIS say the service will seize hundred of `` at risk '' item this weekend include egg , feather and nest make of dried grapevine , and straw . 
He say many come from Eastern Europe or the Mediterranean and could introduce bird flu , Newcastle disease or other virus capable of devastate Australia 's poultry industry . 
`` The obvious one be avian influenza which can be transmit on egg , '' he say .

Priority scheme in place for dwindle Q fever vaccine supply 
Meatworkers will be give priority access to the last remaining dos of Q fever vaccine to protect against the debilitating disease that be spread to human through contact with infected feral and domestic livestock . 
This year 's demand for the vaccine be expect to exceed current supply , and fresh stock can not be produce until a new lab open early next year . 
Dr Rachel David , from CSL Pharmaceuticals , the only company in the world that make Q Vax , have now set up a scheme to reduce the impact of the looming shortage . 
`` We 've put in place a prioritisation system so that people involve directly in meat processing will be able to contact CSL and get access to the vaccine a a priority , '' she say . 

Abattoirs give green light for halal beef export to Malaysia 
Three Australian abattoir , one in Queensland and two in Victoria , have be give approval to send halal beef back into the Malaysian market . 
Last August , Malaysia suspend beef import from Australia due to concern that slaughter method do not meet Islamic standard . 
The general manager of Norvic Foods , Jon Hayes , say approval be receive to resume beef export from the company 's Wodonga abattoir after religious and technical auditor inspect the site . 
`` Malaysia be only take a very small percentage of the Australian beef and it 's another market that Australia need , '' he say . 
`` We ca n't consume what we produce for 20 million people and we need the total global scene , and Malaysia be a very important market . '' 

Shareholders vote not to rebuild Norply factory 
The Kyogle community , on the New South Wales north coast , have have it bad fear confirm with Norply Timbers decide not to rebuild it factory after a fire last year . 
Up until last September 's devastating fire , the Norply factory employ about 140 people , make it one of the most significant employer in a town with a population of 4,000 . 
There be hope that the company would eventually rebuild on it exist site but those have now be dash . 
Norply 's 30 shareholder meet earlier this week , when a majority vote to declare a dividend rather than rebuild the mill . 

Little central Aust critter become a popular pet 
It might not be the Easter bunny but a little critter from central Australia be prove a hit in the Top End . 
The spinifex hopping mouse have become a popular pet in Katherine . 
And a vet Sam McMahon explain , you can not cuddle them , but with their big eye , kangaroo leg , and basil brush tail , they be great to watch . 
`` They 're a very interesting pet , they can live quite happily in you know a reasonable sort of set up , '' he say . 
`` And they 're very interesting to watch . They dig hole , they dig tunnel , they bind around , they 're quite interesting to sort of sit there and stare at . 

Govt call for Q fever vaccine tender 
The Federal Government have call for tender to produce Q fever vaccine a supply of the drug reach critically low level . 
Q fever be a debilitate disease which mainly affect meat and livestock worker , and be transmit through infected animal . 
Though the tender process should be complete by next month , the Government say it be unlikely a new supplier will be find in time to prevent a vaccine shortage . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran have criticise CSL for end production and bulldoze the vaccine plant . 
`` The Government have call for expression of interest for a tender to produce long term supply of Q [ fever ] vaccine , it may well be that CSL will be a tenderer but there may be other company a well , '' he say .

The Cole inquiry examine AWB 's role in the oil-for-food scandal have be adjourn to a date to be fix after hear evidence last week from John Howard , Alexander Downer and Mark Vaile . 
But there be at least one key witness still to come . 
With public hearing all but finalise before Easter , senior counsel assist John Agius inform Commissioner Terence Cole he would require him to sit again for several day after Anzac Day . 
Mr Agius tell the inquiry he be make arrangement for a witness to appear before the commission . 
He later confirm that witness to be Felicity Johnston , who work for the UN 's Office of Iraq program . 
Mr Agius say the commission have obtain clearance from the United Nations but be still go through necessary protocol with the British Foreign Office . 

Extreme weather event affect rural commodity outlook 
Cyclones and hurricane continue to affect the outlook for rural commodity across mining , wheat and sugar market . 
The late Commodity Price Index from the National Australia Bank be predict a slight easing in rural price over the next two year , with sugar , beef , wheat and cotton all expect to perform well . 
Agribusiness economist Skye Dixon say extreme weather event have a big affect on rural price . 
`` They do certainly have an impact because so much of rural commodity price be derive from what 's happen with supply , '' she say . 

NSW drought worsens 
New South Wales be slip further back into drought , with 46 per cent of the State now drought declare . 
That be up eight percentage point on last month . 
Only 20 per cent New South Wales be consider satisfactory for rainfall . 
But the State 's Primary Industries Minister , Ian Macdonald , say despite worsen condition , farmer be optimistic about a big winter crop than last year . 
`` The State need widespread rain particularly in the north but also many area in the south-west which be major crop region need a good downpour fairly quickly , '' he say . 

Tomato plant virus spread 
There be confirmation today that the tomato yellow leaf curl virus be spread in one of Australia 's major production area . 
The virus stunt tomato growth and drastically limit yield . 
Discovered for the first time in Australia a couple of week ago in Brisbane , it have now be identify on two commercial property near Bundaberg . 
Inspections be be plan in other Queensland tomato grow region . 
Chris Adriaansen from the Department of Primary Industries say it be prove difficult to trace the origin of the virus . 
`` This be what we 're find a we 're go through all the property that we 're get positive diagnosis on - there 's no common linkage in term they 're not use the same supply of seedling , they 're not use the same supplier of anything , there 's no other linkage , '' he say . 

Protesters vow to continue gold mine protest 
Environmentalists be continue to picket a New South Wales gold mine over the use of cyanide , which they claim will permanently poison the local water supply . 
The Lake Cowal open pit mine , in the state 's central west , begin process recently but operation be shut down yesterday and a delivery of cyanide have reportedly be delay . 
Eight protester have be charge with trespass but Graham Dunstan from Cyanide Watch say the protest will continue until the mine be close . 
`` This mining company have be grant water lease by the NSW Government to pump up 3,650 megalitres a year for this cyanide operation , '' he say . 
`` They leave this water behind permanently poison . Now in a time of drought give people the equivalent of a Dubbo 's water supply each year be profligate . '' 

Search for grapevine genome move a step closer 
An Italian team of scientist have produce the world 's first draft of the grapevine genome sequence . 
The work , on the pinot noir variety , could lead to the development of high yielding , disease resistant grape that still make good tasting wine . 
Project leader with CSIRO Plant Industries , Doctor Mark Thomas , have be in close contact with the Italian team and say it be an important step towards the final grapevine gene map . 
`` Once the genome sequence be complete it will be the foundation I think for 21st century grape research a it will allow u to understand what gene be involve in grape quality and those gene that also control fruitfulness and yield , '' he say . 
In Australia , the CSIRO have be work with a group in France try to isolate the gene responsible for powdery mildew resistance and downey mildew resistance .

Riverland grape grower who supply to wine giant McGuigan Simeon say they be satisfy with the fruit price determine by an independent analyst . 
The analyst be call in after a dispute arose over price for grape , many which have already be deliver to the winery .

Floodwaters affect search for banana prawn 
Floodwaters and muddy river sediment be make it hard for trawler in the Gulf of Carpentaria this season . 
The banana prawn harvest begin on Saturday , across the northern fishery . 
Newfishing Australia 's Steven Valentine say the fleet be be force to use depth sounder to find the prawn . 
`` With the water clarity not be a it be - not very good , due to the mud slick - and we ca n't spot the mud boil , boat be have to rely heavily on their sounder , which mean we do n't cover the area quite so efficiently , '' he say . 
`` So it 's be a pretty slow start to the season . 
`` Traditionally we road freight them out of Karumba . But , at the moment , with all the road close , we have n't get anywhere to send them to . 
`` Hopefully within the next four to five day , the river will drop enough so that the road will be open and we can truck prawn out . '' 
The Newfishing Australia fleet be hop to catch up to 60 tonne of banana prawn per trawler this season .

Tasmanian scallop fisher say they be feed up with a bureaucracy that have lock them out of the Bass Strait scallop fishery for the past six year . 
Now the Federal Government say the fishery will remain closed for another three year . 
Scallop fisherman Peter Stegmann say scientific advice show a limited season be viable and blame overlap Commonwealth and state fishing jurisdiction for the problem . 
He say part of the $ 220 million earmark for industry restructure should be spend sort out the mess .

`` Most of the others have be fish to extinction .

Global oil price continue rise 
Global oil price continue to climb to record height a Australia 's grain grower prepare for this year 's planting season . 
Last night New York benchmark crude oil close at more than $ US70 a barrel for the first time in 23 year of trading . 
Commodity analyst Tobin Gorey say running cost and fertiliser price will rise far but there could be more demand for wheat and canola to make replacement biofuels . 
`` The cost be actually high so people need to be compensate farmer and so on for produce it so it be profitable otherwise they wo n't stay in the business , '' he say . 
`` But the other side of that too be that demand for thing like ethanol or biodiesel that create further demand for oilseed and grain as well . 
`` Perhaps that can also help boost the price and be perhaps already influence market now to a small degree . '' 
The combination of rise fuel and fertiliser cost be cause for concern for many farmer . 
Graingrowers in South Australia 's Mallee tell Kerrie Lush cut back on cropping be not an option and they be look at other way to reduce cost . 
`` We 're certainly not cut back on any acreage we 're sow but David 's certainly go to try and do as much direct seed without work up anything to save a bit of fuel that way , '' Val Gibbs from Wunkar say . 
She say fertiliser price be also far more expensive than last year . 
`` We have trialled put zinc on through seed dress instead of through fertiliser so that save a bit of money that way . ''

`` For that reason I 'd be more comfortable if we have a government appointee or someone from the public service on that board . '' 
Meanwhile tough international wheat marketing condition have be reflect in AWB 's first payment to grower from the 2005-06 national pool . 
The dividend of just over $ 30 per metric tonne for Australian premium white ( APW ) grade wheat represent just 16 per cent of the total price grower can expect to receive . 
Tony Smith from Plumgrove Commodity Trading say first payment be usually much high but buyer be not prepared to pay high grain price .

Push on for high capital gain tax threshold 
There be call for the capital gain tax ( CGT ) threshold to be lift to at least $ 10 million to protect farmer . 
Combined asset worth more than $ 5 million mean farmer can not access small business concession on the tax . 
It be start to hit farm family when they try to expand , relocate or retire , because of rise property price . 
South Australian accountant Peter Hayes be part of a group that be lobby federal politician to increase the threshold , which have not change for seven year . 
`` One client of mine want to relocate and their combine asset be in the order of $ 6 million , so they do n't comply with the CGT small business threshold and for them to move be go to cost them $ 1 million in tax , '' he say .

Canada have confirm it fifth case of mad cow disease . 
But it be unlikely to cause further trade restriction with the United States . 
US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns say he expect no change in import of Canadian beef and cattle under 30 month , after mad cow disease show up in a six-year-old British Columbia dairy cow . 
But Greg Doud , with the National Cattlemen 's Beef Association , say base on the cow 's age there be a concern over the effectiveness of Canada 's ban on feed cow part to cow , think to spread the disease . 
`` Having the second animal that seem to be after the feed ban go into place in August of 1997 ... do seem to suggest that there be a feed ban compliance issue , '' he say . 
The US resume import of young Canadian animal and their meat last year , but still prohibit trade in old one .

Iraq finalise wheat purchase 
The Iraqi Grains Board say it have finalise a $ 100 million wheat purchase from Australia after almost two month of negotiation . 
Although the three company sell the wheat say they have not yet sign a contract , the Grains Council of Australia believe term have be agree . 
The head of the Iraq Grains Board Khalil Aassi have tell reporter the country will buy 350,000 tonne of wheat at $ 190 a tonne from the Wheat Australia consortium . 
The deal be broker by Trade Minister Mark Vaile , who visit Baghdad in February to save the Iraq wheat trade , after it announce it would no longer deal with monopoly exporter AWB because of the oil-for-food kickback scandal . 
The deal with Wheat Australia , which include ABB , GrainCorp and Cooperative Bulk Handling , break AWB 's hold over wheat export . 
But the Grains Council 's David Ginns say the deal will not be a lucrative one . 
`` As we know , time cost money and they certainly spend a lot of time and money on finalise this deal , '' he say . 
Australia have traditionally supply around a quarter of Iraq 's wheat , make it Australia 's third large wheat market .

Wheat exporter AWB say the next few month be critical for the global grain market , a weather condition determine the size of the world crop . 
Australian grower have already receive a low than expect return on the 2005-06 crop , largely due to fluctuate demand for hard wheat variety and tough international marketing condition . 
And general manager of AWB International , Sarah Scales , say global demand remain subdue . 
`` I think the next couple of month be very critical , I think it 's make or break as far a the world wheat market go for the next 12 month , depend on particularly rain condition in the hard red winter wheat belt of the United States , '' she say .

Australia 's big apple packhouse be launch a multi-million dollar upgrade .

The technology have be import from New Zealand and second grade fruit be identify electronically and then remove from the premium packing line . 
It be expect to increase it efficiency . 
The grower-owned co-operative be establish in 1922 and produce 6,000 bin of apple each year . 
The district 's grower be suffer after price fell last year under the weight of a big crop and import apple juice . 
It be well recognise that the gap between city-slickers and their country cousin be grow .

Drought program speed up aid application 
Farmers will get faster access to drought assistance under new change unveil by state and federal agriculture minister today . 
They be the first in a raft of drought assistance change farmer hope to see over the next six month . 
The National Agricultural Monitoring System ( NAMS ) be expect to slash the time it take to gather the information farmer need to lodge a drought assistance application . 
It will provide instant online rainfall , soil moisture , crop yield and commodity price information , streamline contact between farmer and local , state and federal government . 
Vice-president of the National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) Charles Burke say there need to be fundamental change to the way drought assistance be deliver but this be a positive first step that will help farmer . 
`` It 'll really give an overall picture of say one particular region and how it 's perform in a drought , '' he say . 

Money launder law change 'draconian ' 
Rural bank branch and agency could be under threat from propose change to federal money launder legislation . 
While the law be design to target organised crime , a report by the Chartered Secretaries of Australia say it will be too hard for many small bank agency to comply . 
Chief executive Tim Sheehy say bank will need to have personal contact with client , there will be change to identification requirement and big fine . 
`` They be draconian , they 're unfortunately a one size fit all approach , '' he say . 
`` The way that the propose legislation be , there 's no difference in penalty for a fairly minor transgression or a major $ 10 million one if you 're an agent . 
`` [ When ] you 're face with the risk of a major penalty for a small error , you 're probably go to pull out of the business . ''

Debate intensifies about fuel alternative a oil price rise 
Oil price be not get any good with the price of West Texas crude jumping again last night to $ US72 a barrel . 
As price go up , debate be intensify about fuel alternative . 
Bruce Robinson from the Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas say Australia could halve it transport fuel usage by minimise it dependence on car . 
He say fuel tax should be increase similar to the system introduce by former prime minister Margaret Thatcher in United Kingdom in the 1980s . 
`` If we continue to provide very cheap petrol and to give excise free petrol to everyone and subsidise it a happens in Queensland then we be just go to continue down the oil dependence [ road ] , '' he say . 
`` The enormous legacy Margaret Thatcher have leave to Britain , she 's give the price signal that oil be go to be more expensive then they be not nearly so dependent on cheap fuel a we be . '' 
The high price of crude oil be cause investor to take a close look at the biofuels industry .

Cyclone cause minor damage 
There have be big rainfall in the wake of cyclone Monica in far north Queensland . 
The category three cyclone cross the north-east coast late yesterday but do not appear to have cause too much damage . 
Cyclone Monica follow almost exactly the same path a cyclone Ingrid which rip through the region about 13 month ago . 
Monica hit land just south of the Lockhart Aboriginal community . 
Very few commercial fishing boat be shelter in Lockhart River 's mangrove and so far there have be no report of major incident . 
On cattle property in the cyclone 's path the strong wind bring down some branch , tree , shed and fence but overall damage have be minor . 
Tom Burns manage Orchid Creek station and he say his big problem be find his dog .

`` Whether that 's true or not I do n't know but it just highlight the concern that one of the process have to be fumigation because while wheat bug may not affect the Batlow or the Australian apple and pear industry it would sure a hell play havoc on the Australian wheat industry . ''

Salt interception project to benefit Murray River 
A project to stop thousand of tonne of salt enter the Murray River have just be open near Kerang in north-west Victoria . 
The $ 13 million salt interception project will pump saline groundwater from Pyramid Creek into evaporation basin . 
The salt will then be commercially harvest instead of flow into the Murray . 
Goulburn Murray Water 's Carl Mather say the project will benefit both farmer and the environment . 
`` The scheme will stop approximately 22,000 tonne of salt reach the River Murray , '' he say .

Govt 's hand tie in water trading dispute 
The Federal Government say it be powerless to intervene in a cross-border dispute which be hold up water reform . 
Three state have be fin million of dollar for fail to meet agreed target on interstate water trading . 
Victoria , New South Wales and South Australia will have $ 10 million , $ 13 million and $ 3 million in competition payment withhold respectively , open up a new row between them and the Federal Government . 
South Australia and Victoria claim they be be punish for New South Wales fail to agree on their trading model but the Iemma Government say it have meet all of it water trading requirement . 
National Water Commission chairman Ken Matthews will not buy into which state be responsible for the hold-up . 
`` I 'm not take side among the state , all three state have be work hard , '' he say . 
But Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull say the Federal Government have no constitutional power to end the state stand-off . 
`` That be the constitutional reality , '' he say . 
Victoria and South Australia have agree on an exchange rate system of open-border trading but New South Wales be call for a different model which take into account it low security water entitlement . 
Minister for the River Murray in South Australia Karlene Maywald say she be bitterly disappointed because an agreement on water trading reform have be reach with Victoria . 
`` We believe that 's grossly unfair and we think that South Australia be be dock $ 3 million when we have do everything we can to ensure that our border be open , '' she say .

The Federal Government be be call on to buy Snowy Hydro and keep it a a publicly-owned water and power asset . 
The call be unanimously make at an angry meeting of 350 people at Cooma , in southern New South Wales last night , who be oppose to the joint state and federal sell-off . 
The scheme be expect to earn $ 3 billion if the sale go ahead this year , but Snowy River Mayor Richard Wallace say public ownership be much more important .

`` We do need a long term sustainable timber industry and the investment scheme have really encourage that softwood planting , '' he say . 
`` So I guess if the region and the country want another for example $ 400 million investment in Tumut that be really fundamental to it . 

GrainCorp 's silos closure plan anger farm group 
Anger be mount among eastern state ' farm group about plan by GrainCorp to close more than 100 grain receival site . 
Some farmer say the decision will force them to travel up to 100 kilometre more to deliver grain . 
North-west Victorian farmer Rod Bishop say he will need to purchase another truck to be able to cart grain more efficiently . 
And he say others might be leave with no choice but to spend hundred of thousand of dollar to set up on-farm grain storage . 
`` I personally do n't like it that much because you have to market the grain , keep the weevil out and all those issue come into it but you certainly could n't discount do it , that 's for sure , '' he say . 
GrainCorp chairman Don Taylor say the company will consider keep the silo open if grower can guarantee supply . 
The grain handler have close most site which process less than 5,000 tonne of grain . 
Mr Taylor say GrainCorp 's also willing to look at sell old infrastructure to farmer but do not think grower will be interested .

Farmers expect to get tax concession 
Farmers look set to win capital gain tax concession in the federal Budget to cut the cost of pass down family farm . 
There could also be a billion dollar budget bonus for rural road with the National party believe to have secure money to link strategic road to port . 
Currently many farmer pay huge capital gain tax bill when they sell their farm because rise rural land price have push their farm value above a $ 5 million threshold . 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say that mean producer can no longer access small business tax concession , make farm succession plan a costly process . 
Reports now suggest the Government will allow more farmer to get the tax concession .

AWB 'apology document ' suppression ruling loom 
A bid by wheat exporter AWB to stop the release of an `` apology document '' be be hear in the Federal Court in Melbourne . 
Earlier this month the AWB board vote to lodge the court challenge to AWB inquiry Commissioner Terence Cole 's decision to lift a non-publication order on the document , which be prepare for the company last year . 
The document be write by a crisis management expert , who suggest the company take a strategy of `` over-apology '' . 
Commissioner Cole rule the document be not prepare for the purpose of legal advice and so could be publish . 
An AWB spokesman say the board felt the document , and others to do with AWB 's internal investigation into the scandal , should be protect by legal professional privilege . 
Former manage director Andrew Lindberg have tell the court he engage a US public relation consultant to put together the statement of contrition , which would be present to the Cole inquiry . 
Under cross-examination he deny the statement be prepare for PR purpose but maintain it be part of the company 's legal strategy . 
However Mr Lindberg acknowledge any statement to the inquiry would attract widespread publicity . 
The court be expect to make a decision today on whether to release the document .

`` Sixty-five per cent say they do not act ethically , only 12 per cent say they do , '' Mr Morgan say . 
`` We ask the question : 'Do you think the Prime Minister John Howard act ethically on this issue or not ' . 
`` Fifty-four per cent say no , he do not act ethically , 29 per cent say he do , 17 per cent be undecided . 
`` We ask the same question about Alexander Downer . Fifty-six per cent say 'he do not act ethically ' . 

Darwin resident prepare for Monica 's onslaught 
Preparations for tropical cyclone Monica be under way across the city of Darwin in the Northern Territory . 
The category 5 system have already create major disruption with commercial fishing . 
As tropical cyclone Monica track west across the Gulf of Carpentaria , many of the 75 prawn trawler that fish the remote off-shore region take shelter in calmer water to the south near Karumba and the Northern Territory-Queensland border . 
Others steam back to their northern port such a the Francis Bay Mooring Basin in Darwin . 
The interruption to the banana prawn harvest have create at least one week of disrupt fishing time and waste fuel in not ideal fish ground . 
One of the large company , NewFishing Australia , estimate the disruption will cost them ten of thousand of dollar . 
It be an unusual sight to see trawler and fishing vessel in the Darwin Port in the middle of the season which end in just under one month . 
They be be double lash to mooring with rope and pack in tight side by side with tyre fender between them to reduce friction . 
And the level of water in this mooring basin will be drop to allow these large vessel to rest on the bottom for the bad of the weather . 

Flooding 
And rain from cyclone Monica be cause the bad flood in live memory in part of far north Queensland . 
Residents from a Cape York Peninsula aboriginal community and at least three family from cattle property have be airlift to drier ground . 
Glen Shephard from Lilyvale Station , near Princess Charlotte Bay , say he have never see anything like it 
`` Wednesday afternoon it start to rain and by about seven o'clock the next morning we 'd have seven inch so the water be start to tickle our toe , sort a thing , '' he say . 
`` It come through the house about fourteen or fifteen inch ... have to walk across the airstrip to get over on a bit of high ground . 
`` It 's always a concern about crocs in this country [ but ] ... I do n't tell the kid that . '' 
Senior forecaster at the Bureau of Meteorology David Alexander say Monica be one of the most perfect cyclone system he have see . 
He say it be far more dangerous than cyclone Larry which cause massive destruction in far north Queensland last month . 
`` It 's probably the best developed cyclone I have see in many , many year , '' he say . 
`` It 's get a perfect circular eye , it 's right at the top of a category 5 range , so it 's a very , very severe cyclone .

A four year project have show commercial angler can use long line for deep sea fishing without kill thousand of seabird . 
In the past trailing bait hook behind trawler in Antarctic water have cause the death of up to 3,000 bird a year . 
Techniques , include quickly sink hook and haul them in differently , have reduce sea bird death to zero . 
Les Scott from fish company Petuna Sealord say other country should follow Australia 's lead . 
`` The statistic show that the mitigation method work because if you look at our neighbour their bird mortality be still 2,000 plus , '' he say .

Increased production in Australia and strong global competition will keep grain price low .

`` The price of grain have be fall at about an average of 2.2 per cent for the last 28 year and yet we all know that the cost of fertiliser , fuel and in particular debt servicing be go to be at an all time high for the come cropping season and the commodity price be n't all that great yet , '' he say . 
`` It 's always great for the top 25 per cent and if we look at any of the ABARE study they do shine .

A total of 383 millimetre have fall so far this month and weather bureau forecaster Patrick Ward say that be close to four time the average . 
`` Darwin have about 53 mm at the airport , down towards Adelaide River it be a lot heavy . East branch Adelaide River have 224 mm , which be quite a lot , '' he say . 
`` This time of year it 's sort of the clear up period of the monsoon season and into the dry . It 's unseasonably late to get a cyclone . It 's just about the late cyclone we have have . ''

In a natural state , the same be true for human . 
But Professor Steve Simpson from the University of Sydney say modern diet with high fat and salt content trick people into overeat . 
`` But if you simply change the ratio and you can do that in one or two way - incorporate high quality protein item in the diet and by that I mean lean meat or fish or high quality vegetable protein , '' he say .

Panel urge national approach to GM technology regulation 
There be a call today for a national approach to the regulation of gene technology because of confusion cause by state-based ban on genetically modify ( GM ) crop . 
The Gene Technology Act be introduce in 2000 to oversee the use of GM technology in Australia but since then all state except Queensland and the Northern Territory have impose their own rule . 
Chairwoman of an independent panel which have review the Act , Susan Timbs , say the regulation have become too confusing . 
`` This be a point that be make very strongly to u by industry , that if they go through and get their approval from the regulator , suddenly they feel that there be a complete block because they do n't know the criterion that they need to meet to convince the relevant state government , '' she say .

A former Snowy Hydro commissioner , Vin Good , urge people to oppose the sale . 
`` This Australian heritage icon should be keep in Government ownership forever , '' he say . 
With harvest draw to a close , up to 3 per cent of wine grape will be leave unpicked this year , due to oversupply . 
The national vintage be expect to reach 1.9 million tonne , just 1 per cent down on last season . 

Row brew over european bumblebee plan 
A row have erupt over a plan to import european bumblebee to mainland Australia . 
While the horticulture sector say they could help boost production in greenhouse and hydroponic operation , environmentalist be worry about other impact . 
A Department of Environment and Heritage report release for public comment last week be consider the importation of bumblebee for control crop pollination . 
Queensland greenhouse tomato grower David Da Pra say it would dramatically boost production . 
`` Bring high pollination , which will give good fruit quality , good shelf life , more saleable fruit , '' he say . 
The Wide Bay Conservation Council 's Pam Soper want further research into artificial pollination , strongly oppose the importation of the bumblebee . 

Resource boom behind zinc mine 's reopening 
The booming base metal price have lead to the reopening of an old zinc mine in the Kimberley region of Western Australia . 
Canadian company Teck Cominco will reopen it underground mine near Fitzroy Crossing because of a recent hike in zinc price on the London Metal Exchange . 
Teck Cominco exploration general manager Wayne Spilsbury say zinc be perform well after a three-year price glut . 
`` We be watch the stock of zinc in the LME warehouse and make sure those number be come down before we make a decision to reopen . There be now an under supply , but that have only turn up in the last year or so . '' 
In South Australia , junior zinc explorer Terramin Australia have also benefit .

Some of the Northern Territory 's most isolated pastoralists be in Tennant Creek to improve their medical skill today , amid concern over the future of health service . 
Station manager and worker from around the Northern Territory 's Barkly Tablelands have travel hundred of kilometre to the central Australian town of Tennant Creek for the annual Barkly Health Seminar . 
Heavy rain and boggy road have do nothing to keep people away at a time of uncertainty about the future of remote health service in the region . 
Pastoralists have express concern that visit by health expert to pastoral station may soon be cut back .

Fruit fly find concern grower 
Fruit and vegetable producer on the Adelaide Plains be worry about the impact of a fruit fly outbreak . 
Mediterranean fruit fly , which also target vegetable , have be detect in Adelaide 's north-west suburb . 
Mike Redmond , from the Virginia Horticulture Centre , north of the outbreak , say a quarantine area have be establish and sterile fly be be release to contain the spread . 
`` If it get into our greenhouse it would be horrific for our industry , '' Mr Redmond say . 
`` Tomatoes , capsicum , eggplant would be the main impact from our perspective . 

Eucalyptus rust fear 
The Primary Industries Ministerial Council meeting last week sound an alarm call on the fungal disease , eucalyptus rust . The council note the tree disease , native to South and Central America , have reach Hawaii , and there be fear it could get into Australia . Indeed the council go so far a to suggest that prevention and contingency plan for the disease be prepare a a matter of urgency . The disease attack plant under two year of age , cause leaf and shoot dieback and kill the plant . Potentially it could kill not only large number of young plantation tree but also native eucalypt , a it have a wide number of eucalypt which could act a host . Ensis have predict the area most likely to be at risk be the NT , coastal Queensland and NSW . However , generally warm condition could see it easily colonise region far south . In Brazil , there be a 40 per cent fatality from the disease . 

Footrot control review 
The continuation of the state 's sheep footrot control program have be assure after a comprehensive review by representative from the South Australian Sheep Advisory Committee , the South Australian Farmers Federation and PIRSA . In the 1950s , about one third of the sheep flock in the south-east be suffer from the disease but eradication program and improve diagnosis have eradicate the most virulent strain . Sheep with the disease find it difficult to walk and can get fly blow foot and leg from the disease , and they must be quarantine . Footrot be still a notifiable disease although new technology would be trialed to find good control method . 

More work to be do on fresh produce code of conduct 
The Federal Government deny it have break a key election promise for a mandatory code of conduct for the fresh produce sector , despite further delay .

`` I think that be quite ambiguous and be a broaden out of his other statement that I 've have regard to , '' he say . 
`` So it might have be in Mr Anderson 's mind to expand it to supermarket but that would have be policy on the run . '' 
The National Farmers Federation say the Government 's 100 day deadline be always unachievable . 
Despite want the retail sector include originally , vice-president Charles Burke now just want the policy in place as soon a possible . 

Veg price increase not flow through to farmer 
New figure show vegetable be cost 15 per cent more than at this time last year . 
The Australian Bureau of Statistics say the cost of food overall jump more than 4 per cent last quarter due to a hot summer and high cost for input like fuel and packaging . 
Mike Badcock from vegetable grower group AUSVEG say despite the rise , farmer be not see any increase in their profit . 
`` The very hot summer that eastern Australia experience this year really affected production , it basically cook the product in the ground and it be n't suitable so there 's be some quite large shortage of product - that 's the reason price have go up , '' he say . 
`` The two major supermarket chain control about 76 per cent of the market , they 've never have so much market share and they 're become quite aggressive on what price they pay for product .

Security be tight at the World Meat Congress with police surround the Convention Centre in Brisbane and security guard everywhere inside the building . 
The protest come a Australia be experience unprecedented growth in the cattle and beef industry . 
Cattle number be expect to grow by nearly 3 million head in the next four year and the value of export have rise by $ 870 million since 2003 , that 's on the back of growth in Japan and Korea . 
But keynote speaker at the Congress , Professor David Hughes , say while industry can not ignore concern about animal welfare , the total opposition to the farming of livestock represent a minority worldwide .

But he say other factor be also have an impact . 
`` Commodity price globally really have n't go anywhere over the last 12 month or if anything perhaps have ease a bit , '' he say . 
`` So this strong Aussie dollar , of course , be crimp back our exporter income for the farmer and really when you be think about the farm sector - high interest rate yes they will bite a bit around the margin . 
`` But perhaps the real significance be what we ca n't control and that be the rainfall out there and that be really go to be the driving factor of whether farmer have a good year or not . ''

Adelaide River battle flood 
The Northern Territory community of Adelaide River be battle flood in the wake of tropical cyclone Monica . 
More than 150 millimetre of rain fell on Anzac Day alone this week . 
Kai Hansen live on Goat Island on the western edge of Kakadu National Park and say brown , crocodile-infested water be roar past his house . 
`` There be no dry land leave at all . We know this beforehand that there be a potential for it to come up here but 800mm of rain in one month , and 290mm of rain in 19 hour we have - it 's an incredible amount of water , '' he say . 
`` I do n't think we will see any crocs because as soon a water get a bit rough the crocs seek quieter land . 
`` We do n't worry about it , we walk around chest deep in the water now and then outside to salvage more thing and get the boat and barge tie up and get to the generator shed , and we do n't even consider it . ''

Sterile fruit fly fail to satisfly partner 
Sterile fruit fly have be tout a a way of control number of the pest insect but researcher say they be not prove to be satisfy mate . 
Research have show female fruit fly be attract to the sterile male but they be not always satisfy and head off look for other mate . 
Dr Phil Taylor from Macquarie University say they be now try to fix the problem , to stop them from cause major damage in horticultural region . 
`` Wild fly do n't seem to mind mat with them , however the sterile male have some issue with the amount of sperm they transfer and then the female 's likely to re-mate , '' he say .

Water in the bank 
While water scarcity be not much of an issue in the Top End at the moment , in central Australia attempt to develop a new horticulture industry depend very much on new water save technology . The water re-use project in Alice Springs have be under development for some time but emerge technology could make a number of similar project viable and workable . Professor Stuart White from Sydney 's University of Technology have work on water save project with government and council around Australia and he say there be a new sense of urgency to develop water saving project . `` When we start to move away from the urban sector and talk about water use more generally and remember 80 per cent of water be not use in town and city it 's actually use in irrigated agriculture and so on , we do have to take a bit of a long hard look at some of the industry that be use water and say be this appropriate and what be the trade off between the impact of some of these industry and the impact on water way and the benefit we derive from them . However there be huge scope for efficiency there , I mean we 're talk about efficiency level which can be improve even beyond what we 're talk about in the city , in term of relatively low cost saving , and some of those be start to be pick up and that 's a good thing . ''

WA native title battle resolve 
A 12-year native title battle surround the Western Australian town of Broome have finally be resolve . 
The Federal Court have recognise the Yawuru people a the rightful native title holder of land surround Broome . 
The full effect of native title will take place on the Indigenous-owned cattle property , Roebuck Station , while the neighbouring property , Thangoo Station , will continue to operate a a privately-owned lease . 
Fred Chaney from the Native Title Tribunal say the decision also extend to area like the famous Cable Beach . 
`` The beach be of course a very significant feature of Broome and that be an area where you ca n't have exclusive possession the court find but where the Aboriginal people have continue traditional interest which they share with the general community , '' he say . 
`` There be area of town where native title have be find to survive ( in other word not extinguish ) and there be very large area outside town , in particular the Aboriginal own pastoral property which have exclusive possession native title . ''

Climate change may shift Goyder 's Line 
Climate change could force South Australia 's iconic Goyder 's Line to shift 100 kilometre south . 
The imaginary line be draw in 19th century by surveyor general George Goyder mark the 250 millimetre rainfall area from the Eyre Peninsula around to the Riverland . 
He believe the region north of the line should not be crop . 
Peter Hayman from the South Australian Research and Development Institute say with an increase in temperature and a reduction in rainfall , the line could shift a far south a the Clare Valley . 
`` What we find be that the bad scenario , so the bad amount of warm and the most extreme scenario be for it to move by 2070 as far a a somewhere like Clare , '' he say .

The Reserve Bank 's decision to lift interest rate be more bad news for farmer , follow on from high fuel price . 
The interest rate rise , to 5.75 per cent , be the first in more than 14 month . 
Senior analyst with Hartleys , Rob Brierley , say the announcement will hurt the outlook for commodity . 
`` Most of the commodity be price in US dollar so it mean that the seller of the commodity actually get less in Australian dollar for it , '' he say . 

Farmers dispute Govt report figure 
Vegetable grower say the Federal Government have make up figure in a report , which show extend country of origin food label would cost consumer $ 120 million a year . 
Farmers want the label on package and can food as well a fresh produce to give consumer more information and promote locally grown fruit and vegetable . 
But the Government say the study show the cost of the change would far outweigh the benefit for both consumer and grower . 
John Roach from grower group AusVeg say the study be base on flaw data . 
But while reject new law to enforce more detailed label , Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say he want to change the Trade Practices Act to give consumer more accurate information . 
He say under the change , 'made in Australia ' would be replace for some package food to 'grown in Australia ' . 

Fruit grower attend crisis summit 
Australia 's summerfruit industry be draft an action plan to try to keep producer in business . 
Peach , nectarine , plum , apricot and apple grower be battle cheap import and a lack of export sale since access to Taiwan be restrict last season . 
Fruit grower be still thrash out the detail at a crisis summit in Melbourne , but Heather Chong from Summerfruit Australia say some priority be emerge . 

Wool pool to help Tas grower 
In a departure from the traditional auction system , wool grower in Tasmania will be able to sell their fibre through a new wool pool . 
Agribusiness Roberts Limited have launch Wool Link to market Tasmanian grown and brand wool direct to the fashion house of Japan and the US . 
Ten thousand bale will be sell in the first year , and the company say grower will be pay more than they have receive on average in the auction room . 
Marketing manager Eric Hutchinson admit there be bind to be scepticism . 
`` And for some it 's go to be a leap of faith in what we can deliver , there 's no doubt about that , '' he say . 

US producer implement animal ID system 
US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns say major beef buyer have give the country little choice but to implement a national animal ID system . 
The National Animal Identification System could become compulsory if not enough US producer volunteer to join by 2009 . 
Mr Johanns say in response to industry opponent of animal ID in US , major beef competitor Australia and Canada have already implement system to trace and contain disease outbreak . 
And most recently , Mr Johanns cite retail demand in Australia . 
`` I just notice that in Australia , a representative of McDonalds , which of course be a major purchaser of beef , make a statement about the need for this animal ID system . '' 
Mr Johanns predict the US industry will have to change with the time , despite some who oppose new cost and less corporate privacy . 

Restraint box to improve cattle slaughter in SE Asia 
Australia be invest almost a million dollar to improve the slaughter of cattle in South-East Asia . 
Fifty restraint box be be instal at abattoir across Indonesia and Malaysia . 
The aim be to ensure all Australian cattle be process humanely within two year . 
Meat and Livestock Australia 's Patrick Underwood say he be confident the box will be use . 
`` It 's a fully galvanise and enclose box , whereby the animal enters through a raceway into an abattoir , be place in a restraining box and restrain prior to slaughter , '' he say . 
`` I have form an animal welfare task force , with member of APFINDO ( the Indonesian feedlotters and farmer association ) , so the Indonesian importer be with u , illustrate the clear benefit of use these restrain box . ''

It be not all conference and seminar though . The Iron Man and Woman event will see competitor eat marinate bull testicle and there 's a great debate , be beef well than sex ? 

Decision to abandon water transport plan 'not surprising ' 
Residents of Western Australia 's far north say they be relieve at a decision to abandon plan to transport Kimberley water to Perth . 
Three option be investigate by the State Government , involve a water pipeline , a canal or transport by sea . 
None have be find to be economically viable . 
Kununurra resident Dick Pasfield say he be not surprised , 
`` I think there be a reasonable amount of scepticism about whether a project like this would actually be viable in term of the economics , '' he say . 
`` I guess that what the report have say be basically what a lot of people think in the first place , that it 's go to cost far too much money to do a project like this . '' 
The WA government be still on the hunt for alternate water source , look at option include the Yarragadee aquifer in the state 's south-west .

An Aboriginal corporation in Western Australia have be fin $ 10,000 for fail to provide sufficient water for 1,500 head of cattle on a station in the state 's interior .

Dry condition take their toll in NSW 
Dry condition be continue to hurt in New South Wales , where producer in the Upper Hunter be be knock back from graze cattle on the travel stock route . 
A lack of water be be blame for the situation in Singleton , Scone and Merriwa , where some producer be wait up to 12 month to access reserve . 
Scone ranger Gerard McLaughlin say he do not have a choice , with half the water point in his area dry . 
`` There 's 590 head at the moment wander around the road in my area ... there could probably be a lot more if we have water that 's the problem , '' he say . 
`` At the moment I 'm get more and more request for people want to go on the road but it 's a bit awkward when you ca n't access water . '' 

Farmers battle fleabane 
Farmers in Western Australia be battle a nightmare weed which can take over paddock and be difficult to kill . 
The area affect by fleabane on the south coast be increase rapidly , with the tall woody plant also spread into agricultural area far north . 
Dr Sally Peltzer from the state Department of Agriculture and Food say good summer rainfall have make the problem worse . 
`` I 've be out and about actually try to collect a bit of fleabane and I have see some pretty nasty paddock , '' she say . 
`` It look bad because they 're sort of tall and hairy look so that do n't tend to look , compare to the other , pasture plant or whatever . '' 

Govt holiday worker scheme to be extend 
A scheme to use backpacker to ease labour shortage in the horticulture and cropping sector be be extend to cover livestock , forestry and fishing . 
From July , holiday maker who work for three month in job like shearing , stock handling and pearling will be able to apply for a second 12 month visa . 
The Federal Government will also double the length of time backpacker can work for one employer - from three to six month . 
The National Farmers Federation 's Denita Wawn say producer would prefer to employ local worker but there be not enough people willing to work in regional Australia . 
`` At NFF certainly it be our preference that we can [ use ] local to work in these job but experience show that people , a lot of people simply be n't interested in work in agriculture , '' she say . 
But some primary industry be highly critical of the change . 
The Territory 's pearling industry say the increase to six month work placement will not solve labour shortage , because that 's still not long enough to cover the cost of induction and training . 
The Horticultural Association say the extension will benefit the nursery , prune and pack industry but spokeswoman Tracey Leo say there could be a big impact on the mango harvest . 
`` We be see a thinning of the available labour pool . So in short I guess we be now go into competition with industry that we may not have be compete for labour with before , '' she say . 
`` In our high volume year , they [ foreign worker ] be a significant portion of our labour force .

Despite miss a crucial deadline in global negotiation to reduce trade distort tariff and subsidy in agriculture , Trade Minister Mark Vaile say a deal can be reach this year . 
Mr Vaile fly back into Australia this morning after talk in Europe and say the European Union be now look at further reduction in the financial support it give to farmer . 
But he be warn a failure to get a deal this year , could delay the Doha Round of talk until 2011 . 
`` That be the great unknown because once we go beyond the northern summer which be fundamentally August , the farm Bill have to be renew and there 's already pressure come on in Congress in Washington to start write a new farm Bill , '' he say .

`` We 're very upset with the result of this . So the grower do their figure a to whether they grow again or whether they give the land a spell , or whether they go into another crop or another enterprise . That 's their call . ''

Farmers wary of govt change to fuel rebate 
Farmers already fight high interest rate and the strong Aussie dollar now face change to their fuel bill from July 1 , which could add further pressure to their budget . 
The Federal Government will scrap a tax subsidy rebate worth up to three cent a litre to regional motorist , and change the 18-cent a litre on-road energy credit scheme . 
Under the scheme , farmer and transport operator will receive their fuel rebate off their GST bill , instead of a cash grant pay directly into their bank account . 
Luke Fraser from the Livestock Transporters Association say the change will create a cash flow headache for rural and regional business . 
`` We have a business where over 30 per cent of our total cost input be fuel . Farmers would probably understand that sentiment , '' he say . 
`` And in that sort of position , when you 're be ask to go through administrative hoop to try and claim that back , and you never actually see it in cash , it 's just come off a tax bill , well that 's a big change . 
`` To say , look on July 1 it 's all go to switch over and everyone will be fine , be incredibly naive and insulting . '' 
A spokesman for Assistant Treasurer Peter Dutton say it will be simpler in the long run to deliver the energy credit to farmer and trucker through their GST bill .

It be not often you see Mexicans swill tequila and rid donkey in central Australia .

While the adult gulp down bean and tequila and race donkey , organiser Sarah Debney say it be sheep that people really want to see . 
`` That 's the Mexican mutton chase ... we 've get team of two child and the team put on their poncho and hat and they run down the other end and do the same scull with water and baked bean , run back and we let sheep out of the shoot and they have to herd the sheep over the line , '' she say .

Beef program add to producer return 
A new economic analysis have find the beef quality program MSA be add an extra 20 cent a kilo to beef producer ' return . 
The meat standard be develop by the Beef Cooperative Research Centre and use a set of scientific criterion to allow consumer to identify beef which be guarantee to be tender . 
Centre head Dr Heather Burrow say the program will add $ 85 million to beef revenue this financial year . 
Overall , she say it have generate three time what it cost to industry to develop . 
`` Averaging 20 cent a kilo , beef producer , retailer and processor be get a premium for beef that they can guarantee be good than every day eat quality , '' she say . 
The Bureau of Statistics will conduct a census of livestock producer for the first time in five year . 
It will collect data from 190,000 farm across the country and be expect to highlight the value of the cattle industry to the Australian economy . 
Census manager , Jim Williamson say the data will help to drive the live export industry . 
`` Being able to ensure we can meet future export market if we want to enter into future contract , we can be confident we have enough cattle to fill the contract , '' he say . 
`` People can keep a handle on whether the cattle herd be go up or down . ''

Shareholders expect to launch class action against AWB

`` The most extraordinary positive act of mislead conduct we think be October 27 when the company issue a statement to the stock exchange after the Volcker suggestion be make in 2005 that the company may have be involve in sanction bust , '' he say . 
`` The company make a statement to the stock exchange that it be not . Well that 's another course of action that be even more powerful . '' 
AWB share have defy stockmarket trend to gain ground this week , despite the Reserve Bank 's decision to lift interest rate . 
AWB stock fell considerably during the Cole inquiry , but yesterday gain 5 per cent . 
Stockbrocker Matthew Baker say the prospect of more trade with India be behind the gain . 
`` But basically AWB have get on with it job and it 's go out there and it look like it 's go to win more business in India which be basically ship more product out the door , '' he say . 
`` Their price will vary because of the currency side but they 're happy because they 're go to be sell a lot more stock . '' 
The Indian Government be expect to announce a tender for 3 million tonne of wheat within a week . 
Soaring domestic price and a low than expect crop be put pressure on Indian authority to provide enough wheat for the population .

`` There 's not an automatic link essentially unless they 've get contract pricing in place , which for a lot of sector of the industry that just do n't exist , it 's commodity market pricing , '' he say .
