Farmers be call for regional road and rail spending to come before further investment in the Future Fund when Federal Treasurer Peter Costello hand down the Budget tomorrow night . 
The fund be design to cover future superannuation payment to public servant . 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) be warn the Government against boost investment in the Future Fund and add to the surplus , at the expense of infrastructure spending and tax reform . 
Chief executive Ben Fargher say the Government must commit to lift the standard of grain rail line in New South Wales and Victoria . 
And he be call for basic all weather road access to farm and the sealing of all designate arterial road by 2013 . 
`` Farmers need to actually get the produce from to the farm to the National Highway in the first place , '' he say . 
Mr Costello be already talk up big money for regional road and rail , with spending expect to be in excess of a billion dollar . 
`` Better transport mean a good economy with a high speed limit for growth , '' he say . 
The Government be also hint at capital gain tax reform , which should help succession planning for farmer . 
Meanwhile transport operator in the Northern Territory be look for funding in the Budget to improve remote road . 
For the past fortnight 60 road train have be unable to cross the Victoria River , west of Katherine , due to damage cause to Highway One by flood . 
The delay be estimate to have cause the industry at least $ 7 million , with weight restriction only lift at the weekend to allow single trailer through .

`` We have seven road train there , there be a total of 60 wait in Kununurra to get through . That be come north , come south there be probably about 40 road train wait on this side . 

Oil price may pass $ US100 a barrel 
A transport expert say although biofuels and ethanol may help in the long term , nothing can stop oil price hit high of $ US100 a barrel . 
David Lamb , who head the Energy Flagship of the CSIRO , say there be no way production of any alternative fuel can match more than about 1 per cent of our energy need . 
His concern come a a world expert on energy market , Claude Mandil , warn that with strong demand and fall supply , oil price could eventually rise above $ US100 a barrel . 
Mr Lamb say without any alternative fuel , cut consumption be the only option . 
`` By 2011 our Government 's plan be to be produce 350 million litre of ethanol per year but that 's only about 1 per cent of the amount of oil we use so that 's no solution by 2011 , '' he say . 

Wool price expect to pick up 
A new report say wool price be about to climb again , despite seven week of loss . 
The eastern market indicator be 46 cent per kilogram below the seasonal high record in March . 
The late business survey from market body Woolmark say the fall be inevitable , with not enough demand to support high price . 
But with strong order come through from China , western Europe and East Asia , Woolmark economist Kerry Stott say price will pick up through the June quarter . 
`` It 's the best it 's be in almost five year , '' he say . 
`` The really good thing be that it 's more widespread geographically than in the past and not only that , it seem to be more widespread right through from comb through to weave . 
`` And I think if people look at what 's happen to our price in US dollar , and see that our price be still go up in US dollar , they 'd be pleasantly surprise . '' 
The eastern market indicator close at 708 cent a kilo clean on Friday . 
Woolmark 's prediction be be back by some analyst . 
Elders Queensland wool manager Maurie McNeill expect a decent recovery base on price indication out of China . 
`` We can probably see 20 per cent retracement of the loss that we 've see in this market over the last four or five week , particularly in the fine end of the market , '' he say .

Water cost to push commodity price up 
A national conference have hear rise water cost will push some irrigators out of primary production . 
The Irrigation Association of Australia 's conference in Brisbane have also hear high water cost will push up commodity price . 
Chief executive Jolyon Burnett say some irrigators face rise of up to 4,000 per cent , a water authority move to recover more of the delivery cost . 
`` It be important that we attach a more realistic value to water and that there be signal , if you like , to the grower to value that water and to improve their efficiency . '' 
Despite the rise cost , Professor Paul Perkins from the Australian National University predict Australia will be one of the few country in the world with enough water to grow it own food in 25 year time . 
He say it be a great opportunity to expand export . 
`` The global water shortage be much bad than the Australian water , so-called water crisis , '' he say . 

Vic expert play part in mine rescue 
Three mine explosive expert from Victoria have play a role in the final stage of the Beaconsfield Gold mine rescue . 
The tunnel inching towards the two trap men hit very hard silt stone , which resist the hand drill and jack hammer . 
General manager of Stawell Gold Mines Mark Mitchell say the men test the explosive in other part of the mine before they have to be use in the Beaconsfield rescue shaft . 
`` We send the guy down to help with the PCS type explosive , which you would have hear people talk about , '' he say . 
`` We use that at Stawell Gold Mines for a number of task . It 's something we use in the normal course of our operation . We do n't consider it to be a particularly specialist thing , it 's just something we have some experience in . 

India tender for 3m tonne of wheat import 
Wheat exporter AWB will face tough competition in the late tender from India for 3 million tonne of wheat , which be announce overnight . 
The Indian market have emerge this year a a replacement for traditional market in the Middle East , which be buy cheap wheat from Europe and the Black Sea . 
Grains analyst Malcolm Bartholomaeus say that have leave Australia and the US struggle to find other customer for last year 's bumper crop . 
`` India be very important both for Australia and for the global wheat market this year , '' he say . 
`` Egypt , of course , be a major importer of wheat . Right at the moment they tend to be favour cheap wheat out of Europe and Russia , so that both Australia and the US be miss out on that particular market . 
`` In term of the Australian crop , and obviously lose a lot of market share in Iraq , India be equally important from that perspective as well . '' 
While AWB have confirm it will tender for the contract , detail on price and volume remain confidential . 
Meanwhile , it be unclear if some of AWB 's legal cost for the Cole inquiry will come out of the return for the national pool . 
The legal bill be likely to have blow out from the $ 16 million AWB shareholder be tell about at the annual general meeting in February . 
The chairman of AWB International , Ian Donges , say AWB Limited be pick up all account at the moment . 
But he say there be still discussion about whether some of those should be pass onto AWB International on behalf of the pool . 

Local council 'starved of fund ' 
With a quarter of all local council in New South Wales on the brink of financial collapse , farmer be call for change to Australia 's system of government . 
A symposium hold in Sydney have hear expert on governance discus how local council be struggle to cope with new responsibility and a lack of fund . 
Former president of the NSW Farmers Association , Mal Peters , say state government be ignore rural community and what be need be a system of government that be close to the people . 

Credit scheme change anger farmer 
Impending change to the energy grant credit scheme have not be welcome in rural Australia . 
Until now , claim the 18 cent a litre credit have be a simple process of post off a claim form and get the money back quickly . 
But from July 1 , the fuel rebate will be deliver through the GST reporting process . 
For farmer and other agricultural business who be not file a monthly Business Activity Statement , it will take much long to get the money back . 
Livestock transporter Jim Savage , from Tamworth in New South Wales , fear delayed payment will create problem with cash flow . 
`` See you , you get ta be up front to pay your fuel bill , otherwise there 'd be no fuel , '' he say . 

Bananas do big business for NSW farmer 
Banana grower on the north coast of New South Wales be continue to harvest some spectacular profit in the wake of cyclone Larry . 
Mullumbimby wholesaler Jan Trueman say carton of fruit that fetch about $ 10 to $ 12 before the devastation of the Queensland industry , be now worth between $ 60 and $ 80 . 
He say it be set to become even more lucrative a winter approach . 
`` Oh most definitely , for sure , '' he say . 
`` Our fruit be , y'know , be at a premium now and go into winter , I mean our fruit start to slow up anyway , so it 's only go to get dearer and dearer . 

World trade change pose problem for fruit grower 
Tasmanian apple grower be feel the pressure of change in Australian horticulture and be host a meeting later this month to address their future . 
Thomas Frankcomb from Fruit Growers Tasmania say the industry be at `` yet another cross road '' , with significant change in global production , market price and the threat of cheap import fruit . 
He hop the meeting will help grower make choice about their future and believe the issue be big than just one state or one sector . 

PETA take aim at Middle East 
Animal right group PETA say it will target Middle Eastern country for the first time , a part of it campaign to stop live export from Australia . 
The group say it will reveal alleged abuse in slaughterhouse in several Gulf country at a press conference next week in Dubai . 

Incitec Pivot to buy Southern Cross 
In a complex stock market deal , superphosphate fertiliser company Incitec Pivot have announce it plan to buy out Australia 's only producer of ammonium phosphate , Southern Cross . 
Trading in Incitec Pivot share have be halt for two day while share holder learn detail of the deal , which include Orica sell it 70 per cent share hold in Incitec . 
Incitec will recommend share holder buy back Orica share . 
Chairman of Incitec Pivot John Watson say the 35,000 farmer with share in the company should enjoy significant growth in profit . 
`` All this do be add to our manufacturing base a very important strategic asset , not only for our business but for the farmer of Australia a well , '' he say . 

Scientists successfully grow southern bluefin tuna cell culture 
In a world first , South Australian scientist have grow cell culture of the southern bluefin tuna . 
Flinders University and the CSIRO have grow the cell so they can experiment with antioxidant to extend the shelf life of tuna and test for virus . 
Dr Kathy Schuller from Flinders University say it be much cheap than use live tuna worth $ 50 a kilogram . 
`` We can test 24 different concentration and combination of antioxidant at a time , '' she say . 

Unwanted grape to be use in non-alcoholic sparkling wine 
A small group of grape grower in South Australia hope to use up their unwanted fruit by crack into the non-alcoholic sparkling wine market . 
The Virginia Horticulture Centre , north of Adelaide , have begin a pilot project to see if it be viable . 

Dingoes may be use to sniff out cane toad 
Enlisting dingo be the late suggestion to help keep Western Australia free of cane toad . 
Dog trainer Sarah Fyffe have apply for a licence to use dingo a sniffer dog at the border and in bushland between Western Australia and the Northern Territory . 
She say dingo be natural for the outdoor job , 
`` We 're not talk about work in a building , we 're not talk about work in an airport , we 're talk about work in rugged terrain , '' she say . 
`` [ It be ] very unforgiving - and where 's the dingo from ? That 's it natural habitat and they cope brilliantly with it and know how to handle the element . '' 

Budget good news for rural Australians 
There be a fair bit of good news for rural Australia out of Treasurer Peter Costello 's 11th Budget . 
There be more than $ 2 billion in extra funding for road and rail , money for the Murray River and a big crackdown on illegal fishing . 
There be also wide range tax cut , which be suppose to leave more money in our pocket and change to capital gain tax to make it easy for farmer to pass on their property . 
President of the National Farmers Federation Peter Corish be certainly happy . 
`` This Budget be probably the most positive budget that Treasurer Costello have deliver for rural Australia , '' he say . 
`` NFF have three major priority lead into this Budget , the first one be sustainability , the second one be infrastructure and the third one be taxation relief for rural Australia . 
`` And I can say that positively we 've have movement on all three area . '' 
More rural Australians will also be able to access the age pension . 
There will also be incentive for farm and mining business to invest in new plant and equipment with change to depreciation rate . 
There will also be around $ 50 million for extra mental health service in country area . 

Vaile start Budget sell 
The Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the Nationals , Mark Vaile , have be out this morning tell rural area the Budget set up the bush to take advantage of the current resource boom through big infrastructure spending . 
He be especially proud , a most National party member be , of the $ 2.4 billion in road fund he say the Nationals have help secure . 
`` If you be talk about regional Australia , my view be one of the most important targeted component in this budget be that $ 307 million of extra money direct at local government for local road and bridge this year , they 're the important thing to regional Australia , '' he say . 
When Australia 's peak rural lobby group the National Farmers Federation say this be the best Budget in 11 year , that should not leave too much room for the Opposition to be critical . 
But that have not stop Labor 's agriculture spokesman Gavan O'Connor describe the Budget a missed opportunity . 
His point be you can have all the new bitumen in world but if it be not too dear to drive on that bitumen because of high fuel price and high interest rate , well the big spending backfire . 
He be also talk up what he say be the Government 's failure to target it infrastructure spending , failure to address environmental issue and failure to ease skill shortage in regional area . 
`` No mention of the productivity challenge and no attempt to get on top of the foreign debt , '' he say . 
`` No attempt to address the massive skill crisis in rural Australia and there 's no movement on the last great frontier for Australian agriculture that be the regeneration of our soil . 
`` There be no attempt to engineer through these expenditure a new wave of research and innovation in the rural sector . 
`` On that basis I think there will be some significant question ask about this Budget . '' 

Punters 
What do the punter think of the Budget ? 
`` For me , I 'm in a retirement age so the amount that I can earn tax-free have go up , the threshold there , so I think the threshold for low-income earner have be very good , '' one person say . 
`` It 's quite encouraging about the water , that 's go to be the big problem and I think people in the town have get to realise that they 've get to pay more for their water and not be so greedy and they 've get to do something about storage , '' another say . 
`` I think the Budget lack vision because it should have look at the long term infrastructure issue and I just think that politician be drive by short term decision make all the time which we pay a big price for , '' a third person say . 

Economist warn about spending 
The tax cut be expect to ease pressure on rural household which have face high petrol price and grocery bill in recent month . 
The expert say while the cut will not put pressure on interest rate in the short term , there be no guarantee the Reserve Bank will not increase rate towards the end of the year . 
ANZ chief economist Saul Eslake say there be still reason to be cautious about spending . 
`` Even allow for the fact that people in rural area tend to drive long distance than those in the city , the tax cut be enough to offset the most recent roughly 10 cent a litre increase in petrol price and the rise in interest rate , '' he say . 
`` But any further rise in petrol price or indeed in interest rate would probably be sufficient to eliminate the benefit of the Budget tax cut altogether . '' 
Meanwhile Treasurer Peter Costello tell a medium conference yesterday the only way fuel price will come down be if the cost of crude oil fall . 
There be more than $ 11 million allocate for two new study on the use of biofuels but Greens Senator Christine Milne say Mr Costello be waste his time spending up big on road , when it be become too expensive to drive on them . 
`` He 's about the only person in Australia who do n't see increase oil price a a major issue , '' she say . 

Industry group concern about lack of initiative 
There be concern about a lack of initiative in the Budget to improve the national skill base and tackle the labor shortage in Australia . 
Although new measure have be announce to make it easy for overseas worker , the Australian Industry Group say the Budget should have make more progress in big nation building project . 
While happy with many of the initiative announce for business and the road funding , Heather Ridout say there be a long way to go to provide the necessary infrastructure to improve productivity and cope with future demand . 
`` I think that 's another area where there could have be more do , '' she say . 
`` They 're certainly bring forward some of the spending which be important , some increase in road funding but it need a more coherent plan . 
`` We still need good interaction between road and rail , I think we still need more of a national plan and that 's get to be really agree between the state be very big spender in this area . 

Little in budget to encourage exploration , say mining group 
The WA Chamber of Minerals and Energy say there be little in the Budget to encourage exploration in the resource sector . 
The industry want a flow-through share scheme to boost exploration but do not have any joy last night . 
Chamber director David Parker say more need to be do there as well . 
`` This be something which industry have be argue for a number of year , '' he say . 
`` We see exploration a very much the future of the resource industry . 
`` We be tend to rest on our laurel in term of the future sustainability of the industry . 
`` I think if you look at the medium to long term outlook for renew Australia 's resource inventory we really be at cross road . 

Budget fail to tackle climate change , green group say 
The Federal Government have come under fire from green group , which claim the Budget fail to tackle climate change . 
The major allocation in environmental spending be $ 500 million for the Murray Darling Basin Commission . 
That money will fund project like salt interception scheme , fishways , local and weir upgrade , and possibly buy water from farmer . 
South Australian River Murray Minister Karlene Maywald say the money have be desperately need . 
`` Projects be underfunded , the Murray Darling Basin Commission be underfunded , our project that we all agree to from a jurisdictional point of view be all start to slip and it look like we be never go to achieve what we need to do to save the River Murray , '' she say . 

Budget boost funding for illegal fishing fight 
The Federal Government have announce a big crack down on illegal fishing in Australia 's northern water . 
The $ 389 million package be design to double the number of boat apprehend each year through increase surveillance and patrol , along with improved boat-burning facility to destroy illegal fishing boat . 
Indigenous coastal ranger will also be employ a part of the plan but Gary Ward from the Gulf of Carpentaria Commercial Fishermen 's Association say the money be be use in the wrong way . 
`` Spending this money on Aboriginal community be very fine but you 're talk about a radius of probably 25 kilometre each side of the community , '' he say . 
`` Now these boat range widely over the Gulf of Carpentaria , we need more surveillance but we need more active now , the fishing fraternity in the Gulf of Carpentaria that 's work so hard for a sustainable and viable fishery have be leave out in the lurch . '' 

Plan unveil to secure veg industry future 
A new $ 3 million strategy to secure the future of the vegetable industry have be unveil in Brisbane this morning . 
VegVision 2020 be the product of month of talk between grower , the Federal Government , supermarket and food processor . 
It be a $ 3 million plan with a very simple message - how to lift the industry 's growth from an unsustainable 3 per cent by get more vegetable on consumer ' plate . 
Fair Dinkum Food Campaigner Richard Bovill be a member of the Australian Vegetable Industry Development Group and say grower must work with retailer and processor if they be to secure their future . 
`` There be adversarial issue out there , there will always be competitive pressure but we also have to understand our common goal and work together with those , '' he say . 
`` I think we can look to a range of different industry model and we should n't just look at vegetable and the horticultural sector . '' 

US Farm Bill debate begin 
The battle have start early in Washington over the next US Farm Bill , due to be draft next year . 
The White House and Congress do not see eye to eye on farm policy . 
While US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns and the White House be call for sweep change in US farm policy , lawmaker be defend the status quo . 
Top Democrat on the House Agriculture Committee Collin Peterson tell a farm bill field hearing in Texas , US agriculture should not be single out for cut . 
`` This budget talk irritate me a little bit because agriculture do not cause these budget problem . And I do not agree that we ought to be the one that have to pay the price because we 've actually save money , '' he say . 

Row erupts between Grains Council and Agriculture Minister 
A rift have emerge between Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran and Australia 's peak grain lobby . 
The Grains Council be outrage that the oil-for-food inquiry be be use a an excuse to backflip on plan to reduce a key levy for the Wheat Export Authority . 
The council want the industry levy reduce from 22 cent a tonne to 19 , leave the authority with a million dollar cash surplus . 
Spokesman David Ginns say the surplus will now be double and have accuse Mr McGauran of ignore grower . 
`` There have be a number of matter that we 've raise with him where he have n't take the advice of the key industry body and we be concern that our batting average be not particularly good at the moment and we seem to be get some excuse back at the moment , '' he say . 
But in an unprecedented attack on a peak commodity council , Mr McGauran have accuse the Grains Council of act dishonourably and not work in the best interest of grower . 
Mr McGauran say the council have also deliberately leak confidential ministerial document and spread misinformation . 
`` I believe this be an ill-considered and ill-timed intervention by the Grains Council which be more puzzling than anything else , '' he say . 

Saltbush shrubland plan anger grazier 
Graziers in western New South Wales be furious about a proposal to list old man saltbush shrubland a endanger . 
The New South Wales Scientific Committee have find saltbush shrubland have fall by 70 per cent since European settlement and the rest be at risk of extinction from clear and grazing . 
But Graham Morphett , who have a property north-west of Hay , say the plant be thrive in the western division due to good management and rabbit control . 
`` I 've get 170,000 acre out here and I have ten of thousand of acre of old man saltbush with up to 5,000 acre stand , '' he say . 

Calls to scrap WET tax 
The Western Australian wine industry want the Wine Equalisation Tax ( WET ) abolish despite a big Budget boost . 
The Federal Government have increase tax rebate to small wine producer by $ 210,000 . 
They be available to producer with up to $ 1.7 million in sale . 
But Ron Fraser from the Margaret River Wine Association say it be band-aid therapy , which be lull small producer into a false sense of security 
`` It 's avoid the issue that the WET tax be an impost on the cost of wine and should be scrap altogether , '' he say . 
`` The only way that you can get the benefit from this extra threshold be to increase your sale and in today 's market to increase your sale be an increasingly difficult job . 

Grape grower mull mothball vine 
Grape grower in South Australia 's Riverland be consider mothball their vine , hop to ride out the industry 's oversupply . 
Many local grower could not sell their fruit this year , with winery suspend or not renew contract . 
With no relief in sight , grower say they could prune heavily or use chemical to hinder fruit growth to hibernate vine instead of have to pull them out . 
Berri grape grower Bill Ruediger say he will have to make a decision very soon . 

ACCC to investigate Sunbeam price-setting 
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ( ACCC ) will investigate whether dried fruit processor Sunbeam Foods breach the Trade Practices Act in set low price this season . 
ACCC Commissioner John Martin hold talk with grower in Mildura in north-west Victoria this week after the Victorian Farmers Federation lodge complaint of unconscionable conduct by the industry 's major processor . 
Growers claim Sunbeam be take advantage of it virtual monopoly position in the industry , and have set price at a 20-year low . 

Rural property value tip to even out 
Rural property value have double and in some case triple in just four year , outperform most other capital investment . 
But they could be about to come off the boil . 
Wayne Carlson from the National Australia Bank say price be expect to even out in the next 12 to 24 month . 
`` We probably do n't really expect price to come down , '' he say . 
`` We expect more a plateau effect . 
`` These may be some discount in the low , standard and marginal type lends . And there 's no doubt the trend of this off-farm investment super fund , manage investment scheme et cetera will continue to tip money into this market . 

Plantation tax reform plan unveil 
The Federal Government have unveil propose change to tax incentive for investor in the plantation timber sector . 
The incentive , which currently provide 100 per cent tax deduction for manage investment scheme , have be under review for the past 12 month . 
Dr Judy Clark , from the Australian National University ( ANU ) , say the draft change which will affect investor interest . 
`` Putting a cap on the immediate volume of money that can be tax deduct and you also add on that reduction in top marginal tax rat from 47 to 45 per cent , both of these work to down play the attractiveness of these scheme for investor , '' she say . 
`` We do n't need to plant more softwood to meet Australia 's entire timber need . 

Marine park boundary 'botched ' 
The Marine Conservation Society ( MCS ) want change to the way boundary be establish for national marine park . 
It say the new park between Tasmania and the mainland be a botched job , which fail to protect marine biodiversity . 
The park 's boundary be redrawn after concern from the fishing sector . 
The MCS 's Craig Bohm say the revised boundary have miss biodiverisity hotspot , and the Federal Government must review the process . 

G-G head up Birdsville Track 
Governor-General Michael Jeffrey have embark on a journey up the Birdsville Track to attract attention to life in the outback . 
Accompanied by his valet , doctor , physio and other escort , the Governor-General will spend five day meet people from remote community a part of the Year of the Outback . 
Major-General Jeffrey hop the trip will inspire others . 
`` I hope to expose the character the lifestyle , some of the difficulty of course , '' he say . 

Leaping croc shock scientist 
An airborne four-metre crocodile have make scientist ' heart skip a beat during research on the Ord River in the far north of Western Australia . 
Scientists have be use an electrical current to temporarily stun fish , so a to study them . 
But they accidentally send a shock wave through a nearby crocodile . 
Scott Goodson from the Department of Environment say the jumping croc give everyone a start . 
`` He breach the water , he get a metre out of the water , that 's a big croc ! '' he say . 
`` He get a fairly good tickle up , I would have think ! '' 
Mr Goodson say the reptile be probably just a bit stunned after the accidental shock treatment . 
`` He 's probably take off and just kick back behind another rock , I do n't think he will come too close to that boat again , '' he say . 

AWB hop to salvage India wheat deal 
Wheat exporter AWB hop last minute talk can salvage a half million tonne wheat deal with India . 
Indian authority have raise new concern about quality issue , this time with wheat which have not even leave Australia . 
The first consignment of wheat under the deal be hold up last week while test for pesticide contamination be carry out . Those test clear the wheat for unload . 
National pool manager with AWB David Johnson say the company be try to limit the damage to grower , with the national pool bear any cost of delay . 
`` We be look to mitigate an exposure , cost to grower , by potentially divert some of those vessel to other market , '' he say .

Ms Johnston have tell the inquiry she inform Australian Government official in both Washington and New York about inland transport fee be pay by AWB to the Iraqi Government . 
Ms Johnston appear at the inquiry via video link from Washington . 
She tell senior counsel assist John Agius she mention the inland transportation payment in discussion with DFAT 's delegate at the Australian mission to the UN , Bronte Moules and with AusTrade Commissioner Alistair Nicholas . 
Ms Johnston say she raise the issue in January and March 2000 follow a complaint from the Canadians . 

Govt accuse of use Budget to shore up Nationals ' vote 
The Federal Government have attack Labor 's plan for a national high-speed broadband network , accuse it of allocate rural telecommunication money to the city . 
But Labor leader Kim Beazley have use his Budget reply speech to criticise the Government for base road spend on shore up National party vote . 
Mr Beazley say Labor would provide free Tafe for traditional trade , more childcare place across Australia and put a stop to import foreign apprentice . 
He also criticise the Government for fail to invest in climate change research , do more to tackle water shortage and lay down plan to provide all business and household with fast Internet . 
`` To you and me this mean a broadband system 25 time faster than the sort of speed available in Australia today , '' he say . 
But the Government say Labor plan to spend $ 2 billion earmark for rural telecommunication to fund broadband in the city . 
And National Farmers Federation president Peter Corish say money Labor want for it plan be already be spend . 

Heemskirk wind farm mothball 
The Federal Government 's decision not to increase renewable energy target be be blame for a decision to mothball Tasmania 's $ 300 million Heemskirk wind farm . 
Tasmanian energy company Roaring 40 say it remain committed to exist Australian project but will be wind back work on new development . 
Managing director Mark Kelleher say there be no incentive for electricity retailer to buy wind energy , make Heemskirk unviable . 

Controls on explosive chemical sale to be tighten 
The Queensland Government be further tighten control on the sale of explosive chemical after the arrest of a Brisbane man find to be in the possession of 53 kilogram of explosive . 
The Government will meet with farm and mining group in Brisbane today to discuss the implication of the new control . 
Police allege a Brisbane high school teacher illegally purchase the explosive Powergel from chemical company Orica under the pretense of use it for movie stunt . 
The 40-year-old be expect to be the first Queenslander charge with terrorism . 
The Queensland Government have announce seller of chemical , like ammonium nitrate use by farmer , will need to report fortnightly to the Government on who they sell explosive material to and even call the Department of Natural Resources to double-check the detail of new and exist customer . 

NQ wildlife to benefit from grape glut 
Grape grower be have trouble get rid of their fruit this year , but one solution have be to send it to north Queensland , to fee hungry wildlife . 
With habitat destroy by cyclone Larry , surplus grape from Lopresti Wines in South Australia be be feed to bird like the Southern Cassowary . 
Scott Sullivan from Queensland 's Parks and Wildlife Service , say they be happy to get them . 

Cape call for cyclone assistance 
Graziers , tourism operator and Indigenous community on Cape York be call for immediate financial help from the Federal Government in the wake of Cyclone Monica . 
The cyclone bring heavy rain and severe flooding to the cape , and grazier say there be widespread damage to roads , and huge stock loss . 
The Cape community want to know why they can not access the same assistance offer to victim of cyclone Larry . 
Cape grazier Darcy Burns say they be desperate . 
`` It look like Larry 's get everything , '' he say . 
`` We 're not hear one word on Monica , I think people have forget how much damage that 's do up there . 
`` We understand fully about Innisfail 's do and they need all the support they can get , we 're not knock that at all , but they 've also get to look at u as well , there 's people up there at the moment , we 've lose our income for the next 12 month because we ca n't get in there , and the season 's so short now . ''

The Government have confirm a surplus of $ 2 billion for this financial year , with the windfall to pay for the Perth to Mandurah railway . 
Trevor de Landgraft from the WA Farmers Federation say rural people have be ignore . 

Rural job hard to fill : survey 
A joint federal and Victorian government survey suggest one third of rural employer can not fill job vacancy . 
The survey of the Wimmera Grampians region be be roll out across the state , with the result to be compare with other state and territory . 
Penny Ireland , from the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations , say professional and trade position in health , finance and construction be the hard to fill . 
`` There be a lot of health relate professional occupation so general practitioner , registered nurse , occupational therapist , physiotherapist . There be also a number of trade position , in particular motor mechanic , which we see across the country and electrician , '' she say . 
Meanwhile , grey nomad be be use to temporarily fill some of the shortage in central Australia . 
Under the Outback Links program , retired traveller be help to fix the plumbing , or mind child on outback station , in exchange for a taste of remote living . 
Gold Coast retiree Bobbie Perkins be the first volunteer to be place , and say help with the housework on New Crown Station , south of Alice Springs , be actually a good way to learn about rural Australia .

Seafood lover to feel the pinch on crab price 
Commercial crab fisherman in the Northern Territory say they be pot just over half the number of crab they use to , because of new catch size rule . 
The minimum catch size of both female and male mud crab have increase by a centimetre , but angler say there be not many around at this time of year . 
Melbourne seafood wholesaler , Spencer Wilkinson say diner could be wrestle big crab on the dinner plate in the future , if they can afford them . 
`` It will just price itself out of the market and what happen be , when it get to exorbitant level , the Sydney market soak up basically all the crab , '' he say . 

Govt tight-lipped on Snowy Hydro sale 
The New South Wales Government have confirm an international offer for Snowy Hydro , but say it need to keep tight-lipped on the detail . 
State Finance Minister John Della Bosca say yesterday any discussion of detail before the release of the prospectus would incur the risk of litigation . 
But Lester Wheatly , chair of the Murray Valley Community Action group , say it be just an excuse to keep the public in the dark . 
`` The Government attitude be that `` look here , we 're involve in very sensitive international negotiation at the moment and ca n't tell you anything '' . At the end of the day , that 's just not good enough . 

Two in run for peak farm job 
Australia 's top job in agripolitics will be contest for the first time in four year , with Peter Corish set to step down a president of the National Farmers Federation . 
NFF trade representative Allan Burgess and former Meat and Livestock Australia chairman David Crombie have nominate for the key post . 
Mr Corish will not comment on speculation he will contest the seat of Gwydir in the next election , which will be vacate by former deputy prime minister John Anderson . 
He say water reform and more money for rural telecommunication have be major achievement during his presidency . 
`` The National Water Initiative I think be a key opportunity that we 've lock in while I 've be NFF president , '' he say . 
`` We 've make significant progress in the area of workplace reform , we have lock in significant funding for rural Australia in regard to telecommunication , and I 've enjoy my time immensely over the four year . '' 
Board election will be hold at the next NFF annual general meeting on June 14 and 15 . 
Meanwhile former executive director of the NFF , Rick Farley have die . 
Mr Farley be make a slow recovery after a stroke , but die from injury he receive after fall from a wheelchair outside Sydney 's Balmain Hospital at the weekend . 
In the mid-70s Rick Farley become the first executive director of the newly form Cattlemen 's Union ( CU ) in Queensland . 
With a background in the art , time spend in the hippy capital of Nimbin and a job with Labor health spokesperson Doug Everingham , Mr Farley be not an obvous choice to head up the organisation , most of whose member be staunch National Party supporter . 
But from his day in Rockhampton with the CU , the farmer ' rally in 1985 in Canberra , the foundation of the Landcare moverment in the late 80 and then the native title debate in the 90 Rick Farley be a smart political operator , In Canberra he cut a distinctive character in moleskin , boot and Akubra and a Cattlemen 's first preisident Sir Grahman McCamley say he be an extremely effective lobbyist on behalf of the farm sector . 

Vaile leave door ajar for Katter 
Leader of the National Party Mark Vaile say he would push for another ministry position if Queensland Independent Bob Katter rejoin the party . 
There be speculation Mr Katter will seek membership of the Nationals , after contest the last election in his seat of Kennedy a an Independent . 
The Nationals lose a ministry position earlier this year when Senator Julian McGauran cross to the Liberal Party . 
Mr Vaile have tell the Nine Network he be keep an open mind about Mr Katter . 
`` Politics be about number and if someone want to commit to the ideal and the philosophy of our particular party or our government then they 're most welcome , so I 'd keep an open mind on that particular matter , '' he say . 

Opponents speak out against Qld dam proposal 
More than 3,000 people attend a weekend protest rally in the Queensland city of Gympie , to fight the propose Mary River Dam . 
The State Government be plan a 660,000 megalitre dam at Traveston Crossing , south of the city , to supply the water need of Brisbane and the Sunshine Coast . 
The Government make it first property acquisition late last week , only day after announce a $ 50 million package to begin the buyback process . 
Local mayor , a federal member of parliament , conservationist and landholder address the public meeting . 
Farmer Ian Allen say a fighting fund have also be establish . 
`` My farm be affect a much anyone else 's , '' he say . 
`` I 've spend a long time get where I want to get , I just felt like I 'm there , and this announcement of a dam have put me back where I start 20-30 year ago . 

Lamb production spring to new high 
Australian lamb production hit a new record during the first three month of 2006 , despite challenge seasonal condition . 
Meat and Livestock Australia say the average jump of 8 per cent come a a surprise , with the big gain in Victoria and WA , where there be a continue shift away from grow wool . 
Despite the grow stock number , export be up and price remain just 10 per cent under the all-time high . 
Grazier Peter Small from Victoria 's western district , say it break his heart to turn away from wool , but there be a lot more money to be make out of lamb . 
`` Well it be what we have do but we be reluctant to do it , '' he say . 

Farmers log on to livestock sale 
Rising fuel cost and more user-friendly technology be say to be drive a jump in the number of farmer sell livestock over the Internet . 
Elders sell around 3 per cent of Australia 's sheep , lamb and cattle in online auction . 
Jack Gleeson from Elders say it be save farmer the cost of truck livestock to saleyards . 
`` Normally there would be freight involve from the point of origin , the vendor 's property to the saleyard , '' he say . 

Big drop in US wheat production tip 
The US Agriculture Department be tip an 11 per cent drop in wheat production there over the next 12 month . 
The late forecast be for a total harvest in 2006-07 of $ 1.8 billion bushel . 
USDA World Agriculture Outlook Board Chairman Gerald Bange blame chronic drought and tough competition from Australia and Canada for low export . 
`` We 're look at export , begin June 1 at about 900 million bushel , which would be about 100 million bushel low than we will export in the 2005/06 year , which be currently estimate at an even 1 billion bushel , '' he say . 
Mr Bange say part of the reason be a strong US price forecast in '06/'07 due to lower production and tighter end stock . 
Wheat price look set to improve on the back of the USDA report , which have also reveal a substantial increase in corn export . 
There be also high domestic demand in the US for corn to make ethanol . 
Natham Omodei from commodity trader Plum Grove , say that should make wheat more attractive a feed for livestock and drive up price . 
`` They increase use for ethanol production , which really cut their stock forecast for 2006-2007 , '' he say . 

NSW Govt announce department restructure 
The New South Wales Government have announce a major restructure of the Department of Natural Resources in a bid to save $ 16 million a year . 
Fifty employee be be move from Sydney to Orange , and voluntary redundancy be be offer for non-frontline staff . 
Farmers be also worry about a decision to scrap regional director position . 
But Jeff Angel from the Total Environment Centre say the change will speed up reform . 
`` You 're not go to get the unbelievable and untrustworthy level of inconsistent decision-making that we have under the previous system , '' he say . 
`` You can go way too far in have autonomous region . 

Fly slow weed threat in Timor 
A natural predator be slow the spread of the world 's bad weed across our northern neighbour . 
The stem gall fly have be introduce across East and West Timor , to control siam weed . 
Researcher Rob Williams say the Australian-funded project also reduce the chance of the weed gain a foothold in the Northern Territory . 
`` Siam weed can be see in 90 per cent of the countryside in East Timor , and it cover the grassland , '' he say . 
The ( stem ) gall fly be re-producing here . They release 200 gall fly here last year . The gall fly survive through the dry season and be grow here now . 

Tassie farmer recognise by vege industry 
A Tasmanian potato farmer have be name the Young Vegetable Grower of the Year , for his leadership during the Fair Dinkum Food campaign . 
Matthew Ryan from northern Tasmania be honour at the national conference of AusVeg in Brisbane at the weekend . 
He say the campaign raise the profile of the vegetable industry , but there be still more to be do . 

Royal Flying Doctor Service turn 78 
The Royal Flying Doctor Service ( RFDS ) be celebrate it 78th birthday today . 
Reverend John Flynn establish the Flying Doctors at Cloncurry in north-west Queensland back in 1928 . 
Senior flight nurse at the Mount Isa base , Mary Noon , say the RFDS have come a long way since then , but still play an essential role in remote area . 
`` One day you can be deliver a baby , and the next day you 're help somebody with chest pain , so it 's a huge variation , '' she say . 
`` You get to meet such a variety of people , you get to see new place , different place every day a oppose to the ward . 

Mining loss a correction , say analyst 
The mining sector have have a rough couple of day , with metal price fall sharply on the commodity market overnight . 
Copper be the big loser , at one stage fall 9 per cent , with gold down 4 per cent , and silver 5 per cent . 
But analyst say it be not a global market meltdown , merely a long overdue correction on the mineral boom . 
Malcolm Condie , from AWB Landmark , say the mining sector have take the big battering , and agricultural commodity should escape relatively unscathed . 
He say the fundamental for wool price be unchanged , the poor US crop have strengthen wheat price and demand from Asia and India for other agricultural commodity will continue to strengthen . 
`` I do n't see any further risk or downside risk for wool at this stage , '' he say . 
`` We might see the market just tread water for a little while now . 
`` Obviously grain , wheat be on a bit of an upward spiral and I mean generally there be no correlation between those and the other mineral commodity that we export . But obviously as far a food stuff go people have to eat and I think we be go to see a lot more go into Asia . '' 
Rising inflation fear in the US have largely contribute to the weak commodity price . 
The All Ordinaries Index have fall 93 point at the close of trade yesterday , with bulk-commodity company like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto the hard hit . 
Chris Monroe of Hartleys say it be the correction the market , `` have to have . '' 
`` Another cliche , the market be , `` price to perfection '' I think , '' he say . 

NFF contender seek to build trust between city and bush 
The man widely tip to be the next head of the National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say his main priority will be rebuild trust between urban and country area . 
The former chairman of Meat and Livestock Australia David Crombie , have be ask to run for the NFF presidency by two state farming group . 
He say farmer need the support of city people to defeat extreme animal right group , which he say be a key issue for Australian agriculture . 
Mr Crombie , who live in Brisbane , say he be not a typical farmer , but do not think that stop him be an effective leader of Australia 's most powerful rural lobby group . 
`` No , I 'm certainly not an average farmer because I currently live in Brisbane , but certainly my interest be in agriculture and all of my professional life I 've be involve in agriculture . I believe I have something to offer . I believe I can make a difference , '' he say . 

NSW farmer chief quits 
The chief executive of the New South Wales Farmers Association have resign , effective immediately . 
Dr Ray Johnson have complete only two year of his three year contract , but the association will not say whether he will be pay out . 
President Jock Laurie reject suggestion the former chief executive be push by a divide board . 

Cool reaction to Qld water plan 
The Queensland Government be look to buy two large cotton property in the state 's south-west to return water to the Murray-Darling Basin . 
The buy-up be expect to cost up to $ 60 million and deliver 58,000 megalitres of water a year over the New South Wales border . 
The Federal Government reject a similar proposal four year ago to purchase the huge Cubbie Station . 
Grazier Pot Peterson be among New South Wales landholder who have be critical of the amount of water Queensland irrigators take out of the Condamine-Balonne river system , and say this plan will not be very beneficial . 
`` I 'm not say that they should n't purchase it , but I just think it would be far more beneficial if they purchase something upstream that would have a big affect on u , because really the water virtually stop at Cubbie , '' he say . 
`` As we saw in the 2004 flood they do have a big flood at St George but we do n't get any of it here . '' 
The plan will be out to the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council meeting in Melbourne on Friday . 
Meanwhile the Cubbie Group , which run Cubbie Station , have slam call by the New South Wales Government for it water allocation to be reduce . 
The station can store 500,000 megalitres of water for it cotton-growing operation , and grazier south of the border complain they be be starve of crucial flood water flow . 
But joint manage director John Grabbe say New South Wales should fix up evaporation loss in the Menindee Lakes in the state 's west , before attack Queensland 's science-based water allocation . 
`` Oh get your own house in order , but let 's be fair dinkum , not just throw stone at each other , but let 's be fair dinkum , '' he say . 
`` I mean , water be too valuable a resource to be go up into the air in shallow storage system . Now we do n't do it at Cubbie , and I implore the southern state to seriously look at their storage system . 
Federal Agricultural Minister Peter McGauran say the CSIRO be scare-mongering , with a report call for big environmental flow for the Murray River . 
An extra 500 gigalitres have already be commit to the Murray , but the scientific body say up to five time more will be need to restore the river 's health . 
Despite criticise that find , Mr McGauran acknowledge progress have be slow on the Living Murray Initiative , and say the report will be consider . 

Eldest child not always the best farm manager : research 
New research have show the tradition of pass the farm onto the eldest child could be cost the sector it best talent . 
Psychologist and social researcher , Dr Ian Ploughman , say by nature , old child be more conservative . 
He say young sibling tend to be the most innovative and creative , but do not have the opportunity to contribute . 
`` The young brother and sister commonly have less interest in stay on the farm , and be more creative and more mobile , '' he say . 

Debt an obstacle to wool merger 
The wool industry remain committed to a merger between it promotion and research arm , despite a dispute over a $ 27 million debt . 
Australian Wool Services , which own the Woolmark brand , be seek financial help from the Federal Government to pay the debt , without success . 
The owe money relate to a pension fund for former UK-based employee . 
Chairman of Australian Wool Innovation Ian McLachlan say he understand the Government 's position , but there will not be a merger between the two company until the bill be pay . 
`` I 've be in government and I think when a government have a position , it have to repeat that position , and it will hold that position until somebody come up with a really bright idea a to how we can solve it , '' he say . 

AWB search for new market for stranded wheat 
Wheat exporter AWB say it be try to find another market for a shipment of wheat strand at Geraldton in Western Australia , due to a quarantine dispute with India . 
The ship have be dock for a month , while talk have be under way to resolve the problem . 
The ship be expect to be load today . 
Paul Ryan , AWB 's industry relation manager in WA , say two other vessel have be unload successfully in India , but he can not say why this vessel have be in port for so long . 
`` It be more to do with a range of quarantine restriction , in term of bring wheat into India , '' he say . 

WA exercise to test response to foot and mouth outbreak 
An operation dub `` Exercise Wild West '' start today in Western Australia to test the ability of authority to fight a foot and mouth disease outbreak . 
The simulated exercise will run until Friday , and involve 180 people from the Department of Agriculture and Food and other agency . 
Director of Animal Biosecurity Ashley Mercy say an outbreak in Australia similar to the 2001 United Kingdom outbreak would cost the Australian economy about $ 15 billion . 

Northern grower put price cap on banana 
It be pretty rare for producer to knock back money , but with soar price a small group of north Queensland banana grower have decide to put a price cap on their fruit . 
Pacific Coast Eco Bananas , which win an award last night for farm in an environmentally sustainable manner , say sustainability need to apply to all sector of the business . 
In the wake of cyclone Larry some banana have sell for more than $ 100 a carton , but the company 's Dianne Sciacca say that level can not be sustain , with the price cap set at $ 70 . 
`` I think if you 're serious about sustainability , you have to live within a sustainable business environment as well and we ask a premium price for our product of which that be support by the supermarket and our customer in the market place , '' she say . 

Scientists consider climate change challenge 
Scientists be meet in Sydney today to tackle climate change . 
The scientist from CSIRO , the Bureau of Meteorology and the Greenhouse Office be debate strategy they say need to be implement to adapt to the change climate . 
Principal scientist with the CSIRO , Kevin Hennessy say it be likely farmer will be force to make big change . 
`` We would need to look at improve water use efficiency , water recycling , so reduce the amount of evaporation from some of our irrigation channel , and smart way of farming , for example direct drilling of seed , retain the stubble to reduce both erosion and water usage , and I guess some challenge for the type of crop that we use , '' he say . 

Land use bid concern fish industry 
Members of the aquaculture and fishing industry on South Australia 's Eyre Peninsula say they be worried about the possible impact of Aboriginal claim over the region 's coastal water . 
Negotiations have begin for Indigenous Land Use Agreements ( ILUA ) , cover coastal land and water from Cowell to Venus Bay . 
Michael Whillas from the Seafood Council of South Australia say because the process be new , there be uncertainty about the future legal status of aquaculture lease and fishing right . 
`` The problem that we face be that under the Native Title Act , a native title claim be extinguish when there be an exist licence or lease , '' he say . 
`` Under the ILUA , that do n't necessarily happen . At this stage , there be some grey area . 

Group oppose give national park back to traditional owner 
A campaign to prevent 17 national park be return to their traditional owner have step up in the Northern Territory . 
The Territory Government intend to hand over the land title to traditional Indigenous owner , and then lease it back for 99 year under a joint management plan . 
With plan to circulate petition , Save Our Parks campaigner Francoises Builder say there be plenty of opposition to any single group own park . 
`` Parks be free , they be for everybody , so why hand it to a group of people and then lease it back with taxpayer ' money for a million dollar a year ? '' 
`` And it be true when you be give away for example Bondi Beach it 's exactly the same thing , we have nothing else to go to . '' 

Infrastructure cost hold up Ord irrigation scheme 
Infrastructure cost be the late hurdle for expansion plan in the nation 's big irrigation scheme , in Western Australia 's far north . 
Native title settlement last October raise hope of a quick go-ahead for Ord Stage 2 but six month on there be still no movement . 
The scheme would more than double the exist irrigation area in WA , with more than 30,000 hectare earmark for development . 
WA 's Minister for Agriculture and Food Kim Chance say a decision be imminent , but it be a matter of decide how much should be pay for road , power and irrigation work . 

WA to reap reward after Brazil iron deal 
Western Australia 's economy look set for further growth , with Brazil , the world 's large iron ore producer , negotiate a better-than-expected price hike . 
The market have tip a rise in the iron ore price of between 10 and 15 per cent , instead , it will go up 19 per cent . 
The deal between Brazil 's CVRD and German steel-maker ThyssenKrupp set the scene for increase iron price for WA miner . 
ANZ Bank commodity analyst Andrew Harrington say it also mean more royalty for government coffer . 
`` The high the price the high the volume , will inevitably lead to high tax revenue for the Government , '' he say . 
`` Earlier in the year ABARE be forecast that iron ore would become the high exporter earner for the country . 

Tasmania set for rail upgrade 
Toll 's successful takeover of transport company Patrick have pave the way for a multi-million dollar rail upgrade in Tasmania . 
Pacific National , which be jointly own by the two company , threaten to stop cart container freight by rail last year , unless state and federal government help to improve infrastructure . 
After month of stalled negotiation , Pacific National have now agree to invest $ 38 million in new roll stock , while the government will provide $ 118 million for infrastructure . 
Tasmanian Minister for Infrastructure Jim Cox hop industry will also support a good rail service . 

Draft dairy report recommend support for GM crop 
The dairy industry have be embarrass by the leaking of a draft report that recommend it join other agricultural industry in support genetically modify ( GM ) crop . 
Until now state government have have the backing of the dairy industry in ban commercial GM crop . 
The draft report be commission by the Australian Dairy Industry Council ( ADIC ) and be not due to be release until much later this year . 
Policy director with Australian Dairy Farmers , Robert Poole , say the current policy be write seven year ago , and be due for review . 
`` Had we not have it happen where it 's now become public we would have certainly go to the point where we would have consult widely especially with dairy farmer and with dairy company , although they 're part of the ADIC process and obviously ultimately government a well , '' he say . 
Mr Poole say it be a draft report and not industry policy . 
Meanwhile a leading plant breeder say the dairy industry would save million of dollar , if it embrace GM crop . 
Viruses in pasture such a white clover cost the industry $ 110 million a year , but a virus-resistant clover could be on-farm by 2009 . 
Research director Professor German Spangenberg say that be just one reason for introduce genetically modify technology . 

Bush see no need for US inquiry into AWB 
President George W Bush do not appear to think there will be need for a US inquiry into AWB , despite pressure from domestic farm group and some senator . 
The President have express confident in the Australian Government 's ability to investigate the kickback scandal , during a visit to Washington by Prime Minister John Howard . 
Mr Bush praise Howard for his free trade effort , and dodge question about the AWB , say Australia be conduct it own investigation into the UN oil-for-food scandal , and Mr Bush look forward to see the result . 
At the US Capitol , Mr Howard tell Senate leader he understand the difficulty surround the Australia-US free trade agreement . 
`` I know that thing of that kind always create some difficult domestic judgment and consideration ... and , I 'm very grateful that it receive such strong support , '' he say . 

Court rule against AWB over 'apology ' document 
A Federal Court judge have rule against wheat exporter AWB , in it fight to keep a so-called apology document confidential . 
The document be prepare on the advice of US-based public relation consultant , and be mistakenly include in evidence AWB tender to the Cole inquiry . 
Justice Neil Young take just 10 minute to rule , AWB have no claim for legal professional privilege , and reject the company 's effort to keep the document confidential . 
Justice Young also find Commissioner Cole have every right to rule on the legal status of the document , a point dispute by AWB . 

Burgess make case to lead NFF 
No surprise and no big policy change be how prospective National Farmers ' Federation ( NFF ) bos Allan Burgess , say he will lead the organisation if elect president . 
Mr Burgess , NFF 's trade representative , will contest next month 's leadership ballot against former Meat and Livestock Australia bos David Crombie . 
The Victorian say make sure farmer get a fair price for their produce and maintain a good relationship with urban Australia be key issue . 
He say bring Western Australia and South Australia back into the NFF fold be also high on his list of priority . 
`` At the very high priority for Allan Burgess in any organisation he 's ever be a part of have be about get a collective view , '' he say . 
`` In my experience farm organisation only work well when you can come to one consensus . 

Inquiry release AWB apology 
The head of the Oil for Food Inquiry , Commissioner Terence Cole have just release the apology document , prepare between AWB , company lawyer and US public relation consultant Dr Peter Sandman . 
The document , draft by former MD Andrew Lindberg , state that AWB accept in pay money for inland transportation and after sale service , it pay money to the Iraq government in contravention of the UN sanction . 
The document also state that although there be warn sign , AWB do not challenge the payment and for this they be truly sorry , and deeply regret any damage this may have cause to Australia 's trading reputation , the Australian Government or the United Nations . 
The statement admit they fail to consider the implication of UN sanction , and should have have their own internal system of check and balance to stop any abuse of the oil for food program . 
It conclude there be no excuse for what happen , that the company simply should have do good , and that Mr Lindberg be deeply sorry that it do not . 
AWB have decide not to release the document , but it be mistakenly tender to the Cole Inquiry , along with other AWB evidence . 

Live trade to Egypt may re-start soon 
The Federal Government have confirm it be work on a plan which could see the livestock export trade to Egypt reopen in a matter of week . 
The trade to Egypt be ban in February when the 60 Minutes program air footage show animal be treat outside industry standard . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say his investigation prove the cattle be not Australian , but he shut the trade because the humane handling of Australian animal could not be guarantee . 
The Minister now say industry be form a plan which will animal treat well . 
`` There may well be some Australian stockman or vet or locally employ and trusted staff , '' he say . 
But RSPCA National President Hugh Wirth say more than increase supervision be need . 
`` You can do all the supervise you like , it 's not go to change the fact that the abattoir worker have a great deal of difficulty deal with Australian cattle . '' 
Around 12,000 head of cattle be export to Egypt last year worth around $ 10 million . 
The cattle industry say the finding of a new report add weight to the argument to resume the live cattle trade with Egypt , with appropriate monitoring . 
Cameron Hall from Livecorp say the report have find Australia have the high animal welfare standard in the world . 
`` There need to be appropriate system and appropriate monitoring to ensure some of the reason that the trade be halt and suspend in the first place , can not continue and particularly we can guarantee level of assurance that the animal that we market into those country be process and handle with a level of care that we would expect , '' he say . 
The report be commission by Livecorp and Meat and Livestock Australia . 
The first shipment of live cattle out of the far north Queensland city of Townsville in three year be due to leave at the weekend . 

Boom time for feedlot 
Strong export demand and the ongoing drought have push the feedlot sector to record height . 
Australia now have just under 900,000 head of cattle on feed , with Queensland and Western Australia record the big jump . 
But Malcolm Foster from the Lotfeeders Association have sound a note of caution . 
He say the United States could be back supply beef into Japan and Korea as early a next month , which will provide stiff competition for our grain-fed product . 
`` It be very good news , but this situation 's be go on now for two year , '' he say . 

Report recommend GM grass for dairy cow 
The South Australian Dairyfarmers Association say it will support the introduction of genetically modify ( GM ) pasture grass if consumer accept them . 
A leaked draft report for the Australian Dairy Industry Council recommend introduce GM grass for dairy cow , after research point to massive productivity gain from the new technology . 
SA association president , David Basham , say the industry need to do more investigation . 
`` We need to keep that research go , we need to make sure that if consumer be ready to move on , we be there ready to adopt , '' he say . 
`` If the market be not willing to accept GM product then we a an industry ca n't accept it and that may be the way it go . '' 
And there be deeply divided view on GM pasture in Victoria . 

Concerns over inferior wool in bale 
Concerns have be raise about the grow number of wool bale that have inferior quality wool deliberately hide in them . 
The Australian Wool Exchange ( AWEX ) say buyer be lose confidence in the quality of Australian wool because of falsely present bale and a rise in contaminated and unprepared fleece . 
AWEX woolclasser registrar Greg Sawyer say the market slump have see grower try to cut corner , but it be turn buyer off altogether . 
`` We know of mill around the world that have notify AWEX of wool that for argument sake may have 10-bale line of fleece wool , eight bale be well prepared and the last two bale may be top up with inferior wool which have n't be , '' he say . 

NLIS frustration in Tas 
Tasmanian cattle producer be frustrate by the state 's roll-out of the National Livestock Identification System . 
They be still require to use tailtags , as well a the new electronic ear tag , even though the rest of Australia will be tail-tag free from July 1 . 
Tasmanian NLIS coordinator John Cameron say they need to be able to guarantee trace-back to the last property of origin before tail tag can be remove . 
`` At the moment there be still a lot of cattle with NLIS tag in their ear that be not register to the correct property on the database , '' he say . 
`` So if they 're send to a saleyard or abattoir the database do n't have the correct information about where they be . 

Govt ass drought in NSW 
The ongoing impact of the drought be be assess first hand in New South Wales by Federal Government assessor . 
The National Rural Advisory Council have embark on an extensive tour of area come to the end of exceptional circumstance drought relief . 
Sheep specialist Doug Alcock have help the council to understand the severity of the drought from Canberra south to the Alpine region . 
`` Water be the big issue in term of the effort and money that 's be put into infrastructure in term of tank and new bore and reticulation system , '' he say . 
`` People run polypipe anything up to a couple of kilometre just to get water into paddock , it 's very expensive and heartbreaking in country that nobody have any living memory of ever go dry some of the spring . '' 
Coastal farmer in the region be also be hit hard by drought . 

Sick sheep seek out healthy food : research 
Scientists have know for a long time that sheep seek out food to gather the nutrient they need , but new research suggest they can choose food to cure illness . 
CSIRO Livestock Industries in Western Australia believe sick sheep will search for plant that make them good . 
It be conduct a trial in WA 's wheatbelt to work out which plant be eat by sheep to improve their health and production level . 
Senior research scientist Dr Dean Revell say down the track , farmer might even be able to incorporate `` medicinal paddock '' into their farm management . 
`` Maybe they have to have a continual exposure to these , so they have to be incorporate into the grazing base , the feed base , '' he say . 
`` The former option be more attractive , where we can set up and manage a separate paddock and take them there when need . 

WA impose ban to stop virus 
Western Australia have ban any plant material from the east which could host the yellow leaf curl virus . 
The virus be find in tomato crop near Brisbane and Bundaberg last month . 

Fiji look to dairying 
Fiji be hop for a boom in it dairy industry , a it dominant sugar industry face a downturn . 
A delegation have be tour dairy farm in Victoria this week to investigate alternative way of farming . 
Until recently the European Union have give preferential market treatment to Fijian sugar , but with an EU restructure , it be become hard for sugar grower to stay in business . 
Economist with the Fijian Ministry of Agriculture Waisiici Gonemaituba think favourable rainfall condition will be an advantage for dairy farmer . 
`` We get rain nearly every two day which be good for pasture production and the dairy industry a a whole , '' he say .

The Australian Landcare Council plan to pay tribute to co-founder Rick Farley by an annual award in his honour .

He die on Saturday . 
Landcare chairman Bobbie Brazil say the award will honour Mr Farley 's work and vision . 

Wimmera farmer say AWB should have release apology letter sooner 
Wheat grower say AWB could have take the heat of the accusation it have pay kickback to the former Iraqi Government , by publish a letter of apology before the Oil for Food Inquiry . 
The Inquiry yesterday release a document prepare by former AWB manage director Andrew Lindberg in December , which say the company be truly sorry it do not challenge the payment , despite warn sign , and it should have do well . 
Farmers in Victoria 's Wimmera region say by try to block the letter 's release through the Federal Court , AWB have only raise further question about what it be try to hide . 
`` I would have believe that if it have have be presenter prior to the Cole Inquiry it may have defuse quite a lot of the heat and argument within the Cole Inquiry itself , '' one farmer say . 
`` In hindsight AWB should have publish a very similar letter , if not the same letter early on in the piece and the witch-hunt might not have go on to the extent that it have , '' another farmer say . 
A rural public relation consultant agree that the apology document should have be release earlier . 
Mark Paterson from Currie Communications say it would have make a big difference to AWB 's reputation . 
`` Looking at the draft statement of contrition , it 's an excellent letter of apology , '' he say . 
`` Yes it admit guilt , but what it show be that AWB be human , and at no point at any time during this whole process have they demonstrate any humility at all . '' 
Meanwhile , eight wheat exporter , include Cargill , Glencorp and AWB have bid for the late tender to supply 3 million tonne of wheat to India . 
AWB have confirm it will make an offer to supply 1.2 million tonne of the contract , while the other company be believe to have offer for small amount . 

States debate Murray River funding allocation 
There have finally be some progress in effort to establish a national water trading system . 
The eastern state appear to be try to settle their difference over the future of water at a meeting of the Murray Darling Ministerial Council in Melbourne . 
The council be also debate how to carve up an extra $ 500 million in federal funding to improve the environmental health of the Murray River . 
While there be yet to be a national agreement on how water may be buy back by government into the Murray system , the state be make some progress of their own . 
Victoria and NSW have reach an in-principle deal to trade water which may be up and run by the end of the year . 
While the detail of exit fee and other cost be yet to be work out , both state have agree the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission should review any deal to make sure it be fair for all side . 
Victoria and South Australia have already an agreement on water trading prior to today 's meeting . 
Doug Miell from the New South Wales Irrigators Council , say the state have manage to convince Victoria and South Australia of the merit of a system of tagged trading . 
`` We 've get the water that Victoria and South Australia have really get their eye on , so it 's simply a case of he who have the gold make the rule , '' he say . 

Irrigator group oppose Snowy Hydro sale 
Key irrigator group in southern New South Wales have withdraw their support for the sale of the Snowy Hydro electric scheme . 
They be worried about a planned 10 per cent cap on individual shareholding after the company be sell by the federal , New South Wales and Victorian government . 
George Warne from Murray Irrigation say the propose safeguard be not enough to protect the business from an international takeover . 
`` I think one of the really big issue be the fact that Australia 's large single stored water resource - the Snowy Hydro scheme and it operation and the timing of release and the power that be generate from - it be go to leave government ownership and go into private hand , '' he say . 
`` We think they would dissipate that effect by have a maximum cap of 5 per cent or 10 per cent that any one party could own . 

Australia to lead climate change deal negotiation 
Australia will lead negotiation on a new international climate change deal to replace the Kyoto protocol which be due to expire in 2012 . 
The framework , to be co-developed with Germany and South Africa , will apply to almost 200 country . 
Mick Keogh from the Australian Farm Institute say farmer have lead the way in reduce greenhouse emission and should not be far penalise . 
He say federal and state government can not take credit for work largely undertaken by farmer . 
`` There be only one sector of the Australian economy that 's make a very significant contribution to the reduction in the growth of Australia 's greenhouse emission and that be the farm sector , '' he say . 

Seven-day forecast now available to regional area 
Farmers across Australia can now access seven-day forecast from the weather bureau , as well a the traditional four-day advice . 
Week-long forecast have be available to city dweller for some time , but they have now be roll out on a trial basis at 600 weather site around Australia , include regional area . 
Anne Farrell from the Bureau of Meteorology in Brisbane say the forecast have some shortcoming , but will be accurate for a range of factor . 
`` Temperature-wise I think the performance be generally pretty good , '' she say . 
`` Rainfall-wise there 's still a lot of work to be do to try and get high reliability in that a we go further ahead in that seven-day outlook . 
`` But it 's at the point that we think that there 's sufficient skill in that , that it worth put it out there for the public to make use of . '' 
The seven-day forecast will be available free of charge through a website call Australian 

Rio Tinto set new iron ore price benchmark 
Mining giant Rio Tinto have confirm it will receive 19 per cent more this year for iron ore ship from WA , make it the benchmark price for other deal . 
The deal between Japanese steel mill and Rio Tinto closely follow a similar deal between Germany and Brazil . 

Research centre ' economic benefit to be evaluate 
Australia 's Cooperative Research Centres ( CRCs ) be under review again . 
The CRCs be partnership between government , industry and scientific institute , undertake research and development . 
To ensure future funding , the economic benefit of individual program and centre will now be evaluate but Tony Staley from the CRC Association say it be hard to estimate the value of agricultural research . 
`` And happily the government be prepared to fund the next part of this work to endeavour to get a real handle , as much a you can , on those case where you 've get thousand of farmer , thousand of small business implement practice , that have be ... recommend and adopt by many many thousand of people and it 's very very hard to measure , '' he say . 
Meanwhile there be call to establish a co-operative research centre for small farm . 
North west Victorian horticulturalist Jim Belbin say property of between 10 and 30 acre be struggle to compete against much large farm . 
He believe an organisation should examine which crop could be sustainably farm on small holding of land . 
`` I be certain that there be crop that require intensive farming that be suitable to small holding , '' he say .

Tasmanian crop farmer have be deal another blow , a cut in pyrethrum price .

`` While it may be tempt to hold wheat back against this rise market and achieve high price later in the year , the practise in Australia have really be to clear each crop before the next one come in basically at whatever price , '' he say . 
`` The storage and handle company and grower get pretty cranky if we go into the next harvest with stock still be hold in the system and I guess if AWB think that to get rid of the wheat they need to push it out at low price , then that 's what they 're do . ''

Australia 's status a a country free from mad cow disease have officially be confirm by the world 's lead animal health agency .
