Locals in the northern Victorian town of Strathmerton say they be shock at a decision by Kraft Foods to move cream cheese production out of the state . 
A total of 150 employee will be affect by the restructure over the next two year , with the production be move to Suttontown , near Mount Gambier , in south-east South Australia . 
Former Strathmerton resident and the head of Moira Shire , Gavin Cator , say the news be devastate . 
`` The impact on the town , it 's go to obviously have a huge impact in confidence , '' he say . 
`` We believe the dairy industry very have a good future , we have strong dairy industry in the Goulburn Murray valley , and it 's disappointing that manufacture component of it and the value add we seek locally ca n't be provide . '' 

Compost access hit mushroom grower 
Half of Queensland 's mushroom grower say they be face closure because they can not access locally-produced compost . 
The state 's large supplier , Darling Downs Mushrooms , will shut it plant near Toowoomba next month . 
It be own by multinational company Chiquita , and provide more than 20 of Queensland 's grower with compost , a vital ingredient for mushroom production . 
Withcott producer Bruce White be accuse Chiquita of try to squeeze small grower out of the market .

Contruction of the world 's first bluefin tuna hatchery have begin on South Australia 's Eyre Peninsula .

Shake-up for wool industry 
The wool industry be set for a major shakeup , with the Australian Wool Exchange ( AWEX ) to abandon it auction room in Sydney and Melbourne and slash the size of it board . 
AWEX will end it auction room lease at Yennora in Sydney and Brooklyn in Melbourne by the end of the year , hand the ball to wool broker , who already run sale room in Newcastle and Fremantle . 
A review of company service have find the wool industry hold market reporting and wool classer service above the provision of sell centre , although grower body and exporter have be surprise by the decision . 
Chris Kelly from exporter Itochu say rival auction by Australian Wool Handlers have put AWEX under pressure . 
`` Look I 'm quite sure that if AWH do n't do what they do , I think this decision would n't have be make , '' he say . 
`` I think the exporter now would quite rightly question the benefit of AWEX in regard to saleroom issue . '' 

Grim winter rain outlook for eastern Australia 
Despite previous forecast , eastern Australia now look set to receive below average rainfall this winter . 
The late outlook from the National Climate Centre say most of Victoria , Tasmania , New South Wales and Queensland can expect a dry than average year , while Western Australia , South Australia and the Northern Territory can expect close to average rain . 
Climatologist Blair Trewin say region still struggle with drought be the least likely to see big winter rain . 
`` The outlook for northern New South Wales and southern Queensland be a rather dry one , '' he say . 
`` In most of that region we be say the chance of above average rainfall be only 35 to 40 per cent so about a 60 to 65 per cent chance of come in below normal . 

AWB to boost payment to grower 
In some good news for the wheat industry , AWB Limited have increase the amount of money it will pay grower next year to reflect a big jump in world grain price . 
The National Pool Price be up $ 15 a tonne , at $ 220 for the benchmark Australian premium white wheat . 
That be $ 32 high than the current harvest price . 
AWB 's National Pools manager David Johnson say the move have be fuel by a poor crop outlook in the US , and high investment in the future market by hedge fund speculator . 
`` While future have be rally the cash market for wheat have not be reflect that full rally in price and this be one of the major reason why we have a number of people say the pool be n't go up as much a they could have and that be because the cash wheat market internationally have not go up as much a the future market be reflect , '' he say . 
`` Stocks continue to tighten , that certainly augur well for price a we move forward . ''

`` The work in the district continue on , we need to build plant material up , ready for next wet season , '' he say . 
`` Cassava , sweet potato , corn-seed and those plant be still grow on . 
`` We have staff in the district who be continue on with the work . The civil disturbance have n't affect them , anywhere near as much a it have in Dili . There 's driver deliver sweet potato cutting , we have staff irrigate maize crop , so that we have enough seed and plant material for next year .

Efforts by the horticulture industry to stop use one of the bad chemical to affect the ozone layer have be internationally recognise .

`` There 's be some research do on alternative and that be to use soft chemical and the other one be to use steam generator to steam the soil , or to use solarisation where they plough it in the hotter climate and let the sun get rid of nematode and problem in the soil , '' he say . 

Merger could have dire consequence for Nationals : analyst 
An expert on rural politics say the in-principle merger agreement between the Queensland Liberal and National party be a disaster for the federal Nationals . 
The agreement stem from month of talk between the Queensland conservative party on how best to beat Labor Premier Peter Beattie . 
But political analyst Professor Brian Costar from Swinburne University say a merger even at a state level would have dire consequence for the Nationals in Queensland and federally . 
He say a merger could cut the Nationals representation in the federal ministry and reduce the vote of both parity , lead to the rebirth of a 'One Nation style ' party . 
`` Some of the issue that give rise to One Nation , and particularly in Queensland where it be strong , be still bubble along below the surface , '' he say . 
Federal party leader Mark Vaile have distance the Nationals from a federal merger say there have never be a good time for regional area to have a specific rural conservative party . 
In Queensland , the merger proposal have receive a mixed response . 
Just 18 month ago it be reject out of hand , but today it be see a the only way to ultimately topple Labor . 
Lecturer in politics at Brisbane 's Griffith University Paul Williams say farmer could be the ultimate loser . 
`` I think that they potentially have a lot to lose , '' he say . 
`` One can suspect that over time that the Nationals ' voice will be drown out .

Nearly one third of farmer be expect condition to worsen in the coming year . 
With a third successive survey in which confidence have decline , Rabobank head of rural banking , Neil Dobbin , say it be almost at the low level since survey begin . 
Many farmer in New South Wales and Queensland be anxiously wait for rain in order to start their winter cropping and livestock producer be also affect by the lack of feed and on-farm water supply .

`` We be really concern for our client and for the rural industry a a whole , there be nothing bad than be in this period of time when you be sit on the fence if you like , wait for rain , '' he say .

`` We just need that break , get the crop in , there be a lot of hand feed go on at the moment .

AQIS officer on alert in NT 
Quarantine authority in the Northern Territory be on full alert , a evacuee from East Timor continue to arrive . 
More than 700 of the estimated 25,000 people displace from Dili have fly into Darwin . 
C-130 Hercules cargo plane be carry up to 180 evacuee at a time from Dili to Darwin on unscheduled flight . 
So far , the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service have check over 720 evacuee from East Timor and 209 crew from the Defence Force . 
Whilst many of the passenger be traumatise and be carry the bare minimum in the haste to escape the unrest , all bag be be X-rayed or search for exotic plant like siam and khaki weed , and disease such a grapevine leaf rust . 
The giant African snail be also a major risk , and clothing , and footwear be be search for it egg , which can be carry in soil material . 

Wine export price drop 
The late wine industry survey have find wine export price be down by a third since 2002 and 40 per cent of Australian winery be run at a loss . 
The Deloitte Wine Industry Benchmarking Survey indicate many winery be struggle to survive , particularly in export market . 
Deliotte partner Stephen Harvey say the big supermarket chain in Europe have take advantage of the Australian wine glut and be force price down , and the whole industry be feel the pain . 
`` We be see a lot of it go over for buyer ' own brand in the big supermarket chain , your Sainburys , Tescos , Aldis etc , '' he say . 
`` That of course do have a flow-on effect to the brand wine . If people be able to buy buyer ' own brand at very cheap price , it naturally add some pricing pressure to your more popular and well-known brand . '' 
Meanwhile , grape grower in South Australia 's Riverland have welcome the proposal for a partial compensation package . 
About 600 people attend a rally yesterday , hear proposal from the local grower association , which will be put to Friday 's wine industry summit in Melbourne . 
The package recommend grower with uncontracted grape be pay $ 5,000 per hectare to not harvest them in the hope of reduce the national oversupply . 
The $ 80 million cost would be share by government and industry . 
Loxton grower Glen Arnold say he hop the proposal be consider . 
`` It 's a way forward for grower to have some hope , '' he say .

NFF concern about Snowy Hydro privatisation 
Opposition to the privatisation of Snowy Hydro continue to build . 
The nation 's chief rural lobby group have , for the first time , express serious concern about the sale and it effect on the National Water Initiative . 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) fear little regard will be give to farmer who rely on Snowy Hydro 's water if the scheme be sold-off . 
And NFF president Peter Corish say fund from any privatisation should be use to protect the environment , irrigators and affect river community . 
He have also call for tight regulation of Snowy investor , include a permanent 10 per cent cap on ownership of Snowy share . 
`` We want to ensure private ownership of the water behind a dam wall , which be something that be certainly new , it 's a new principle for u in Australia that do n't negatively impact on the people who benefit from that water currently , '' he say . 
The three federal independent will table a motion in Parliament today , call for the sale to be block entirely . 
And Nationals MP Kay Hull plan to introduce a private member 's bill into Federal Parliament to permanently cap individual shareholding in Snowy Hydro to 10 per cent . 
The legislation would also stipulate that the majority of director be Australian and that the head office remain in this country . 
Mrs Hull oppose the sale , but say , a a last resort , this bill would limit foreign ownership . 
`` I will continue to fight the sale , this be a safety net in the event the sale can not be cease , '' she say . 
`` I want to ensure that enshrine in legislation be all of the safeguard that need to take place to ensure that big company and overseas company ca n't come in and buy up the Snowy . '' 
It be unclear whether the private member 's bill will receive the support of the Government or the Opposition .

The Ricegrowers Association of Australia say the cap on foreign ownership of Snowy Hydro be not enough to protect irrigators ' interest . 
The New South Wales , Victorian and Federal Governments yesterday agree to permanently limit foreign ownership of the scheme to 35 per cent , with a cap of 15 per cent for individual foreign investor . 
But Ricegrowers Association president Laurie Arthur say that would not prevent a large Australian company buy a majority stake . 
`` It 's some recognition that the government be listen to the concern that have be put to them , '' he say . 
`` It do n't go far enough , we still believe there 's the capacity for an Australian company to have undue influence a regard to the licence that control the water and the release of water . '' 
The Murray Darling Basin Commission and the National Farmers Federation be also worry about aspect of the deal . 
But federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say regardless of who own Snowy Hydro , the interest of irrigators be guarantee in the Snowy water licensing agreement . 
`` It be develop by the Australian , New South Wales and Victorian Governments at the time of corporatisation specifically to protect security , it guarantee the volume for irrigators , '' he say . 

McGuigan Simeon write down wine stock 
Wine company McGuigan Simeon will write down wine stock by up to $ 20 million and will not pay a final dividend to it shareholder this year . 
On Monday the company ask the Australian Stock Exchange to halt it trading until this morning , when the result of an operational review be release . 
Managing director Dane Hudson say the company be force to write down stock because of the recent decline in bulk wine price . 
`` It 's a small percentage of our total stock , '' he say . 
`` This be probably a 9 per cent reduction and it 's for old vintage . We be comfortable with our 2006 vintage but this be old stock that we need to reprice to clear on the bulk market . ''

Naracoorte meatworkers angry over wage 
Local worker at a South Australian abattoir be angry that their hour have be cut , while Chinese employee on temporary visa be be pay full-time wage . 
Two hundred and sixty Australian worker at the Teys Brothers meatworks at Naracoorte have be work a four-day week because of a shortage of stock . 
But even though the Chinese worker be work a similar number of hour , their visa condition require that they receive a full week 's pay . 
Graham Smith , from the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union , say it be absurd . 
`` The meat industry be seasonal to start with , '' he say . 
`` Where the term of the visa be that you 've get to have a severe skill shortage that you 've get to fill , it seem absurd that in an industry where we stand people down for large part of the year because there 's no work for them , that you can say there 's a corresponding skill shortage . ''

In fact , the farming body say the State Budget be so disappointing that it may campaign against the Bracks Government during the November election .

`` The road be the main one , '' he say .

The currant lettuce aphid have be find in South Australia for the first time . 
Authorities have detect the pest on property in the Adelaide Hills and the northern Adelaide Plains . 
The aphid be find in Victoria last year and have plague lettuce crop in Tasmania since 2004 . 
Originally , South Australia ban import of interstate lettuce to protect the industry , but this have now be remove .

He expect to see export level drop but hop Australia will be able to hold onto a market share of around 50 per cent . 
`` Australia win brand of the year twice in a row here with the country of origin label with our statement : 'Australian beef clean and safe ' , '' he say . 
`` But since the US have be out it have give u an opportunity and we grow beef for the five star dining hotel and that sort of stuff - we have get manufacturing beef for the McDonald 's and the Burger King [ chain ] and those guy . 
`` So I think we will hold our own pretty well up here . '' 
The Cattle Council say Australian producer be likely to retain their stronghold on the market for bone-in beef in Korea . 
The amount of US beef allow in will be limit by a continue ban on cattle over 30 month of age , which will help Australia remain competitive , accord to council president Bill Bray . 
`` The main trade in beef into Korea have be the bone-in short rib and we 've be ask to continue to supply that because we have the high freedom-ranking for BSE in the world , '' he say .

Irrigators say they be surprised and relieve at the collapse of the sale of the Snowy Hydro electricity scheme . 
The Federal Government pull out of the sale this morning , cite concern from backbencher and grow public opposition . 
The New South Wales and Victorian Governments have also back down .

He say irrigators be worry about their access to water once the scheme be privatise and most will be please with the about-turn . 
`` I 'm sure probably 80 per cent of irrigators be delight that Snowy Hydro will not be privatise , '' he say . 
`` I think some of our people think that government do n't do a particularly good job of run company and so it 's still a very complicated issue and I would predict that we have n't actually see the last of it within the next 10 year would be surprise if it do n't raise it head again . '' 
Prime Minister John Howard say although irrigator licensing condition be a factor in the Government 's decision , it be public opinion that force the change . 

Govt urge to protect local ethanol industry 
The ethanol industry say it will be devastate by a Federal Government proposal to allow cheap import into Australia . 
Legislation table in Parliament call for the excise on import ethanol to be reduce by 2011 to the same rate a locally-produced biofuel . 
It also outline a planned increase in tax for Australian-made ethanol from 2.5 cent a litre to 12.5 cent . 
Bob Gordon from Renewable Fuels Australia say the Government should do more to protect the local industry . 
`` Unlike other country we be go to be one of the first country in the world to actually tax renewable fuel , '' he say . 
`` Now we 're prepared to live with that but we want a regime for transition that stimulate new industry growth rather than undermine it . 
`` The one propose in the tax Bill will clearly undermine that goal . '' 
Resources Minister Ian Macfarlane have deny the claim . 
He say ethanol will still have an excise advantage over petrol and the industry have have year to prepare for the change . 
Meanwhile the Federal Government have decide to phase in it change to the diesel fuel rebate , to give farmer and transport operator time to adjust . 
The plan will replace cash payment to farmer with a refund add to GST rebate and be due to be implement on July 1 . 
But now , during a two-year transition period , farmer will be able to claim their rebate , but will also have to report it in business activity statement . 
South Australian farmer Doug Hall say that will make the system more complicated . 
`` I just do n't see it be any easy at all , it just do n't make sense to me so why be they play around with this you know , who be the winner at the end of the day ? '' he say . 
`` I 'm certainly not sure it 's the farmer , it 's the damn Government again . '' 
The renewable energy industry want a national incentive-based market to encourage consumer to use clean fuel . 
It have release a report look at development to 2050 , in which renewable energy will be cheap , have high export potential and provide a clean and cheap solution to climate change and energy shortage . 
David Holland from Renewable Energy Generators Australia say the Federal Government should extend tax break to get the technology up and run . 
`` The technology will always be more expensive than the old process of pull coal out of the ground and set fire to it , '' he say . 
`` The environment be a critical issue not just for Australia but for the planet and really the government be the only people that be in the position to take that leadership but there need to be some systemic process that drive the move towards renewables . '' 
The Government have reject the call , say hundred of million of dollar have already be allocate to renewable energy generation .

`` By the same token we need the sow stall for the first six week that they be pregnant so that they do not abort and have other problem at that stage . ''

Tas cow test positive for hydatid tapeworm 
A Tasmanian breed cow have test positive for the hydatid tapeworm , the state 's first case in a decade .

The state be declare provisionally-free of hydatid disease in 1996 . 
Chief vet Rod Andrewartha say the infected cow be part of a mixed line of cattle . 
`` Occasionally of course we will detect cyst and we can normally trace them back to sheep or cattle import from the mainland , in this particular case we find it in an animal which be bear and breed in Tasmania , '' he say .

CSIRO report urge rural , urban water trading 
A major scientific report say city water authority should be allow to buy water from farmer to sustain the grow urban population . 
The CSIRO say without reform , water cost in metropolitan area could rise more than 10 time over the next 25 year . 
The report from the CSIRO and Monash University predict Perth , Brisbane and Sydney will be the bad affected city with the price of water jump up to 10 time unless good reform be put in place . 
Three model have be test and CSIRO say the most successful would be a combination of urban and rural water trading , alongside more efficient water use include desalination plant . 
And while farmer could make a lot of money from water trading , the system would change the face of agriculture in Australia . 
The CSIRO 's Mike Young say urban/rural water trading be already work in South Australia and WA farmer be lead the way in save water . 
`` Agriculture 's a lot more skilful in improve water use efficiency and in 25 year time they 've make a 50 per cent great advance than urban Australia , so there 's a challenge for urban Australia to catch up and show they 're actually as smart a our farmer be , '' Mr Young say . 
Bit some irrigators be worried about the social impact of water be divert into the capital city . 
Although he believe some form of water trading with the city be inevitable , Victorian dairy farmer Max Fehring say government need to make sure urban resident share the cost of water infrastructure with rural community .

`` You 'd probably recall that we 've have two record season 's in a row , give that there 's be quite a significant surplus in place in the industry I think everyone be hopeful we 'd have a vintage that be a bit lower this year and it have be . 
That say though there 's be a lot of fruit leave on the vine or work into the ground and have that all be process we probably would have have another record this year . '' 
Meanwhile the national wine grape grower body will put forward plan for a $ 60 million revival package at an industry summit in Melbourne on Friday .

Mr McKenzie say the money could be generate by levy , and use to pay grower to put their vineyard into hibernation .

Believed to be the first scheme of it kind in the state , the $ 15 million project at Tintinara , south of Adelaide , follow investor interest in vineyard , olive and blue gum plantation .

`` International indicator be good , here in Australia projection for demand continue to exceed projection for supply , '' he say .

While the Bureau of Meteorology be predict a dry than average season , others be tip good condition , particularly for the southern state . 
Queensland-based Hayden Walker , who predict the weather up to 18 month in advance , reckons this winter will be wet than last year , although patchy . 
'It 's go to be a sort of topsy-turvy , or spasmodic , winter . Queensland will have light rain during June , with moderate fall in July , [ and ] probably get some reasonable fall on a finishing note in August , '' he say 
`` NSW will be look at light to moderate rain in June and some moderate to reasonably good fall for the balance of winter .

Call for more climate research to maintain wheat production 
There be a warning today that wheat production could fall by 15 per cent and cost the nation $ 1 billion over the next 30 year unless the grain industry step up research into manage climate change . 
A study of five major grain grow area show a drop in production of between 5 per cent and 25 per cent , with short grow period and high threat from disease and pest a the country get warm and drier . 
Professor Peter Grace from the Institute of Sustainable Resources in Queensland , say farmer may need to look to new wheat variety and good use natural resource like water . 
`` Drought resistance be probably the number one area we need to get into in Australia , '' he say . 
`` We have a long history of scientist who have do a lot of work in traditional plant breeding in drought resistance and have be very successful , so we 're well position to meet what 's go to happen in the next 30 to 50 year . 
`` Global warming be here , that be a proven fact . Farmers play a role in that as well by move towards conservation tillage practice , so farmer be in the driver 's seat . ''

`` And there be fantastic sub-soil moisture there in the majority of the state .

US lower wheat production forecast 
The US Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) have again lower it 2006 and 2007 wheat production forecast , at the same time a grain price soar . 
Production estimate now total just over 1.8 billion bushel , or more than 48 million tonne . 
Last month 's US wheat forecast be down 11 per cent from the previous marketing year . 
Now , USDA World Agriculture Outlook Board chairman Gerald Bange say continue dry condition have cut the 06/07 forecast by 14 per cent , and stock by nearly 25 per cent . 
`` And a a result of that , we be in fact , see a strong price , '' he say . 
`` The price outlook now call for about $ 3.90 at the midpoint which be up nearly 50 cent from the 2005-06 year and would , in fact , be the high price since the $ 4.30 that be record in 1996 , contribute to lower US wheat export , forecast off about 100 million bushel , at about 900 million bushel . 
The USDA report catch commodity trader in Australia offguard . 
Tony Smith from Plum Grove say no one be expect such significant change . 
`` Well , in the first two minute , the market react a expect , '' he say . 
`` The future exchange open up , the market go straight up and then within two minute everyone , include myself , be catch by surprise because they just fell in a heap .

Cane smut find on Qld property 
Authorities have confirm the discovery of the exotic disease sugar cane smut at a farm near Childers , in south-east Queensland . 
At the start of another cane crush , it be a massive blow to the sector , which have be enjoy good price . 
The infected property have be quarantine and wide surveillance be underway . 
Property owner Joe Russo , who be also the chairman of the Isis District Canegrowers , say it have be a horrible time . 
`` Not only myself , but the whole family , be quite devastate to hear the news , '' he say . 
`` There 's no doubt we 've all understand the disasterous effect smut can bring , but to have it record not only in your district , then to have it on your own property , be of a concern . '' 
The entire cane crop on the east coast will be inspect for the disease . 
Queensland have be one of only a few commercial grow region in the world without cane smut , which can cause major production loss . 
Eoin Wallis from research group BSES Limited say the situation be extremely serious , even though only one infect plant have be find . 
`` At the moment , because we have n't find anymore plant , we be not able to say whether this be a widespread infestation or simply quite local , '' he say . 

Water shortage threaten lettuce supply 
Production of Australian lettuce could drop by up to 60 per cent by Septelettuce shortagember because of a lack of water in storage outside Melbourne . 
Southern Rural Water have cut water allocation to the Bacchus Marsh and Werribee irrigation district to between zero and 5 per cent , leave grower without water , or use recycled waste water . 
One of Victoria 's big colour lettuce grower , Frank Ruffo , say the both domestic and export supply will be hit . 
`` We use all our water for grow lettuce , salad , '' he say . 
We supply on a national basis around Australia and we also supply overseas so that be go to ruin our export market , especially when we 've manage to take them off the American supplier . 

Results on mad cow disease research may take year 
Scientists say it could take year to work out whether there be a new strain of mad cow disease or whether the original virus have mutate . 
US researcher have confirm that two case of BSE in Texas and Alabama during the past year be a new variety of the disease , which be similar to others in Europe and Japan . 
Professor Colin Masters from Melbourne University say it be frustrate for agricultural industry which have to wait for the research before find out whether they can stop any further spread of the disease . 
`` So far they 're very rare and they 've only be find because of this massively increased surveillance , '' he say . 

Wheat grower call for continued government assistance 
With a new farm bill on the horizon in the United States , wheat grower there have join call for continued government assistance . 
The wheat industry be concern it have a shaky future , after figure show wheat 's portion of the national crop have fall 10 per cent since the 1980s . 
Grower organisation say the wheat industry be at a crossroad with little growth in export , low domestic consumption and loss of acre to other crop . 
As well , there be concern that wheat disease be affect farmer ' profit and there be little research be do on new wheat variety . 
But while the the industry be keen to encourage new research , it have emphasise it must make economic sense for farmer to want to plant wheat in the first place . 
According to the US department of agriculture , the wheat sector be face long term challenge to it profitability , but ask for increase subsidy from government be not the answer . 
The USDA say subsidy only artificially increase demand , rather than provide long term solution . 
The industry plan to hold a wheat summit later this year to try to work out how it can stay profitable and competitive in the international market . 
The Indian Government have call for tender to supply 2.2 million tonne of wheat , after a lack of interest in a 3 million tonne deal last month . 
Only 800,000 tonne be allocate from the original wheat tender , with two third expect to be fill by AWB .

The Western Australian Department of Agriculture be warn livestock producer to either reduce sheep number or pay close attention to feeding requirement . 
There be a severe lack of feed due to dry weather and stock death have be report because sheep be not get enough roughage . 
Veterinary officer Marnie Thomas say producer be feed their sheep lupins a an alternative feed source but they need great diversity to maintain condition . 
`` If you 've get stock that you can quit , I would definitely be quit them now because if this dry keep go , you 're go to be look at supplementary feeding for anywhere up to six week from the break of the season , right up to eight week , depend on what sort of pasture you 've get , '' she say .

Night time temperature across the Darwin rural area have be more than three degree cool than average this month .

A new report have find worker in rural industry like agriculture , forestry and mining be most at risk of develop cancer .

`` Agriculture forestry and fishing be dangerous occupation - but normally we tend to think in term of accident , '' he say . 
`` Now we have get this report which frankly surprise me that it be also the cause of high rate of cancer .

Cold snap take toll on prawn operator 
The cold weather snap in the far north of Western Australia have take it toll on one aquaculture venture . 
Six hundred and sixty thousand prawn fingerling be fear dead after the spate of cold weather , include overnight low of eight degree . 
The marine prawn stop feeding at 20 degree and die at 13 degree , and owner Ian Crimp say there be not much movement in the tank . 
`` The water monitor show the temperature be down to 14.5 at the present time and it 's get pretty low and will be probably devastate for the prawn , '' he say . 
`` These little one might be in the great prawn house in the sky by now . Prawn heaven ! '' 
The rise cost of fuel be also threaten the seasonal harvest of banana prawn . 
Some trawler catch up to 10 tonne more when authority extend the season by a fortnight .

`` It 's be be a bad year than previous year even though we catch more , '' he say . 
`` This year we find it very hard to get people . We will probably look at bring in overseas labour ( from Indonesia ) .

Drought be worsen across south-eastern Australia .

In Victoria 's north-east , several farmer be shoot sheep , or sell stock below market price .

`` In the last drought we find that people if they become isolate from each other , if they simply work hard on farm or simply sat around wonder what they could do there be enormous amount of stress , '' he say . 
`` It just have an impact on the whole sense of well be on the family or the individual and we find last time the great lesson be how important it be to get out there and talk and get access to information and support from each other and from other agency . '' 
And cold weather be a problem too . 
Citrus grower in the Murray Valley and the Riverland be keep an eye out for frost damage . 
Industry expert claim that damage occur if the temperature drop below -2 overnight for long than four hour and that have already happen several time this winter . 
Some grower fear a repeat of 1982 when young tree die because of the extreme weather .

`` We 're all hearing that there 's a great big shortage of skilled miner on the mainland , '' he say . 
`` Maybe a position in Cobar , there 's another position up in Cannington , Queensland , Bendigo . 
`` Got in four application up in Olympic Dam with BHP Billiton themselves , also I 've try to get in with the contractor up there .

Landholders in the Macquarie Marshes of central western New South Wales have be force to disband their local management committee because of ongoing drought and a lack of funding .

Sue Jones , from the now defunct management committee , say it be a struggle to survive . 
`` With drought and reduced flow in the river , landholder just can not keep go , '' she say . 
`` They need to at the moment put their time and resource into their own enterprise just to keep themselves afloat .

The continue drought have worsen Australia 's outlook for grain production .

Recent change to the Royal Commissions Act now give Commissioner Cole the power to examine the document , and decide if the privilege claim be valid .

`` They be still part of a system and obviously they be very largely responsible for oversupply by give very strong market signal over many year for grower to plant . '' 
Meanwhile , the Australian table grape industry say it will continue it battle to try to export to China .

Australia have never have formal access to China but our fruit use to be sent via Hong Kong .

`` But I think also there be a preference to citrus as well . Children have get a preference for mandarin because they be easy to peel , whereas these day kid seem to want a sliced apple and that be very difficult to put in a lunchbox . ''

Citrus canker report recommend AQIS change 
A Senate report into the Queensland citrus canker outbreak have recommend the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service ( AQIS ) respond to allegation of breach of quarantine in few than three work day . 
The five recommendation also include police train for some AQIS staff and an overhaul of the National Management Group for pest incursion . 
The Senate rural and regional affair committee find citrus canker have destroy 500,000 tree around Emerald in Central Queensland , and cost the region $ 70 million . 
Managing director of 2PH farm , John Pressler , lose more than 250,000 tree to canker , but say he be not surprised no-one be charge over the outbreak . 
`` It 's really only subsequent to the Senate inquiry that the investigator actually revisit the whole scene , '' he say . 
`` By this time , a whole lot of evidence and information be miss , so it 's not surprising , it 's just another indictment against the way AQIS perform in this entire charade . '' 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say he will carefully consider the finding of the Senate report , and believe at least two of the recommendation make good sense . 
He have defend AQIS against criticism that it be too slow to investigate report of illegal import of citrus budwood . 
`` I do n't agree with the criticism of AQIS . These investigation be conduct professionally and thoroughly , '' he say .

WA Govt look to Europe to toughen illegal fishing law 
The Western Australian Government have look to lead from Europe for tough new law on illegal fishing . 
Fisheries Minister Jon Ford say those catch in state water will now face fine of up to $ 150,000 and long jail sentence . 
The change also give state fishery officer new power to seize suspected illegal vessel , even if they do not have an actual catch on board . 
Mr Ford say international fishing law do not have enough clout . 
`` I send my officer over to Europe to talk to the OECD authority that deal with illegal fishing , '' he say . 
`` They tell u it be very difficult to get a conviction under international law , it be unlikely that it would change in the near future . Our best chance be to strengthen our law at a domestic level . ''

Now on the eve of a visit to the US by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi , Japan have agree to resume import , but keep out the vast majority of US beef with what Mr Doud say be an unscientific barrier to trade . 
`` We 're not go to be happy until we 're at an international guideline , and we 're able to trade everything , at a minimum , under 30 month of age , '' he say . 
Japan insist on a 20-month standard to combat mad cow disease . 
The US cattleman back trade sanction against Japan , introduce by several US lawmaker , until Japan finally lift it US beef ban .

`` Since BSE be detect total consumption of beef be down about 15 per cent and what we be about be see that total pie growing of beef consumption .

Laura rodeo secretary Karlene Shephard say the event evolve last year when the truckload of normal dog steer do not turn up , so they use large bullock instead . 
`` [ The ] fella go through and draft off the one that have a little bit of horn that be there and put them in the dogging box , '' she say . 
`` When the first fella go in he look at it and he say 'gee they 're a bit big ' because they be bullock and they be flat out fit in the dogging box and anyway another fella off the committee say 'why do n't two of you have a go at it ' .

Fuel tax Bill expect to negatively impact on biofuels industry 
A fuel tax Bill which pass through the Senate last night be expect to have a negative effect on the biofuels industry in Australia by remove tax advantage for small biofuels producer . 
Last year the Federal Government commission a report into the viability of the industry , include research from the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) . 
ABARE 'S study say the world oil price , feed grain price and tax arrangement all affect the industry . 
The report 's author , Graham Love , say any change to taxation be significant . 
`` They could have a significant effect to the extent that if tax treatment become more generous then you would presume that that would make the industry more viable or if they be to go the other way it would be less viable , '' he say . 
The Senate be also tell the Bill could severely disadvantage rural community who be look to the biofuels industry for investment . 
Gary Tepper , from Swan Hill Council in Victoria , say the whole community be work hard to make sure a local ethanol plant go ahead . 
`` We really see the whole biofuels , renewable energy industry a some sort of hope for region , '' he say .

The Monash Energy and Anglo Coal project in Victoria be explore the feasibility of drying , gasify and then liquefy coal into a new synthetic low emission fuel . 
With 80 per cent of Australia 's power generation come from coal , Jeff Cochrane from Monash Energy say there will be important benefit for the environment

Organic cattle producer in the outback channel country of Queensland and South Australia be find it hard to meet demand because of the continue drought .

Sharon Oldfield from Cowarie Station on the Birdsville Track , who supply organic beef , say they have have to halve their cattle herd . 
`` We would n't have have a good general summer rain probably for four or five year now , in some area it 's be up to six year , '' she say .

There be another medical team celebrate 60 year in the air .

Europe poise to act on foreign wine threat 
Europe be admit it have to do something about the threat from foreign wine produce in Australia , South Africa and Chile . 
The European Commission have unveil plan to pull out more than 10 per cent of Europe 's vine over the next five year to reduce it wine glut . 
The move , which will cost of 2.4 billion euro , be an admission that Europe be worry about the threat from foreign wine producer like Australia , South Africa and Chile . 
The EU also admit it have make mistake in the area of marketing and subsidy . 
The commission 's Michael Mann say it be a radical overhaul to address a massive wine lake . 
`` We be go to get rid of a situation where we have get too much wine . We be go to use money to get people out , '' he say . 
`` We be go to simplify our labelling rule and you know after a five-year period once all be say and do with the re-structuring it will be the market that decide . We want to be in the situation where the European wine be the one people be choose . ''

Wheat Australia , which be yet to ship 350,000 tonne of wheat to Iraq , be watch event in the Middle East closely , after the Iraqi Trade Minister threaten to stop all deal between the two country .

But follow diplomatic talk overnight , Prime Minister John Howard have tell Channel Nine he do not expect Australia 's wheat trade to be affect . 
`` I can tell you that the Iraqi Trade Minister saw the Australian ambassador and the Iraqi Trade Minister tell our ambassador that he do not want this incident to interfere with the bilateral relationship or to affect our trade relationship , '' he say . 
Meanwhile , the Western Australian Farmers Federation deny it be withdraw support for AWB 's wheat export monopoly . 
Federation senior vice-president , Robert Doney , yesterday suggest in a national newspaper interview that the veto power should be remove from AWB 's single desk . 
But grain president Ray Marshall have describe the comment a a `` naive indiscretion '' , and deny any split on the issue . 
`` Always when you have 17 people sit around a table you will have differ opinion , '' he say . 
`` I believe at this moment whilst policy be very clear , we 're at the status quo until such time that the Cole Inquiry come out and we 're very clear about our view . 
Meanwhile , Australia be not alone in suffer wheat crop loss this year from drought . 
The US crop continue to decline in quality , as well a quantity , amid persistent heat and drought . 
The US wheat crop be already forecast off 14 per cent from the last marketing year , and dry condition be also take a toll on the quality of what 's leave . 
Brad Rippey be a US Agriculture Department meteorologist and say the winter wheat crop be rat 29 per cent which be good to excellent . 
`` But a very large 46 per cent be very poor to poor , '' he say .

Earnings from commodity export be boom even more than expect this year , largely thanks to the mineral and energy sector , accord to the late figure . 
Australia 's Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) predict commodity export will rise 16 per cent this year , more than double it original forecast issue at the Outlook Conference in February . 
The increase be thanks to a strong mineral and energy sector which be now expect to earn $ 48 billion - up $ 4 billion on the February forecast . 
It be a different story for farm commodity though with the February forecast of $ 29.6 billion downgrade slightly .

The head of the committee in charge of implement the National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) have defend the time it be take to roll it out . 
That be despite just one state so far - Victoria - have mandatory NLIS without any exemption . 
The NLIS be a national program design to allow all cattle to be trace from paddock to plate . 
The chairman of the national NLIS executive committee , John Wilde , say the rollout have exceed expectation . 
`` We be well into the implementation phase and it 's perform really well , it 's exceed our expectation . It will obviously be a number of year before the implementation phase be finally wash through . But we be very very pleased with the progress to date , '' he say .

Tas fox population confirm : report 
A new report have find there be definitely foxes in Tasmania and they pose a multi-million dollar threat to the State 's agricultural sector . 
Despite a number of report sighting since a state task force be set up three year ago , the existence of fox in Tasmania have remain an open question . 
But main author of the new report , Glenn Saunders , say there be no doubt that a small population exists . 
`` I guess we come in a an external group and look at it impartially , '' he say . 
`` We have nothing to gain or benefit from conclude one way or the other , but on review all of the available evidence that we could gather , and I mean all of the available evidence not just snippet of it here and there , we really could n't come to any other conclusion . '' 
And if they find the Tassie fox , there be a market for them . 
A fox skin buyer and exporter say demand and price for Australian fox skin be rise after year of disinterest from the trade . 
The trade decline and price plummet during the 1980s during a bitter campaign wag by animal liberation group against the use of fur in fashion . 
A large number of fox shooter stop take skin and the skill of skinning , and prepare the pelt , almost die out . 
But fox skin exporter Don McGilvray say renew Chinese interest in fur be lead the trade 's recovery . 
`` I 'm pay from $ 25 for the top and the average be anywhere from 13 to $ 16 , '' he say .

Earlier this year , the Navy seize the 'Harapan ' , which be an Indonesian type three ice boat , inside the Australian fishing zone boundary . 
The 27 metre long boat could store up to 40 tonne of fish , but this one be only carry about 50 kilogram of fish such a snapper aid by GPS navigation . 
The Australian Fisheries Management Authority say these boat burning send a strong message to the owner in Indonesia , that illegal fishing will not be tolerate . 
It have be set alight in a boat burn pit at Hudson Creek , near the busy East Arm Port of Darwin and will take all day to burn completely . Any metal remaining will be salvage for cost recovery .

They hope to isolate the chemical , to create a product that keep roos away from crop . 
Project manager Dr Michael Parsons say they first trialled the smell at a wildlife sanctuary and watch the kangaroo flee . 
`` She walk out of the bathroom with a tube of urine in an evaporative canister and as soon a she get about five metre from them , they look at her and immediately flee ... and this be a whole mob of them , '' he say .

Report highlight desire for change to wheat marketing

The longest-running land claim in the nation be be resolve today in the Gulf of Carpenteria , 700 kilometre south-east of Darwin . 
Just over 21,000 hectare across the Sir Edward Pellew Islands , be be officially hand back to the Yanyuwa people , after 30 year of debate . 
Many of the original claimant be not alive to see their dream come true , but 71-year-old Steve Johnson say the hand back provide an incentive for others to move back onto traditional land . 
`` It 's good to see that we be get our island hand back after so long . There have be a number of death in the Yanyuwa and [ other ] clan group , 130 all up in that time , '' Mr Johnson say . 
`` [ But ] I think it will make them feel a lot well , that they can move around more freely in their own country . 
`` The only thing that would be a factor now be the cost of fuel , petrol , diesel stuff like that to get out there .

Farming practice blame for loom mouse plague 
No-till farming practice and leave over seed from last harvest be be blame for a looming mouse plague on South Australia 's upper Eyre Peninsula . 
Surveys have show more than 4,000 mouse per hectare , the high number since 1995 . 
Unlike conventional seeding , sow crop with the no-till method leave one distinct furrow for mouse to follow and burrow into to eat grain . 
Buckleboo farmer Jim Hamlin say the mouse be just another problem when they be already face a cold , dry start to the season . 
`` Where some of the crop be up , they 're chew off leaf and in other place , where the crop be not up , they 've dig under the ground and get the grain as well , '' he say . 

Businesses suffer a dry condition continue 
Dry condition on pastoral property south-east of Alice Springs have take their toll on business which service the area . 
It have be four year since the region have have any decent rain and stock feed be scarce . 
Rodney Mingel , who run Mingel 's Heli Service , have ground one of three helicopter this season and stand down a pilot . 
He say mustering work have be halve , due to the lack of rain and low stock number . 
`` From now on through to September be really our busy period , '' he say . 
`` There 's just not much happening , I mean people have do their work , work that they normally do towards the end of the year they 've do at the beginning of the year . 
`` Cattle number be down , so there 's not six paddock to muster anymore there 's one .

There be concern about the state of the Murray River this winter .

Colignan citrus grower and river boat enthusiast Robert Mansell say the river be as low a he have see it at this time of year . 
`` It 's really , really interesting , '' he say .

Green light give to abalone farm 
The first land-based abalone farm in New South Wales have be approve on the state 's mid-north coast . 
Native abalone be under threat from poach and aquaculture be see a a way of preserve number . 
But local conservation group fear the development could pollute coastal water and destroy seagrass bed . 
Graham Housefield from Australian Bounty Seafoods say he have do everything he can to deal with the concern . 
`` I guess what it really come down to be that the farm need to have a pristine area because we need water that 's as clean a possible and therefore we ca n't afford to do anything to harm the water from that area , '' he say . 
`` These animal be absolutely and totally reliant on have clean water . '' 

Flower grower surprise at banned-seed list 
Cut-flower grower be call for more time to comment on draft change to seed import regulation . 
For the past two month , Biosecurity Australia have be review the Permitted Seeds List . 
But tropical flower grower , like Alan Carle , say the review have catch many grower by surprise . 
`` We be in a process , a review process to dramatically restrict the number of plant and seed which may be bring into the country in the future , '' Mr Carle say . 
`` Effectively , it slam the door shut . We should all just band together and ask for a moratorium so we have time to consider and work in a constructive way with Biosecurity Australia and Quarantine to come up with a system which we be all happy with and do n't create some sort of black market . 
`` I mean that 's the bad thing that can happen to this country be to get thing bring in without proper control . '' 

US cattle price not expect to increase 
US Agriculture Department official say it will take year to recover from Japan 's mad cow-related ban on beef and producer there should not expect to see massive price rise . 
US Agriculture Department livestock analyst Ron Gustafson say Japan 's expect reopening of it market to US beef after it complete audit of US plant next month , will not bring a huge upswing in US cattle price . 
Mr Gustafson say it will take year to sell pre-mad cow amount of US beef to Japan , which only buy certain cut anyway . 
`` We do n't sell whole carcass to the Japanese or South Koreans , or anyone ... we sell cut that , largely , we do n't have the large demand for here in the US - short rib , plate and so-forth - the fatty item , '' he say . 

Drug bust wasp still some time away 
Wasps might be know for their bite , but their highly-tuned sense of smell could make them the sniffer dog of the future . 
Trials be under way in the United States to train tiny wasp to detect chemical . 
Dr Andrew Austin from the University of Adelaide say the idea be feasible and wasp be quick learner , but he can not see them replace dog any time soon . 
`` They 've be able to demonstrate that you can take these wasp and you can train them to recognise that particular chemical , '' he say . 
`` It 's a long way from that to actually use this particular wasp in a commercial sense , where you could actually use them a drug bust sort of wasp . 

Hotline to help men cope with depression 
The impact of the drought have prompt Beyondblue to establish a national hotline specifically to help men deal with depression . 
Chairman Jeff Kennett say men from country area be more likely to suffer from depression , but be less likely to admit the problem . 
He say the helpline will provide information , treatment and where to get help . 
`` Unfortunately depression be very prevalent throughout rural Australia and particularly among young men , '' he say . 
`` So what we hope with this Beyondblue information line be to give men the capacity wherever and however isolate their environment may be for the price of a local call to seek direction and help a to what to do in overcome their depressive illness . '' 
The hotline number , which will be in operation from July 1 be 1300 224 636 . 
WA-based rural financial counsellor Sue Smith say farmer be traditionally bad at manage stress and many case be ignore . 
She say one of the telltale sign be a change in behaviour . 
`` It 's no wonder that people be feel really stress at the moment , '' she say . 
`` The first sign be in the body , somebody will start to feel tired , they 'll get headache , their body will start to ache . 
`` Sometimes it 's other people that notice that they become quiet irritable , they may withdraw from their family and friend .

The chairman of the Wheat Export Authority ( WEA ) , Tim Besley , will head the regulator for another six month . 
Questions have be raise about the authority 's effectiveness , in the wake of the AWB scandal . 

Sheep chemical declare unsafe 
Access to a chemical commonly use to treat flystrike and louse in sheep will be severely restrict after test show it be unsafe . 
The review of Diazinon be prompt earlier this year after farm worker complain of headache and in some case vomit when use the chemical . 
Joan Ashton from the Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority say other chemical be more costly , but human safety be the priority . 
`` There 's really no way you can mitigate what we think be an unacceptable risk to worker , '' she say . 
`` Australia 's not the only one look at Diazinon , there 's be a range of review that have be go on worldwide and it have progressively be discontinue in other country , as well , along similar line and for similar reason for concern , a we 've identify here in Australia . '' 

Ag pilot dispute crash statistic finding 
New research from the Australian Transport Safety Bureau ( ATSB ) say agricultural pilot do not get enough training and be overly represent in crash statistic . 
The research , which look at wire strike accident where plane hit power line or other wire , find 65 per cent of low level fly accident happen in farming . 
Head of the Aerial Agricultural Association , Phil Hurst , dispute the finding and say the industry have improve it safety record .

The Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) be again under fire for it forecast , this time for livestock price . 
Analysts say meat price estimate be probably too low , while production forecast for beef and lamb be too high . 
Bill Cordingley from Rabobank say the beef figure have not take poor season properly into account .

`` If you 've get a four to six year of operation yet it could be permanent ground water contamination in that area . ''

A Northern Territory mining company hop to have a rare earth mine up and run within five year . 
The rare element be a key ingredient for new technology include computer screen , rechargeable battery and environmentally-friendly hybrid vehicle . 
Arafura Resources have already find an 18.6 million tonne deposit about 130 kilometre north of Alice Springs , but manage director Alistair Stephens say they hope to find more in coming month to meet grow demand .

`` Bearing in mind that the Tax Department be come up today we think really we 'd better do something , '' he say . 
`` I come up and have a look at it and there be obviously a gap there , and say 'hey boys what be we go to do about this ' and they all say unprintable word and off we go .

Regulation of the domestic rice market will end tomorrow .

The price of avocado could be set to rise , with significant frost damage to crop in the Murray Valley . 
Freezing condition a fortnight ago have cause fruit to drop off the tree . 
John Eastoe from Mildura Agricultural Contractors say he have lose 60 per cent of his crop , which have an estimate valued of more than half a million dollar . 
`` We be sit on probably our best have crop ever , we 've be lift our yield for the last three year but a you can see it 's all on the ground , '' he say .

Mail contractor finally quit 400km mail run 
It be a bittersweet day for one outback mail contractor , 
After almost 40 year of service property in south-west Queensland , Cecil Russell be retire 
Since 1968 Mr Russell have be make the 400 kilometre round trip from Augathella to Carnarvon Station twice a week and say the scenery be the best part of the job . 
`` I love the country up there and that 's probably why I 've be do it so long , it 's a for ever change sort of thing , season change and yes there 's a lot of wildflower at time , '' he say . 
`` Every day you get to see a different mob of brumby horse , see quite a few wild dog and I enjoy just look at the cattle a I go and that sort of thing .

Retiring wine group head predict industry turnaround 
The retire chairman of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation be predict a turnaround in the wine industry within the next four year . 
David Brownhill step down today after six year in his government-appointed role . 
With grape grower struggle with poor price and an oversupply , Mr Brownhill do not , however , expect much improvement in the short term . 
`` I believe in two year ' time the light will start to shine at the end of the tunnel , [ it ] do n't mean that it 's come out of the tunnel in two year ' time , but in four year ' time I believe that you 'll be right out of the tunnel and then you 'll most probably find we 'll be a little bit short of red wine for example , '' he say . 

Food safety standard need continual improvement , say scientist 
The safety of the food that we eat be emerge a a crucial global trade issue , which can open or block access to market . 
Scientists at the Australian Food Safety Centre say the three main concern be chemical residue , foreign item in prepared food and pathogen such a bacteria and virus . 
Professor Tom Ross say pathogenic outbreak occur at all level of the food chain from the paddock to the plate and grower , and processor , need to continue to improve safety standard . 
He say E. coli bug in the 1980s be an example of how potentially fatal contaminant continue to evolve . 
`` Twenty year ago that organism have never be see before , '' he say . 

AWB vow to fight any kickback lawsuit 
Wheat exporter AWB say it will fight any legal action launch by American farmer in the wake of the oil-for-food scandal . 
Reports suggest the company could face a billion-dollar lawsuit claim US wheat grower lose trade with Iraq when AWB pay almost $ 300 million in kickback to Saddam Hussein 's regime . 
The ABC understand the initial case may cover just 20 or so farmer but have the potential to see thousand of US and Canadian farmer join them . 
If the action be successful , it could see AWB force to make a payout triple the value of the kickback . 
But US Wheat Associates know nothing of the proposed legal suit at this stage . 
AWB spokesperson Peter McBride say AWB would fight any such legal suit . 
`` Such action be ill-conceived and if any action be formally bring against AWB we will vigorously defend , '' he say . 
The ABC understand that it be hard to argue the case that US farmer be hurt by AWB kickback , because the US have sanction against trading with Iraq .

AWB have challenge the grow number of proposal call for change to the single desk export system . 
National wheat pool manager David Johnston have tell a public debate in Victoria that AWB will accept the outcome from the oil-for-food inquiry . 
But he say if AWB 's export monopoly or it veto over grain export application be remove , wheat grower will be the loser . 
`` The bulk veto , I think , be a core component of the single desk a we know it and if we have people want to send wheat into Indonesia or Malaysia or any of our core market you 'll have Australian wheat compete with Australian wheat , '' he say . 

Electoral boundary change bad for voter : Anderson 
The National Party have accuse the Australian Electoral Commission of take the easy way out , by scrap the federal seat of Gwydir in northern New South Wales . 
With a shift in population , New South Wales be require to lose an electorate to accommodate a new seat in Queensland . 
The commission want to merge the seat of Gwydir with Parkes , which will cover almost half the state . 
But the retiring Member for Gwydir , former deputy prime minister John Anderson , say the move be a tragedy for country voter . 
`` I think it 's appallingly bad to see people face the prospect of be in a seat that 's over twice the size that it be now which make it far hard for people to access the local member , '' he say . 
`` This mean one less country voice in Canberra and a less chance still of be represent around the Cabinet table . 

NFF 'lives in hope ' of trade talk breakthrough 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) be confident there be still life in World Trade Organisation ( WTO ) talk , despite another failure to reach agreement on agriculture over the weekend . 
United States and European negotiator go into the talk say they be prepare to move on farm reform . 
However , negotiator in Geneva say those nation have fail to match their rhetoric with action . 
An agreement on agriculture be the crucial first step in secure broad trade deal around industrial good and service .

`` WTO be the main game , '' Mr Mitchell say . 
`` We live in hope that minister will go home and reflect on what 's happen here this week and will realise that we do have a narrow window of opportunity to make global trading rule well for a long time . 

Cold start to winter cut rainfall 
The freezing start to winter across southern Australia could be cause the ongoing dry weather condition . 
In normal year , cold air from the Southern Ocean collide with warm air from central Australia result in cut-off low , which bring rainfall . 
But this year , the system be not a strong . 
Dr Peter McIntosh , from the Marine Atmospheric Research Centre , say that be because it be cold inland . 
`` We 've speculate a little bit recently about what might be cause these cut-off low to decrease in intensity , '' he say . 
`` We think it be a decrease in the north-south temperature gradient . 

Coroner blame bushfire on powerline 
An electricity provider in New South Wales have be blame for cause a major bushfire in the state 's central west two year ago . 
The deputy state coroner have find the fire start near Parkes , when a tree touch a Country Energy powerline . 
The 2004 fire burn 6,000 hectare , cause the death of 690 sheep and the destruction of thousand of hectare of unharvested crop on 28 farm . 
Craig Ward say he be relieve the four-day inquest quash rumour that his farm machinery spark the blaze . 
`` I just give evidence that I be n't in the vicinity of where the fire start , '' he say . 
`` Through the GPS system on the harvester it plot every two second where the harvester have be over the period of time your harvesting . '' 
Mr Ward say he be frustrate by the approach of Country Energy to the trial , which try to prove his harvester spark the blaze .

The long-awaited second stage development of the Ord River Irrigation Scheme in Western Australia 's far north have be give the green light . 
Tenders have be call by the WA Government , which have settle environmental and native title issue surround the development . 
The expansion of the Ord River Irrigation Scheme will make 16,000 hectare of irrigated farmland available . 
The Government say it be seek expression of interest for development of between 7,000 and 16,000 hectare of land . 
Resources Minister John Bowler say land could be available for plant as soon a 2008 . 
`` We believe we can quadruple the amount of hectare place under agriculture in irrigation , '' he say . 
`` This will make the Ord Valley one of the most significant agricultural area in Australia . ''

Managed investment scheme under review 
Concerns be emerge over the shift in managed investment scheme ( MIS ) from forestry and vineyard to broader agriculture . 
Plantings of walnut and avocado be among those now be offer to investor . 
Rob Dalton , from Avocados Australia , say he be concern by the push , which could massively distort the market . 
`` Reviews of MISs have indicate that the investor be in there primarily for the tax deduction and they have much less concern with profitability at the end of the project , '' he say . 
`` Whereas the normal farmer be in there for a profit and a long-term , sustainable profit . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran be also concern about the impact of MISs . 
`` When they start go into wine grape and citrus and avocadoes where there be well-established Australian industry , that be of enormous concern , '' he say .

Queensland feedlot owner be be tell they may have to buy grain to fee cattle from Western Australia , if local production do not increase .

Kym McIntyre say feedlot already consume about 2 million tonne of grain a year , with a further 1 million tonne likely to be need over the next five year .

VegMachine give farmer eye in the sky 
Landholders across the northern rangeland of Australia can now use satellite monitoring to keep track of environmental change on their property . 
The new system , which be call VegMachine , have be trialed across 80,000 square kilometre in Western Australia , the Northern Territory and Queensland . 
NT Government researcher Luke Peel want to see the free computer software program use more widely . 
`` It give you a birdseye view of the property , '' he say . 
`` The idea be the mystery of satellite imagery , what it can say and do be be expose back . 
`` It still have n't get to the point where we can actually work out kilogram per hectare on the ground . 
`` But , it certainly give an idea of how productivity can be relate to use of the resource or trapping of the resource available . 
`` Whether it 's the actual vegetation , the soil or the nutrient in the soil . ''

Draft chicken meat import rule worry industry 
The chicken meat industry say a decision to allow import into Australia could pose an unnecessary risk to consumer . 
In a draft import risk analysis , Biosecurity Australia recommend allow uncooked chicken meat into the country , as long a export country can prove they be free of disease , include bird flu . 
But Dr Andreas Dubs , from the Australian Chicken Meat Federation , be question whether Australia can be certain about another country 's disease status . 
`` That be not a simple matter , '' he say . 
`` It really come down to the confidence that we can have with the system in place which in the past I suppose have be show to be somewhat questionable . '' 
While Australian quarantine officer usually double-check disease free claim from other country , some say that be not always a guarantee . 
Peter Scott , from the Australian Veterinary Poultry Alliance , say authority rely on get accurate information from producer . 
`` Regulatory authority can only go on the information provide to them and in some case that may not be accurate , '' Mr Scott say . 
`` We do see overseas quite a bit of product move through country . 
`` In other word , while you believe you 're get product from a particular country it may be come in via another country . '' 

Animal-based fertiliser threaten BSE status : vet 
Tasmania 's chief vet say Australia 's status a be free of mad cow disease ( BSE ) could be threaten by the indiscriminate use of animal-based pasture fertiliser . 
A number of cattle death from botulism in Tasmania have be attribute to the use of poultry litter a a fertiliser . 
Dr Rod Andrewarthur say although it be a legal product , the litter must not be use before the end of the official withholding period to ensure cattle do not ingest any linger animal protein . 
He say under BSE protocol , no animal protein can be feed to cattle . 
`` We sell our meat to the world a a premium because we be free of disease like mad cow disease , '' he say . 
`` We be under audit from other country like the European Union to make sure that we 've get all the check and safeguard in place prevent the development of the disease . 

Processing delay force saleyard 's NLIS overhaul 
Processing delay of up to 24 hour have force Australia 's big saleyards to overhaul it National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) infrastructure . 
With 11,000 cattle on offer today , new in-pen scanning be be put to the test at the Roma Saleyards in Queensland . 
A year after NLIS become mandatory in the state , the saleyards ' board be scrap two run-through scanner worth $ 270,000 . 
While they read tag with 99 per cent efficiency , large volume of cattle mean even minor misreads could cause huge disruption . 
Brisbane-based company Livestock Link have be contract to pick up any miss tag and non-reader tag more efficiently , by pre-scanning cattle before sale in pen . 

Ethics campaigner push for teminator gene ban 
Gene ethic campaigner be lobby the Federal Government to ban the development of terminator technology in Australia . 
The process would stop seed from breed naturally , force farmer to buy new stock each year instead of grow their own . 
More than 10,000 people have sign a petition claim genetic engineering company will have monopoly power if the technology be introduce . 
The Government have say it will accept development application on a case-by-case basis . 
However , Bob Phelps from the GeneEthics Network say that be not acceptable . 
`` There 's clearly strong public sentiment that the terminator be not acceptable , '' he say . 
`` We 're submit those petition to the federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran and we 're say to the Australian Government we want you to align the Australian Government policy with the global view that it 's unacceptable and that the global ban on terminator should remain . '' 

VFF push for single wheat desk change 
The Victorian Farmers Federation ( VFF ) have join grow call for change to the single desk for wheat export , in the wake of the oil-for-food Inquiry . 
Under it plan , wheat exporter AWB Limited and AWB International would be split , with international wheat sale return to farmer control . 
The VFF will seek endorsement for the proposal from the Grains Council of Australia later this month . 
VFF grain group president Ian Hastings say the plan address concern about governance of the system , and payment to grower from the national wheat pool . 
`` We 're talk about separation of AWB International and make sure that AWB International continue to have the legislative monopoly for export of wheat , '' Mr Hastings say .

A booming export fodder market be good news for grower but farmer look to fee livestock in Australia be face high price and short supply . 
Lucerne price have almost double since November to around $ 300 a tonne , while hay price be up between $ 30 and $ 40 a tonne . 
Colin Peace , from the Fodder Industry Association , say drought in the US and Canada be help to boost export , at the expense of the domestic market . 
`` Those two market often clash for supply so I think you could anticipate that certainly continue , '' he say . 
`` There be always opportunity for stock that be destine for export to be divert for domestic demand .

`` They 've get different strategy .

Inquiry likely to recommend geosequestration : researcher 
Researchers believe a federal Parliament inquiry will help find funding for more project to stop greenhouse gas from coal , oil and gas field enter the atmosphere . 
The House of Representatives Science and Innovation Committee will investigate the benefit and risk of geosequestration , which be capture carbon dioxide from mining and store it underground for million of year . 
Trials be be carry out in Victoria 's Otway Basin and off the Western Australian coast . 
Dr Peter Cook , from the Co-operative Research Centre for Greenhouse Gas Technologies , say study be make progress . 
`` We 're very confident that that inquiry be go to endorse the use of this technology a one of the option for decrease CO2 emission , '' he say .

A 12-month trial produce ethanol from wine grape have begin in South Australia . 
Tarac Technologies in the Barossa Valley currently distill alcohol from winery waste . 
The company will supply South Australian Farmers Fuel with 100,000 litre of biofuel over the next 12 month . 
Spokesman Chris Zajac say it remain to be see if the process can be economically viable . 
`` The reason we 've decide to run the trial be to basically see how it perform against other ethanol in the marketplace , '' he say .

New figure show Homebrand product like milk , sugar and butter already account for more than 50 per cent of sale through the major supermarket . 
Frozen and can Homebrand vegetable and dry fruit be also become more popular , accord to research by accountancy firm KPMG .
