`` Some of them be fight head on against it , some of them be actually work with it , '' he say . 

Tin mill 's closure to force can import 
In a further blow for the manufacturing industry , tin fruit and vegetable processor will have to import can from next year , after the closure of Australia 's only tin mill . 
High iron ore price have lead BlueScope Steel to shut it Port Kembla mill . 
That will force cannery to either import tin or look for alternative packaging . 
The head of the Food and Grocery Council , Dick Wells , say increase cost be put manufacture under a lot of pressure . 
`` People need to be aware that it 's tough all the way and there 's no easy life here , '' he say . 
`` If we 're not innovative in this country in look for way to take cost out of the structure and produce product that consumer see additional benefit in , then there wo n't be a future . '' 

Organic farmer eye overseas market 
The United States , Europe and South-East Asia be potential market for Australian-grown organic product , accord to a report launch last night . 
The report by the Rural Industries and Development Corporation look at the demographic of consumer , and what drive them to buy organic food . 
Andre Leu , from the Organic Federation of Australia , say in the long-term , China will be a major market , although Australia will struggle to compete with it domestic production . 
`` The late figure that we have from China show that their industry be worth $ US8 billion , which make them one of the large organic market in the world , '' he say . 

Farmers dispute Costello 's federalism reform plan 
The New South Wales Farmers ' Association be back Federal Treasurer Peter Costello in his criticism of Australia 's three-tiered system of government , but do not agree with his plan to change it . 
Mr Costello have trigger national debate on federalism , by want to wrestle all responsibility for utility and the economy from the state government , reduce them to branch office . 
Mal Peters , from the association , say give more power to Canberra be not the answer , and be call for full-scale reform of Australia 's system of government . 
`` Any further centralisation of power into New South Wales be not good , '' he say . 
`` I mean the close the government get to the people the good the government be , and that 's well recognise by all player in the state and federal sphere . 

'Iron Boomerang ' plan onshore iron ore processing 
The resource sector be investigate a $ 55 billion proposal to process iron ore in Australia from 2011 . 
The 'Iron Boomerang ' would be a privately-funded 3,000 kilometre railway to link iron ore deposit in Western Australia with coal field in north Queensland 's Bowen Basin . 
Blast furnace to be build at either end of the track would produce pig iron for the export market . 
An international trade delegation be tour the town of Bowen today to investigate the project . 
Shane Condon , from Project Iron Boomerang , say supply chain saving alone could be worth $ 2 billion per year . 
`` When train run empty and ship be come back from China , or in the Pilbarra , or in the coal field of Queensland , the return trip for these giant empty train and ship be 45 per cent of the total trip cost and that be highly inefficient and use fuel unnecessarily , '' he say . 

City vet student try country practice 
Veterinary student in Western Australia have trade the dog and cat of city practice for a stint on a remote cattle property in the Pilbara region . 
About 1,600 kilometre from Perth , Warrawagine Station be a long way from home for two vet student , who have never do any work with cattle before . 
But student Kate Louden say six week on 1 million acre station be a unique experience . 
`` I do n't realise quite how isolated the station be - 300 kilometre from the near shop , '' she say . 
`` We 've be muster so we 've be move the yard and draft the cattle from different block . 
`` [ We 've ] be up in the plane and the chopper a few time so it 's be great . 

Trucking industry look to recruit foreign driver 
The trucking industry want to start employ migrant worker , a driver shortage and an age workforce continue to cause problem . 
Current skilled migrant visa do not allow for truck driver but the Australian Trucking Association ( ATA ) be confident it can get the industry reclassify a a skilled occupation . 
The ATA 's Damien MacFarlane say it be a worldwide problem , and Australia will face competition from other country hop to recruit driver . 
`` You 'll find the United States and the United Kingdom be currently face the same challenge , '' he say . 
`` There 's many driver be poach from Australia and have go to either the United Kingdom or the United States to drive . 
`` It 's fine to say let 's go and get migrant driver , where be you go to get them from ? And that 's go to be the challenge . '' 

Dry condition see live sheep export jump 
Dry seasonal condition in Western Australia have see a massive jump in live sheep export from Fremantle . 
More than 330,000 sheep be ship out last month alone . 
John Edwards , from the WA Livestock Exporters Association , say there be a direct link between the increase and the weather . 
`` I guess farmer have sort of looked ahead of themselves a to availability of feed stock on farm and very little paddock feed , '' he say . 
`` They 've most probably make the decision to sell sheep early . 
`` Possibly we 've see a lot of sheep come out now rather than in the spring when they traditionally shear and sell off shear . '' 
Meanwhile , ease cattle price in the east be provide northern WA producer with competition in the live export trade . 
Tony Cooling , from Landmark in Broome , say Queensland producer be now sell stock overseas . 
`` Queensland price have come back a bit , so live export be now compete with the domestic market over there , '' he say . 

'Beef only ' cattle grant entry to Qld 
Queensland have open it border to cattle from Victoria and the BJD control zone in New South Wales , as long a it 's class a `` beef only '' . 
The state have previously ban cattle due to concern over the disease bovine Johne 's . 
Cattle which have not be run with dairy cow for five year , or graze on land which have run dairy cattle within 12 month , will meet the classification . 
Michael McCormack , from the Cattle Council , say it 's a successful outcome . 
`` Especially for southern producer it 's a good news story , '' he say . 

Canada continue mad cow test 
Canadian authority be continue test on a suspected sixth case of mad cow disease ( BSE ) . 
The cow be bear before feed ban be put in place in 1997 , and be discover under new surveillance program . 
Final test be due next week . 

Frost hit Riversun 's US export 
A company export citrus fruit to the United States say shipment be likely to drop 20 per cent this season , due to frost damage in the Murray Valley , Riverland and Riverina . 
Riversun chairman Peter Walker say supermarket in the US be aware of the damage to the Victorian and South Australian crop , but he be confident sale will not be affect . 
`` It 's one of the transparency that Riversun have , '' he say . 
`` It go out and tell the customer base that we have procedure and policy in place and it 's adhere to them . 
`` If it 's minus two for more than four hour property be put into suspension until they be assess to see if there be any damage on that property , so we 've explain that to supermarket and they be all still on board . '' 

Dairy farmer form collective bargaining group 
Tasmanian dairy farmer who supply food giant National Foods have form the state 's first collective bargaining group . 
About 30 farmer have come together to negotiate future supply and price contract . 
The chairman of the group , Kem Perkins say the move be inevitable . 
`` It 's the only way we could go to negotiate a price because under the rule and the law these day you ca n't negotiate price a an individual , '' he say . 
`` You ca n't even put in on the agenda when you have a supplier ' group meeting so the way we 've set it up ... mean that we can talk to any company , negotiate with any company and we can take on board any supplier that conform to the condition . '' 
One of the first job for the bargaining group will be to negotiate extra time for next season 's price talk . 

Renewable fuel plant near completion 
Work on the nation 's big renewable fuel plant in Darwin be almost complete . 
Natural Fuels Australia will import Malaysian palm oil to produce biodiesel later this year . 
Charles Darwin University be commission to compare traditional diesel with a 20 per cent biodiesel blend . 
Researcher Mark Thiele say emission be reduce . 
`` Carbon dioxide emission go up slightly but primarily because of the reduction in hydro carbon and carbon monoxide , '' he say . 
`` We also do n't actually notice very much difference in power or torque . 
`` Particularly at the 20 per cent blend , which be what we be test , be only about 1 per cent . '' 
But Mr Thiele say it be not clear how sustainable it will be to import palm oil . 
`` From a sustainability perspective it 's probably a little bit more complicated , '' he say . 
`` We have to look at the whole cycle of biodiesel production and the feed stock . 
`` It be really outside the scope of the research work that we do . '' 

Mary River dam decision outrage farmer 
Farmers near Gympie remain outraged with the Queensland Government , despite it decision to scale back the size of a propose new dam on the Mary River . 
Premier Peter Beattie initially plan a 660,000 megalitre dam , which would have consume almost 1,000 property . 
But he now say a small dam will be build , with the resumption of 500 property . 
Under the three-stage plan , the dam wall would be raise if more water be need in 2035 . 
But local at a public meeting to hear the detail be furious , say they will be leave in limbo for 30 year . 
`` I 've be live here 30 year and be wait to retire , '' one say . 
`` I 'd be retire one week when he drop this bombshell . '' 
Another resident say : `` Some people in stage one will get buy out there 's no doubt if they proceed , and so they 've divide the community even more . 
`` And they leave these people in stage two to whither on the vine . '' 

Competition will cut farmer ' market share : study 
A new report say in the next 10 year Australian farmer will lose market share to develop country like China , Brazil and India . 
The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development ( OECD ) and the United Nations have compare 15 commodity . 
They have find that a develop nation increase production and become more competitive , country like the US , EU and Australia will lose out in world agricultural trade . 
Australian export of sugar , beef , rice and pigmeat will be hard hit , with less impact on wheat and poultry . 
Trade analyst Peter Gallagher say although world trade rule will play a part , global export competition be on the rise . 
`` The world be not beat a path to our door look for primary product , '' he say . 
`` The opportunity for Australia be now go to be much more in the process food area and in the fresh food and ingredient area . 
`` It be important that we realise many develop country be become more effective producer of primary product and we need to look at the structure of our own production for the future . '' 

Apple grower look to boost productivity 
Australian apple grower be investigate way to make their orchard more efficient , to compete with the low production cost of other country . 
The industry will set up 60 trial site around the country to compare different planting style . 
The chairman of Apple and Pear Australia , Darral Ashton , say one option be to double the number of tree per hectare , use dwarf root stock . 
`` The tree do n't take the usual say four or five year to come into production - they come into production very easily , '' he say . 
`` Because you have so many tree per hectare , each tree do n't have to carry so many apple to get that high production per hectare . 

Climate change threaten blackcurrant industry 
There be a warning today that Tasmania 's niche blackcurrant industry be under threat from global warming . 
Plant pathologist Steve Wilson say there have be a progressive drop in yield over the past 15 year because of a sharp increase in extremely cold night . 
Mr Wilson be trialing other black currant variety in an attempt to boost yield , but say he be not hopeful . 
`` This , I think , may be the canary in the coal mine , '' he say . 
`` It be show that climate change can impact on commercial crop . 
`` w We 've often think of climate change a something that can impact on natural population , but here it be have quite a distinct impact , quite a distinct economic one , on a small industry . ''

`` Not very much at all - I think that 's what capture the imagination of the market , '' he say . 
`` In fact it 's really be a meteoric rise . 
`` There be a long way for this company to go , but it 's great to see that a discovery can still capture the imagination of the investment public . '' 
Shares in Australian Mining Investment be in a trading halt .

A propose $ 3 billion float of the state and federal-owned power and irrigation provider be scuttle in the wake of public protest last month . 
At a hearing in the Snowy Mountains town of Cooma yesterday , inquiry chairman Gordon Moyes say he hear evidence of a systematic , long-term lack of transparency by Snowy Hydro . 
`` There 's be an absolute failure in term of communication , not just recently , it 's be a culture that 's come to u from evidence for at least 20 year , '' he say . 
`` Who tell them not to communicate , who actually authorise the change in nature of the company 's business ? 
`` They be very significant and important question and will determine the result of the inquiry . ''

It accuse AWB of sell to Iraq from it wheat pool through the consortium . 
Rebecca Coleman say AWB still control the pricing .

Ms Coleman say Iraq be now one of the US 's top 10 wheat customer .

Western Australian broadacre farmer could be confront one of their bad harvest season in history , after another month of warm and unseasonably dry condition . 
The state 's grain handler and marketer , Co-operative Bulk Handling , have earlier predict that summer subsoil moisture would help produce a crop of around 11 million tonne , despite an historically dry start to winter . 
But operation manager David Fienberg say the entire state 's yield could now be as low a 7 million tonne . 
`` What we 're concern about be keep farmer on farm and of course that directly relate to their profitability and of course that come from volume , '' he say . 
`` My gut feeling be that lupin be go to be considerably down compare to where they might have be give that early break in summer , I think canola also go to be substantially down . ''

`` Drought be a big one - a number of part of the country be in drought and that really do stuff up people 's ability to do what need to be do in the long-term .

Agricultural commodity price remain strong , with the Westpac-National Farmers Federation Rural Commodity Index up nearly 8 per cent compare to this time last year . 
Dairy be the only sector which have fall below last year 's level .

`` In addition , with interest rate around the world rising , do suggest it will be a soft year . 

Rig demand delay geosequestration trial 
Researchers say the first Australian trial of technology to try to trap greenhouse gas underground be be delay . 
The $ 30 million geosequestration project in south-west Victoria aim to test whether carbon dioxide from coal burn power station and gas mining can be store underground . 
The Federal Government have fund the project a one of it preferred way of combat climate change . 
The project 's leader , Dr Peter Cook , say preliminary test be be carry out but he do not expect to be able to start pump carbon dioxide underground until next year . 
`` A lot of people want to drill for oil at the moment so it 's a bit hard to get rig , '' he say . 
`` Also it 's a constraint on u that cost have generally go up . 
`` We 're not a major company , we 're a research organisation with limited fund so we have to be rather careful the way that we use those fund . 

Cattle killer think highly organise 
Police in Western Australia suspect there may be an organised network kill pastoral cattle to sell their meat . 
Seven cow have be report butcher on Pilbara station in the past month , and police believe there may be more which have not be report . 
Pastoralist Richard Climas , from Mardie Station 150 kilometres west of Karratha , say cattle theft be become a regular occurrence . 
`` I 've find a few carcass , generally only the leg and hide leave , and they 've take the whole lot , '' he say . 
`` It happen quite often . A good bull at the moment be probably worth $ 600 , $ 700 a beast , it add up pretty quick . 
`` What else be they do while they 're out there ? 
`` If they 're brazen enough to kill a beast what else be they go to be do while they 're out and about ? 
`` We 've have solar panel steal and all sort of stuff steal . '' 
Further north in the Kimberley , the state 's stock squad say there have be significant cattle theft over the past 12 month . 

Cane smut find on 30 property 
Sugar cane smut have now be find on 30 farm in the Childers area of south-east Queensland . 
The disease , which can cause major crop loss , be find for the first time on the east coast less than a month ago . 
Chris Adriaanson , from Queensland 's Department of Primary Industries , say the disease will not be eradicate . 
He say in the future , farmer will have to rely on resistant crop variety to eliminate the impact of the disease . 
`` It depend on what you define a eradication , '' he say . 
`` If eradicating mean biologically extinguish the disease , then that 's never be the objective , it 's not part of the way we have to do this business . 

Abattoir closure to impact on livestock producer 
Livestock producer in South Australia 's north say they will be hit by high freight cost , after the closure of Conroy 's abattoir at Port Pirie . 
The plant close on Friday and sell to T and R Pastoral , which have no plan to reopen it in the short-term . 
One hundred people be employ at the abattoir . 
Sandy Morris from Yardea Station in the Gawler Ranges say it will cost him up to $ 5 a head more to send stock to the meatworks at Murray Bridge instead . 
`` The impact on u will be that we wo n't have the option to send them to Pirie which be the close abattoir for u , '' he say . 
`` We 'd have to send them on to Murray Bridge , which would be double the amount of freight . 
`` I 'm not quite sure how far Murray Bridge would be from Pirie but it would have to be another 250 [ kilometre ] I 'd imagine . Probably look at something like $ 2.50- $ 5.00 . '' 
Meanwhile an abattoir at Stanthorpe , in southern Queensland , say it have to temporarily shut down this morning after temperature drop to -20 . 
The Bureau of Meteorology have report temperature of minus six at nearby Warwick and Applethorpe . 
John Allan from Don Allan and Co say the abattoir 's hot water system froze . 
`` We still have n't start work because the cold outside freeze the pressure of the steam inside our steam valve , '' he say . 
`` It just blow from sheer pressure , so that 's let all the steam out now , so we have to replace that now .

Dr Tiger say a survey have find 78 per cent of Australians rate a roast a among their all-time favourite meal and it be a more natural craving than those for sugar and fat-rich process food . 
`` Australian beef be grass-fed and a lot of the hostility to beef depends in part on the American style of make beef which be grain-fed and therefore much fatty , '' he say .

Just when many farmer in Western Australia think the season could not get any bad , there have be confirmation of a fatal wasting disease in a cattle herd .

There be claim today that the Federal Government 's complex fuel tax bill could spell the end of the biofuels industry . 
The renewable fuel sector say investor be be turn away because the bill have reduce it access to the market since it introduction on July 1 . 
Bob Gordon from Renewable Fuels Australia say the Federal Government need to go back to the draw board to make the legislation fairer . 
`` Unlike the rest of the world which be surge ahead with biofuels industry growth and all of those country that have emerge biofuel industry have high tariff regime to protect them against import until they 're establish in the market , '' he say . 
`` Australia be go in the opposite direction . Progress be go to freeze in Australia , if not bad . '' 
A Victorian dairy company say with the a grow number of biofuel project on the draw board , company will have to convince the Federal Government to offer tax incentive . 
John McLean from the Warrnambool Cheese and Butter Factory say his company want to use bio-gas from it cheesemaking operation a a dual fuel for it milk tanker . 

VFF group call for restructure 
There be call today for a major restructure of the Victorian Farmers Federation ( VFF ) . 
The VFF 's livestock group say it membership have fall from 6,000 to 3,000 and it may no longer be able to afford representation on peak industry body like the Sheepmeat Council . 
Group president Ailsa Fox say the VFF need to change the way it allocate it budget . 
`` There 's two way of deal with this question , whilst we need more fund , our executive officer identify that there be perhaps resource that could be share a lot well within the organisation , '' she say . 

Sheep theft may lead to more livestock truck check 
Police on South Australia 's Eyre Peninsula say they may resort to check every livestock truck on the region 's road after a grow number of sheep theft . 
About 1,200 sheep have be report stolen this year , include 250 head from near Wudinna this week . 
Senior-Sergeant Paul Roberts say all peninsula police station have be alert . 
`` It may well be that we want the staff to stop all stock crate that be move throughout the local service area and along the highway , '' he say . 

US wheat farmer sue AWB 
Six American wheat farmer have launch a class action against AWB in the United States , claim the wheat exporter 's dealing in overseas market damage their own income . 
According to medium report , the US wheat farmer be allege AWB engage in a global campaign of racketeering , money laundering , fraud and bribery . 
While some of the allegation relate to the Iraq market , others relate to deal in Yemen , Pakistan and Indonesia . 
The US farmer be argue for million of dollar in compensation , claim AWB 's action result in them be exclude from certain wheat market and damage their economic interest . 
But law Professor Richard Garnett say even if the action be successful , there be doubt about whether AWB in Australia could be financially liable . 
`` We do n't generally recognise judgment from foreign country which be punitive or design to punish defendents , we only recognise judgment which be compensatory , where a sum of money be provide in compensation for loss , '' he say . 
AWB , which have not yet be serve with the writ , say the action be ill conceive and the company will vigorously defend any claim . 
Meanwhile the first shipment of 350,000 tonne of grain through the Wheat Australia consortium be expect to set sail for Iraq this week . 
But AWB International say if there be a new tender to supply Iraq it would prefer to strike the deal itself . 
The Iraqi Grains Board have refuse to deal with AWB because of it involvement in the oil-for-food scandal . 
But AWB International chairman Ian Donges be hop for a change of heart . 
`` We 'll wait for that tender of course and we 'll be talk to Iraq in term of whether the ban still apply to AWB firstly , '' he say . 

CSIRO begin research grape quality potential 
New equipment be be develop to measure the potential quality of grape before they be harvest . 
The CSIRO have be research the link between grape and the quality of the wine they produce , use chemical and sensory analysis . 
It be hop the research can be use to develop bio-sensor technology , which will be use to test grape at the vineyard or weighbridge . 
CSIRO scientist Dr Aggie Cox say that should help grower receive fairer price . 
`` What we 're basically try to do be look for thing that we can measure to be able to tell u what sort of wine those grape can produce , '' he say . 
`` And the reason we 're do that be to try and make the wine a lot more consistent so the winemaker have some sort of idea of what that parcel of grape be potentially able to produce in the end .

Australia 's leading beekeeper be in Launceston today discuss the challenge of fall honey price and the grow threat of disease . 
It be estimate that the beekeeping industry be worth $ 1.7 billion to Australian agriculture , and at today 's meeting , apiarist from around the country be decide how best to allocate the annual half-a-million-dollar research and development budget to protect the future of the industry . 
Chief among concern be the threat of the verroa mite , which have already decimate the US industry and be find in New Zealand 's South Island just three week ago .

The first commercial timber harvest from far north Western Australia be destine to be floorboarding for Perth 's housing boom .

`` And of course they be look at two to two and a half , maybe three time the growth time frame that we be . 

Wwoofers on the increase in Aust 
Australia now have the large number of wwoofers in the world . 
The term wwoofing stand for `` willing worker on organic farm '' where traveller help with farmwork in exchange for food and board . 
Australia have around 11,000 wwoofers work on 1,600 farm each year . 
Jordyn Rettinger , a 22-year-old from Ontario in Canada say it be a great way to see the world . 

Fungi use in weed kill trial 
Scientists be close to understand how native fungi can kill introduce weed across northern Australia . 
Trials in north Queensland have identify 10 variety of fungi which have be cause dieback in parkinsonia , a weed which threaten 75 per cent of Australia 's north . 
Victor Galea from the University of Queensland say it be unusual to find a native organism that can be use a a cheap biological control agent . 
`` We suspect that a lot of these fungi which be in the soil be adapt to live in that situation and parkinsonia be not adapt so well , '' he say . 

Wool price increase predict 
Some good news for the wool industry today , with analyst tip good price increase in the second half of the year . 
Retail demand be down in key market like the United States and Japan , but economic condition in most wool consuming country be forecast to improve , which should see sale pick up . 
With most Australian auction centre enter the winter recess , chief economist at Woolmark , Chris Wilcox , say confidence for the rest of the year be high . 
`` We would expect to see a similar price gain to what we 've see in the first six month , '' he say . 
`` It be a fairly positive outlook , in fact Woolmark business survey result , the last survey we do be the most positive we 've see in nearly five year . And I think we 'll see more of that in the come few month . '' 
Meanwhile , the late figure from Australian Wool Innovation show wool production be set to fall away in Western Australia by about 7 per cent over the next year , with a minor increase in the eastern state . 
Although dry condition be affect most of the country , sheep number be not expect to decline any further . 

Study show more severe drought ahead for Aust 
New research into the sun suggest eastern Australia could face more severe drought over the next 500 year . 
A study at the University of New England in New South Wales have show a link between solar cycle and rainfall pattern , which can be use in conjunction with the southern oscillation index to more accurately predict drought . 
Associate Professor Robert Baker say few sunspot or cold patch on the surface of the sun may mean the eastern state be head for dry time in the long term .

`` If you 're not go to get away from where you live then you may as well make the most of what you 've get there and so yes I think there probably have be some more spending on thing like a DVD machine and a decent TV because they 're actually spend more week at home and less week away on holiday . ''

Investment need to control buffel grass : expert 
Control of the introduced pasture buffel grass be prove a major challenge across central Australian park . 
For the past 12 year , Sydney University student have assist Finke Gorge National Park ranger , south-west of Alice Springs . 
The control work involve hot fire and a new soil sterilant . 
An anonymous trust fund the majority of the work , but Professor Lester Burgess from the Faculty of Agriculture say there need to be continual investment . 
The overall program cost $ 10,000 each year . 
`` The buffel grass be continue to increase slowly overall in the park , but I think we have be quite successful in slow it in some area , no more than about 50 hectare and we have reasonably good control over a further 250 to 500 hectare , '' he say .

Stakeholders discuss quarantine concern 
A top-level meeting be today discuss how Australia 's quarantine system can be improve . 
About 60 government and industry delegate have gather in Canberra to examine a range of concern . 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) , which be facilitate the meeting , say the relationship between AQIS and Biosecurity Australia could be improve to ensure Australia 's competitive advantage in agriculture . 
While some stakeholder such a the New South Wales Farmers Association have express a need to combine the two quarantine authority , NFF president David Crombie say that be unnecessary . 
`` I think the really important thing be to make sure that we have the right people sit around the table when we 're put probability on the likelihood of occurrence and we have the right people sit around the table - and I include industry in that - of assess what the likely consequence be , '' he say . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say the Federal Government have drop it defence to ensure an open and frank assessment of the system . 
`` It will be a free-wheeling discussion and there will be different point of view because not all of the many organisation present share entirely the same approach , '' he say .

A European snail have be find in Australia , discover on the outside of grain container in Launceston in northern Tasmania . 
Known a white snail , they arrive on container of lupin from Western Australia .

`` When you come to think about it , there 's hundred of thousand of container come into the country and there 's always a possibility that thing will get through the barrier , '' he say . 
`` It all depend on what stage the snail be at when they come in . They could 've be in the form of egg , they may not have be develop , they could have develop during the storage process there . 

Scant rainfall dash farmer ' hope 
A forecast of heavy rain have end in disappointment for South Australia 's northern pastoralists . 
The weather bureau be predict fall of up to 40 millimetre in some part , but most property get less than 20 . 
Tony Williams from Mt Barry Station near Oodnadatta say it be an anti-climax . 
`` There be a big build up to this one ... but it be a bit of fizzer , there be good fall north of Oodnadatta , handy fall , but south down our way we only have nine millimetre - so very disappointing , really , '' he say . 
`` It 's be eight month since we 've have a decent fall . 
`` Around 30 millimetre would have be nice but maybe next time . '' 
Meanwhile , grain farmer in north-west Victoria be hop the weather bureau 's prediction of rain this weekend be accurate . 
There be no subsoil moisture on some farm at Ouyen , some farmer have give up on sow crop , while others have significantly revise their plan . 
Farmer Dean Munro be not sure what be in store for the crop he plant eight week ago . 
`` The stuff that we do sow only about 20 or 30 per cent have actually come up , the rest of it be still in the ground , thing be look pretty grim , '' he say . 
`` This weekend 's probably the last roll of the dice for this crop I 'd say . 
`` If we do n't get substantial rain this weekend it 's certainly in a fair bit of trouble . '' 
But pastoralists in the Northern Territory have fare much well . 
Every district receive fall in the past 24 hour . 
In the Alice Springs district , most community and station receive between 10 and 20 millimetre , with 54 millimetre record at Hamilton Downs Station .

Russia to open up beef export market 
Russia will open up it beef export market to international bidder due to a shortage of beef from the European Union . 
About 230,000 tonne of beef be need to fill the Russian quota , with Brazil and Australia consider to be the big contender . 
Prices for beef in Russia have jump 40 per cent since the beginning of the year . 
Andrew MacCallum from Meat and Livestock Australia say it be a significant new market and should keep international beef price buoyant .

NZ butter suspend from Europe 
The world dairy market look set to far weaken after the suspension of New Zealand butter from Europe . 
The European Court of Justice make the ruling after a German company challenge New Zealand 's import licence . 
New Zealand 's export to Europe make up about 15 per cent of the total world butter trade . 
Rabobank dairy analyst Tim Hunt say Australian farmer will feel the effect . 
`` Fonterra and the New Zealand Government be work hard to reverse the decision but if the issue be not resolve and trade resume within four to six month we 're go to have a lot of butter look for a new home on the global market , '' he say . 

Name change for sherry , port label 
Australia 's wine industry will no longer use sherry or port on their label to try to gain good access to the European market . 
Under an agreement to phase out the use of traditional European wine term , port will become Australian tawny , while vintage port will be know a Australian vintage . 
Sam Tolley from the Wine and Brandy Corporation say it will mean more freedom . 
`` We 've be able to use this a a bargaining chip to get good access to the marketplace , '' he say . 

Pulp mill integrate impact statement release 
Timber company Gunns have release an integrated impact statement for it propose pulp mill at Bells Bay in northern Tasmania . 
The company say the $ 1.4 billion project will create 4,000 job during construction and add hundred of million of dollar to the value of export woodchips . 
Environmental group be worry the mill could result in more logging in native forest , although that have be reject by project manager Les Baker . 
`` Not one tree will be cut down or one tree plant a a result of this project , '' he say . 
`` It simply transfer 60 per cent of Gunns export chip [ that otherwise go to Asia ] where it value add to a pulp mill in Tasmania . 
`` Woodchips be sell for about $ 90 a tonne where a pulp be sell for approximately $ 800 a tonne so it 's a terrific value add project . '' 

Indigenous community urge to take good care of dog 
With animal number on the rise in remote community , Indigenous community be be urge to take good care of their dog to help improve their own health . 
A national dog conference in Darwin today be try to unite Indigenous family and reduce livestock loss . 
Community leader , vet and health worker have come together to share idea , include the development of share responsibility agreement to attract funding . 
Dr Mark Lawrie from the RSPCA say that might help in a range of way . 
`` I guess there 's another over-arching thing that we 're look at at this conference too and that 's the concept of the linkage between violence to animal and people , '' he say . 

Giant pumpkin attract tourist 
Giant pumpkin be a major attraction at the weekend 's Kununurra Agricultural Show in Western Australia 's far north . 
Just under 5,000 people come to see the Ord Valley 's produce , include tourist travel across Australia 's north . 
Two pumpkin tie for the title a the show 's big , weigh in at 55.9 kilogram . 
The oversized vegetable catch most by surprise , include Gumi from Osaka , Japan . 

Rain band save crop in south-east 
There be plenty of smile over south-eastern Australia today after the first decent rain in month . 
A big band of rain from central Queensland to southern Victoria have save crop and put some water back in tank and dam . 

NSW 
Farmers in the central crop belt of New South Wales have a short-term reprieve , with fall of between 20 and 30 millimetre ensure the survival of winter wheat crop . 
But the best fall be in the northern and far western region , with the top total of 60 millimetre record at Louth , west of Bourke . 
Local grazier Wally Mitchell say it be great . 
`` This have be a magnificent rain change . Many of u have be push scrub , feed cotton seed , keep our breeder alive and some of u have even have a big punt , and join , so the little lamb be just come on the ground here and this will really turn the job around for u , '' he say . 
Parts of Victoria be lucky than others , with talkback caller to the ABC reporting fall of up to 60 millimetre in the state 's north . 

SA 
In South Australia , widespread rain be expect to keep the state 's harvest on track for a bumper season . 
The top reading be at Maralinga in the far west with 65 millimetre , but while most farmer be say it be the most significant rain they 've receive all year , others miss out . 
Rodney Lush from Coombe in the upper south-east be pin his hope on a good rain after suffer a dry June and heavy frost . 
`` It have n't be heavy rain , it 's barely be drizzle a lot of the time , it 's only make thing damp , it certainly have n't wet thing , barely enough to get my pasture growth go again and it 's certainly not enough let u go sow lucerne with any confidence , '' he say . 

Qld 
In Queensland there be some good fall in the parched west and south-west , but little rain fell in the south-east , where dam level be at critical level . 
Quilpie grazier Brian Rutledge say the 60 millimetre in his rain gauge be the best in six year . 
But Mr Rutledge say much more be need if the region be to recover from drought and lose it title of `` heartbreak corner '' . 
`` It have be dub heartbreak corner in the year go by and it be certainly live up to it name , '' he say . 

AWEX in backflip on auction room decision 
Australian Wool Exchange ( AWEX ) have reverse it decision to give up it auction room in Sydney and Melbourne . 
AWEX have want wool broker to take over the Yennora and Brooklyn site by the end of the year . 
The move be not support by exporter or Sydney-based broker , but Melbourne broker Don Fraser say it be vital to keep the auction room open . 
`` Our focus be on ensure that our client have a continuous selling arrangement for their wool , '' he say . 
`` Should AWEX have decide not to go ahead , we would then have take the lease back after all the broker do set up 691 Geelong Road . 
`` The arrangement will be a it have be in the past , which be a one year lease with a one year option . '' 

Copper explorer 's share halve 
Investors strip almost $ 200 million from the value of Queensland copper explorer Cudeco Limited yesterday after it reclassify the size of it Rocklands deposit near Cloncurry . 
The company be hold in a trading halt for 12 day while the Australian Stock Exchange query initial exploration work detail release to the market . 
Yesterday Cudeco be force to halve the size of the deposit because original estimate do not follow market standard . 
Shares in Cudeco , formerly know a Australian Mining Investments , be also slash by half , finish yesterday 's trade at $ 3.56 . 
Hartley 's resource expert Rob Brierley say it be a timely warning for shareholder in speculative exploration stock . 
`` Certainly it 's a touch of reality for Australian Mining Investments , it obviously get a little bit over excited , '' Mr Brierley say . 
`` It 's by no mean the end of the road , but it 's probably a little lesson that sometimes you need to prove these thing up in a little more detail . '' 
A number of investor in Cudeco have contact law firm Slater and Gordon about their loss . 

Farmers set to be compensate for vitamin price fixing 
Eligible farmer , feedlotters and feed supplier be set to be compensate over the vitamin price fix scandal of the 1990s . 
Australia 's first class action against a price fix cartel have be settle with three major pharmaceutical company agree to pay more than $ 30 million in compensation and more than $ 10 million in legal fee . 
The settlement still need to be endorse by the Federal Court . 
Lawyer Kim Parker from Maurice Blackburn Cashman say it be a breakthrough case . 
`` It be issue a a result of a global cartel be expose in relation to vitamin product manufacture by a number of different vitamin , pharmaceutical company include Roche , BASF and Aventis , '' Ms Parker say .

Bananas from tree which escape the full force of cyclone Larry in north Queensland earlier this year will begin arrive on supermarket shelf as early a September . 
The price of the fruit have skyrocket with most of the crop wipe out during the cyclone . 
Craig Allen from the Banana Industry Promotions Company expect the industry to be back to full strength by Christmas . 
`` The response to the news have be great because banana ticket price have be at absolute record level , '' Mr Allen say . 

Looming lettuce shortage prompt grower to buy new farm 
With a looming shortage of lettuce due to water restriction near Melbourne , one of Australia 's large grower have be force to buy land in another part of Victoria . 
Water allocation have be severely slash in the Bacchus Marsh district due to low storage level . 
Frank Ruffo from National Fresh Salads have now buy a farm near Swan Hill , on the Murray River , to obtain more secure water allocation . 
`` This be probably the first time in history that Bacchus Marsh have be so severely hit , prior to that we have n't really have a great problem with water , '' Mr Ruffo say . 

Tuna industry welcome poach report 
A report that Japanese fisherman may have illegally catch more than $ 5 billion in tuna over the past 20 year have be welcome by the Australian industry . 
The report by the International Commission for the Conservation of Bluefin Tuna find that about 8,500 tonne of tuna be be poach each year . 
Brian Jeffriess from the Tuna Boat Owners Association say while illegal fishing have cost them income , the figure show there be more tuna in the wild than previously think . 
`` That 's a large loss of income over the last 20 year , if the report be correct , '' Mr Jeffriess say . 
`` That 's a worrying situation . 
`` Strangely enough , if indeed it 's true , then it show the stock in a much strong condition . 
`` The way the science work be in fact that the more that have be catch , the more productive the stock be .

World Trade Organisation ( WTO ) director-general Pascal Lamy have be in confidential talk with key country include Australia , the United States and the European Union to discover their final position on farm trade reform . 

Sleeping disorder among mine worker on the rise 
With the Western Australian mining industry continue to boom , the number of shift worker suffer sleep disorder be grow . 
Mining company be operate 24 hour a day and the expert say many worker do not get enough sleep between shift . 
Dr David Hillman , from the Sir Charles Gardiner Hospital in Perth , say he be treat a large number of shift worker and there be safety concern which must be address by mine company . 
`` First of all there 's a decrease in alertness level , secondly our reaction time get slow , '' Dr Hillman say . 
`` Mood and memory be adversely affect , it just make u under perform so we become safety risk amongst other thing . 
`` It really be a massive issue for the Pilbara . 

Hay balers fail to meet safety standard : survey 
It be farm safety week and hay balers be the late equipment to come in for some attention . 
A recent survey by the Kondinin Group find two commonly-used hay balers fail to meet industry safety requirement . 
Engineer Josh Guimelli say farmer should be wary when purchase new equipment . 
`` A couple of the machine actually do n't have an upper walkway rail which , on a baler - large square baler - be quite a mission because they 're rather high off the ground , '' Mr Guimelli say . 

Researchers develop vaccine for de-sexing dog 
De-sexing dog in the future may just involve a quick vaccination . 
Researchers be develop non-surgical way to control breed without surgery . 
Professor Henry Baker from Auburn University , in the United States , be visit Australia and believe the emerge technology could help solve animal problem in remote Indigenous community . 
`` [ It involve ] chemical sterilisation , injection into the reproductive organ to cause their destruction and vaccine , '' Professor Baker say . 
`` Most people think of vaccine with respect to control infectious disease , but now vaccine have a new role to treat non-infectious disease . 
`` In my country direct injection into the testis of dog [ be show the most promise ] . 
`` That 's a registered product . 

Court decision loom over AWB document case 
Wheat exporter AWB will know this afternoon if the Federal Court will hear it case to keep 1,300 secret document from the oil-for-food inquiry . 
The company have claim legal privilege over the material , say it represent confidential advice and should not be see by Commissioner Terence Cole . 
AWB claim disclosure of over 1,300 document will expose the company to irreparable harm , even though the Federal Government amend legislation last month give Commissioner Cole the power to see the secret material . 
AWB say the new law be unconstitutional and Commissioner Cole will be in contempt if he use it . 
The wheat exporter want the Federal Court to impose a permanent injunction restrain the Commissioner from inspect the document . 
Justice Neil Young will decide this afternoon if the court will intervene to hear the matter . 
Meanwhile farmer in New South Wales have vote to continue their support for the single desk for wheat export after a vigorous debate . 
With the finding of the Cole inquiry into AWB still pending , farmer state their support for the single desk while call for good control . 
A motion be carry call for improved corporate governance within AWB and good transparency between AWB and it export arm AWB International . 

Nut grower look to overseas market 
Macadamia nut grower be look offshore for market for their near record production level . 
With fall consumer demand here in Australia , grower be take advantage of reduced tariff for value-added product which be introduce a part of the United States Free Trade Agreement . 
Jim Twentyman from Suncoast Gold Macadamias in south-east Queensland say tariff will be reduce to zero by 2008 . 
`` At the moment , because of the duty reason , we 're have to have that pack and process in the USA so we believe from next year we 'll be able to do the packaging and processing in Australia , '' he say .

Australia have negotiate a deal to supply rice to South Korea .

Sheep producer urge to make 'bare bum ' check 
Sheep producer be be urge to check for sign of 'bare bum ' sheep in their flock , because new research show the trait be more widespread than first thought . 
The condition , where the breech of the animal be bare of wool and have less wrinkle than other merino , be find on South Australia 's Eyre Peninsula last year . 
Australian Wool Innovation have be research the trait to find out if it can be pass on , and whether it could be an alternative to mulesing . 
Head of sheep productivity , Dr Troy Fischer , say the sheep may also produce good wool . 
`` Like with any trait there 's variation involve , but [ it ] essentially demonstrate there be potential to select for improved wool quality plus the bare breech trait , '' he say .

Australia have beat the world at an international sheep shear competition at the Calgary Stampede in Alberta , Canada . 
The Australian team of Rob Glover , from Bothwell in Tasmania and Jason Wingfield , from Victoria , beat New Zealand , the United States and Canada in a test match series over two day at Canada 's big agricultural show , which attract more than 1.3 million people . 
Mr Glover say it be great to get a win over the highly favoured Kiwis .

The New South Wales Farmers Association have withdraw it support for a ban on genetically modify ( GM ) crop . 
The association have pass a motion ask for the immediate lifting of the state 's moratorium on GM crop .

`` This be a technology that we have to have to be able to compete on the world stage . Without this technology we 're go to be sink further and far behind , '' he say . 
`` This technology be all about produce greener crop , clean crop , healthy crop , crop grow with 70 per cent le herbicide and be more friendly to our environment . 

Councils say water initiative hurting rate revenue 
New South Wales local council say they be face a dramatic drop in rate revenue a a result of the National Water Initiative . 
Under the water reform process , land and water title be be separate which be expect to cause a drop in rate for irrigated land . 
Councils now have to come up with a new rating formula to make up the difference . 
The Nationals ' Member for Murrumbidgee , Adrian Piccoli , be call on the State Government to give council more time and more help to make the change . 
`` The Victorian Government have postpone the implementation of these new council rating structure by two year , '' he say .

Foreign buyer warn Australian sheep too expensive 
Overseas buyer of live sheep be complain that Australian livestock price be too high . 
In the Middle East , importer be warn that live sheep from country like Somalia and India be constantly undercut Australian mutton in the marketplace . 
Jasem Al Dhahi from the Emirates Livestock and Meat Trading Company in Dubai say the price of Australian sheep have jump four time in the past month , and his customer be look elsewhere . 
`` In the last four ship now , the price get high , high , high , '' he say . 
`` I can not in the future buy more sheep from Australia . In the past maybe I buy 15,000 , the next ship I will say send me 7,000 . '' 
Meanwhile , another shipload of Australian live sheep have just be unload at the port of Jebel Ali , near Dubai . 
About 12,000 be now be hold at one of the Middle East 's most modern feedlot . 
The feedlot be one of the most advanced facility of it type in the Middle East . 
The condition be extremely hot at 50 degree in the sun , but under the 34 hectare of shadecloth it be a more respectable 45 degree Celcius . 
When full , the housing facility can accommodate about 90,000 Australian sheep . 
The most recent shipment arrive after a 16-day journey from Fremantle , with no evidence of foot soreness or too much heat stress , and be feed water that be specially cool by big refrigeration unit .

The transport sector be brace for even high fuel price , a a result of the escalate crisis in the Middle East . 
Analysts say it be only a matter of time before crude oil hit $ US100 a barrel , lead to bowser price of about $ 2 a litre . 
Luke Fraser from the Livestock Transporters Association say trucking operator be already find it hard to break even , and they will have to pass on the increase cost , with flow-on affect for the farming and export sector . 
`` It be go to be difficult , but I think that more than that it be probably go to affect the whole meat and livestock chain and indeed grain and anything else that be be carry in the bush , '' he say .

The recall will see 17 line of ready-to-eat product include shave and slice ham turkey and chicken replace , and be expect to cost the company $ 500,000 . 

Bagasse project 's potential excites mill manager 
Yesterday morning you might have hear Gordon Edwards talk about his plan to process and then sell Bagasse from the Mossman Mill to buyer in Japan . 
Mr Edward 's company Kristevefourspace have form a joint venture with the mill and the plan be to sell bagasse fibre a a healthy food additive . 
He say there be a strong demand for bagasse because the Japanese Government be push for an increase fibre content in school child 's lunch . 
Mr Edwards say if everything go accord to plan they should produce about $ 17.5 million worth of bagasse fibre . 
`` We currently have a joint venture agreement with the mill where we pay for all consumables with a percentage of gross on top so the mill ca n't lose out , '' he say . 
`` The value of bagasse powder compare to raw sugar be ten to one . 
`` Basically 40-50 cent for raw sugar , $ 5 a kilo for bagasse powder . '' 
He say one processing machine have already be instal at the mill and soon three more will be in place . 
Mossman Mill manager Alan Johnstone say he be excite about the bagasse project 's potential because the technology have already be trialed in Okinawa and he hop the Mossman trial prove equally successful . 
Mr Johnstone say so far only a memorandum of understanding have be sign between the mill and Kristevefourspace and nothing be in write regard the breakdown of future profit . 

Timbercorp , Costas launch Chiquita takeover bid 
Agri-investment company Timbercorp have announce it be involve in a take-over bid for mushroom and fruit marketing company Chiquita Brands South Pacific . 
For the bid , Timbercorp have join force with the Costa family to form a company call Tradefresh , which have offer 73 cent per share to buy out Chiquita . 
The Costa group already own 26 per cent of Chiquita share . 
If the bid be successful Timbercorp would end up with a 35 per cent share in Chiquita and the Costa family the remain 65 per cent . 
Bananas only represent about 15 per cent of Chiquita 's normal annual turnover and before cyclone Larry the company market about 12 per cent of all banana sell in Australia . 
Mushrooms be Chiquita 's big commodity make up about 35 to 40 per cent of it annual turnover , some from the Stanthorpe area in south-east Queensland . 
Chiquita manage director Mano Babiolakis say he have only just hear about this takeover bid so he have advise shareholder not to take any action until it have be carefully assess . 
Timbercorp be a specialist investment management company involve in the Australian horticulture and forestry industry . 
Timbercorp 's deputy CEO Sol Rabinowicz believe Chiquita would be a sensible addition to their portfolio . 
`` Both we and Costas believe that there 's an opportunity to join together the strength of the Costa group a one of Australia 's leader in fresh produce , farm management , pack , processing and marketing together with Chiquita 's strength a a category manager particularly in the area like berry , mushroom and citrus , '' he say . 
`` We think that it can sit together , they can become a more efficient operator . ''

Some Cape York Peninsula cattle producer believe far north Queensland property offer the ideal training ground for young trainee into the industry and they be appeal to the Government to support some sort of subsidised training scheme . 
The big side benefit would be property could access much need worker for dry season mustering . 
Yesterday Greg Jenkins , from Strathburn Station , bring up the problem of worker and how hard it be to recruit young people to cattle property in far north Queensland . 
The problem be young people can earn more money elsewhere and compare to previous generation , Mr Jenkins believe the youth of today be less inclined to work in remote area . 
Jay Willmann 's family run Yarraden station near Coen but they have only be there three year after come up from central Queensland . 
Mr Willmann say on Cape York Peninsula property the work be intense , varied and excite so young people learn the rope a lot quick than down south . 
`` I work in central Queensland a lot , all over station , '' he say . 
`` The big thing be they do n't have the variety of work that we have up here .

Farmers across four state have welcome the Federal Government 's decision to extend drought relief until next year .

Tiffany Lord , from Yudnapinna Station west of Port Augusta in South Australia , say it be impossible to underestimate the importance of the assistance . 
`` It 's help out keep u afloat , I 'm sure that it 's help a lot of other people who be in the same predicament out this way , '' he say .

Businessman fin $ 1.2m over abalone trade 
A Queensland businessman have be fin a record $ 1.2 million for his role in an elaborate abalone trading ring . 
David Wei Meng Lee be be find guilty in Hobart 's Criminal Court of five count of illegally possess abalone . 
Between August 2001 and March 2002 the 49-year-old received consignment of dried abalone from Tasmania at his Gold Coast seafood retail outlet . 
Lee be one of 17 people who be charge a a result of a police surveillance program know a Operation Oakum . 
The $ 1.2 million fine be the large penalty impose on any of them . 
In hand down the fine , Justice Shan Tennant say she think it unlikely Lee would be able to pay it all .

State and federal-owned corporation deal with road , rail , port and other export infrastructure be under-performing , accord to a new analysis by the Productivity Commission .

Federal Transport Minister Warren Truss say the review result be disappointing . 
He say the mindset within government-owned company have to change . 
`` Obviously we expect maximum performance from our service and our utility - that 's essential to build a productive trading arrangement and to ensure that our country be able to pay it way , '' he say . 
`` It be disappoint that some company do not perform well , . 
`` Of course the very act of corporatising a utility do n't make it profitable .

A new report by the New South Wales auditor-general show 40 per cent of the 74,000 hectare clear of vegetation last year be do illegally .

`` The Government and the Department of Natural Resources need to make it clear to those element of the rural community that want to continue to clear land illegally that the new legislation do have bite , '' he say .

A Queensland company try to produce biodiesel from algae be among the recipient of $ 10.5 million in federal grant for renewable energy project .

`` The algae produce an oil extract which can then be use for biodiesel , '' he say . 
The company want to commercialise a process which could be suitable for farm dam and irrigation lagoon . 
The big grant recipient be CSR Sugar 's centre at the University of Queensland , which have receive $ 5 million for work to produce a new sugarcane with more fermentable sugar suitable to ethanol and biofuels .

Countries aim to salvage trade deal 
The world 's most influential trade minister be meet in Geneva this weekend to try to resurrect global free trade talk . 
Six nation , include Australia , will be attempt to salvage a deal . 
Australia 's push to reduce trade barrier be receive support from local meat importer in Europe . 
The Australian sheepmeat sector be push for an increase to the 19,000 tonne sheepmeat quota in the European Union . 
One of the big importer of lamb and beef into France , Claude Thieblemont , say if import quota be lift , local consumption could double . 
`` France be very short of production , we supply 40 per cent of all need and we import 60 per cent of our lamb from abroad , '' he say . 
`` We would expect to import more from Australia because we like the Australian product . French supplier [ be ] buying five kilo per caput per year which be very low and we could multiply this by two or three , easily . '' 
Professor Andrew Stoler from the Institute for International Trade say world leader appear keen to agree to reform after this week 's G8 summit in St Petersburg . 
He say that should help to break the deadlock . 
`` What be go to move the process forward be not the sort of political direction that come out of the recent G8 meeting , '' he say . 
`` You ca n't really get any high level than that unless God come down and tell them you have to get a deal . 

Authority approve canola export licence 
The Grains Licensing Authority ( GLA ) in Western Australia have approve three small export licence for 75,000 tonne of canola aim at high price market in Europe and the Middle East . 
GLA chairman Wayne Obst say high tonnage be not approve because crop prediction be forecast to be dismal this year . 
Two application to send malt barley to China be knock back because of the dry condition in the west . 
Mr Obst say the authority can easily prove the restriction on export licence will benefit grower . 
`` These canola licence have go to a high price market , that 's be cause by the request for canola into the biodiesel market , '' he say . 

Much need rain fall on very dry region 
There be some hope for Western Australia 's grain grower today after rain fell overnight in some very dry region . 
While it be too late for farmer in the large grain grow district in the northern-mid-west , moderate to good fall far south will boost thirsty crop . 
Weather bureau forecaster Noel Puzey say the really good news be that a more wintry weather pattern be set in . 
`` There have be some reasonable fall to help people along at the moment , fall range from about six millimetre at Dalwallinu in the Central Wheatbelt to 20 millimetre through some part of the Great Southern and it be still move through to the east so mainly southern district can pick up a few shower around the place , '' he say . 
A group of Victorian farmer be develop a national grading system for biodiesel to assure it quality . 
With more and more farmer blend their own fuel , the Central Wimmera Community Enterprise group say the system will quash concern that biodiesel could damage engine . 
Chairman Peter Neiwand say once an Australian biodiesel standard be in place , the Federal Government will be lobby to reinstate tax break . 

US to scale back mad cow disease test 
United States Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns say his department will scale back it expanded testing for mad cow disease due to it extremely low rate . 
Mr Johanns say year of expanded and normal testing show the US be likely to have four to seven infected animal and reduce current test almost ten-fold to 40,000 a year be still well above international guideline . 
Mr Johanns dismiss concern the move will cause a new rift with Japan , whose food safety body want continued high US testing . 
`` We have bend over backwards with the Japanese , we 've even agree with them to ship only beef from animal under 20-months and that 's a very unique , very , very unusual agreement , '' he say . 

Qld mining sector continue to boom 
Queensland 's mining boom continue to power ahead with the Queensland Government nominate a large parcel of land for future mineral exploration . 
Labor Member for Mount Isa Tony McGrady say nearly 3,500 square kilometre will be offer under a tender system for prospective mining company . 
He say they will also get data show deposit of copper , lead , zinc and silver . 
`` As a result of the work they now have information on mineral prospectivitiy in an area of land big than the ACT , '' he say . 

SAFF seek help to boost membership 
South Australia 's peak farming body want farmer to help boost membership level . 
Only 65 farmer make the trip to a public workshop in Adelaide today to help redirect the South Australian Farmers Federation ( SAFF ) into the future . 
SAFF be ask farmer across the state to come up with idea to make the organisation more relevant particularly to young farmer . 
The organisation 's membership be fall there be currently 4,000 member while there be 11,000 back in the 1980 's . 

Grower challenge importer to buy Aust coffee bean 
An organic coffee producer from New South Wales be challenge Australia 's three main coffee importer to buy locally grown bean . 
Australians drink nearly 50,000 tonne of coffee a year and almost all of it be import . 
Organic grower Cath Ford say the industry have to demonstrate the quality of local coffee to consumer and coffee supplier . 
`` Quite frankly people will buy commodity fair trade coffee over Australian coffee if we can not get across that the quality and flavour be different , '' she say . 
`` We need to get on our bandwagon and show that what we have be a supreme product over other people 's . '' 

Scientists discover bug behind sheep mastitis 
Scientists have discover sheep mastitis be be cause by a different bug than first thought . 
The inflammation of milk gland kill 5 per cent of ewe in Poll Dorset , Suffolk and Texel flock each year . 
Dr Stuart Barber from the University of Melbourne have find mannheimia be the most common bacteria cause the problem . 
It be previously think staphylococcus bring on the disease , a it do in cow . 
Dr Barber say this new information be crucial . 

Sprouts can curb cancer : DPI 
New research have show eat the sprout that be often find in mixed salad can help curb cancer . 
The Queensland Department of Primary Industries ( DPI ) have investigate 22 different brassica , include broccoli and cauliflower . 
It have find sprout can contain up to 200 time more of a chemical which help dissolve carcinogen , than mature vegetable do . 
DPI physiologist Tim O'Hare say radish and broccoli sprout rat the high .

A new program tackle depression in country school be try to encourage student and teacher to be more open about mental illness . 
The beyondblue program come a new research show depression and suicide be the two big concern for country kid . 
And while student be most likely to turn to their family and friend for support , it be hop they will also open up to their teacher . 
Queensland school counsellor Gary Quinn say student at his school be become more willing to talk about depression . 
`` Most student , once they start do something to say 'hey help me ' , they really do want some help , '' he say . 

Fergies flock to flood festival 
The heroic feat of the famous grey Ferguson tractor be be celebrate in the New South Wales town of Wentworth this weekend . 
The Festival of the Flood will see 300 fergies of all shape be sizes attend to commemorate massive flood in 1956 . 
The fergies will be the star of the show because they be use to build levee bank to stop the rise floodwater and protect the town . 
Fergie enthusiast John Reeves from Geelong will be there and can not wait to catch up with others who share his passion . 

Website to track drought impact 
The Federal Government have unveil it plan to make it easy for farmer to apply for drought relief . 
The national agricultural monitoring system be a website which will track how major agricultural region be perform . 
While state government could take week or month to collate drought information under the old application process , John Sims from the Bureau of Rural Sciences say the new system will take minute . 
`` There 's information on rainfall , there 's information on how that rainfall affect pasture and crop growth , and how that translate into impact on say farm financial performance over the last couple of year , '' he say .

With Western Australia in the grip of a dry year , local council be look for different way to help farmer who be struggle to grow a crop this season . 
The Shire of Mullewa and the Shire of Chapman Valley will offer road work and community project work to farmer , so they can generate an income . 
Mullewa president Nino Messina say the council have receive extra funding for road work and employ farmer make sense . 
`` The harvesting will come and farmer wo n't be able to do anything because they 'll have no crop to harvest , '' he say . 
The Queensland Nationals be call on the Federal Government for good measure to protect regional medium diversity under it propose change to medium ownership law . 
The Nationals want the Government to set a mandate for local radio content and legislation to prevent a single company from own more than two out of three news service in regional centre , include television , radio and newspaper . 
But lecturer in medium policy and research at the University of Western Sydney Dr Tim Dwyer say the provision in the Nationals ' resolution fall well short of any sort of guarantee to provide a diverse range of local news .

Pork producer have welcome a new identification system to trace animal from pig pen to plate .

It be be roll out now and should be fully in place by January 2007 .

`` There 's get to be traceback . If we have n't get traceability well we 're not go to be able to export or do anything professionally and it will control the industry , a I understand , and the VFF pig group we 're quite happy with this , '' he say .

Top End water region to be map 
The last major unstudied water region of the Northern Territory 's Top End be about to be map and model . 
The Gulf region extend from Mataranka to the Gulf of Carpentaria and have a number of large , permanently run river . 
Over the next three year the Territory Government will uncover not only how the aquifer and river interact , but also measure how much water the environment use . 
Project officer Ursula Zarr say they need to know how much water there be so they can protect everyone 's interest .

The State Government rule out try to sell off it share of the scheme earlier this year , when the Federal and Victorian Governments pull out of the plan . 

Banana industry look at cyclone-proofing 
The banana industry be look at way to become cyclone-proof to avoid a repeat of this year 's shortage . 
The Australian Banana Growers Council want to strengthen small grow area , such a Western Australia 's Gascoyne to ensure customer demand can be meet . 
Cyclone Larry wipe out most of north Queensland 's crop in March , drive up the price of available fruit . 
Spokesman Tony Heidrich say market and retailer need to allow small grow area to keep a foothold in the market once Queensland fruit return . 
`` You 'll never completely cyclone proof the industry , '' he say . 
`` But what we 're say be we 've obviously get a real problem this time around in have such a big cyclone knock out so much of our production .

`` Farmers in New South Wales lock into contract for a 12-month period and do n't see the step-up payment that be pay out in Victoria .

Tas vodka win international award 
A Tasmanian distillery which export vodka to Russia have win two international award at the Wine and Spirits Fair in London . 
The Tamar Distillery , at Beauty Point in northern Tasmania , receive bronze medal for it citrus-infused dry gin and Tasmanian pepperberry vodka . 
Manager Phillip Ridyard say Tasmania 's pristine water help the company to crack into the tough Russian market . 
`` The primary reason be the water and the selection of the water because the crucial part of vodka be low calcium , '' Mr Ridyard say . 
`` And we produce three blend use three water , one from the west coast , one from near Scottsdale and a sample from York Town . 
`` We then hold a blind tasting with a group of expatriate Russians . 

Wine glut blame for price drop 
Wine price have hit an all-time low , with a major supermarket chain sell bottle of clean skin chardonnay and merlot for $ 2.00 a bottle . 
The move have send shockwaves through the battling industry , with the wine normally sell for $ 6.00 . 
The massive discounting be be blame on the wine glut and follow a trend set in the US in 2003 . 
Chief executive of the Wine Makers Federation of Australia Stephen Strachan say it be a very worrying development . 
`` I do n't think anyone in the industry would 've expect that we get to that point , '' he say . 
`` What it do be it undermine the strength of exist brand and it mean that the temptation for those brand to try and meet similar price point be there because they obviously want to be able to sell their wine . 

Farmers warn to watch out for food mile phenomenon 
Australian farmer have be warn to take note of a new consumer trend in the United Kingdom . 
Companies who import Australian beef into Britain and the European Union be wary of the new phrase 'food mile ' which could be use to limit import into that country . 
Food mile refers to the grow practice of importer and supermarket chain stack their shelf with exotic item from around the world . 
The criticism be they be chew through too much aircraft and truck fuel in get them there , thereby increase carbon emission . 
Retail manager from Global , UK 's big meat importer and also an importer of Australian beef , Bob Rose , say we need to keep an eye on the food mile phenomenon . 
`` In the UK at the moment , global warming be a very big issue , '' Mr Rose say . 
`` And one of the issue that have raise it head be bring product from around the world , and the cost of the carbon emission to the environment of bring that product from around the world ; would it not bet good source locally-produced product ?

A bid by Labor leader Kim Beazley to dump his party 's opposition to new uranium mine be expect to be a major talk point at the annual Australian Uranium Conference in Perth this week . 
Three hundred uranium expert , include 30 delegate from China , be at the conference . 
Uranium Information Centre chief executive and conference delegate Ian Hore-Lacey say a major change in political opinion could lead to Australia export more uranium . 
With current export go to Korea , Europe and Japan he say the next two big customer will be China and India . 
`` China be quadruple it nuclear capacity by 2020 and it 's go to need to import most of the uranium to fuel that , '' he say . 
`` India be another possible country but that 's much far out . 

Draft timber harvest regulation anger landowner 
Landowners in New South Wales be angry at the State Government 's draft regulation for timber harvesting in privately-owned forest . 
The result of year of debate , the code of practice aim to protect rare timber specie , and wildlife and biodiversity , on farm . 
But it do not include compensation for landowner . 
Robert Dyason , a tree grower in the state 's north , believe the draft code be a missed opportunity . 
`` We could have be present with a complete package of code , education and compensation for reserved area , it would have promote adaptive management with provision for improvement in management a knowledge improve , '' Mr Dyason say . 

Fire and factory closure leave 100 jobless 
Almost 100 job will be lose with the closure of a fibre board factory in Tasmania 's north . 
Carter Holt Harvey have announce it will shut down it Bell Bay plant , which produce the building product MDF . 
Operations there be suspend a month ago after a multi-million dollar fire . 
Andrew Eastick from Northern Tasmanian Development say it be a difficult decision . 
`` The plant have always be marginal and one of the difficulty for the plant be the market for MDF have move on , it produce a material which be only able to be manufacture down to a certain thickness , '' Mr Eastick say . 
`` Is the plant able to be re-engineered so that it can produce an MDF material that can attract a premium ? 

Fungal disease could wipe out WA wheat crop 
A disease that can completely wipe out wheat crop appear for the first time this season in Western Australia . 
The fungal disease stripe rust , which can reduce crop yield by up to 90 per cent , have be spot in the state 's south , near Esperance . 
Agronomist Phil Smyth say farmer be grow wheat variety with good resistance to the disease but this outbreak could be similar to the epidemic of two year ago . 

Two confirmed case of Q fever in NSW border city 
Victoria 's Department of Human Services have confirm two case of Q fever in the border city of Wodonga . 
A third person be suspect of contract the disease , which cause heavy flu-like symptom . 
People work with livestock be usually most at risk of the disease , although the two confirm patient do not work with livestock . 
Director of population health in Albury , Tony Kolbe , say it be unusual , but not impossible , for people who do not work with animal to become ill . 

Average rainfall expect right across Australia 
The Bureau of Meteorology say most of Australia look set for average rainfall over the next three month , although the north-east could be dry . 
The bureau say there be a 60 to 80 per cent chance of below average rain in the region from Daly Waters in the Northern Territory , south to the corner country and across to Rockhampton in Queensland . 
Elsewhere there be a 50 per cent chance of at least average rainfall between August and October . 

Producing , manufacturing cost high than expect 
The cost of manufacture good and grow produce have rise high than expect , add more weight to a forecast interest rate rise next week . 
Theoretically the big price increase for produce banana , grain , beef , sheep and dairy product should mean a pay rise for farmer . 
But the ANZ bank 's chief economist Saul Eslake say the jump in producer price reflect a lack of supply due to weather condition , high fuel price , and interest rate . 
`` Drought have constrain grain supply , the long-term reduction in sheep number across Australia have be a factor in rise meat price , rise beef price be partly due to the very good price that Australian producer have be get overseas and sugar price have roughly treble , '' he say .
