Suspension of trade talk cost farmer 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say the overnight suspension of world trade talk have cost Australian farmer $ 1.5 billion in potential new market . 
The G6 group of nation include Australia , Japan , the US and European Union fail to resolve five year of discussion about agricultural trade reform . 
Scott Mitchell from the NFF say the US fail to agree to further subsidy cut , while Europe would not drop it import barrier . 
`` All Australian agricultural industry be extremely disappointed at the suspension of the WTO [ World Trade Organisation ] negotiation overnight , '' Mr Mitchell say . 
`` This be a huge lost opportunity for Australian farmer to lock in the elimination of export subsidy , to lock in significant cut in agricultural subsidy be spend around the world and to lock in actual improvement in market access . '' 
Meanwhile Nationals leader Mark Vaile have play down speculation that he will now hand the trade portfolio over to Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran . 
`` I think that there 's still a lot more that can be do , a we 've get quite a busy agenda on the bi-lateral front with negotiation well under way with China and Malaysia and the ASEAN [ South East Asian Nations ] country and I 'm certainly keen to pursue those , '' Mr Vaile say . 
US farmer say they will fight to retain their current level of subsidy , now that the trade talk have stall . 
Lobby group , the US Farm Bureau , say farmer be not prepared to give ground until Europe offer more concession . 
The group 's spokesman , Chris Garza , say internal debate will now begin on the next US farm bill due next year , and farmer will attempt to lock in subsidy . 
`` What we 've see be , a these negotiation have go on country like the European Union have request more and more from the United States to give up , '' Mr Garza say . 
`` We feel a an organisation that there 's no reason to give up anything at this point . which mean we should not make any change to our farm bill so that when these negotiation do begin again , we 're still where we be before , and we still have something to give up if we have to give something up . '' 
America 's top trade official say the collapse of global trade talk mean the US presidential trade deal authority will now likely expire , before any WTO deal can be save and send to the US Congress . 
There have be a US push to complete a new world trade deal this year leave enough time for the US Congress to ratify it before the presidential trade deal authority expire next July , when the body could again amend any deal possibly kill it . 
US trade ambassador Susan Schwab say the bad will now likely happen . 
`` We do not expect to be able to use the current TPA [ US Trade Promotion Authority ] to enact a Doha Round agreement , if and when one come together , '' Ms Schwab say . 

Rare butterfly find in Arnhem Land 
A rare and endanger butterfly in north-east Arnhem Land be now a bit safer . 
The gove crow butterfly be previously think to live in only four small patch of rainforest , but now a fifth location have be confirm . 
Naturalist Ian Morris say he first saw the butterfly 30 year ago , but be only recently able to confirm it be the gove crow . 
`` It certainly extend it range by a few hundred kilometre , but probably do n't stop them be an endanger or threaten specie simply because the habitat they live in be so restricted and unique that any disturbance to that could soon cause a crash in their population , '' he say .

Community drought officer in Victoria 's Wimmera region be at a loss to explain why their job have be cut . 
Three of the four position be no longer be fund by the Victorian Government , even though the drought be linger across the region .

`` I be totally amazed , '' she say . 
`` To me it just seem the strange decision and now more than ever the community strengthening be need . 
`` I can not understand why the State Government would make the decision to wipe out the position when , a most people will tell you , that the situation now be probably as dire a it 's ever be . ''

The number of rural financial counsellor in South Australia will be scale back , follow change to the way the service be provide .

Uranium shortage force commodity price up 
As Australia debate the merit of open up new uranium mine , analyst say a global shortage of the commodity be push up price . 
The spot price for uranium have jump $ US2 in the past week to $ US47.25 per pound . 
ANZ Bank commodity analyst Andrew Harrington say half of the world 's nuclear power be currently source from recycled nuclear weapon leave over from the Cold War . 
He say Australia 's massive reserve of uranium be in high demand for nuclear powered plant , because recycled uranium be run out . 
`` Mostly it be to do with the renew interest in uranium a a commodity , because the recycled uranium from nuclear weapon be start to decline , so the primary source of uranium come from mine need to make up for that shortfall , '' he say . 

Quarantine boost follow marine pest find 
The increased threat of an exotic marine pest have prompt Northern Territory authority to strengthen offshore quarantine measure . 
The black-striped mussel have be find twice in the past week on seized illegal fishing vessel inside Darwin Harbour . 
The pest be find after the boat be moor . 
Territory Fisheries spokesman Peter Zeroni say quarantine check will now be do five nautical mile offshore . 
`` As a result of event that occur last week , we have make a decision a an interim measure to now inspect all vessel out at the five nautical mile buoy in open water , where the risk be less , '' he say . 
`` The risk at 1.5 be low due to it be an open-water environment ... however , a a precautionary measure we have move the boat now far out . 
`` From an NT Fisheries perspective , the risk be manageable where they be . We be concern about the NT 's internal water , water within three nautical mile and probably out to 10 . 
`` We have a strong interest in ensure those water be free of aquatic pest . '' 

Grain price rise a US turn to ethanol 
The rise cost of fuel in America be have a positive impact on Australian wheat price , accord to an agriculture publication . 
More consumer in the US be turn to corn-based ethanol , increase corn consumption by 15 per cent to 60 million tonne and boost price by up to 20 per cent . 
Richard Koch from Profarmer say the US corn price set the basis for the global feed grain market , which will have spin offs for Australian wheat and canola grower . 
`` I 've see some analysis that indicate the value of soft commodity in the medium-term could increase six-fold , '' he say .

Farmers say an oversight by Australia 's peak food regulator be allow fruit and vegetable to be sell on the Internet without new country-of-origin labelling .

However , with major supermarket now offer online grocery sale , the rule do not apply . 
Brian Bond from the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association say FSANZ should have identify the issue . 
`` It 's obviously be an oversight by Food Standards Australia and New Zealand and it 's something that certainly need to be look at and if we can plug the gap we should , '' he say . 
`` We need sale and I guess this area of sale be go to increase rather than decrease so it 's certainly something that need address . '' 
Lydia Buchtmunn from FSANZ say the issue have not be overlook . 
`` Actually we 've be address that for quite a long time we 've be look at the whole label standard to look at thing perhaps that be home deliver , '' she say .

Cattle producer in the United States be not hopeful of a quick resumption of their beef trade to Japan , despite a successful tour of US meat plant by Japanese inspector . 
The beef trade be await confirmation that US beef will again be allow into Japan after a two-year bovine spongiform encephalopathy ( BSE ) -related ban . 
The ban be lift late last year but reimpose after early shipment be find to contain trace of spinal cord . 
Jay Truitt , from the National Cattlemens Beef Association , think many producer and processor might not want to supply Japan again . 
`` I think there 's some excitement , obviously , it 's temper , because history have be a good teacher for u , that we should n't get too excited , '' he say . 
`` More importantly though , from our perspective , be that we really look at our industry and we begin to now look sincerely at what be the opportunity for u in Japan and they 're still quite limited and we 're not go to over prepare for it , it 's an expensive market for u to function . 

No growth predict for south-west WA pasture 
The CSIRO say pasture growth rate in Western Australia 's south-west be shape up to be the bad in nearly 100 year . 
New satellite data show growth rate be expect to be down 60 per cent on last year , due to abnormal weather pattern . 
The CSIRO 's Dr Steve Gherhardi say , a a result , many farmer have reduce stock number to give paddock a spell . 
`` Even now , if farmer have have a break , they 'd need to make decision on how long they would want to defer that pasture to ensure that they 'll get some growth occur , '' he say . 

Drought , cost force farmer to cut water usage 
The number of irrigated Australian farm have drop a further 13 per cent , accord to a new report by the bureau of statistic . 
In the year 2004-05 , just over 35,000 Australian farm use irrigation , down 5,000 on the year before . 
The report show less water be be use to grow pasture and rice , although more be go into grow cotton . 
Doug Miell from the New South Wales Irrigators Council say the fall be partly due to drought , but also because of high water price . 
He say many irrigators be focus on crop , which give them a high return , or sell their water . 
`` There 's obviously a consolidation happen right across agriculture in the irrigation sector , there 's no difference in that regard , '' he say .

The board of Australia 's two peak wool company be still talk up the industry 's future despite now have to look at way of join force without a full merger . 
Plans to unit Australian Wool Services ( AWS ) with Australian Wool Innovation be on hold while the Federal Government decide whether to help AWS pay off a $ 27 million overseas debt . 
Chairman Barry Walker be hopeful the Government will come to the rescue , but say the two company be look at how to integrate part of their organisation anyway . 
`` There be certainly major saving in run a single company , '' he say . 

Public interest test urge before hospital closure 
The Australian Medical Association ( AMA ) want all state government to introduce public interest test before downgrade or close any more public hospital in rural area . 
The doctor ' lobby group say after year of neglect , government should do whatever it take to keep country public hospital open and properly staffed . 
AMA rural reference group chairman Dr David Rivett say the test should examine how closure affect the health need of resident , local employment and the availability of other health service . 
`` We want to see the impact on the maintenance of skill of the medical workforce factor in , the impact on the health need of the local community and that include the social dislocation they have when they have to travel many mile to seek treatment , '' he say . 
`` We want to see the impact of employment on the community when people have to travel with sick child to the city and give up their job for day or week , and we want to see the availability of alternative resource all factor into the equation . '' 

US lamb market set to slow down 
There be a warning for lamb producer today that growth in the US market be set to slow down over the next year . 
Sales of our lamb to the US grow by 28 per cent between 2004 and 2005 to become Australia 's high value market worth $ 327 million . 
But Shane O'Hara from the Australian Lamb Company say export be under pressure from similar factor to here , like competition from cheap meat like chicken . 
`` We 've see some high fuel cost , that 's have a big pinch on disposable income , '' he say .

Fruit wholesaler say banana return increase 
A leading Queensland fruit wholesaler say he be surprised that banana be be blame for a high than expect rise in inflation . 
Economists blame skyrocket banana price , as well a fuel cost , for the 1.6 per cent jump in the June quarter Consumer Price Index . 
More than 90 per cent of the Australian banana crop be wipe out earlier this year when cyclone Larry hit far north Queensland . 
Peter Kedwell from the Brisbane Markets say while volume be down , return be actually up . 
`` Bananas [ on ] average use to be around $ 15 to $ 20 a box , now it 's $ 150 a box , '' he say .

Trip may have clear up river diversion concern 
Local Aboriginal people may now be more open to the idea of expand a Northern Territory lead and zinc mine . 
Xstrata be currently seek environmental approval to move the McArthur River five and a half kilometre , so it mine can become an open-cut operation . 
The company recently take a group of traditional owner to a coal mine in Victoria to see first hand what river diversion involve . 
John Moriarty , the chairman of the Borroloola Community Reference Group , think the trip might have clear up some concern . 

Farmer hop assistance package will keep town afloat 
The Western Australian Government have announce an assistance package for farmer in some of the State 's most severely drought-affected region . 
Farmer Glenn Thomas be one of 150 local at a dry season crisis meeting in the wheatbelt town of Mullewa yesterday . 
Although detail of the package be not yet know , Mr Thomas hop it will help to keep his community afloat through the bad farming year he have ever know . 
`` There 's different situation throughout the shire . There 's many in the outlying area that have really only have one good season in the last five or six and , really , that 's just not enough to get back on your foot , '' he say . 

Mental health concern switch to young people in rural area 
The National Mental Health Initiative have raise concern about the lack of information available about how the drought have affect young people in rural Australia . 
Craig Hodges from beyondblue say the last survey be carry out in the late 1990s and data be up to 10-years-old . 
He say the spin-off from the drought be significant , with about a quarter of young people affect by depression , anxiety and other mental health issue . 
`` We only get this data every five to 10 year and the last one that be take be in the late 90 which show there be roughly one in four young woman experience depression and one in six young men experience depression , '' he say . 
`` They see what be happen with their parent , how parent respond to tough time on the farm and that also may mean there 's less disposable income so that might mean they ca n't do the thing they once do , so the spin-off be quite significant . '' 
The drought be also affect young people choice at school . 
At Redbank Catholic College in the west of central New South Wales , 68 student from across the state be study agriculture in their final year . 
Just a few say they will go onto work in the sector . 

AWB announces restructure 
Wheat exporter AWB have announce a further restructure to improve transparency but say it be not a result of the oil-for-food scandal . 
Under the plan AWB International , which hold the licence for the single desk for export , will be far separate from the company 's corporate division . 
It will have an independent board and management team , and it own governance and committee structure . 
AWB chairman Brendan Stewart say the change be a result of feedback from grower group and grower and be not a knee-jerk reaction to the Cole inquiry . 
`` These change that we be make have absolutely nothing to do with the Cole inquiry , these be change that we have initiate 18 month ago , '' he say . 
`` They have be a long time come , they have be a process of detailed analysis and impact so that we deliver on the key promise that we give to grower . '' 
Mr Stewart reject any suggestion from grower group that it be too little too late . 
`` I don ' think that 's the case at all , '' he say . 
Grains analyst Malcolm Bartholomaeus say there be major flaw in the restructure because the wheat sale division will not be part of AWB International and still will not be accountable enough . 
`` One of the implication be that the situation we 've see with the Iraq inquiry and the scandal there , and potentially the allegation of other payment be make in other market place , basically that could still happen again and put the single desk at risk with no control over the situation by AWB , '' he say . 
AWB have reject the suggestion . 
Meanwhile AWB have cut it estimate before-tax profit by between 20 to 25 per cent . 
The company say the drought have lead to lower merchandise and fertiliser sale , and result have also be affect by difficult ongoing trading condition and volatile world market . 
Profits for the year end September 30 be expect to drop from a forecast $ 184.5 million to around $ 140 million . 

Wool company sign merger MOU 
Australia 's two peak wool company will press on with a merger , despite an outstanding $ 27 million debt . 
Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) and Australian Wool Services ( AWS ) have be in long-running talk about a merger , but the stumbling block have be AWS 's outstanding debt to a UK-based superannuation fund . 
The two company have now sign a memorandum of understand to look at the legal and financial implication of integration with work to start immediately . 
The Federal Government have be approach to help pay off the debt , but the company now say they will work together to solve the issue . 

Producers tell not to panic over Japanese beef decision 
Japan have lift it ban on US beef but the expert say Australian producer do not need to panic just yet . 
Japan will only accept US beef under 20 month of age and from a limited number of accredited meat plant . 
Meat and Livestock Australia say Australian export to Japan should remain steady at around 390,000 tonne a year . 
Malcolm Foster from the Australian Lotfeeders Association do not think the US will pose any short-term threat and say other market be available anyway . 
`` The alternate market to Japan be obviously other Asian market , in particular Korea , Taiwan and those market , although market in the Middle East and even market in Russia be start to open up now for Australian exporter , '' he say . 
`` So there be other market but Japan will always be a very important one for u . '' 
US cattleman be upset over the tough restriction impose by Tokyo . 
The National Cattlemen 's Beef Association argue Japan 's partial reopening be just a first step toward full resumption of trade worth $ US1.4 billion , before America lose the market to Australia follow a 2003 mad cow case . 
The association 's Jay Truitt say Tokyo 's limit on US cattle age and number of plant that can ship be far too restrictive . 
`` Everyone of these restriction add cost to the system - that 's not what we want , '' he say . 

Food price hit 15-year high 
Australia have post it big increase in food price in 15 year . 
Rabobank say the figure , which be be blame for a big jump in inflation , show an 8.3 per cent rise in food cost . 
But head of food and agribusiness research Bill Cordingley say the rise be mainly drive by soar banana price , with fruit price up a stunning 52 per cent for the June quarter . 
Prices rise for citrus fruit , apple , melon and strawberry , due to consumer demand for an alternative to bananas . 

AWB restructure not enough , say US lobby group 
America 's peak grain lobby group claim a major restructure announce by wheat exporter AWB be just for show . 
AWB have announce a multi-million dollar plan to separate it export arm AWB International from it corporate division . 
As part of a push for good corporate governance , AWB International will continue to manage the single desk for wheat export , but have it own management team and board . 
Rebecca Coleman from US Wheat Associates say it still want the AWB 's monopoly on export remove . 
`` US wheat do not think that it be go to make a difference , we think that it 's just another show game and a shifting of box , '' she say . 
`` US Wheat 's concern have always be the power of the monopoly board , the way that they function in distort trade and so a shifting of box around do n't change the monopoly structure . '' 
Australia 's peak body , the Grains Council , will not comment on AWB 's restructure plan . 
In the wake of yesterday 's announcement , AWB share fell by 33 cent but recover to finish at $ 3.85 , just five cent below the opening price . 
There have be little movement on the company 's share price today , and Austock Agribusiness analyst Paul Jensz say the market have react positively . 
`` With this restructure I think investor probably look at it a a first small step of a long road of recovery , '' he say . 
`` Investors broadly be say that this level around $ 3.50- $ 3.90 be the bottom of AWB at this point . '' 

Crop forecast 
Winter crop forecast in the eastern state have have a remarkable turnaround due to recent widespread rain .

Govt urge to stop river environmental flow 
Water shortage in western Victoria be now so severe that farmer be ask the State Government to halt environmental flow into river . 
With reservoir only 7 per cent full , farmer be face the prospect of no available water to fill house dam and pay to cart the water they need for livestock and crop spraying . 
President of the Victorian Farmers Federation Simon Ramsay say if there be not enough rain in August , water for river should be re-allocated to farm and home . 
`` The 2,859 megalitres that sits under the bulk entitlement for environmental flow would be good use and have a great impact to provide water for stock and domestic use , if need , rather than the sort of nil effect it will have flush down the Wimmera River , '' he say . 
Meanwhile Australia need five year of average rainfall to rebuild water level in irrigation storage . 
That be the view of Professor Wayne Meyer , chief scientist at the Co-operative Research Centre for Irrigation Futures . 
Irrigators have not have full water allocation since 2001 and Professor Meyer say ongoing low rainfall have reduce the amount of water available by a third . 
`` If you look at the storage situation it will take several year of even average rainfall to get our storage back up to those , for example , that we have at the end of the 90 , early part of 2000 , '' he say .

`` I believe the state ' opposition to genetically modified crop be purely philosophical or ideological , it make no economic or environmental sense , '' he say . 
`` Farmers should make the decision for themselves base on their reading of the marketplace .

A one in 12 year weather event be create an unusually wet winter in the north of Australia but dry condition in the south , accord to a Queensland forecaster . 
Dr Roger Stone say the sub-tropical ridge have drop below the Australian continent to the south of Tasmania this year . 
He say it be an important cyclical event which might explain this winter 's condition . 
`` It 's the second most important factor after the El Nino SOI system , '' he say . 
`` As people may have notice it 's be way south , it give u a lot of easterly or south easterly on to the Queensland coast , but also tend to bring in a bit more moisture than might normally be the case . 
`` It tend to get a bit too wet up around Cairns in this type of year , but it can help the situation in central Queensland .

In the northern agricultural region , around 13,000 lamb and ewe have be destroy and another 15,000 have die , because the season have be too hard .

`` People do n't make that decision light-heartedly , '' he say .

Egg farmer produce under the HenCare label will be audit to ensure they meet free-range farming , animal welfare and biosecurity standard .

An exotic marine pest have be eradicate , once again , from boat moor off Darwin Harbour . 
The black strip mussel be find on three illegal fish boat , apprehend in Australian water . 
Peter Zeroni , from the Northern Territory Fisheries Department , say chlorine be use to kill the mussel , but monitoring will continue . 
`` The vessel be treat in open water by a contractor with AFMA , '' he say . 
`` The chlorine we use to treat the vessel obviously affect the mussel . The chlorine will have go into the woodwork and be likely to kill anything else that 's in there . 
`` So we be pretty confident those boat be safe now . However a a precautionary measure , they will be re-dived every month , any vessel of hull that be moor in the harbour will be re-dived on an ongoing basis .

`` But that 's a very traditional package , it 's be around for hundred of year , so we have n't be all that creative . 
`` Look at how you buy milk , how you buy fruit juice , how you buy even tomato paste in the store . We use to buy it in can , now you can buy it in tube like toothpaste .

`` I 'm very conscious of the fact that Gordon should not be in any way , shape or form deem to have be involve in anything that 's go before u at AWB , '' he say . 
`` He be new to the organisation , he be a cleanskin in that sense and we look very much forward to him run the business a it go forward , and essentially the board , and myself , will be deal with any issue that come out of the Cole inquiry . '' 
Mr Davis will start his role in mid-September .

The mining boom have see record demand for aluminium , lead to record production of bauxite at Comalco 's Weipa mine on Cape York . 
After produce 16 million tonne last year , the company be on track to set a new record . To cope with grow demand , the company have spend $ 78 million upgrade it port . 
The main part of the upgrade be the installation of a second ship loader , which weigh 650 tonne . 
Weipa manager Rob Atkinson say it can fill giant ore ship in no time at all . 
`` The ship loader be basically a device which allow the bauxite from the stockpile to be directly load into a ship and then it allow the bauxite to be feed into the ship at a rate of about 6,500 tonne an hour , '' he say .

`` It 's not a very nice thing to do , to chop open a rabbit and take out a bit of liver , but we only need a little piece , about maybe a thumbnail size , chuck in a bottle and throw into a freezer label and then call the local authority responsible for animal or plant control and let them know they have one , '' he say .

One of the best season in year in South Australia have machinery dealer confident of big sale at this year 's Eyre Peninsula Field Days . 
High fuel price and low commodity have not deter thousand from attend the big event on every farmer calendar in South Australia . 
The Eyre Peninsula Field Days play host to more than 650 site of large machinery and rural supply along the outskirt of the small town of Cleve , one-and-a-half hour north of Port Lincoln . 
The season in this part of the world have be treat well , with some say it be one of the best they have see . Others claim the stem rust could be the downfall of this year 's crop . 

Kalgoorlie lack gold treatment facility , conference tell 
Treatment mill in Kalgoorlie in Western Australia be work overtime to turn as much ore into gold bar to take advantage of record gold price . 
This week the Kalgoorlie region be host the Diggers and Dealers conference , attend by some of the world 's leader in the resource sector . 
Analyst Dr Sandra Close have tell the conference that local plant can not keep up with the amount of gold be dig up to ship overseas . 
`` One of the actual problem we be actually see - I guess , in a way , it be a good problem to have - and that be there be a lack of gold treatment facility in the Kalgoorlie area , ' she say . 

Divided view on wheat marketing 
Four hundred delegate meet at the Agriculture Australia conference and all eye and ear be on a panel session - look at the future of the wheat industry in the face of AWB inquiry . The key question be should grower retain the single desk , and if so , should they allow AWB to continue to manage it ? The Grains Council of Australia , which represent state-based grain body , say producer want to keep the system a it stand until the end of the Cole inquiry . But a pressure mount from the impend cost of the inquiry , the Grain Growers Association , which represent 17,000 producer on the Eastern seaboard , say there 's little choice but to change . So what option should grower go with ? On the one side , international trader who want to get a share in the market say grower have nothing to lose . On the other hand , AWB have staunchly defend the benefit of have a single marketer a the best way to maximise return to grower . 

Grain dispute settle out of court 
A legal dispute over grain warehouse by Creasy 's Grain Enterprises have be settle out of court . When Creasy 's collapse last year , the receiver Ferrier Hodgson cite a 1933 High Court to claim title to a significant tonnage of grain store under warehouse agreement . The Whillock family from the north-west , with financial and legal support from the Australian Farmers Fighting Fund , challenge that claim in the court . A settlement of $ 97,000 have now be reach , return the full market value of the grain to the Whillock family , plus a large portion of the legal cost . The NSW Farmers Association take up the fight for the Whillock family and the president , Jock Laurie , say although a legal precedent be not set it 's still a significant win for the family . Meanwhile , Jackie Whillock have mix feeling about the case . She 's glad that they 've receive the full value of the grain , but disappoint the 1933 ruling have n't be overturn . 

Live at the Agriculture Australia 2006 conference 
Matt O'Sullivan bring you National Rural News today live from the Agriculture Australia conference in Sydney . 
MATTHEW O'SULLIVAN : Hello , I 'm Matt O'Sullivan , bring you National Rural News today from the Agriculture Australia conference in Sydney , the peak gathering for the grain industry . 
As you 'd expect the future of the single desk for wheat export be a hot topic , and confusion seem to be the common theme . 
The future of GM crop be also be debate today and , of course , there 's plenty of speculation about whether we 'll actually get a decent grain harvest this season - a the ongoing dry drag on , many part of Australia desperately need follow up rain . 
But everybody seem to be talk about alternative fuel , with crude oil price hit new high this week . Delegates believe it 's time the Federal Government offer new incentive to make the switch to ethanol and biodiesel . 
DELEGATE : `` I think there be such an abundance of energy in Australia , you know , they 're not very worried about it . They might as well just sit on their arse and not worry about it . '' 
DELEGATE : `` We 're not get any result at all with the biofuel . The Government 's just not interested to mandate it , and this be not actually go to get off the ground until it 's actually mandate , so it 's really up to the Government . '' 
DELEGATE : `` This issue be now on the table , it 's here . And we ca n't afford to be sit in here in three year ' time not really know where we 'll be and not pick up on the advantage that be there right now . '' 
DELEGATE : `` I fully support the biofuel concept in industry . I disagree with the fact that they 'll be get an excise and I want a level playing field in term of acquisition of raw material . '' 
MOS : Certainly , there 's a feeling that the Government need to do more , and the grain industry need to do more as well to get on the front foot and make sure that grain grower have a big slice of this market for grain . There do seem to be a concern that Australia be a long way behind other country in tap into the ethanol and biodiesel market . One of the speaker here today be Terry Reinhart from Advance Trading in the US . Thanks for join u , can you give u an idea of the industry in the US ? 
TERRY REINHART : Today , it 's about a 4.2 billion gallon industry , which compare to five year ago when it be about a 1 billion gallon industry , and projection be that by 2010 it 'll be a 10 billion gallon industry . 
MOS : So do a country like Australia have a long way to go to try and catch up to that ? Can we catch up to that ? 
TR : The good news about ethanol be it 's a 3000-year-old process by which you take corn and distil it into ethanol , so it 's not real rocket science , and if you have the money it 's fairly quick to build . You can build a 100 million gallon plant in 15 to 16 month , so it 's not like it take 20 year to develop this thing . 
MOS : One of the big concern here be from end user of feed grain , that it 'll be much more expensive and it 'll be hard to get access to that grain . How be the corn go into ethanol in the US affect the market there ? 
TR : To date , there have n't be any effect on the end user , because corn be still relatively cheap . Today in the US we 're over supplied with corn , which be one of the motivator to develop ethanol a a demand for corn , but down the road , a we continue to increase their production , we 're go to have to price corn a fuel a oppose to price corn a food and the livestock producer be concern greatly in the US also . 
MOS : That , I think , be go to be a grow theme , be n't it , that you have more and more different type of grain go into produce fuel and into produce food , when that 's a big issue ? 
TR : Yeah , it 's a big issue , and you can kind of sum up the whole thing if you go back to , I think it be 1998 , one barrel of crude would buy 4.7 bushel of corn and today one barrel of crude would buy 30 bushel of corn , so the price relationship strongly favour corn a a fuel a oppose to be a food . 
MOS : In term of the US industry , here in Australia we 've get a lot of different plant set up in small operation . There 's no sort of overall structure . Is that go to tell against Australia in the long run ? 
TR : I do n't know . In the US , there 's not much structure at this point either . The early people in the ethanol industry be the Cargills and the ADMs of the world . They 've be make ethanol for quite some time , but all the new capacity or much of the new capacity be small start-up operation , group of farmer go together invest in ethanol plant and there 's not much organisation today to all the ethanol plant that be out there and time will tell . My guess be some of these plant be build in the right place and some of them be n't , and we 'll just have to see over time which one be build in the right place . 
MOS : I see a story quote Sir Richard Branson say he 's invest in ethanol plant in the US . Are they start to attract that big business investment ? 
TR : Yes . Early on , four or five year ago , capital be a problem and you just work and work and work to try and find enough money to build an ethanol plant . To put it in perspective , to build a 100 million gallon plant - which be the one they 're build now - it take about $ 170 million to build that plant . Whereas five or 10 year ago it be terribly difficult to raise that money , today you 're hear story of people raise that kind of money in 30 and 60 day period . 
MOS : So there 's reason for farmer get involve in this to have some hope that it will take-off ? 
TR : In the US , I 'd say it have take off , it really have . And the limit resource in the US right now be plant capacity . And if we build all the plant that be on the draw board today , the limit resource be soon go to become farmland , enough land to produce enough corn to fee the ethanol plant . 
MOS : Thanks for your time , Terry Reinhart from Advance Trading in the US . 
You 're listen to a special broadcast of National Rural News from the Agriculture Australia conference in Sydney . 
Of course , alternative fuel have n't be the only item on the agenda here - an entire session have be devote to the future of the single desk for wheat export in the aftermath of the oil-for-food Inquiry . 
Reporter Alice Plate sit in on the session - and Alice , what 's the feeling about the future of our wheat export system ? 
ALICE PLACE : Well the feeling have actually change a bit . In the past , many grower , I think , have try to separate the single desk issue , that be , AWB 's right to veto other exporter ' application to sell wheat overseas , from the ongoing oil-for-food inquiry . And yesterday , at the panel , many of the grower group admit that change be now inevitable . 
MOS : They 're unsure though about what sort of system they want for the future , be that right ? 
AP : That 's right . Looking at the single desk marketing system , it 's not simple , by anyone 's analysis of it . Breaking it down , you 've get on one side the trader , other major competitor - CBH , Graincorp , and the like - all try to get into that market , say that they can give grower good return . And AWB , on the other hand , be say that it can maximise return for grower and give them security . But the Grains Council of Australia , which represent state-based grower body , say that the majority of grower do n't want a change from what they 've get . They want AWB to stay there . They want the single desk . On the other hand , the Grain Growers Association , which be east coast grain grower , say grower do want to know more about their option , that they be really start to question the current system . 
MOS : So be they look for more leadership from the grain body ? 
AP : That 's right . We do have a grower stand up yesterday and say , `` Why be n't you put forward option and recommend those to u ? '' And we have see the Grains Council of Australia , they have do independent report , also they 've look at the Victorian Farmers Federation 's option for the single desk , but they 're say they 're unwilling to analyse and make those recommendation until the Cole inquiry wrap up in September . 
MOS : Thanks Alice . Speaking of the inquiry , AWB have tell the Federal Court today it will cut by a third the number of document it 's battle to keep away from the Cole inquiry . Lawyers for the wheat exporter have tell the court that nearly 400 document will be strike from the confidential list , leave 900 still to be contest . And that hearing be continue in Melbourne . 
Here at the conference , reporter Michael Condon have be in one of the GM session . What have be discuss ? 
MICHAEL CONDON : One of the contentious issue surround the grain industry always be genetically modify crop , particularly food crop . Today we 've hear a couple of distinct point of view express . We hear from the the director of scientific affair for Monsanto . He 's actually address the conference a we speak now . Bit of a coup for the conference . 
He 's come from the United States say that he know that farmer already support GM crop . He say they get good yield . They use few chemical . They have high initial seed cost , but those be easily recoup . He 's say thatHe 's say that farmer be in favour . He do concede , though , that there be a bit of a way to go to convince consumer about eat the food that 's make from g-m crop . Monsanto , of course , famously put their GM wheat on hold for the time be . He say there be no plan to change that . 
But Mr Glick say he 's get a strong feeling that consumer will soon be convince . They 'll come to the party , he say . They 'll realise that g-m crop can do all sort of thing . They can put in special oil to reduce heart disease . They can have certain complex carbohydrate to combat diabetes , and g-m food also have less exposure to chemical in the grow process . So he say he think they will be convince . 
MOS : What about the food company ? What do they think about that ? 
MC : At this stage , George Weston Foods general manager be here as well . He be ask that question . He say at this stage consumer be n't ready . They 'd prefer to see the segregation process remain . He be particularly relate to canola . Keep the oilseed separate that be GM . The other , that 's non-GM be use in food . But he say too that he think that eventually consumer would change their attitude , and it be up to industry and up to research to try and find way of promote health benefit in GM to consumer as well . 
MOS : Thanks Michael , reporter Michael Condon here . 

Cole inquiry set to resume public hearing 
The Cole inquiry into the oil-for-food scandal will resume public hearing in Sydney in less than two week after delay cause by a legal challenge to the release of document . 
Board member of wheat exporter AWB could be among those call to give evidence from August 22 , although witness detail have not be confirm . 

Irrigators fin for steal water 
Two irrigators in south-west New South Wales have be fin for steal water . 
The state 's Department of Natural Resources claim a farmer at Euston be find to have extract more water than he be entitle to , while an irrigator at Barham tamper with a meter on a water pump . 
Department spokesman Peter Wells say the breach be discover during routine monitoring and prompt follow-up investigation . 
`` In a drought it 's more important than ever that everyone stick to the rule because the river be very stress the other user be typically on low or nil irrigation requirement , '' he say . 

Wool grower plan ethical wool brand launch 
A group of wool grower be plan to launch an ethical wool brand to try to capitalise on consumer demand for environmentally and humanely grown product . 
The Australian Wool Growers Association say new branding and marketing innovation be need to help lift low wool price and stop the loss of grower from the industry . 
Director Will Crozier want to see all sector of the grow , processing and manufacturing chain benefit from the brand . 
`` Our broker have be talk to people in China and Italy , '' he say . 

Fruit and vegie campaign push gain momentum 
An international push to encourage more people to eat fruit and vegetable be gather momentum . 
Backed by the World Health Organisation , the campaign encourage people to eat two serf of fruit and five vegetable every day be run in 10 country to try to reduce disease and death rate . 
President of the International Fruit and Vegetable Alliance Ron Lemaire say increase consumption will help grower as well a save life . 
`` In WA we know that right now there be 97 per cent awareness of the 'two and five ' campaign , they have already increase the number of serving by one per day per person , we already see improved health within that community , we already see reduced health care cost , '' he say . 
`` The producer also benefit through increase sale . 

Wine blueprint to focus on new innovation 
New innovation dominate a new seven year blueprint for the Australian wine industry which be launch in Adelaide this morning . 
Compiled by the Australian Wine Research Institute , the plan look at what consumer want from their wine , how grower and winery can improve production and how to ease the grape glut . 
Managing director Sakkie Pretorius say it will help the industry to stay competitive . 

Rural commodity price index up 2.5pc 
Stronger global commodity price be help to offset rise interest rate and the high value of the Australia dollar . 
The Westpac-National Farmers Federation rural commodity price index for July be up 2.5 per cent on the same time last year . 
The jump be be attribute to solid demand and dry seasonal condition in the Northern Hemisphere . 
Meanwhile the cotton industry be predict price to jump to more than $ 400 a bale next year due to demand from China . 

Surveys to try and identify Timor Sea diamond field 
Oil company work in the Timor Sea have discover that there may be diamond on the Tiwi Islands . 
Oil and gas explorer have find evidence of kimberlite , the host rock of diamond , in the ocean floor west of Melville and Bathurst Islands . 
As a result , the Northern Territory 's Department of Mines will carry out aerial magnetic survey of the island to try to identify new diamond field . 
Richard Brescianini , director of the Northern Territory Geological Survey , dream of find a major deposit .

A farmer at Esperance in Western Australia be fight to stop uranium exploration on her property . 
Yvonne Hallam take court action this week to try to stop the exploration application but her case be dismiss . 
She say she be worry about biosecurity problem from let people on to her land . 
`` I think we 've get the right to continue with the farming that we 've be do for probably 40 year , and people before u , and people after u without have to worry about who 's come and go , and opening , and shut gate , or maybe not shut gate and all that sort of thing , '' she say . 

More woman enter mining workforce 
The resource boom have lead to a more woman enter the mining workforce across Australia . 
More than 3,500 woman have start work on mine site over the past three year and now make up 18 per cent of the workforce . 
And Mitch Hooke from the Minerals Council say the trend will have to continue to make up for a severe shortage of worker . 
`` They be attract by pay , yes they be attract by the opportunity but they 've start to see that the macho image of the mining industry be not quite as stringent a it be , '' he say . 
`` Do n't forget woman make the best truck driver . 
`` I mean we 've get a couple of mine manager that be woman , we 've get an Indigenous female mining engineer .

It be a big day in Broome in northern Western Australia yesterday , with Ladies Day at the race and the annual bull sale . 
One hundred and thirty-six beast go under the hammer , with a Kimberley pastoralist pay the top price of $ 4,500 for a brahman bull . 
Tony Cooling from Landmark Broome say the sale be solid , without be outstanding . 
`` We have a very very good clearance , the average be slightly up on last year so both the vendor be smile and the purchaser all get the fair share of bull , '' he say .

A New South Wales beef producer have have a very successful trip to the Ekka in Brisbane . 
After a 12 hour drive from Singleton , in the Hunter Valley , Greg Ball have score win in three of the four category of the lead steer competition at the annual agricultural show . 
And the auction of his win prime cattle , set a record price . 
`` Twenty-seven dollar a kilo for the champion steer - I think that 'd be the most money we 've ever receive for a steer at a competition and I think some people be claim it a an Australian record , I do n't know , '' he say . 

Tassie camembert take out world cheese award 
A Tasmanian camembert have beat the country that invent it at a world cheese show in the United States . 
The win sample from the National Foods ' cheese factory in Burnie be up against 100 entry from all over the world , include the best from France . 
Chuffed cheese maker Kurt Wyss say the Tasmanian Heritage Signature Camembert be unlike any other in the world . 
`` It really stand out compare to other camembert a the flavour be a more fuller , earthy and a really , really creamy texture , '' he say . 

Govt accuse of sit on oil review 
The Democrats have accuse the Federal Government of fail to force the major oil company to meet their biofuels target . 
The party believe the Government be sit on a review which reveal the oil company be less than halfway towards meet their target of sell 350 megalitres of biofuel by 2010 . 
Nationals Senator Ron Boswell also believe the oil retailer be not make a big enough effort to adopt alternative fuel . 
`` I know fairly closely that from the time the Prime Minister call the oil company in , the oil company promise the Government that they would sell 89 million litre this year , we 're now almost in September and I would expect they 've sell about 10 million litre , '' he say . 
`` Now that be not honour the commitment to the Government ... and they need to be bring to account . '' 
The Federal Government have defend the oil company , say they be on track to reach the target . 
Meanwhile the nation 's peak motoring body say fuel price could surge to a $ 1.80 a litre by the end of the year . 
Alan Evans from the Australian Automobile Association say there have be trouble in the Alaskan oil field , Nigeria and the Middle East which make u vulnerable to a price increase : 

Forrest defend decision to abstain on migration Bill 
Former National party chief whip John Forrest say his decision not to support the Federal Government 's controversial migration legislation be base on his personal experience of refugee ' contribution to rural Australia . 
Mr Forrest resign from the position yesterday after abstain from the vote on the plan to detain and process all asylum seeker offshore . 
The Victorian-based member for Mallee say he have support the visa case of asylum seeker work in horticulture and local abattoir and have visted others in detention . 
`` We have literally get thousand of refugee live amongst u , more particularly along the Murray Valley but they be spread right across the electorate , '' he say . 
`` When people meet these folk and listen to their story , their perception about them change . 

Biodiesel price cut unlikely 
The country 's big oil refiner say it will not be offer incentive for biodiesel to match it announcement to make ethanol cheap at the pump . 
Under a new program , Caltex and BP will offer ethanol-blended fuel at three cent per litre less than regular unleaded fuel . 
Caltex government affair manager Frank Topham say biodiesel be too expensive to cut price for motorist . 
`` Biodiesel be significantly more expensive than ethanol for u to purchase , for the producer to produce and therefore a three cent a litre discount will not be possible , '' he say . 
Caltex have also reject claim that it be not buy fuel from the county 's big biofuels producer . 

Govt lawyer seek access to secret AWB document 
Lawyers for the Federal Government be fight for access to a handful of secret AWB document which it claim involve possible fraud . 
In submission today , counsel for the Commonwealth , Ian Harrison SC , tell Justice Neil Young in the Federal Court , the select material must be release to the Cole inquiry , even if it be privilege because it indicate evidence of possible fraud . 
Mr Harrison say AWB inflate it wheat price to pay Tigris $ 8 million , with part of this money be use to pay $ 2 million in compensation to Iraq for iron filing contamination in wheat shipment . 
Mr Harrison say this be a clear breach of UN sanction and fraudulent . 

Third party to oversee NLIS audit 
The Federal Government will appoint an independent third party to oversee an audit of the National Livestock Identification System database to address cattle producer concern once and for all . 
The Australian Beef Association lobby group fear the audit would be conduct in-house , and not effectively address it claim that the electronic livestock tag system be not work effectively . 
But Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran have release the term of reference for the 10 week audit and say he be just about to appoint a major accounting firm to run it . 
He say every major group will have a say . 
`` The Australian Beef Association will be contact and their concern will be completely and fully explore , '' he say . 

Wool grower urge to keep research levy 
Wool producer be be urge not to lodge a protest vote against maintain the 2 per cent levy which fund research , development and marketing by Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) . 
With plan afoot to merge AWI with Australian Wool Services ( AWS ) , some grower be worry their fund will be use to pay a $ 27 million debt owe by AWS in the United Kingdom . 
Chairman of WoolPoll 2006 John Keniry understand grower be hurt from the drought and low wool price , but say cut the levy will create new problem . 
`` Zero per cent mean that there be no levy income , '' he say . 
`` If there be no levy income from grower then there be also no contribution from the Federal Government and that mean there be no ongoing income for AWI . 
`` AWI would spend the reserve it have simply to finish off the contract that be currently in place and then turn out the light , which , from my personal view a a wool grower , would be a sad event if we just walk away from research altogether . '' 
The WoolPoll vote close on November 3 . 
The wool market remain steady this week , the eastern market indicator up just one cent to 742 cent per kilogram . 
The market remain unchanged in the west . 

New regulation restrict animal health work to vet 
Under propose new animal welfare regulation in New South Wales , a range of routine animal health procedure will be restrict to vet . 
From September 1 , vet will be responsible for dehorn cattle , and mulesing sheep over a year old , and castrate cattle , sheep and goat over six month of age . 
The new regulation also classify most equine dentistry a veterinary science , limit equine dentist to basic teeth cleaning and rasping . 
Master equine dentist and trainer Ian Wharton say the regulation will be devastate . 

Sunbeam wo n't renew currant contract 
Australia 's large dry fruit processor say it will not renew or issue new contract for currant . 
Murray Valley grower have receive fall return for the past six year , raise question about the industry 's viability . 
Under exist contract Sunbeam Foods will still have to accept 3,500 tonne of fruit this year , but spokesman Chris Ellis say the global market be oversupplied and it be hard for Australia to compete . 
`` I think we be hopeful that the Greek crop might be diminish this year or that some sort of political trading resolution would have come and the situation would have ease , '' he say . 
`` For those grower impact they 've get to find another opportunity . 

Wine expert predict grape glut 's end 
A leading wine authority say Australia 's grape glut will soon be over and it be nothing to worry about . 
Author of the Wine Atlas of Australia James Halliday say boom and bust cycle be a normal part of agriculture . 
He say like sugar , wine will revive . 
He have play down the fact that up to 100,000 tonne of grape be leave unpicked in the last Australian harvest . 
`` That 's still only 5 per cent of the total potential harvest , so it 's by no mean as dramatic a the headline would have you believe , '' he say . 

Aust firefighter help battle US blaze 
A team of 47 Australian and New Zealand firefighter have fly to the United States to help battle some of the bad summer wildfire in more than a decade . 
The crew be on a four-week deployment in the western part of the US , where more than 40 fire be burn . 
Jeff Pike from Victoria 's Department of Sustainability and Environment say Australian firefighter will have to work in unfamiliar condition . 
`` Most of their fuel be soft wood fuel system , pine spruce and fuel like that , '' he say . 
`` The elevation they operate at be a little high than here . 

Qld 's fine cattle on show at Ekka 
The who 's who of Queensland 's cattle industry be at one place today - at the Brisbane Ekka . 
The Ekka be play host to one of the nation 's most prestigious cattle competition . 
The cattle be bring good price at today 's auction . 
Numbers be down a little at the Ekka prime cattle competition this year , number of cattle that be , but there be certainly plenty of people . 
Between 200-300 have gather around to hear how much Queensland 's meat processor be prepared to pay for the cream of Queensland 's fat cattle . 
Already the grand champion pen of six limousin , exhibit by Eddie Nolan from southern Queensland , have make 250 cent per kilogram liveweight . 
Grand champion steer of the show , another limousin , make 305 cent a kilo . 

Noxious weed find to benefit salmon 
A Tasmanian scientific researcher be turn one of Australia 's most noxious weed into beneficial omega-3 oil . 
Matthew Miller have find that feed pattersons curse , or salvation jane , to salmon significantly increase their level of the healthy oil . 
Mr Miller begin use oil extract from the weed a fish food after identify the particular compound need to stimulate omega-3 production . 
`` Patterson 's curse have this really unique special oil and pattersons curse have the high level of this oil , '' he say . 

Snowy River to reap benefit of western water project 
A big water-saving project be be officially open in western New South Wales today , with benefit for the iconic Snowy River . 
The $ 28 million redevelopment of the Barren Box Swamp near Griffith will save 20 gigalites of water . 
It be one of the big project fund under the New South Wales , Victorian and Federal Governments program to boost flow in the Snowy . 
Murrumbidgee Irrigation chairman Dick Thompson say a natural wetland on the site be also be restore . 
`` We 've already see a lot of the bird life return , '' he say . 

Rural youth force to travel for abortion 
A new study have find teenager in country Australia be travel up to 100 kilometre to have abortion in the city , because of a lack of service . 
The report have be publish today in the Australian and New Zealand Journal of Public Health . 
Co-author Carolyn Nickson , from the University of Melbourne , say almost one in five teenager be leave their regional town to access termination service . 
`` Eighteen per cent of teenager have travel over 100 kilometre , 28 woman in our sample have travel from interstate , '' she say . 
`` Twenty of those be from New South Wales and 10 of those be from the Albury region . 

Cowra Abattoir in receivership 
The abattoir at the centre of a row over the Federal Government 's new industrial relation law have be place into receivership . 
Two hundred worker be lock out of the Cowra Abattoir in New South Wales this morning , and meat supply to local butcher shop be suspend . 
The plant hit the headline earlier this year when management sack 29 worker under the IR law , and offer to rehire them on different condition . 
Charlie Donzo , from the Meat Employees Union , say a new workplace agreement have be develop , and he be surprised and disappointed . 
`` This be absolutely devastate , not only for myself but for the worker at Cowra , '' he say . 
`` Given the problem we have have over the last three or four month , and the effort that the fellow have put into put in a new agreement in place to make the plant more efficient and that . 

Shipment fodder blame for livestock death 
The use of new fodder on four live sheep shipment last year be be blame for a slight rise in livestock death rate . 
Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) and Livecorp figure show small increase in mortality rate for sheep and cattle during 2005 , and a slight fall in goat death . 
Out of 4.2 million sheep export last year , 0.95 per cent die . 
MLA general manager Mike Hayward say that be largely due to the fodder , which be less dusty but contain less fibre and nutrient . 
`` It essentially lead to an increase in mortality because a more than normal number of the sheep fail to eat , '' he say . 
`` There be a high level of disease in the animal a a result of that lack of fibre . 
`` It be as simple a that . '' 

Single desk change 'would hit AWB share ' 
Investment banker JP Morgan say share in wheat exporter AWB could drop to $ 2.80 , if the company lose control of the single desk for wheat export . 
Shares fell last week to $ 3.36 , which be low than the company 's debut price on the Australian Stock Exchange . 
An analysis by the banker also show that AWB 's share value would hover around $ 4 a share if it hold onto the single desk but more competitor be allow to sell wheat overseas . 
Greg Canavan , a senior equity analyst from Fat Prophets , say that be not surprising give AWB 's experience in wheat sale . 
`` When you look at the whole structure of the market AWB , give it monopoly position , do have a very big market share , '' he say . 
`` If it do n't have to give that market share up then it would still be in competition with the other player come in . 

US wheat forecast continue to drop 
The US wheat production forecast continue to slide but there have be a sharp rise in grain price . 
The late US Agriculture Department wheat estimate be off another 5 million bushel from last month at 1.8 billion . 
But that be just a small decline compare with the 14 per cent drop so far from the last marketing year . 
USDA 's World Agricultural Outlook Board chairman Gerald Bange say the big story be a 20 cent price increase on tighten competitor production in Argentina , Canada and the EU . 
`` EU-25 , in particular , be down pretty sharply , '' he say . 
`` We can down 6.8 million ton on our estimate of their 06/07 crop and the reason for that be they be hit really hard by some real extreme heat in June and July . '' 

Farmers fear further chemical ban 
Farmers be worry the Federal Government will ban access to more chemical commonly use in agriculture , in response to last week 's terrorism arrest in the United Kingdom . 
Some say restriction on the ammonium nitrate fertiliser have make the chemical prohibitively expensive . 
The Victorian Farmers Federation say the future of another 84 fertiliser , herbicide and fumigant be be consider by the Government . 
Spokesman Geoff Kendall say because farmer already have to obtain training certificate for many of the chemical , the Government should not over-react . 
`` We understand it will be the farmer wo n't have access to these product , '' he say . 
`` Basically they 'll be ban from use them in the future so we 're very very concerned .

The Federal Government have previously reject any change to the visa scheme which allow skilled migrant into the country 
But the bank say the Government could introduce a pilot program , allow islander to spend part of the year work in seasonal labour job . 
Senior economist Manjula Luthria say the the islander need the work or some Pacific economy could collapse . 
`` Forty per cent of the population be youth and in less than 10 year from now , they 're go to want to be make the transition from work basically off the land to pay employment , '' he say . 
`` A small percentage be actually go to find it domestically .

An increased world supply have cut the price of macadamia nut by almost half and investor be count the cost . 
Up to 20 per cent of macadamia farm have change hand in the past two year , due to strong demand and sustained industry growth . 
But Andrew Heap , from the Australian Macadamia Society , say increase fuel cost and mortgage repayment have now hit consumer demand .

`` Most of those investor have be in a financial position to pay more than the agricultural value say these farm be worth , '' he say . 

Cattle TB surveillance program nears end 
After more than 30 year , the tuberculosis surveillance program for cattle will wrap up at the end of this year . 
The nation-wide program have be monitor the health of cattle in northern Australia since 1970 . 
The chief veterinary officer in the Northern Territory , Brian Radunz , say it be seven year since tuberculosis be detect there , and he be 99.9 per cent certain it have be wipe out . 
`` Due to the nature of TB you can always have a infection hide out there but it 's very unlikely give the fact that for the last 10 or so year if we have find infection we have be remove all the animal that have be expose to that infect animal , '' he aid . 
`` So unless there 's some undetected infection around we should never detect it . 

Logging detrimental to possums ' sex life : study 
The result of a five-year study claim farm and logging be have an impact on the sex life of possum . 
The mountain brush tail possum of north-eastern Victoria have be in the spotlight , and find to only have one mate in area which have be clear . 
Professor Jenny Martin , from the University of Melbourne , say monogamy be rare in mammal , and it be occur because there be few tree for sleep and eating . 
`` But at the other site where there be heap and heap of large tree with hollow , huge amount of food tree and most importantly that those two type of tree be very close to one another , female could have extremely small home range while still get access to the same amount of resource in term of food and shelter , '' she say .

`` We 've be very lucky because we 've have three inch - nearly four - of rain over the last six week and everything 's very green .

The Queensland Government have reject criticism of the National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) , after use it for the first time to track six potentially diseased cattle across three state . 
The system , which aim to achieve whole-of-life traceability , have be accuse of be inaccurate and costly , and be now subject to an independent audit . 
But Queensland 's principal veterinary officer , Dr Rick Webster , say the system have be use to trace cattle from a herd diagnose with Bovine Johnes disease ( BJD ) , avoid a costly eradication program .

`` Of course this have be make worse by closure of Cowra Abattoir .

Rockdale 's general manager Paul Trojah say the ethanol production will complement the feedlot 's plan for a biogas plant to generate electricity from cow manure . 
`` Rockdale Feedlock will be produce about five megawatt of energy a day from all of the waste stream , '' he say . 

Farmers question fuel package benefit 
The Federal Government have pump $ 1.5 billion into a plan to tackle high fuel price , but there be question over whether the farm or transport sector will benefit . 
Almost half of the package will cover the cost of convert and instal LPG tank . 
Grants of up to $ 2,000 for the conversion be available immediately . 
But it be not expect to benefit farmer because it only apply to private user , and most farmer use machinery run on diesel , which can not be convert to LPG . 
There be also concerns conversion will be delay because of a huge demand and limited resource . 
A three-year program to help service station adopt equipment to sell ethanol-blended fuel , have also be announce . 
But the biofuels industry would have prefer a mandate for ethanol-blended fuel and more pressure on oil company to buy ethanol . 
The Federal Government will also spend $ 123 million to encourage people to use wind and solar power over generator in remote community . 
There be $ 76 million to encourage more oil exploration .

The cost of phone line rental in regional Australia could rise dramatically if the Federal Government accept new recommendation from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ( ACCC ) . 
Telecommunications consultant Gavin Priestley say the ACCC have recommend a wholesale line rental of $ 7.00 a month for CBD customer , but $ 34 for major regional centre . 
He say that mean rental cost for line in small community could rise much high . 
`` What it signal be the average of the access price for telephone right across Australia be go to change and our bad fear potentially be go to be realise , '' he say . 
`` That be country people will not get parity and will pay more for access to their phone line . 
`` When the sale of Telstra be tout we be guarantee that we would get parity of price and future proofing of the service . This be certainly not parity . '' 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say it be concern and seek more detail from the Communications Minister .

Scientists be call on farmer to lobby for more natural way to control weed . 
The Co-operative Research Centre for Weed Management say the use of bug and disease to control invasive plant over the past 100 year have provide $ 10 billion worth of environmental and agricultural protection . 
Despite criticism that natural control method be too slow and unreliable , Dr Rachel McFadyen say the new research suggest previous effort have prevent invasive plant from wreck the environment . 
`` What we 're say to farmer be if farmer have get a significant problem year after year then they should be ask their agriculture representative and their state government member , be there a bio-control program against this weed ? '' she say . 
`` And if there be , do it have enough funding to get it go and if there be n't why be there one ? 
`` Because it 's one of the best return on money that they can get . ''

`` We 'd have to spray the weed within the plantation or we would have to slash round the outside of the plantation .

Under the practice of mulesing , skin be cut from the backside of lamb to reduce the risk of flystrike . 
Secretary of the program , Charlie De Fegely say the wool industry want to show it have ethical standard . 
`` I 've even hear of some contractor pay for their producer to do it simply because they want to have best practice and they do n't want to be part of hold the industry back , '' he say .

The sky around the Northern Territory town of Katherine have be clearer over the past 10 month , due to a mystery virus that be wipe out large number of native 'little red ' fly fox .

`` There 's possibly a roundworm and a virus , not know exactly what to pinpoint , '' he say . 
`` Flying fox be actually a huge ecological benefit to the bush around here a pollinaters and seed distributor and so the loss of those big mega colony that we typically have they can number up to hundred of thousand have disappear at least from the Katherine region . '' 
Meanwhile for the first time all effort to manage the fruit fly be be record in a national stocktake . 
It be look at surveillance , research and development , market access and trade , and quarantine inspection .

The new national agreement to handle exotic pest and disease outbreak be be question , after a decision to withdraw financial support for Queensland 's attempt to control sugar cane smut . 
The fungal disease , sugar cane smut , be first discover in south-east Queensland just over two month ago and since then more than 50 property have be put under quarantine , disrupt harvest and put strict protocol on local grower . 
As a signatory to the new Emergency Plant Pest Response Deed under Plant Health Australia , canegrowers be anticipate federal and state government would pay 80 per cent of the $ 43 million emergency response plan . 
But the National Management Group ( NMG ) vote against the proposal , suggest the disease could not be eradicate or contain . 
Isis Canegrowers chairman Joe Russo say the decision have shock the cane grow community . 
`` It 's no different from when you 're tell you first have smut , you 're somewhat quite gutted to hear the response to what NMG have come down with , '' he say .

Future growth in agriculture depend on export : ABARE 
The Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) say most of the future growth in Australian agriculture will depend on export . 
The peak commodity forecaster have release a report show agriculture 's contribution to gross domestic product ( GDP ) have fall from around 3.6 per cent in the early 1980s to 2.7 per cent in the year lead up to 2005 . 
That be mainly due to the growth in the service , mining and manufacturing sector . 
ABARE spokeswoman Lisa Elliston say while agriculture continue to expand , it need to focus on international market because the domestic market be so small . 
`` In particular that mean that we have to focus on thing like barrier to trade , so that we have tariff and import quota that continue to be an important issue , '' she say .

A Senate inquiry into water have be tell that successive Queensland government have ignore the advice of expert scientist , to create what be possibly the 'worst environmental disaster in inland Australia ' on the Culgoa Balonne floodplain in northern New South Wales . 
NSW farmer Ed Fessey tell the Senate 's Rural and Regional Affairs Committee that over extraction of water in Queensland be destroy both the environment and the livelihood of those on the Culgoa floodplain . 
`` This be highlight by the flippant , nonchalant and at time dismissive attitude that successive Queensland Natural Resources to due process ; the complete ignorance of a very strong and detailed submission by the New South Wales Government in 2004 ; the very select use of Peter Cullen 's scientific report to endorse their plan , whilst ignore the clear warning that significant ecological problem will occur , '' he say . 

Grim outlook for SA grain harvest 
A warm and windy day in South Australia yesterday have not help what be look set to be a decent season for grain grower . 
The grain harvest will now be well below average this year , unless there be significant rain in the next two week . 
Peter Fulwood from Rural Solutions South Australia say the state be head for it dry winter on record . 
`` If we do n't get substantial rain in the next couple of week , we could be look at one of , if not the dry , winter on record and then we go into our spring weather where temperature can rapidly rise in those month and we can get drying wind , crop can come under extreme moisture stress , '' he say . 
`` Overall , the state crop certainly wo n't be anything above average unless we be to get a complete change in the weather . The estimate we would be look at would be below average . '' 
Unusual weather pattern in Australia and overseas be put new pressure on global grain price . 
Dry weather in Western Australia mean grain handler CBH will not be export lupin this year , to ensure stock feed supply into 2007 .

The authority 's David Loschke say the plan include national regulation for label and handle pesticide .
