Scientists map DNA sequence for bovine animal 
Scientists have finish a five-year project to build a genetic map of bovine animal , which be expect to lead to good cattle production , breeding and disease control . 
The $ 70 million project to map the DNA sequence be a joint effort between Australia , New Zealand , Canada and the United States . 
Dr Chris Prideaux from the CSIRO say it be now time to apply the science . 
`` Really this map will speed up the roll-out of thing like genetic marker , such trait a meat tenderness [ and ] for marbling , '' he say . 

Winemakers pay tribute to Len Evans 
One of the great name of the Australian wine industry have die at the age of 75 . 
Wine judge and writer Len Evans be credit with bring Australian wine to prominence on the world stage , by encourage a move away from fortified variety into other blend . 
In 1968 , Mr Evans found the Rothbury Estate in the Hunter Valley with Murray Tyrrell . 
Mr Tyrrell 's son , Bruce , say his father 's friend be instrumental in build Australia 's wine export industry . 
`` He be certainly a very important cog in what wheel , there 's no question or doubt about that , '' he say . 
`` Len be a large than life personality , and he be one of those people that no door be ever lock to , because if it be , he just open it and walk through it . 

Fed Govt to contribute to wetland restoration in NSW 
The Federal Government will help to fund work to restore two major wetland in New South Wales . 

Rural woman 's isolation a key topic in youth survey 
The isolation of woman have emerge a a big issue in a national survey of youth in rural Australia this week . 
Workshops be be hold in five state a part of the Year of the Outback , to identify key issue and find some answer . 
Coordinator Fiona Campbell-Maybury , say woman want some kind of network to help them get access to resource . 
`` They be not necessarily suggest that the resource be not there , what they 're suggest be that they 're not necessarily aware of them , '' she say . 

Wave Hill walk-off celebration under way 
It have be 40 year since the Wave Hill walk-off , a protest which lead to the Indigenous right movement in Australia . 
Celebrations have begin in the remote Northern Territory of Kalkaringi , 800km south-west of Darwin . 
An overwhelming mood of friendship and reconciliation bind more than 1,500 people gather by the Victoria River , the site where stockman Vincent Lingiari lead his people on strike in 1966 . 
Originally protest against the pay condition on nearby Wave Hill Station , the nine-year strike soon become a battle for land right . 
Among the crowd today be descendant of the original Gurindgi striker , pastoralists , politician and visitor from across the country . 
As part of the festival an agreement be be sign between the Northern Territory Cattlemen 's Association , the Northern Territory Government , the Land Councils and the Indigenous Land Corporation to boost Aboriginal participation in the pastoral industry . 

NZ stone fruit grower get WA access 
New Zealand stone fruit grower will be allow to sell their fruit into market in Western Australia , six year after apply for access . 
Biosecurity Australia have make the decision in a risk import analysis , as long a fruit be fumigate and inspect to keep pest out of WA . 
Peter Gubler from the WA Summerfruit Council say he be concern , but do not expect import to have a major impact , in a market where price be already low than in the eastern state . 
`` Money wise , the commodity like peach and nectarine , I do n't think they 'll benefit from that because of the low return that grower here in the state get anyway , '' he say . 

Apple , pear industry unveils competitiveness plan 
The apple and pear industry have launch an ambitious research program to make Australian orchard globally competitive . 
The million-dollar program , Future Orchards 2012 , be unveil in Hobart this morning . 
Years of rise production cost and low price have leave Australian apple and pear grower fight for survival . 
The industry have to reduce cost while increase the amount of fruit harvest per hectare , and Future Orchards 2012 should prove it can be do . 
The current yield be 20 tonne of fruit per hectare from an average of 640 tree . 
Under the plan tonnage would more than double and high density plant would almost triple the amount of tree . 
The intensive orcharding would also be capital intensive , cost up to $ 60,000 a hectare . 

Labor 's ethanol pledge get mixed response 
There have be a mixed response in Queensland to Labor 's election promise to make all petrol include 5 per cent ethanol . 
Premier Peter Beattie say the mandate would increase to 10 per cent after 2010 . 
The Premier say the 5 per cent mandate will increase the use of ethanol 20-fold , to over 200 million litre , in a year . 
The Opposition say it be their policy five year ago . 
Grain grower on the Darling Downs say it be good news , a they have plan to build an ethanol plant at Dalby which will consume 400,000 tonne of sorghum and produce 160 million litre . 
The petrol company Caltex and BP be less supportive of a mandate and the RACQ say there be no evidence that ethanol blend be be sell at price below normal petrol . 

Red wine fail to meet Chinese standard 
China have reject more than 10,000 bottle of Australian red wine because it contain too much of the preservative sulphur dioxide . 
The 840 carton be reject by Chinese custom authority at the port of Shenzhen . 
It be understood the wine be bottle in 2003 by a winemaker from New South Wales , whose name be be keep under wrap . 
Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation chief executive Sam Tolley say the wine have be knock back because it do not meet Chinese standard . 
`` So when the sulphur be add to the wine , the blend be n't mixed thoroughly , so there 's some part of the wine that have this high sulphur content and the rest would have low , '' he say . 

Lamb industry thrive despite drought 
Although the prime lamb industry be in it fifth year of severe drought , the number of new season lamb come into the market be expect to rise another 3 per cent in the next 12 month . 
Meat and Livestock Australia say that be due to a 16 per cent jump in second-cross lamb , which be produce for meat . 
And there have be a dramatic fall in the price of cattle contract on the Sydney Futures Exchange . 

Farmers predict crop failure within week 
Farmers in Victoria 's Wimmera Mallee grain grow region say if it do not rain within two week their crop will fail . 
The effect of a lack of rain have be make worse by a run of frost and strong drying wind . 
Neil Simpson who have plant 1,500 hectare of wheat at Berriwillock in the southern Mallee say the early sown crop be already die and it be look bleak for the rest . 
`` Assuming that there be n't further rain , the late crop will also fail and they may not even produce a head in the circumstance so the outlook be certainly very dismal at this point and continue to deteriorate , '' he say . 

Nickel shortage cause panic 
The London Metal Exchange be force to intervene in the nickel market last night for the first time since the 1980s , to curb panic buying among metal trader . 
Analysts predict there be only enough nickel leave on the exchange to cover one day of world consumption . 
Supplies have shrink because of a strike at the world 's large nickel mine at Voisey 's Bay in Canada . 
In Australia , share in nickel mining company have skyrocket , a speculator predict the situation will not ease in the short term . 
Commonwealth Bank commodity strategist Tobin Gorey predict the market tightness will continue to force up price . 
`` In term of supply be tight yes it will [ force price up ] . Whether it be actually so tight that people ca n't complete transaction be another matter , that 's really what define the current circumstance , '' he say . 

Plan aim to tackle climate change impact on agriculture 
The federal , state and territory government have unveil a national action plan to tackle the affect of climate change on agriculture . 
It be design to help farmer adapt to a change climate , mitigate and prevent the impact of change , provide good research and development and increase awareness . 
While there be no funding or specific project yet , Ben Fargher from the National Farmers Federation say it be a significant step . 

Australia on track for driest August on record 
The National Climate Centre say we could be shape up for another major drought year if it do not rain soon . 
Australia be on track for it dry August on record , with an average of just 2.6 millimetre of rain so far this month , compare to the low recorded total of 7.1 millimetre . 
Meteorologist Blair Trewin say while south-west WA be in trouble , the eastern state be in a slightly good position because of rain last month . 
`` [ It ] certainly have n't be as dry a year like 1994 and 2002 generally speak , '' he aid . 
`` If we be to have a very dry September/October period then we might start get down into the kind of territory we saw in 1994 and 2002 , but our outlook be not currently indicate a particularly high chance of that happen . '' 

Growers fear Coles Myer takeover 
Fruit and vegetable grower be concern a foreign takeover of Coles Myer could squeeze them out of the market . 
A US-based consortium have launch a bid to buy the retail giant . 
Michael Badcock , from AUSVEG , fear a sale would leave producer at the whim of major international corporation . 
`` The big problem we 've get in Australia be that we have two major supermarket chain and that 's it , who control about 70 per cent of Australia 's market , '' he say . 
`` If one of these be take over by a big world player - and they 're quite ruthless in the way they cut cost and cut staff and everything else - if one do it the other one would do it . 
`` That would be a disaster for producer in Australia . '' 
The Federal Government can reject takeover that be deem not to be in the national interest . 
But Griffith University 's Tony Makin say even with lobbying , farmer be unlikely to stop a takeover bid . 

GE rice contaminate US crop 
The US agriculture secretary say US supply of long-grain rice be contaminate with a genetically-engineered variety which have not be approve for human use . 
Mike Johanns have announce that Bayer CropScience of Germany have tell the US Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) and the US Food and Drug Administration that the experimental rice pose no threat to human or the environment . 
But Mr Johanns do not know where the contaminated rice be find , how widespread it be , or how it enter the food supply . 
As for US customer , Mr Johanns say he be `` be provide information to my colleague '' . 
`` I 'm talk to them . I have indicate to them that we will provide whatever information they need , '' he say . 
Testing kit will be supply if require and USDA will investigate . 

Court to rule on wallaby cull 
Plans to cull wallaby on the two big island in Bass Strait be be challenge in the Federal Administrative Appeals Tribunal . 
The Wildlife Protection Association of Australia want to stop approve federal management plan , which allow farmer to shoot and export wallaby on King and Flinders island . 
President Pat O'Brien allege the plan allow inhumane killing of joeys , breach the national rifle code and misjudge the size of the wallaby population . 
He hop the case will reveal critical information . 
`` In the last appeal we have in New South Wales we find out that both Western Australia , South Australia and Queensland have overshoot their quota by about 15,000 animal , '' he say . 
`` But they would n't tell u unless we sort of have them in court and have them on oath . 

Land Rights Act change please fisherman 
Land right claim over some inter-tidal area on the Northern Territory coastline will be automatically terminate by change to the federal Land Rights Act . 
The move affect claim win more than three year ago through the High Court and have be label `` un-Australian '' by the Northern Land Council . 
But Iain Smith , from the Territory 's Seafood Council , have welcome the change . 
He say some claim have big ramification . 
`` If at some future stage a court decide that while water be over Aboriginal land the water and the animal in it belong to the relevant land trust - it be freehold title - then of course we would be totally exclude from the area unless we pay a fee , '' he say .

There be a call today for more private investment to help solve the nation 's water shortage and fix ail infrastructure .

Ethanol plant construction under way 
Work on Australia 's first purpose-built ethanol plant be start in north-west Victoria today . 
Australian Ethanol plan to produce 100 million litre of ethanol annually at the Swan Hill plant , which be due to be complete late next year . 
Chief executive Peter Anderton say local farmer will supply it with 350,000 tonne of grain and corn . 
`` Corn would provide about a third of the grain require and then the remainder we would source off winter crop , wheat and barley , '' he say .

The Victorian Government have approve the construction of one of Australia 's big wind farm .

`` It be in an open windswept area . 
`` It 's not something , for instance , that 's on the cliff of view overlook the Great Ocean Road or the ocean or anything like that . 

Rabbit infestation hit SA crop 
The bad infestation of rabbit in 10 year have cause ten of thousand of dollar of damage to crop and pasture on the low Eyre Peninsula in South Australia . 
Early rain and green grass be be blame for the high breeding number , and neither calicivirus nor myxomatosis be have an impact . 
Andrew Ware , from Lipson , say his farm have be hit hard . 
`` Just drive into our property at night-time , usually you would n't see any rabbit but at the moment we 're see five or six just at the entrance to our property , '' he say . 
`` I reckon we would have lose perhaps 25 acre of crop .

Beef production pioneer Wright dy 
One of the pioneer of modern beef production in Australia have die . 
David Wright , 73 , head up a cattle dynasty base on Wallamumbi Station near Armidale in New South Wales . 
He be also responsible for develop the V2V breed of cattle , after cross Australia 's old hereford herd with new genetic stock . 
Mr Wright 's cattle empire fell apart after a long-running legal battle in the 1990s . 
The founder of the Co-operative Research Centre for Beef , Bernie Bindon , say Mr Wright be a pioneer of the scientific research which now underpin the industry . 
`` David Wright leave his imprint on many aspect of the Australian beef industry , '' he say .

Horses kick up dust and punter bet their luck over the weekend , at the 120th year of the Wyndham race in the Kimberley in far north Western Australia .

`` My father-in-law flew from Darwin to Wyndham for the race 60 year ago in a Tiger Moth aircraft , an absolutely fantastic event with just a little bit of hessian all around the place , '' she say . 
`` Today I 'm here to relive the memory for him .

It be 40 year ago today since the first shipment of iron ore from Western Australia 's Pilbara region . 
In 1966 , the 52,00 tonne shipment leave the port of Dampier , on WA 's north-west coast , bound for Japan . 
David Smith , from Pilbara Iron , say Japan remain a major customer but there have be big change in the past four decade . 
`` It start off with about a hundred or so people in it first operation , '' he say . 
`` There 's about 5,000 employee that work in Pilbara Iron now , plus of course a lot of contractor who be important service provider that work and help support the company as well .

Western Australia 's big beef processor be move away from it traditional grass-fed cattle supply . 
EG Green and Sons be force into administration last year . 
The new owner be now try to make the abattoir more efficient by focus on lot-fed cattle . 
Harvey Beef 's chief executive Scott Henderson say it will be some time before the abattoir be run at full capacity . 
He say it be unlikely that stock price will match the eastern state in the short-term . 
`` The most important thing for u be to cut cost wherever we can and that 's what we be do to make sure that we have profitable business here , '' Mr Henderson say . 

Dingo preservation plan anger pastoralists 
South Australian authority want to protect the pure-bred dingo in the state 's far north , but pastoralists be not happy with the move . 
The Department of Water , Land and Biodiversity Conservation say some dingo population in the Simpson Desert should be protect to stop inter-breeding with wild dog . 
But Rodney Fullerton , from Mungeranie Station on the Birdsville Track , say it be unrealistic and impossible to get a balance between conservation and control . 
`` What happen out there in the desert , in the good season there 's a lot of dog out there and they breed up out there , '' he say . 
`` Once it get dry out there in the desert , they come in on these pastoral property . 
`` They come in and they play havoc with our calf and they kill them pretty quick because they 're hungry .

`` Yesterday we stand in the middle of 12.5 million hectare of invasive native scrub land that ABARE [ Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics ] have identify a be at risk because of inappropriate native vegetation regulation .

Wheat streak mosaic virus have be find in a commercial crop in Western Australia for the first time . 
Wheat seed be ban from enter WA last year to prevent the virus spread into the state , but it be find in April this year . 
Roger Jones , from the Department of Agriculture , believe the virus probably find it way west before the ban be impose . 
He say it have now be find on a farm at Merredin in the Wheatbelt . 
`` The danger from the disease be when you get early-sown crop , sow at a time of year when it 's still warm , '' he say . 
`` The mite can actually build up to very large number .

The big buyer of Australian wool say high oil price should help to drive up the wool market by another 10 per cent before Christmas .

`` Once again Indian beef continue to make huge inroad into that market , probably 180,000 , 210,000 tonne go into that market .

She negotiate contract worth $ 750 million a year for storage , handle and movement of grain .

Increasing exploration for offshore oil reserve be cause a shortage of diver in the aquaculture industry .

A Victorian report have find migrant woman in country area be have trouble get help to deal with domestic violence . 
Across Australia one in every three to four family be affect by domestic violence .

`` It 's language barrier but it 's also trust , '' she say . 
`` What the community say in the report be be it a service that 's go to understand me , understand my culture , be I just go to be pressure to leave and break the family ? 
`` I ca n't leave because I 'm on a farm or I ca n't leave because I 'm be threaten with deportation .

A survey of country driver have find high rate of complacency when it come to drink driving , fatigue and speeding . 
Insurance group AAMI have interview 2,500 motorist about their attitude to road safety . 
It find 40 per cent of people survey have probably drive while over the legal alcohol limit . 
A third have momentarily fall asleep at the wheel , while most have exceed the speed limit . 
Professor Craig Veitch , from James Cook University , be involve in a five-year investigation into regional road safety . 
He say the figure show education campaign be not work . 
`` A lot of people we 've speak with have remember road safety message that have n't be use in 10 year - that 's the 'bloody idiot ' campaign , that 's be use , '' he say . 

AWB attempt to retract Cole inquiry evidence 
Tempers have flare at the oil for food inquiry , after wheat exporter AWB try to keep secret a document that be enter into evidence six month ago .

The exhibit relate to Iraq 's claim for compensation over wheat shipment it say be contaminate with iron filing . 
In the February 2003 memo , AWB executive Peter Geary describe the matter a sensitive and political and that AWB would need to inform Mr Downer . 
AWB 's lawyer leap to their foot , demand the document be remove . 
They say it be confidential and part of AWB 's Federal Court challenge . 
After a heated altercation , Commissioner Cole take an immediate adjournment .

Cereal crop deteriorate amid dry weather 
Cereal and canola crop in New South Wales have start to deteriorate . 
Producers be pin their hope on a weak rain system due to come through tomorrow , but warm than normal daytime temperature be stress crop . 
Callers to ABC Central West this morning say 50 to 100 millimetre be need within the next two week . 
`` Pretty much on a knife edge at the moment . Our crop be n't sow until about mi- June . They be look for rain , '' one caller say . 
`` It 's very marginal here at the moment . Everything be just struggle . The pasture be go back into the ground and the crop be just sit there , '' another say . 
`` Like the rest of the region , thing will begin to deteriorate I should imagine , '' a listener say . 

Dry condition boost cattle , sheep sale 
A grow number of farmer in the south-eastern state be sell off cattle due to dry seasonal condition and low water allocation . 
Saleyard price drop sharply yesterday a lower-quality dairy and beef cattle flood into the market 
Aaron Iori , from the National Livestock Reporting Service , say stock figure be dramatically high than last year . 
`` If you look at south-east South Australia for instance , number there be about 80 per cent high than this time last year , '' he say . 
`` That 's specifically because the area north of Naracoote be in a severe situation and number be just continue to come on to the market . '' 
More sheep be also appear in the saleyards because the dry winter have leave many farm without feed . 
Extra sale be be run in some place to cater for the high number . 
Gary Tapscott , from Elders , say the dry condition be affect everyone . 

Spring forecast to be hot , dry 
The National Climate Centre say Australia can expect hotter and drier condition this spring . 
The late three-month outlook have a 60 per cent chance of higher-than-average temperature across most of the tropic , a large part of south-eastern Australia and south-west West Australia . 
There be also a high risk of an El Nino weather pattern . 
Senior meteorologist Grant Beard say high temperature in the Pacific and Indian Oceans also mean there be less chance of average rainfall . 
`` Fairly large area of north-east to northern part of Australia stand an increased chance of have a poor start to their wet season , '' he say . 
`` There 's a bit area of the Northern Territory and a fair bit of Queensland that have a less than 40 per cent chance of receive their median rainfall from September to November . 

MLA apologise for hack tag poll 
Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) have be force to apologise , after two staff member hack into an Internet poll on the National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) . 
The Rural Press poll ask reader to rate the performance of the system to trace animal from birth to death . 
Early poll result show more than 60 per cent of voter describe NLIS a poor or terrible . 
But a day later , after tamper by MLA staff , the poll show 70 per cent believe the system be good or excellent . 
MLA 's manage director , David Palmer , say the staff involve have not be sack . 
He concede the organisation 's credibility be on the line . 
`` This be a very damaging moment . I take it very seriously , the company take it very seriously , the board equally be most alarmed and shock by it , '' he say . 
`` We will take all step and measure to set u down a track to try to win back that integrity and win back that credibility that we just so desperately need from industry . '' 
A long-time critic of NLIS , the Australian Beef Association , say the incident do nothing to boost the credibility of electronic identification . 
It say the incident back it claim the system can be easily corrupt . 
Chairwoman Linda Hewitt say Mr Palmer should immediately sack the MLA staff involve . 
`` Possibly the man do not know what be go on , possibly he be very embarrassed , but he certainly need to take very strong action straight away , '' she say . 
`` We will be keep an eye on the situation . 
`` We will be put press release out about how we expect the whole situation to be handle and we will be question the integrity of the MLA 's checking of itself . ''

The European Union ( EU ) have stop import of US rice , which have be find to contain an unapproved genetically-engineered variety . 
American authority will have to prove rice shipment be free of GM trace , before they will be allow in . 
The EU 's emergency measure follow discovery of tract of experimental GE rice in US commercial supply . 
Germany 's Bayer CropScience develop `` LL Rice 601 '' . 
US Rice Federation spokesman David Coia claim the decision be preliminary . 
`` We 're wait for the final decision by the state committee , '' he say . 
`` I think it 's important to recognise that the US Food and Drug Administration have declare that the long grain rice variety in question be safe . '' 
But the EU say it ban will last at least six month .

Stripe rust find in NSW , SA wheat crop 
The fungal disease , stripe rust , have be discover in wheat crop in northern New South Wales and South Australia for the first time this year . 
The highly contagious disease , which can cut crop yield by up to 50 per cent , have be find between Moree and Narrabri , and on the Yorke Peninsual . 
Dr Gordon Murray , from the Department of Primary Industries in New South Wales , say the disease could spread . 
He say grower with low yield need to decide whether it be worth use fungicide . 
`` With the generally dry condition that will tend to slow the amount of stripe rust but it will also mean that the damage it do will be much less , '' he say . 
`` Dryland crop be unlikely to benefit from spray unless we get a turnaround in the season and a lot more rain . '' 
Stripe rust be find on the leaf of wheat plant , in the form of yellow stripe or spore .

Dairy farmer will vote for the first time early next year on how much they should pay to peak body Dairy Australia .

`` As their national service body Dairy Australia , how be we go to fund the service that we currently have which be imperative for the industry , but also what be we go to do about the issue which be on our doorstep or on the cusp of it , issue that we need to manage a an industry move forward ? . 

Drought blame for cattle indicator drop 
A lack of rain be be blame for the big weekly fall in the Eastern Young Cattle Indicator since April last year . 
The indicator of price from saleyards in the eastern state be consider a guide to general price trend . 
It fell 14 cent last week and be hover around $ 3.60 , compare to $ 4.00 at the same time last year . 
Peter Weeks , from Meat and Livestock Australia , say if it do not rain the market could fall by up to 60 cent a kilo . 
`` Certainly without widespread rain in the next four to six week , I think we will see price fall back further , '' he say . 
`` They will gradually decline move into late this year and early next year , simply because demand be come back on export market and we 've get the spring supply about to come on . '' 
In the south-west of Western Australia a surge of dairy herd on to the market have cause the price of cow to fall $ 150 per head . 
With low demand locally , dairy farmer from the east be buy cow , truck them across the Nullarbor , and still save between $ 100 and $ 200 per head . 
Livestock agent Karl Harnett say with more WA farmer leave the industry , there be a big gap for the eastern state to capitalise on . 
`` Basically right across the eastern seaboard over the last 12 month there have be a shortage of dairy cattle , especially quality dairy cattle , '' he say . 
`` Within in the last six month we 've probably see around 700 to 800 dairy cattle that have move across the border .

There be grow sign the horticulture industry will have to be satisfy with a voluntary code of conduct .

`` What have they do for u ? '' he say . 
`` What they 're do now be the repeat of what they do 20 year ago , and what happen 20 year ago be the repeat of what they do 20 year before . 
`` I do n't think they need any more money , I think they squander what money they 've get there now . 
`` They 've have their chance and they 've blow it , I think . '' 
Trevor Little , from Kongorong , say grower have see little output from the AWI . 
`` The money that 's be achieve over the year , and many year of the levy on the wool have not really in the last 10 year achieve anything , '' he say .

`` You 've get to remember that they say goodbye to their wool at the farm gate and there 's about six different owner between them and the retailer that sell the finished product .

`` There have be no problem between the two company in term of the way this contract have be perform - at AWB International , we have be extremely pleased with the performance of AWB Limited .

`` Our concern be just if people do move for work what happen if that job do n't work out , what support and what safety net be we go to put in place to enable people to go back to where they 've come from ? '' she say . 
`` But there 's also and probably more importantly the organisational and emotional cost of move and the relational cost . 
`` People who do move a large distance for work often find that they can feel isolated . '' 
The mining sector do not think the project will help ease the labour shortage . 
Reg Howard-Smith , from the WA Chamber of Minerals and Energy , say the practice of fly worker in and out of mine site could be a major stumble block . 
`` We have n't see detail on what 's propose but if it 's a requirement to live in a regional centre , then obviously that preclude people work on a fly-in fly-out basis , '' he say .

Australia endure dry August since 1900 
On this first day of spring there be little surprise at news Australia have endure it dry August since record begin in 1900 . 
Preliminary figure show a national average rainfall of just 6.87 millimetre for August . 
Overall , an average of 43.9 millimetre of rain fell across Australia during the winter . 
Senior climatologist at the Bureau of Meteorology , Dr Andrew Watkins , say it have be decade since rain be so scarce . 
`` Australia-wide we only average about 6.2 millimetre for the month , so a very dry month , '' he say . 
`` Our previous dry Augusts be in 1914 and unfortunately 1982 be also a comparison - it have about 7.5 millimetre .

Cane grower examine damage cause by deluge 
Cane farmer in north Queensland say it be too early to know the extent of damage from massive , unexpected rain . 
While September be suppose to be the dry month in the tropic , some farmer have receive up to 665 millimetre in the Herbert River District around Ingham over the weekend . 
That be 26 inch on the imperial scale . 
While farmer far south would love even a fraction of that rainfall , plant scientist Ron Van Kerkwyk say it have halt the sugarcane harvest , and could have a disastrous impact on thousand of hectare of newly plant cane . 
`` Planting be the high single operative cost you 've get on a farm and it really be a tragedy of some proportion when we get as much rain a we 've have here at this time of the year which , number one be fairly unusual and number two it 's impact by the fact that so much of the plant cane we have get be , relatively speak , very young , '' he say . 
In the south , where the rain be really need , the dry condition be start to hurt South Australia 's aquaculture industry . 
A lack of typical winter weather mean oyster be grow slow than normal , due to a lack of food . 
Simon Turner from Turner Aquaculture at Cowell , on the Eyre Peninsula , say without wind or rain , few nutrient be be produce in the seawater to make algae , which be a major food source . 
`` When we have deep low that come up from the Southern Ocean , [ they ] promote upwellings which also create algae and feed for our oyster and that 's something that we have n't have much of at all this year , '' he say .

A new Landcare survey show more than 60 per cent of people live in the capital city have little or no understanding of Australian farm . 
It also show that only one in three people have ever visit a farm .

And chief executive Brian Scars Brick say the rural sector need to do more to educate those live in urban area . 
`` The worrying trend of course be that for young people , the figure go right up to 70 per cent of people not know what be go on behind the farm gate , '' he say . 

Sheep flock decrease fast than expect 
The Australian sheep flock be diminish at a great rate than orginially expect , accord to figure just release by Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) . 
The 2006 Sheep Industry Projections show the national flock have five million sheep few than previously think , at around 100 million , due to the drought . 
But overseas demand for Australian prime lamb be boom , with export to Japan up 30 per cent , and the Middle East market be up by 21 per cent due to strong oil price . 
Live export remain steady at around 4.5 million . 
MLA 's chief market analyst , Peter Weeks , be warn that supply will be tighter , because of the slow task of rebuild . 
`` Over the next four year , instead of a 6 per cent a year rise in supply , it 's go down to about 2 per cent a year , '' he say .

Golden spinifex could cut exploration cost 
Spinifex grass might be a natural signpost to untold wealth , accord to research finding in the Tanami Desert . 
Scientists have discover that spinifex plant can carry trace of gold in their leaf , if they be grow above a mineral deposit . 
Further research need to be do , but mine company say the discovery could lead to big saving in exploration cost . 
Dr Stephen Rogers from the Cooperative Research Centre for Landscape Environments and Mineral Exploration , say the grass be prove to be a natural metal detector . 
`` What the plant do be because it live in very arid region it need to get it water from the ground water so it put the most of it energy into create this huge single root that penetrate very , very deeply into the regolith , into the cover of the landscape to the ground water , '' he say .

`` Sometimes regional policy development seem to be aim at increase the population in rural centre , sometimes it seem to be aim at bring new industry into regional area , sometimes it seem to be aim at ease congestion in capital city , '' he say . 
`` So , I think a lot of confusion exists and a lot of government package that be call regional development package do n't seem to have a clear objective . ''

Victorian farmer say overnight rain have give die crop a reprieve and delayed decision to sell livestock . 
More than 20 millimetre have fall across many part of the Wimmera Mallee , a region that have have no significant rain since July , and where reservoir be at criticially low level . 
Farmers say this rain will not break the drought , but will keep their crop alive for another couple of week . 
`` A lot of the stubble crop I think will fire up a bit - they be nearly dead , pretty yellow , but the fallow be okay , it be just hang on , '' he say . 
`` But mainly my stock , I can hang onto my stock . 
`` We can look forward I guess to two or three more week , then we 're look for quite a bit more rain in the springtime to finish the crop off . 
`` We 've have 14 , it 'll turn it around pretty well for a couple of week . It be get pretty desperate up until now .

Prices have peak at $ 350 a megalitre , with the average price closer to $ 150 . 
Brett Tucker from Murrumbidgee Irrigation say after six year of drought some producer be sell water for high price , rather than use it themselves . 
`` You ca n't blame people for sell , there 's be such a differential in the market this year that I think the Murray valley 's become more attractive , '' he say . 
`` Ultimately people need to do whatever they can to get through these sort of circumstance .

A new sand mine on the Tiwi Islands north of Darwin be set to boost employment for the local Aboriginal community . 
Matilda Minerals will produce 200,000 tonne of the heavy mineral concentrate , zircon-rutile over the next six year . 
Managing director Bruce Maluish say he want to reduce the environmental impact of mine an island in the Torres Strait . 
`` The sand average about 4 per cent heavy mineral , '' he say . 
`` The process involve mine the sand , process it , extract the 5 per cent of heavy mineral and put the sand back in the hole where it come from . 
`` So it 's a pretty benign impact and we can be mine through area quite quickly at low impact , and come back and rehabilitate the land quite smartly as well . ''

A Western Australian mining company have be order to pay more than $ 1.8 million to a former senior executive , after fail to disclose a nickel discovery .

In late 1994 , rival company Western Mining Corporation tell Jubilee Mines it have inadvertently find the nickel deposit on Jubilee 's tenement in the northern goldfield . 
However Jubilee Mines do not publicly provide information of the find until two year later . 
In that time , Mr Riley sell his entire holding in the company .

`` I 've get mixed emotion , I be very relieved , '' he say .

Human error 'probable cause ' of GM canola mix-up 
Human error have be identify a the most likely cause of the genetically-modified contamination of conventional canola two year ago . 
Low level contamination of the commercially-grown 'grace ' variety be discover in 2005 during routine sampling of canola export . 
A trial of GM canola be conduct in Tasmania in 1998 , and a year later grace canola be grow on a separate site three kilometres away , but an investigation by the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator have find that be not how the contamination occur . 
Alex Schaap from Tasmania 's Department of Primary Industry say there be not enough evidence to provide a definite answer . 
`` The mystery still remain a to what the source of the contamination be , '' he say . 
`` The only hypothesis leave standing be some form of human error , perhaps something as simple a somebody not label seed bag correctly , and seed hence be mixed . '' 
The peak grain research body say it be continue negotiation to try to secure the commercial release of genetically modify crop . 
The Grains Research and Development Corporation be fund research into GM canola , which can not be release to farmer because of state-imposed ban on the technology . 
Chairman Terry Enright say the benefit of GM crop , such a disease tolerant wheat and barley , need to be prove . 
`` We 're positively work with industry and with government in a dialogue to make sure that we overcome these issue that be there , '' he say . 
`` And we 're hopeful in the long term that if crop become available and can be assess on a crop by crop basis , if they demonstrate benefit to the industry , that ultimately we 'll be able to grow them , if that be what be require . '' 
Meanwhile , Nufarm have buy the licence to develop and commercialise genetically-modified canola . 
The agribusiness company have pay $ 10 million for Monsanto 's Roundup Ready canola licence and germ plasm .

Transport Minister Warren Truss have release a 15-month study into the project , and say the far western sub-corridor be the top contender from four route name in the report . 
The project will cost more than $ 3 billion , and taxpayer will need to contribute two third . 
The Federal Government want the line to be in operation by 2019 . 
Minister Truss say there will be consultation on the best route , but one be a particular stand-out . 
`` Now that particular corridor would cost about 3.1 billion dollar to build and achieve a transit time of just under 21 hour , '' he say .

South Korea 's Agriculture Ministry have just announce that 36 US slaughterhouse designate to handle meat for export to South Korea meet require safety measure , clear the last hurdle to the resumption of import . 
MLA Korean manager , Glen Feist say the Americans have have a tough time convince the Koreans to accept meat with bone chip fragment .

Mallee farmer Claire Cook have have to sell most of her sheep , and say most of her crop have die . 
`` It 's a very political , very politician 's response , a in , 'we 'll have a look and we 'll have a discussion about it ' , '' she say . 
`` I be hop for something a bit more practical , a in some subsidy , maybe for some tank that we 're all go to have to buy in order for the water , hopefully that will be cart to u , or that we 'll cart ourselves .

The Australian Veterinary Association have spend the last two year work on a rodeo policy that require the attendance of a vet .

Hi-tech quarantine lab set up in Darwin 
Suspect plant disease and insect gather across northern Australia and Asia will now be check in new secure hi-tech laboratory in Darwin . 
More than $ 3 million have be spend create the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service 's new headquarters . 
Plant pathologist Jane Ray say the upgrade include filter system to ensure that no material escape or hitchhikes on staff . 
`` This facility be specifically design to handle pathogen of quarantine concern like citrus canker for example , '' she say . 
`` Citrus canker could be work on in the bio-hazard cabinet , which would enable the pathogen to be contain within the cabinet . 
`` The negative pressure and the procedure and protocol in place would prevent the escape of this pathogen . 
`` We could actually diagnose it here , rapidly and move for eradication , rather than actually delay diagnosis as well . '' 
Another hi-tech quarantine lab be due to be construct in Cairns , North Queensland .

The key sticking point involve a clear definition of who be an agent and who be a wholesaler , enforceable transparent contract and a dispute resolution process .

Marine biologist have concern about a plan by mine company BHP Billiton to build a water desalination plant near Whyalla on the Spencer Gulf in South Australia .

`` This proposal be to pump 320 megalitres of water a day from the northern Spencer Gulf and return about 200 megalitres of water to the gulf , '' he say .

`` And give when you get hopper band that go across paddock , basically they 'll almost clean the paddock out of all vegetation that 's there . ''

`` In Perth , the actual material be then wash and reprocess , and granulate , and be then make into either new poly pipe . 
`` Also we can coat the CCA treat pine log and make post for vineyard and that sort of thing with the recycled poly . ''

Govts urge not to give up world trade fight 
World farm leader be urge government not to give up the fight to free up world trade . 
Delegates from the 18 member nation of the Cairns Group be meet in far north Queensland this week to mark the organisation 's 20th anniversary . 
They will attempt to find a way to revive the deadlocked Doha world trade talk , with the European Union and the US refuse to offer more concession to cut tariff and farm subsidy . 
David Crombie from the National Farmers Federation say break down market barrier be critical for Australian farmer . 
`` What we be look at be a more level base where we can compete more openly , '' he say . 
`` We think the EU need to open up it market more , we think the Americans need to take away some of their home support and the developing country need to have less exclusion . '' 
Federal Trade Minister Mark Vaile have put forward a proposal to try to revive the trade talk this week , but it have be dismiss by the head of America 's big farm group . 
American Farm Bureau president Bob Stallman say despite his high regard for Mr Vaile , he feel Mr Vaile 's proposal for a 5 per cent EU tariff cut , side by side with a $ US5 billion subsidy cut be unfair . 
`` The 5 per cent be not much , in and of itself but if you add in the potential effect of sensitive product and the percent of product there , not count special product for develop country , that 's not go to compensate u for give up $ 5 billion . '' 
Mr Stallman say Mr Vaile 's plan sound good , five and five , but that 's about the best that could be say for it - it do n't meet US WTO goal . 
Visiting Irish Trade Minister Michael Ahern hop the world trade talk can be put back on track . 
Mr Ahern say improved market access be a key issue because 90 per cent of Ireland 's production be export . 
He say there be room to negotiate the reduction of agricultural tariff and subsidy , but the United States need to come to the party too .

`` In the hour after the cyclone in March , Government phone the ABS and ask what do we know about the farmer in far north Queensland , a in the number of farm , the type of farm , their production , '' he say . 
`` Within hour we turn that information around from the 2001 census and the next day , the Wednesday , the Government announce a recovery package for farmer . ''

Head of the Horticulture Australia Council Kris Newton say she can not believe it . 
`` That certainly have n't be convey to u . We would be bitterly disappointed if that be the outcome and it 's certainly not what we 're look for , '' she say . 
`` I have n't have that information from the Minister or the Minister 's office so clearly we would need to talk with them and get a straight story about what 's go on . '' 
Wholesalers say they will take legal action if supermarket chain be not force to comply with the mandatory code . 
Andrew Young from the Central Markets Association say if the code be anti-competitive , they may take action through the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission . 
He believe politics affect the decision . 
`` The Government have decide to work towards an enforceable voluntary code and then at the twelfth hour this major backflip , '' he say . 
`` So we can only speculate that the National party pursue an outcome and have their way at the end of the day . '' 
Some grower and wholesaler in the horticulture sector be question the need for the code , which they fear will cost them money . 
`` We have some very strong relationship with our fruit and vegetable agent across Australia , '' Mark Boyd , general manager of Tropical Pines say . 
`` Those be very mature relationship and very open relationship that have be very successful for u . 
`` So we 'll have to wait and see the detail of the code of conduct and actually wait to see how it will benefit u . '' 
`` I 'm probably a little bit disappointed . It be go to add cost to our business and how we do business , it 's hard to quantify exactly how much , '' Grant Nicholl , wholesaler business manager with Flavorite tomato marketing say .

`` But if I could just make one other point .

`` What we mean by increased flexibility be the possibility of explore for example thing like tradeable development right - that might require exploration of whether or not we can conserve or allow agricultural development to occur in one area if there 's increased native vegetation conservation in another area , '' she say .

Ian Bolitho from Fruit Growers Victoria say up to half of the 300,000 tonne of fruit grow in the region have be wipe out . 
`` All the apricot have go , they show sign of start to shrivel and drop off now , at least 50 per cent of the plum crop be go and probably most of the nectarine crop , and probably 50 per cent of the peach crop , '' he say . 
`` We 're just assess on the fresh pear at the moment but they 're not look all that flash either . '' 
Growers be now ask why the weather bureau do not give them any warning of the Sunday night frost . 
An Internet-based forecasting service be set up in 2003 after a similar frost cause widespread damage . 
But there be no warn issue on Sunday night . 
Kevin Parkyn from the bureau say that be a mistake . 
`` I think the system be a good one . I think it 's exceptional , '' he say . 
`` Unfortunately we miss this case which do n't look good on our track record . 
`` As I say it sometimes can be a very fine line particularly with such intense vigorous windy condition on the Sunday to have it drop out so rapidly be very unusual . '' 
Elsewhere , grower say they do not expect to see major increase in the price of fruit , but believe the market will be affect .

`` What we 're try to do be put it down over the seed a it be sown and it trap moisture , and trap the heat under the film like a greenhouse , '' she say . 
`` [ It ] give it a well grow environment and also it mean that a it be grow , we 're capture all the water that 's transpire , we 're capture the water in the soil so we get a moister soil environment .

`` Australia do not get a premium for it non-GM canola in Japan . So I ask myself the question - why be we put at a potential disadvantage to our competitor ? ''

The NRMA have reject claim by petrol company that transport cost be to blame for high fuel cost at country service station .

He say petrol retailer must be force to be transparent about why their rural station charge up to 20 cent a litre more than city outlet . 
`` Even the oil company themselves say three cent a litre would account for the freight cost , '' he say . 
`` When you look at differential a we have in the last week between Sydney and Wagga , of nearly 20 cent a litre , 19 , you have differential of 14 between Wagga and Albury on the same day on the average price of fuel , you ca n't explain it by freight . '' 
But there be bright prospect for an alternative fuel . 
An Australian company have be award $ 2 million by the United States Energy Department to trial an alternative hydrogen fuel blend for vehicle engine . 
Eden Energy say some American bus will be power by it hythane mix . 
Hythane blend 7 per cent hydrogen with 93 per cent natural gas . 
Eden Energy executive chairman Greg Solomon say the US particularly want the technology because of stringent emission standard be introduce next year .

Adelaide Resources chairman Keith Yates value the deposit at about $ 650 million . 
`` The zircon content of the heavy mineral component of Tripitaka be in the order of 65 per cent and 65 per cent by world standard be absolutely extraordinary as far a the heavy mineral component of the deposit be concern , '' he say .

Mr Flugge reply : `` Yes , I believe I be . ''

Wool production drop blame on drought 
The drought be be blame for an estimated 6 per cent drop in wool production across Australia this season . 
Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) say the forecast have fall 27 million kilogram to 434 million , because of a lack of rain , pasture growth , and the fact that there 's no end to the drought in sight . 
Chairman of AWI 's production forecasting committee Dr David James agree it will be a tough season for grower . 
`` Partly it 's due to the fact that feed production will be down , '' he say . 
`` For example ABARE be forecast that cereal production level will be down by about 30 per cent and another concern be in fact the capacity of farmer to provide water to their stock , and on top of that of course there be cash flow factor which will make it difficult . '' 
The dry condition be force many sheep farmer to begin their shear early than normal . 
And the big supply be hurt wool price , with the market suffer it big drop since April . 
Tony Kidman from Quality Wool say many farmer can not afford to store wool until price rise . 
`` We appear to be have less people hold onto wool at this moment , people look for more of a cash flow with their wool , '' he say . 
`` I think the drought condition be force people to shear a bit earlier and sell their sheep a bit earlier than they have in the past . '' 
International factor be also affect wool price . 
Bill Cowley from the Australian Wool Network say the market drop be disappointing , especially when the Australian dollar be weak . 
`` China do most of their business in US dollar and when we see the US currency fall , we would normally see a firm to slightly dearer market here in Australia , but the bid that be come from the Chinese at this particular time be get lower and low , and there 's some resistance to the high price that they be have to pay in the US , '' he say .

Australia 's highway below standard : survey 
The first independent audit of the nation 's highway show half be below standard and may be unsafe to drive on . 
The Australian Automobile Association survey 18,000 kilometre of the national highway in all state except New South Wales and give each one a star rating . 
Worst on the list be the Bruce Highway on Queensland 's Sunshine Coast and the Calder Highway in Victoria between Bendigo and Kyneton . 
The association 's executive director , Lachlan Macintosh , say half of the highway be rat three star and more likely to cause death . 
`` In a three star road there be still some deficiency in the road feature ; poor median protection , perhaps too many intersection per kilometre of road , poorly design curve , not enough marking on the road , '' he say . 
`` So those three star road could be well , we could see some pretty inexpensive treatment to make them good and that 's fairly important . ''

A new report say the cash income for beef producer have be halve in the past financial year .

Rhonda Treadwell from ABARE 'S farm survey and analysis branch say producer have be attempt to build up herd number . 
`` Essentially the farm cash income have fall quite considerably and that be mainly because of the incredibly big build up of cattle number across a lot of beef cattle property , so their profit have n't fall as much a their cash income , '' she say . 
But those attempt to build up herd be now be thwart by the on-going drought , with producer start to sell large number of cattle .

`` Our bore on average have go from about 800-900 gallon an hour down to 200 gallon an hour .

Chemical ban will see return to old-fashioned farming : grain grower 
Grain grower say they will be force to return to old-fashioned and inefficient farming method , due to a new chemical ban . 
The Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority have ban the use of 24 weed killer contain chemical know a 2,4-D short chain ester , due to concern about contamination of vineyard and horticultural crop . 
Garry Hansen from the South Australian Farmers Federation say grain grower will be force to use more expensive chemical , which they can not afford in the current climate . 

Fodder shortage start to show in key grow region 
There be more evidence of a looming shortage of fodder , due to dry condition in the nation 's key grow region . 
The Australian Fodder Industry Association say apart from the north coast of New South Wales and part of Queensland hay crop need a good drink . 
Executive officer Colin Peace say some grain and canola crop be be bale , but overall production will be down . 
`` The lucerne hay be go to be like hen teeth because there 's not the irrigation water that there be say after the last 02/03 drought , '' he say . 
`` That would be well into the $ 200 per tonne on farm . 

Demand for water tank increase 
The drought be also increase demand for water tank from farmer . 
They be not be use to collect rainwater , but to hold water be truck in to property across Victoria , New South Wales , Queensland and South Australia . 
Ross Hendy from Tankworld in north-west Victoria say around 250 tank be be sell each week , and there be a six-week wait for them . 

New irrigation model save water 
A water cooperative in Western Australia be be hold up a a model example for the irrigation sector . 
The Harvey Water Cooperative in south-west Western Australia have replace open irrigation channel with pipe , create water saving of about 25 per cent each year . 
The saved water be pip to Perth to be use in the urban area . 
Dan Norton have be name Rural Achiever of the Year at the Royal Show for his contribution to the cooperative , and he hop others can benefit from the project . 
`` By pip the system and eliminate the irrigation channel you cut those loss by 25-30 per cent , which be [ the ] world 's best practice for an open channel system , '' he say . 

Global demand boost export of dairy goat 
Growing global demand for dairy product be help to boost export of Australian dairy goat . 
Argentina and Mexico have be big buyer to expand their local goat milk industry . 
Now demand be emerge from Asia , Yemen and Papua New Guinea . 
Jane Hewlett from Tasmania 's Dairy Goat Society say there be a grow acceptance of dairy food , particularly in Taiwan and China . 
`` Originally dairy product be not high on their list of food , '' she say . 

North-west WA worry about biosecurity risk 
In far north Western Australia , farmer who want to develop new luxury bed and breakfast accommodation in the Ord River irrigation area will now have to take biosecurity risk into account . 
The Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley be amend it Town Planning Act to protect the region 's agriculture , which be highly regarded because of it isolation . 
It be worry about the threat of pest and disease that could be bring in by tourist . 
Vaughan Davies from Tourism Western Australia say it be the first time biosecurity have play such a major role . 

Australian consortium launch new beef marketing strategy 
A big push into 4,000 Japanese supermarket have be launch by Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) and the Australian Agricultural Company . 
Qantas and Wolf Blass be also join the marketing strategy , to promote Aussie beef in the lead-up to Christmas . 
MLA 's manage director David Palmer say it be a unique marketing plan to snare ongoing commitment from tough Japanese consumer , and fight off competition from the US . 
`` It 's an initiative to help continue to drive that loyalty , to help to continue to hold shelf space here in the Japanese retail market , '' he say . 

Pollen from feral olive can cause 'severe respiratory problem ' 
The expansion of olive production across the country could be lead to human health problem . 
The Cooperative Research Centre for Australian Weed Management say leave fruit on tree after harvest be cause feral olive to spread outside the grove . 
Chief executive Rachel McFadyen say the pollen from feral olive can cause severe respiratory problem . 
`` Olive pollen be quite a severe allergen , that 's to say if people breath it they develop an allergy to it , and then they start to suffer from hay fever and sinusitis and eventually perhaps asthma , '' she say .

A leading climate change expert have tell a summit on alternative fuel that the Federal Government have no far reach strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emission . 
The former head of atmospheric research at the CSIRO , Dr Graeme Pearman , say Australia will face grow international pressure to meet target and it do not have any in place . 
The NRMA be push for an alternative fuel task force , challenge the Government to fund it . 
Dr Pearman say if politician do not set aside their electoral aspiration , Australia face an immediate crisis .

The former president of the National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) , Peter Corish , have confirm he be think about run a a candidate in next year 's federal election . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say the Nationals would welcome the former leader , but Mr Corish say he be yet to make up his mind . 
He believe it would be logical to run in the new New South Wales seat which incorporate the seat hold by former deputy PM John Anderson . 
The National party have welcome an apparent softening in the Federal Government 's plan to allow great power for cross-media ownership in rural area . 
Communications Minister Helen Coonan say she be prepared to listen to propose change to the new ownership law , to ensure radio , television and newspaper be not own by one company in the same region . 
Nationals ' MP Paul Neville say member be hop to convince the Minister to protect rural medium . 

Farmers air mining worry 
The search for copper , cobalt , nickel and uranium near the Northern Territory town of Batchelor be worry some local farmer . 
Compass Resources have revive exploration near the town , originally build to service the nation 's first uranium mine , Rum Jungle , in the 1950s . 
Small rural block have be develop since then , include a commercial vegetable and fruit farm . 
Compass 's community manager Tracker Tilmouth say they have yet to reach agreement over how to share resource , include water . 
`` Because of where the mine be locate we have a very large water supply that we have to de-water , so we will be look at a whole range of activity that we can complement their water supply or whatever , '' he say . 

Barrick up-beat about gold price rise 
The price of gold have slip yet again overnight , but the world 's big gold miner remain confident about the long-term market . 
Barrick Gold Corporation be stand by it prediction of a gold price of $ US700 an ounce by the end of the year . 
That be a fair way above the current price of $ US566 . 
But chief executive Greg Wilkins say not enough gold be be produce globally to replace current reserve , which should drive the price back up . 
`` Clearly one of the challenge for the industry and for the viability be try to manage the cost , '' he say . 
`` If gold price come back down below $ 500 an ounce it wo n't take all that long for the supply side to shrink more rapidly than we 're see today which in turn I think would have positive impact and bring the price back up . 

Beefed up price record at Rockhampton bull sale 
Australia 's big bull sale have attract record price and a clearance rate of 98 per cent . 
The sale at Rockhampton , in central Queensland , finish last night , with more than 1,000 bull fetch nearly $ 6.5 million over three day . 
The top sale of $ 90,000 be pay for both a grey and a red brahman bull .

`` They have certainly invest in the breeding herd and the genetics that they be use and it be certainly pay off , '' he say . 

SA grain harvest begin early 
The grain harvest have start two week early in South Australia this year because of the lack of spring rain . 
Ian Mudge from Telowie , near Port Pirie , have reap 300 hectare of pea and barley so far and say despite very low yield , the grain be of reasonable quality . 
However , he say not all of his crop will be worth harvest and expect to be finish well before Christmas . 
`` I reckon we 'll have most of November and December off . I think it 's just one of those year that we 'll just chalk up to experience and forget about and zip back next year and have another go , '' he say . 
On the far west coast of the Eyre Peninsula , the Thevenard silo have also report it first delivery of oat . 
Meanwhile , the estimate value of South Australia 's crop production have be slash to $ 600 million , about half of what it be last year . 
The grim outlook have prompt ABB Grain to close at least two silo over summer . 
And operation manager Peter Weaver say other silo throughout the state could be add to the list .

Australian rice grower be be guarantee a record price of $ 320 a tonne to plant a crop this year . 
The author of a new book on way to good manage water say all user should have to account for the way they use the resource . 
John Pigram , a Professor of water policy at the University of New England in New South Wales , say farmer have already be force to improve their efficiency to make the most of low commodity price . 
He be call for a national audit system to force user to justify their water allocation . 
`` Whether that be for irrigation , for industry , for a wetland , or a brewery , [ they have ] ... to be accountable for it use , '' he say . 

Bunnings at centre of grapevine quarantine concern 
Giant hardware chain Bunnings could face prosecution for allegedly bring grapevine into South Australia from a phylloxera risk area in Victoria . 
Phylloxera , aphid-type insect that attack and kill grapevine , be not present in SA . 
The Department of Primary Industries say 122 grapevine be find in four Adelaide Bunnings store . 
Spokesman David Cartwright say any breach of quarantine condition could put the state 's $ 2 billion wine industry at risk . 

Tough condition may halve Barossa crop 
South Australia 's famous Barossa wine region could only harvest half it normal volume of grape this vintage . 
A major frost this week have damage bud vine and come on top of a lack of rain and reduced water entitlement . 
Bob Taplin from the Barossa Winegrape Growers Association say while low yield might help to reduce the industry 's grape glut , it will not help grower because price be set to stay low . 

Reduced canola crop prediction may see oil seed import 
A forecast of the small canola crop in more than a decade have prompt speculation that local crusher will import oil seed from Canada . 
Grain analyst Malcolm Bartholomaeus say there be likely to be a shortfall between Australian production and customer demand . 
He say with canola $ 90 a tonne cheaper in Canada , crusher might look there to fill the gap . 
`` One of the consideration be plant utilisation , so import the canola would be attractive from that perspective , '' he say . 
`` Also what 's the value of the oil come out and canola oil be reasonably highly price at the moment , particularly with the underlie biodiesel demand - then you look at the demand and the price that might be achieve for the meal and at the moment there 's certainly go to be domestic outlet for canola meal in Australia with the current feed situation out of this drought . ''

Rural financial counsellor say they will have to cut staff because the Federal Government 's late round of funding do not go far enough . 
The Federal Government top up funding for the scheme by $ 10 million in the last Budget and the new program kick off this month .

`` It be slash hugely , but there 's be no negotiation regard that and I think this have be the big issue right across the country , '' she say . 
`` That from the region and the state we 've put in what we think be an applicable appropriate number of counsellor , but we have n't be able to fund that level of counsellor and with the climate change and condition across Australia our demand be go to become great not lesser . ''

The fishing industry be have trouble sell it commercial fishing boat , in the wake of a federal buyback of more than 400 licence around Australia . 
In the major southern port of Eden in New South Wales a $ 2 million vessel be on the market for just $ 200,000 . 
Processor and boat owner Titch Rodahl have accept a buyout package and have sell his boat at 1 per cent of it value . 
With the buyout , it 's not viable to stay open with the overhead and all that sort of stuff , it 's not worth run the boat , '' he say . 
`` I sort of give my boat away because I get pay for it in the buyout . 
`` Three year ago I buy the vessel for $ 210,000 .

`` We 're find that we 're get a lot of cost squeeze happen , price be not rise very quickly .

`` That money could go elsewhere .

For the first time , a national accreditation course will be available for irrigators to help improve their image a water user .

`` Many farmer be still schedule their irrigation by the tried and true old method of wander out into the paddock , kick the dirt , have a look to see how moist it be and then make a subjective judgment on how much water to apply , '' he say .

Victoria could host Australia 's second large gold producer follow a takeover offer for Leviathan Resources by Perseverance Corporation . 
The bid by Perseverance be worth $ 46 million , value each Leviathan share at about 56 cent . 
Perseverance intend to close Leviathan 's Melbourne office and move some staff and equipment from Leviathan 's Stawell Gold Mine to Perseverance 's Fosterville gold mine , near Bendigo . 
Managing director Graeme Sloan say if accept , the offer will deliver big benefit to Perseverance shareholder .

Grape vine strip a drought continue 
In far western New South Wales , a table grape grower be strip healthy vine to keep them alive , with the Menindee Lakes system at just 15 per cent capacity . 
Menindee irrigator Paul D'Ettorre say if big rain do not come by March , he face the prospect of walk away from his family 's 60-year-old farm . 
While he expect table grape price to remain steady for the season , Mr D'Ettore say the long-term future be uncertain . 
`` We will be okay as long a we keep get the top-up rain , but we keep fall back , '' he say .

The price of a tray of mango have halve in the past fortnight , a the Northern Territory harvest get into full swing . 
The Docking family , who be base on the fringe of Darwin 's rural area at Berry Springs , be make the most of dry early build-up weather . 
It can be blisteringly hot , up to 35 degree in the shade , with humidity easily 80 per cent at picking . 
But so far , 3,000 tray of mango have be pluck from their orchard . 
That be compare to 220,000 tray across all of Darwin . 
Strong wind have scratch the surface of some fruit , increase the amount of second and the early premium price have already fall away , to below $ 30 a tray in the Sydney market .

In just it third year of compete , Tasmania have win the team 's event at the national shearing championship , in Hay , NSW , at the weekend .

Water sensor may cut irrigation loss significantly 
An irrigation expert say multi-million dollar project use water sensor could cut irrigation loss by between 10 and 20 per cent across Australia . 
That be equivalent to all the water use in urban area . 
John Langford , director of the Water Research Centre at the University of Melbourne , say the first year of trial have be complete and indication be that it could halve the cost of irrigation efficiency program . 
`` It involve a unit call a nictor , which would be about the size of a coffee pot , you can dot them around at random in the landscape , so long a they be close enough to each other they will form their own wireless network , '' he say .

The Grains Council of Australia say an annual survey of stored grain be need to stop livestock farmer panic-buying overseas during drought . 
It want both federal government research body , like the Grains Research and Development Corporation and the livestock industry , to pay $ 50,000 a year for the survey . 
Grains Council chairman Murray Jones say livestock farmer need to be make aware that domestic grain be still cheap than import grain . 
`` [ The ] Grains Council of Australia support the livestock industry who 've be ask for an indication of a clear picture of the availability of grain stock , '' he say . 
`` I think it 's important , both from the livestock industry and from farmer as well , that we have some some record of the great transparency of the grain at hand . '' 
Meanwhile the worsening dry in southern and central New South Wales will lead to job loss at Graincorp . 
The large east coast grain handler believe it will only open two third of it silo and dramatically cut it casual staff .

Drought expect to cut cotton production 
Analysts be predict cotton grower this season will plant Australia 's small crop in nearly 20 year . 
Independent Commodity Management 's Matthew Leeson say a range of factor , include the drought , will cut production to about 1 million bale . 
He say the commodity 's subdue price be also significant . 
`` Compounding the marginal moisture availability be poor price for cotton versus the well above average price for the feed grain due to the shortfall from the winter cereal crop this year , '' he say . 

Farming region run out of water 
One of Victoria 's wet farming region be run out of water . 
The water storage at Leongatha , in Gippsland , be at 24 per cent and fall and resident be on stage four water restriction . 
South Gippsland Water be audit local business , include the major dairy processing plant Murray Goulburn , to see if their water use can be reduce . 
Meanwhile oil tanker could ship Tasmanian water to the mainland under a new proposal . 
Environment company Solar Sailer will propose harvest fresh water from a number of site in the state 's north , when it meet the Tasmanian Government next month . 
The company 's Robert Dane say selling water to major city could prove a lucrative industry . 

Wine export to UK drop 
Australian wine export have slip to their low level in 16 year , with sale to the UK down 3 per cent . 
The late data from the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation also show the average price per litre of $ 3.77 be the low in nearly a decade . 
But cheap bulk shipment to China be outstrip all other market , increase fivefold to 16 million litre . 
The corporation 's Lawrie Stanford say the wine glut and foreign exchange issue be partly to blame and the outlook be not good . 
`` The Australian wine sector be clearly oversupplied at the moment and whilst volume be grow on the back of principally bulk sale , price be clearly fall a a result , '' he say . 

Frost decimate Limestone Coast vineyard 
After frost earlier hit the Barossa Valley , they have now decimate vineyard along the Limestone Coast of South Australia , wipe million off the value of this year 's vintage . 
The region that 's famous for it full blood red wine could lose most of this year 's grape crop after the temperature drop below minus three for the second morning in a row . 
Damage have be most severe in the Padthaway Valley . 
Grower Ian Ward say he have lose about 90 per cent of his crop . 
`` I 've get a couple of neighbour who be a hundred per cent affect , I have another neighbour who might be only something like 10 per cent [ affect and get off pretty lightly , '' he say .

The Rural Doctors Association of Australia say the federal and state government need to fund fly-in , fly-out mental health worker to deal with a major shortage in regional and remote area . 
It say the Federal Government 's announcement yesterday that it be expand access to mental health staff under Medicare and set up new rural clinic will not work if staff can not be persuade to go to the bush .
