King Is plantation development ban worry timber industry 
Tasmania 's timber industry be worry that a ban on plantation development on King Island will set a precedent . 
The chief executive of the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania , Terry Edwards , say he be surprise that the planning policy to prohibit plantation on the island be uphold yesterday after legal scrutiny . 
He be concern other council will now try to limit plantation development . 
`` We now have a situation seemingly in Tasmania where council can tell farmer what crop they can or can not grow on their land , '' he say . 

Apples may be use to produce ethanol 
Apples could be the next agricultural commodity use to produce ethanol . 
The horticulture industry in Western Australia 's south-west say unsaleable fruit could be juiced and be turn into biofuel , fetch up to $ 120 a tonne . 
And Vic Grisotis from Apple and Pear Australia say other fruit could also be use . 
`` If it 's a sugar base product there 's no reason why it ca n't be , '' he say . 

Govt may extend drought assistance 
The Federal Government be consider extend it drought assistance in the face of worsen condition across many state . 
It say the current system be set up to deal with one or two-year drought rather than the series of dry year farmer have face . 
The federal Agriculture Minister , Peter McGauran , say the Government be worry that farmer in area where there have be some rain be slip through crack in the system , so change be be consider . 
`` We do n't believe now with the failed spring any of those area have any possibility of recovery , so rather than wait until they meet another criterion , we should be able to move them straight into drought declaration , '' Mr McGauran say . 
But the Opposition 's agriculture spokesman , Gavin O'Connor , say the Government have be too slow to act . 
`` Even in EC declare area , only 13 per cent of farmer have ever access these particular provision . '' 
The Government say plan change will make it easy for area to become drought declare for EC assistance . 
It say they will stop rainfall in one district rule out help for a whole region and allow EC declaration to last long than 12 month . 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say the current drought emergency require immediate intervention . 
Chief executive Ben Fargher say the politician be now aware farmer be not whingeing , but look for targeted measure to deal with the crisis . 
`` We need to make sure that EC program be work as well a it could , '' he say . 
`` We would also like the government to consider further change to EC about some eligibility criterion , lift cap on interest rate subsidy assistance and some technical matter like that . 

Wheat shortage prompt price spike 
World wheat price have enjoy their big two-day gain in 18 year on the Chicago Board of Trade , amid global supply concern a drought affect Australia , India , Europe and the US . 
Prices soar 13 per cent to $ US5.24 a bushel , the high level in 10 year before drop slightly . 
The frantic price spike come after the Grains Council slash it forecast for the Australian wheat harvest to 12 million tonne , though American producer believe the Australian crop will be even small than that . 
The wheat future rally have be spur by the massive area of cereal and canola crop fail in southern and central New South Wales . 
These be the comment from producer today from Dubbo through to the Murray River . 
`` Things have really go downhill in the last couple of week , our delivery say to Condobolin be probably lucky to get 10 per cent of the normal 150,000 tonne , '' one producer say . 
`` Some area there will be a small amount of grain harvest , probably about 90 per cent of the canola have now be cut for hay and a small proportion of the wheat have be cut for hay , '' say another . 
`` Very little more than 30 per cent will see a header at this stage , I think people be gloss over just how serious this be , another producer say . 
`` I know we have get people around here turn there stock in on their crop for the first time in 40 odd year . It 's very ordinary . 

Dairy farmer ' income increase 
Australian dairy farm cash income have increase by nearly a quarter in the past financial year to just over $ 100,000 a farm . 
Figures release by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) show Victoria , South Australia and Western Australia perform strongly . 
But income fell in Tasmania , New South Wales and Queensland a the drought push up fodder cost and cut milk production . 
Colin Mues , from ABARE , say high price pay by dairy processor make a big difference to the bottom line . 
`` The main factor drive that be high milk price through improvement in the dairy market , '' he say . 
`` Production be fairly steady , it go down marginally at a national level but there be a fairly uniform improvement in price across all state and I think that 's be the key factor drive it and the price increase be , you know , between 3 and 5 per cent . '' 
But dairy farmer in Western Australia refute ABARE 's figure . 
Farmer John Giumelli say cost of dairying land be so high that profit making be almost impossible , even with good milk price . 
`` The attrition rate in dairy farm in WA be absolutely shock but it 's an indictment of what pressure the industry be under and I take no joy out of the ABARE figure , '' he say .

Environmentalist Rick Farley have be remember at this year 's national Landcare award . 
The award winner be announce last night in Melbourme . 
One thousand people fly in from across Australia and as far a Africa to attend the event . 
Eleven award be hand out to farmer , school , and shire council for excellence in land conservation . 
Western Australia dominate take home three award , New South Wales and South Australia two and one go to Tasmania , Queensland and the Northern Territory . 
Governor-General Major General Michael Jeffery present the ABC with an award for it support . 
But for many whose life be touch by the late Mr Farley , a co-founder of Landcare , it be the dedication of an international award in his name that be the highlight of the evening .

The NRMA be call on the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to investigate what it allege be price gouge by Australia 's oil company , a fuel price fall . 
NRMA director and former NFF president Graham Blight be meet National party senator in Canberra today to discuss the issue . 
He say claim by the oil company that they be pass on all of the recent fall in wholesale fuel price be simply not accurate . 
`` The Singapore unleaded price have drop by 29 per cent , '' he say . 
`` The crude price have drop 22 per cent . So the difference between what we 've have here be a drop of 14 per cent and the Singapore unleaded be 15 per cent .

The Bush administration have be sing the praise this year of cut farm support . 
But farm state lawmaker be resist sweep reform and opposition could stiffen if Democrats regain control of at least the House amid several Republican scandal . 
Likely Democratic Agriculture chairman , Collin Peterson , blame US WTO concession . 
Mr Peterson say he be not go to give up 60 per cent of the US farm program until the EU , Japan and others give up their barrier to trade . 

Zinc price soar 
The price of zinc have soar to $ US1.66 a pound a world stock slip to their low level in 15 year . 
Zinc miner Zinifex say official stock be likely to drop to zero next year because of low production .

`` What they 're say be the official stock in LME [ London Metals Exchange ] will probably get very , very low and obviously a they do that price go up , '' he say .

`` There 's no safety data whatsoever to describe their use in people and we just do n't know what be the effective level or safety level , '' he say .

A gold mine in far north-western New South Wales that close more than 100 year ago may reopen . 
A 700 square kilometre prospect centre on Tibooburra be originally mine from 1880 to 1891 before water shortage and low gold price force it closure .

Rural training body have give the Federal Government 's plan to give training voucher to school drop-outs a cautious welcome .

`` It 's a very positive response . The skill shortage be a complex issue through rural and regional Australia , '' he say .

Tasmanian fire service say they have bring under control all 12 bushfires around the state . 
The bad blaze be in the state 's south , although fire have also be report on Flinders Island and Cape Barren Island . 
There have be no report of serious property damage but with temperature push 30 degree , the fire service warn the situation could worsen . 
In Victoria , a bushfire burn south of Mt Baw Baw in Gippsland have spread to 300 hectare , drive by strong northerly wind . 
Fifty firefighter be work on the blaze and bulldozer be cut containment line to stop it spread . 

Cyclone warn for Top End resident 
Residents live the Northern Territory 's Top End region be be urge to take preparation for the come cyclone season very seriously . 
CSIRO survey have show tropical cyclone Monica , which hit the Arnhem Land coast in April , devastate a wider area and more vegetation , and bring strong wind than cyclone Tracy , which flatten Darwin in 1974 . 
Researcher Dr Gary Cook say Monica snap off tree at the trunk up to 40 kilometre inland . 
`` The cyclone go past and do a lot of damage in Maningrida , but in the bush there be only about 15 per cent of the tree be snap off or topple over , '' Dr Cook say . 
`` Whereas out where cyclone Monica cross the coast be close to 80 per cent that compare to cyclone Tracy with Darwin , where it be only about one third of eucalyptus tree in town be topple over with cyclone Tracy .

Climate modelling from around the world continue to support what farmer have believe for year , that it be get drier .

He say that trend be now also come through elsewhere in Australia .

DNA cattle fee test draw attention 
Queensland 's Gold Coast saw a gathering of 650 people today for Beefex , the Australian lot feeder national conference . 
The cost of grain feed be on everyone 's lip . 
The commercial release of a new DNA test that can identify which cattle be likely to put on the most weight with the least feed have be announce today . 
CSIRO Livestock Industries and it commercial arm , Genetioc Solutions , take 18 month to identify four genetic marker that influence the feed intake efficiency of cattle . 
Feedlotters might fee a steer 1.5 tonne of feed over a 100 day . 
The announcement have draw lot of attention a feed price spiral across the country . 

AAC grazing plan prove successful : manager 
The nation 's large pastoral house have prove you can graze cattle productively in the outback without fence . 
The Australian Agricultural Company ( AAC ) be use water and herd to control graze across 500 square kilometre . 
Rockhampton Downs manager Ben Wratten say it have take two year to change the habit of cattle and so reduce overgrazing . 
`` We rotate them and alternate them from water point by shut off the one we do not want them to drink at , '' he say . 
`` We have get hard evidence now that it have definitely make a difference in the recovery of our pasture and we have full crown of mitchell grass within 200 metre of the trough . 
`` The cattle be burn a lot less energy to access good bulk feed .

A German owned ship load with 72,000 tonne of AWB wheat bound for Sudan remain idle in Port Lincoln in South Australia . 
Following negotiation overnight , eight crew member who go on strike over pay and condition will now be send back to the Philippines , leave the ship anchor in the port . 
Dean Summers from the International Transport Workers Federation say the ship 's owner be look for more crew but it might be hard to attract them . 
`` I think it will be a couple of day and these guy will be send home , '' he say . 
`` We have get to wait for the Filipino seafarer to join it again , so there will be eight more guy come onto this . 
`` Although the guy come on will have to realise that they will be expect wage about half the already low international minimum , so it would not be a very attractive deal for anybody . ''

Mining expansion may affect water resource 
The coal industry have concede that water resource may be damage by rapid expansion of underground mining in New South Wales . 
Spending on coal exploration in New South Wales have increase by 50 per cent in the last year and many new mine be set to open in the Hunter Valley and the state 's north west . 
Chris Moran , from the Sustainable Minerals Institute at Queensland University , say the scientific understanding of underground aquifer and the technology need to mine around them still haven not be develop . 
`` The question here be whether we have do the technical engineering research early enough to have effectively work out the cracking , the surface slumping and start to look at underground technique that will allow either the crack to be seal up or the cracking to be minimise during the process of mining , '' he say .

A supermarket in Australia 's second large wine grow region be currently sell wine more cheaply than bottled water . 
In another sign of the wine industry 's plight , the Fisher 's supermarket chain in north-west Victoria 's Sunraysia area have locally produce cleanskin red and white for $ 2 a bottle . 
Director Alan Fisher say he be not cash in on the difficulty of wine-grape grower in his local community because the only answer to the oversupply will be to move excess stock . 
`` There be a huge glut and we have get to get rid of it somehow , '' he say . 
`` I think what we be see be people sell it to people like ourselves to get rid of it a a cleanskin .

Farmers have react angrily to the Victorian Government 's drought assistance package , announce yesterday , say they have miss out once again .

Assistance for farmer include mental health service and counsel , business support and farming advice .

`` I think they 're treat u like idiot , '' he say . 
`` They think that we need social worker run around here pat u on the back and tell u that everything be go to be all right . 
`` And they 've miss the real point , [ which ] be that farmer and rural community can look after themselves . 

Water Initiative have room for improvement : report 
The first stage of a national assessment of Australia 's water resource have find there be considerable room for improvement . 
The Australian Water Resources 2005 report be a baseline assessment of Australia 's national water resource conduct by national independent agency include the CSIRO . 
It be design to show how the National Water Initiative , a blueprint for the country 's water reform , be influence Australia 's water resource . 
It reveal there be considerable room for improvement and say the state and federal government need to take firm action to put in place effective water planning to protect river system and to agree on a national standard for sustainable yield of surface and ground water system .

National party Senator Barnaby Joyce say the Federal Government 's current water trading plan will damage the social and economic infrastructure of regional town .

There be plan to take more water for environmental flow and increase water trading across state boundary .

`` What 'll happen be the function of small town base around irrigation on a sustainable basis will lose their water to other mechanism that probably do n't have the same history , the same infrastructure , economic and social infrastructure base round them , '' he say .

A small group of cereal farmer from northern New South Wales have have enough of drought condition and have buy some of the wet agricultural land in the country . 
They have purchase cane farm in north Queensland 's Tully area , where annual rainfall regularly exceed 4,000 millimetre . 
Until now , Hugh Ball have grow thing like wheat , barley , chick pea and dry land cotton , but he say he and a few mate decide to branch out . 
`` Really there be three fella sit round a table and we 're all farmer , '' he say . 
`` We 're all [ from ] family driven farm and we be just look for an opportunity . 
`` We could n't do it ourselves so we think if we team up and use individual expertise this be a logical place to start look , good rain . 

Oil company deny collusion claim 
Australia 's oil company have tell a Senate inquiry they be not collude with each other to manipulate price . 
Caltex be appear before the petrol pricing inquiry in Canberra today , while BP have also make a submission . 
Caltex 's chief executive Des King say the company only make a profit of 2.2 cent after tax on each litre of fuel sell . 
He have tell senator that competition , not collusion , be the main driver for set petrol price . 
`` It be very important to people who operate petrol station to have high-volume traffic through their station because if somebody find that if their traffic through their station be low , they will then follow the price down , if somebody 's already lead the price down , to get their volume back up , because this be very much a low margin , high volume kind of business , '' he say . 
Committee member , Senator Andrew Murray , say it be unlikely collusion be take place between the oil company . 

Natural resource management a high priority for farmer : survey 
A new survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show farmer on average spend 121 day of work , or $ 28,000 in financial term , maintain their property each year . 
The survey of 20,000 farmer between 2004-2005 , find Australia 's primary producer spend $ 3.3 billion annually on natural resource management . 
While the grain and beef industry be the big spender , the high spender per farm be the cotton industry at a $ 250,000 a year . 
The director of environment statistic , David Brereton , say the study identify how much time and money farmer spend maintain their property and their environment , and in what way . 
`` Out of the $ 3.3 billion nationally , weed stack up a the major cost with $ 1.3 billion or one third of that be spend on weed , land and soil issue be $ 900 million and pest issue be $ 720 million , '' he say .

The Queensland Government will pay cane farmer $ 2,000 a hectare to plough out and remove sugar cane crop infest by smut . 
The long awaited plan of attack come month after the fungal disease be first discover near Childers in the state 's south-east . 
Since smut be find in June , surveillance have uncover it on more than 60 property , total 380 hectare in the Isis and Bundaberg region . 
Isis Canegrowers chairman Joe Russo say destruction measure will help contain the disease to south-east Queensland . 
`` I see no point in leave smut infest block out there , '' he say . 
`` We 've now identify smut in some of those block of ratoon that have be harvest for the 2006 season . 
`` So it do go to show that we can not leave it there and let the wind just blow it around .

The Federal Health Minister , Tony Abbott , say a four-day bird flu pandemic simulation will test Australia 's quarantine and health system on Monday . 
He say the $ 4 million exercise be the big health crisis simulation ever undertake in Australia and will involve more than 1,000 Commonwealth and state government official and staff . 
Mr Abbott say part of the exercise will involve a passenger carry bird flu arrive at Brisbane Airport on Tuesday . 
`` It will help test our border control , disease detection and surveillance , contact tracing , quarantine and treatment system , '' he say .

Drought force revision of USDA wheat forecast 
The US Agriculture Department ( USDA ) have make dramatic change to it late wheat forecast base largely on the unfolding Australian drought disaster . 
The USDA knock down it estimate of Australian wheat production by a whopping 8.5 metric tonne to just 11 million tonne in just one month and this have sharply change US number . 
Chairman of USDA 's World Agricultural Outlook Board Gerald Bange blame Australia 's drought and extreme heat . 
`` The Australians will not be in the export market the way they would have be otherwise , '' he say . 
`` As a result of that , we have increase our export forecast today . 
`` We go up 25 million bushel from our previous forecast . '' 

Water restriction yet to be introduce in Broken Hill 
Despite the critical shortage of water in the Menindee Lakes in western New South Wales , the city of Broken Hill remain without water restriction . 
The lake system , which supply the city with all it water , be down to just 14 per cent capacity . 
But Country Energy 's Brian Steffan say restriction have not be introduce , partly because of concern about lead poisoning . 
`` Broken Hill be situate where it be have significant issue with lead dust , so what we need to do be make sure that we have enough water , '' he say . 
`` We use more water than other eastern city [ and ] town because we need to make sure that we have water to keep the lead dust down . '' 
Meanwhile high security irrigators in the New South Wales Murray Valley have become the late farmer to have their water allocation reduce . 
Allocations be now back to 80 per cent of entitlement . 
A similar cutback be make recently in South Australia . 
The New South Wales Government say inflow in September be the low on record and there have be no October rain so far . 
The chairman of the New South Wales Irrigators Council , Col Thomson , say he be not surprise by the decision , which he say will affect many farmer . 
`` Dairy farmer and those people that have n't have enough water on low security have be very active in the market and a lot of high security have trade down to what they would normally use in a year , '' he say .

A 5,000 hectare bushfire in the Kosciuszko National Park have be contain by weekend rain but it be still a complex operation to put it out . 
No property be lose in the blaze but sear temperature and hot westerly wind sweep the flame through new grassland that have grow where the tree be burn in the 2003 summer fire .

`` Yesterday we have a FLIR [ forward look infra red sensor/laser range ] machine come down , that 's a helicopter with a forward look infrared device which pick up hot spot , '' he say .

The dry weather and crown rot disease have force South Australia 's durum wheat production to be cut dramatically this season .

Australia 's resource sector say it will be difficult to find an extra 70,000 worker over the next decade , estimate to meet it demand for labour . 
A new report by a nationwide skill shortage work group show that Western Australia will struggle the most , with the mineral industry there demand an extra 42,000 job .

`` I think one of the thing that we will have to do be continually look at immigration , '' he say . 
`` Immigration 's not go to be the sole solution by any mean , it 's across the board and a I say , work with the people that be here . 
`` But immigration be go to be an important element , I think , if we be to meet these target . '' 
Meanwhile Australia 's coal industry have be tell it need to properly coordinate it infrastructure need if it i to reap the benefit of future export .

Residents of King Island in Bass Strait be call for a feasibility study into wave power , in the hope that one day the island could be self-sufficient in electricity .

He say the island 's position be ideal . 
`` We have an active wave climate here on the western side of the island in particular , be at 40 degree south in the path of the roaring forty , '' he say .

An agribusiness analyst predict the unprecedented drought will wipe ten of million of dollar of profit off key grain handling and marketing company . 
Austock predict Australian winter wheat production will be down 60 per cent on the national five year average to 13.4 million tonne .

`` Graincorp for instance will be the most impacted , it will have a negative profit of around minus $ 20 million for 07 in our estimate , '' he say .

Collinsville mine wait for final green light 
After 10 year of exploration in the Collinsville area and 18 month of preliminary development , Q Coal Pty Ltd be expect to start serious construction early next year . Situated in the Charters Towers mining district , the open cut mine be six kilometre south of Collinsville . Managing director Christopher Wallin say the final deadline for community objection to the project be November 8 and they have apply for three , 30 year lease to support the open cut mine . 
`` We believe that there 'll be over 100 job full time and during construction of course there 'll be several hundred job in the construction phase . '' 

Grain price hike felt from the trough to the plate 
It 's go to cost a lot more to put food on your plate , a the flow on effect from a hike in grain continue down the line . As the State 's overall supply dwindles , it 's not just the big agricultural industry like cattle feedlot feel the pinch , small time producer , egg farmer , baker , and even coffee shop be be force to increase their price to keep afloat . 
Fiona Eastwell and her family have just buy an agricultural business near Townsville and while it 's too early for them to feel it in the north , their coffee shop and restaurant business in south-east Queensland have see the consequence . 
`` We be consider pull sandwich price up , meal price up- just a little of everything over the board because it effect from make pikelets , from buy in gateau and cake . '' 
Jeff Ironside own 12 Oaks Poultry , Townsville and manage 200,000 chooks to supply egg to a number of business . He 's see a huge increase in grain price , a he buy over 5000 tonne of grain annually and be look at a rather dramatic increase in his own price to maintain a profit margin . 
`` Normally we 're look to stock up , but there 's not a lot of grain on the ground and what there be , be as dear a poison . '' 
David Henderson from Riverina Australia , a grain supplier base in Oakey in south-east Queensland say there be a major shortage of sorghum , wheat and barley , and a their product be send to agency all around Queensland can see the whole industry from the paddock to the trough . 
He say he have n't see a price hike as severe a this before . 

NFF encourage support for farmer 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) say critic of the Federal Government 's extension to it drought support be ignore economic reality . 
Environmental scientist from the Wentworth Group and the Australia Institute say the $ 350-million extension to the relief program be encourage farmer to stay on unviable land . 
But NFF president David Crombie say farmer must be support , so when the drought break they be ready to quickly ramp up production . 
`` I mean Australian agriculture contribute something like $ 103 billion into the Australian economy , $ 30 billion in export , 1.6 million job , we 're achieve productivity growth of 3-4 per cent . Australian agriculture be very important to Australia , '' he say . 

Package welcome 
The exceptional circumstance ( EC ) extension be very welcome in the grazing country from Canberra south to the Victorian border . 
From Braidwood to the Snowy Mountains , grazier have be destocking and try to survive for several year on less than half average rainfall . 
Brian Clifford , from the Cooma Rural Lands Protection Board , say government can not do any more now for farmer , unless they can make it rain . 
`` At least they 're recognise that they need the rural industry and it be a one in one hundred or probably bad now , '' he say . 
`` I think it 's great news what they have do and let 's hope we get a break in the autumn . '' 
But the first stage of the drought assistance package will offer relief to only a handful of Queensland primary producer - about 14 farmer in the North Burnett region . 
Queensland Farmers Federation executive officer John Cherry hop future announcement will have more benefit for his member . 
And Western Australian farmer have miss out altogether because a state drought assistance scheme end at a later date than state aid elsewhere . 
Meanwhile a prominent Australian researcher say the drought be even bad than most of u think . 
Professor Paul Perkins , from the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University , say our dry condition be be mirror in place like the western United States , Spain and Portugal . 
He say Australia must learn to produce twice as much food with half the water , to help fee the world . 
`` It appear that in area of the Northern Hemisphere , similar to ours , this summer just finishing have be much bad than 2002 , '' he say . 
`` Which mean you have get another bad summer come in Australia , much bad than any since European settlement in Australia . 

Govt abandon Paradise Dam water tender process 
A new way of marketing water to irrigators in Queensland appear to have fail . 
Queensland Government-owned SunWater have abandon the tender process for the sale of water from the new Paradise Dam in southern Queensland . 
The 300,000 megalitre dam , currently at just 13 per cent capacity , be west of Bundaberg on the Burnett River , but it water have attract only limited interest from irrigators . 

Cane toad may head south with flooding rain 
If the drought end , with the traditional flooding rain , it could introduce an unwelcome pest to the south-eastern state . 
Frog expert Professor Mike Tyler say cane toad be already present in the southern Queensland area of the Murray Darling basin and will start move downstream along the Darling when it flood , possibly as far a South Australia . 
He say it be not a matter of if they head south , but when . 
`` The Murray system itself be really perfect environment for the cane toad , '' he say . 
`` I 'm not talk about the major river channel itself but instead the billabong along the side . 

Iron ore price forecast to increase 
The head of Rio Tinto Iron Ore have forecast an increase in iron ore price in the next round of international negotiation , due to get under way next month . 
Chief executive Sam Walsh say while the Brazilians settle the price in the last round , Australia be the number two supplier in the world and be in a strong position this time . 
`` The first part of the negotiation be , in fact , set the scene , particularly in relation to economics , GDP growth and obviously steel and iron ore usage , '' he say . 

Mine expansion bond not enough : WWF 
Traditional owner and conservationist have vow to continue campaign against expansion of the Northern Territory 's McArthur River lead and zinc mine . 
That be despite the Territory Government give the green light for diversion of the tropical river , to allow mining of one of the world 's large ore deposit beneath the river bed . 
Dr Stuart Blanch of the World Wide Fund for Nature ( WWF ) say the $ 55 million bond will not be enough to safeguard the Gulf of Carpentaria . 
`` What can it do if there be major pollution spill into the McArthur ? '' he say . 
`` I have never hear any reasonable technical or engineering proposal that would say for $ 55.5 million or in that ballpark , this be how we can recapture lead and zinc or other acid or heavy metal that be escape into the river that have be absorb by fish or dugong , or turtle and pollute the sediment . 

Frost hit cherry grower hardest 
Severe frost have destroy up to half of this season 's fruit crop in Tasmania . 
It have be confirm that cherry grower have be hard hit , with loss range from 30 to 80 per cent , while apple and apricot grower have also report heavy loss . 
Domestic shortage be now expect in the coming month after frost also decimate Victoria 's Goulburn Valley crop . 
And Gerald Ellis , from the Vineyards Association of Tasmania , say some grape grower expect to lose half this season 's fruit . 

US vow not to compete over Japanese beef market 
The United States beef industry have pledge to try to expand the Japanese beef market , rather than take market share from Australia . 
Australia be currently host beef producer from the United States , Canada , Mexico and New Zealand for the annual five nation beef talk . 
The president of the US National Cattlemen 's Beef Association , Mike John , say they would rather grow a contracted Japanese beef market than compete against Australia . 
`` I do n't really look at it a a competitive issue , I think that the entire beef consumption be down in Japan - I mean regardless of where the beef come from , '' he say . 

Authorities monitor European bluetongue virus outbreak 
Australian authority be carefully watch an outbreak of the bluetongue virus in Europe . 
Bluetongue be spread by bite insect and can kill infected livestock . 
Richard Norris , from Western Australia 's Department of Agriculture and Food , say while the virus also exist in Australia a new strain could affect Middle East trade . 
He say the late outbreak have affect more than 700 cattle and sheep on the border of Belgium , Holland , Germany and France . 
`` It 's mainly affected sheep but it 's also make some cattle sick and a few of them have die , '' Mr Norris say . 
`` Now this be the first time it 's be record with credibility that cattle have be sick with a particular strain of bluetongue . 

Communities feel drought impact 
A report have reveal 10 per cent of Queenslanders live in poverty and those in regional and remote area be among the most vulnerable . 
The study be carry out by the University of Queensland 's Social Research Centre . 
Jill Lang , from the Queensland Council of Social Service , say 400,000 people in the state be survive on half the average weekly income . 
`` There be a number of reason for this , '' she say . 

Cloud juice head for export market 
Rainwater from Tasmania 's King Island could soon become part of a Japanese tradition . 
King Island Cloud Juice , a it be retail , be currently be seek after to make the rice wine - sake . 
Company director Duncan McFie say demand for the rainwater be increase across the world and expansion be likely . 
`` I have this idea year ago that just a King Island Dairy have a tanker that drive around and pick up all the milk , I have this little cloud juice tanker in my head that drive around and pick up all the water , '' he say . 

Boxer Bronco Johnson die at 78 
Australia have lose one of the last true box showman , north Queenslander Don 'Bronco ' Johnson , who die this week at the age of 78 . 
Bronco Johnson earn a reputation throughout Australia for his wild fighting style , his courageous rodeo riding and his Errol Flynn moustache . 
In the 1950s and 1960s he lead a travel 10-man boxing and rodeo troupe , take on all challenger . 
Troupe member Harry Grogan say it be a tough way to make a living , but he thoroughly enjoy work with 'Bronco ' . 
`` Any time he fight he use to get the crowd in because they use to love him , the way he would swing at people and hit them from his knee , '' he say . 

Parasitic wasp ' project secure $ 4m 
A research project into parasitic wasp have be award $ 4 million by the National Science Foundation in the United States . 
Professor Andrew Austin from Adelaide University will lead the international research to examine and name the thousand of wasp specie . 
He say wasp be crucial for ecological balance and may be important biological control agent in the future . 

Concerns govt regulation limit mining investment 
The Western Australian mineral exploration sector claim government regulation be cost the state billion of dollar in lose investment . 
WA have record it low ever level of exploration spending , while other state , like New South Wales and South Australia , have almost double theirs . 
Justin Wolawski , from the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies , say Western Australia have a reputation a a difficult place to do business due to native title and environmental constraint . 
`` The mineral exploration and mining industry take up point zero three percent of the state land mass , it 's a minuscule amount of the state , '' he say . 
`` But what 's in front of mineral exploration and mining company in some case be approval of both house of Parliament , approval from the Minister of Environment , and then further impediment alongside there . 

Abalone farm keen to restock after virus 
An abalone farm be attempt to get it business back on track after the discovery of a herpes-like virus on the south-west coast of Victoria earlier this year . 
Port Fairy 's Southern Ocean Mariculture voluntarily destocked three million abalone to prevent the disease spreading . 
The company say test during the past six week have show the farm be now free of the virus . 
General manager Mark Jervis say an application to move stock back onto the farm need to be approve by the Victorian Government 

Old wife ' tale confirm , milk help people sleep 
If you have have a few sleepless night over the continue dry weather try a warm glass of milk before bed . 
A Dutch study have find that the amino acid find in milk not only make for a good night 's sleep , but also activate a hormone in the brain that make people more active in the morning . 
Dairy Australia dietitian Maree Garside say it be really confirm what many have know for a long time . 
`` They 're suggest that be alert in the morning may be due to a good night 's sleep and this serotonin , that 's produce in the brain be sort of help along by have tryptophan in your food such a a glass of milk , '' she say . 
`` This be I guess a bit of research to back up something that we may have know for a while . '' 
Meanwhile , Victorian scientist have find that the amount of feed a dairy cow eats do not affect it ability to withstand a long lactation period . 
Researchers believe extend lactation can make cow healthy and give farmer good cash flow . 
Dr Martin Auldist , from the Victorian Primary Industries Department , say the finding that no extra feed need to be buy to sustain a long lactation come a a big surprise . 

Possibilities for GM cotton raise at conference 
Northern Australian irrigators and researcher have not give up on genetically modify cotton . 
The crop have be exclude from the Ord Valley , by the Western Australian Government , and be ban in the Northern Territory . 
But grower attend a national irrigation conference in Darwin want to plant it . 
Researcher John Moulden say trial have prove GM cotton use less water than exist Ord Valley crop like sugar cane and banana . 
`` We be not advocate cotton a the be all and end all for the Ord , it 's just one of the option we feel farmer in the Ord really need and deserve , '' he say . 
`` There 's no scientific or environmental reason why GM cotton should n't be grow in northern Australia - the issue have be extensively address . 

Govt unveil quarantine change 
The Federal Government say change to Australia 's quarantine system , announce today , will streamline assessment of import . 
The Agriculture Minister , Peter McGauran , say quarantine risk assessment process will be strengthen by more scientific scrutiny , as well a improve and early consultation with importer and farmer . 

Transporter 's business boom a farmer send stock to Tas 
Desperate Victorian dairy farmer be send their stock to Tasmania . 
One of Tasmania 's big livestock cart contractor , Page Transport , be bring up to 40 load of cattle a week from Victoria , include some dairy cow still in milk , to be agisted on the north-west coast . 
The company 's operation manager , Chris Page , say it be an unfortunate consequence of the drought that his business be flat out . 
`` The transport industry in Tasmania will be busier through a drought , which like it or not that 's our stance on it , but it be an awful thing , '' he say . 

Pool arrangement 'do n't secure ' grower 
The Grains Council of Australia say new trust arrangement for the national pool , which make AWB Limited the sole beneficiary of the trust , will not protect the financial interest of grower . 
AWB National Pool Trust Pty Limited have be set up to quarantine the liability of each pool within that national pool , start with this financial year . 
But Grains Council chairman Murray Jones say the arrangement do nothing to change the status of grower from unsecured to secure creditor . 
`` Our legal advice be tell u that because they 've make AWB Limited a beneficiary of the trust then that do n't really achieve what we aim to do , which be to ensure the grower and the pool participant be the secured creditor , '' he say . 
`` Growers today be really focus on how serious the drought be . They be really do it tough , and we need to do whatever we can to preserve their equity in this current pool . '' 
But the chairman of AWB International , Ian Donges , say the Grains Council have get it all wrong about the new trust . 
He say grower will enjoy more financial security , not less . 
`` The reason we go down the trust path be that we want to give pool participant additional protection against any unforeseen liability , '' he say . 

Coalition split over AWB 's single desk 
The Deputy Prime Minister , Mark Vaile , say a split between Coalition MPs , on whether the single desk wheat export system should be scrap , be just a symptom of a healthy debate . 
In the wake of Cole inquiry evidence about AWB kickback to Iraq , up to six MPs include Wilson Tuckey , have call for the end of the single desk . 
But Nationals member , include Senator Barnaby Joyce , say it must be maintain . 
Mr Vaile say the Government be consider all the view of MPs and Senators , along with wheat grower group . 
`` We really do need to wait until Cole report , which be about a month away , and have a look at what the recommendation be and what the outcome of the inquiry be and how that affect the whole structure , '' he say . 
`` We do n't want to be make decision that may be see a knee-jerk reaction and then have to go through another set of change if there be particular recommendation come out of Cole . '' 
Liberal Senator Bill Heffernan say that , while he support a single desk , it be debatable whether AWB be the best company to run it . 

Natural Resources defend water cutback 
The NSW Department of Natural Resources have defend the way it cut back water allocation to 80 per cent for Murray Valley Irrigators . The announcement on Sunday shock many farmer because it come without warn . Executive director for water management David Harriss explain it have be a complex issue to work through . He claim they could not flag the cut in entitlement to irrigators because it would have breach commercial confidence . The reduction will apply only to water still in user ' account , and be n't calculate on the full entitlement . 

Abalone farm 
A Port Fairy abalone farm have be work hard to get it business back on track after be affect by the abalone virus that affect the south-west earlier this year . Southern Ocean Mariculture voluntarily destocked to prevent the disease spread further and now have no commercial stock on the farm . The company have be run a sentinel trial for the last six week to see if there be still any disease outside the water of the farm and the result have come back negative . Sarah Farnsworth catch up with general manager Mark Jervis to find out what process be now take place so the farm can be restock . 

Fishing licence buyback scheme will secure industry 's future : Abetz 
The federal Minister for Fisheries , Eric Abetz , say he be confident the Government 's fishing licence buyback scheme will secure the industry 's future , despite continued illegal fishing in Australian water . 
He be particularly encouraging Bass Strait scallop fisher and northern prawn fisher to apply to have their licence buy out in the second round opening later this month after most of their tender be unsuccessful . 
Senator Abetz say significant success be be make in stop illegal fishing . 
`` I think we be slowly but surely get on top of illegal fishing , '' he say . 
`` In northern Tasmania , a the time we speak now we 've catch 308 vessel this calendar year . 

Greens call for climate change inquiry 
The Greens be call on the Federal Government to establish a Senate inquiry into the implication of climate change for the future of Australian agriculture . 
The party say climate change could profoundly affect rural community and be vital to get a clear picture of what step can be take now to minimise the impact . 
The chair of the Senate 's rural and regional affair committee , Senator Bill Hefferenan , have indicate he will take the Greens proposal to his Liberal partyroom . 
Greens Senator Rachel Siewert be hopeful there will be enough support for an inquiry . 
`` We also want to look at what we can do about it , what be the adaptation strategy need to deal with these impact on our rural community to ensure that they be viable , '' he say . 

Unsold sheep to be take to the tip 
Sheep could be bury in a pit if they be not sell at a South Australian livestock market . 
Prices for old sheep be plummet in the saleyards , with a lack of buyer during the drought . 
One of the state 's big saleyards , Naracoorte , have draw up contingency plan . Any unsold sheep will be place in a pit at the local tip . 
Denis Hovenden from the Naracoorte Lucindale Council say stock agent and the council be try to prevent unsaleable sheep from come into the yard . But under the current regulation , stock can not be return to their owner if they be not sell . 
He say no one want to put the plan into action , but there be very little choice . 
`` At this stage it be very much an unknown , '' he say . 

Compo for Murray Valley irrigators rule out 
The New South Wales Government have rule out compensation for Murray Valley irrigators affect by water cut back . 
High security allocation and carry over water in the Murray Valley have be cut by 20 per cent because of record low inflow . 
The Natural Resources Minister , Ian Macdonald , say the water will be pay back in future , so there be no need for compensation . 
He say more measure to help the farming community will be announce in the next fortnight . 

Drought dominate National Field Days 
New and innovative way of cop with the drought be the most popular exhibit at this year 's National Field Days , currently under way at Orange in central-western New South Wales . 
Amazingly , the long-running drought have not dampen the spirit of those attend the National Field Days at Borenore . 
It be the old field day in Australia , run for 55 year . 
Organisers say exhibitor number and attendance level be very similar to last year , with 30,000 expect through the sun-drenched gate to the parched earth of the Field Days site . 
The hot topic be debate in forum there include manage the risk of climate change . 

Graincorp back call for end to AWB wheat export monopoly 
One of the nation 's big private grain trader have back call for AWB to lose it monopoly for wheat export . 
Western Australian Liberal MP Wilson Tuckey be spearhead a campaign to dismantle the single desk for wheat export , in response to speculation that AWB will make significant trading loss this season . 
Tom Keene , manage director of Graincorp , will not directly criticise AWB . But he say grower would do good if other company be allow to trade in export wheat . 
`` It would be wrong of me to comment on the AWB 's hedge arrangement , '' he say . 
`` My reaction have be and continue to be that a marketplace that have more competition in it would ensure that grower could choose who they sell their grain to , just a they currently do with their other grain . 

Ecuador hopeful banana import ban will be lift 
Ecuador and other banana export country be hopeful the ban on Australia import banana from the Philippines will be overturn before the end of the year . 
The Australian Banana Growers Council say Biosecurity Australia have change it position on the issue several time , but it must take account of the danger of Moko disease in it current import risk analysis . 
Ecuador 's Ambassador Antonio Rodas Posso say if Filipino import get approve , it will make the application process easy for other country . 
`` We have hear that you right now , the Australians , be make research on another kind of banana from another country , '' he say . 

Incidence of breast cancer higher in rural woman : UK study 
A British study have find that rural woman be three time more likely to suffer from breast cancer . 
But Australian researcher say this contradicts with their finding , which indicate the incidence of breast cancer be high in city . 
John Harding , head of the health register and cancer monitoring unit at the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare , say the statistic show that woman in remote Indigenous community have the low incidence of breast cancer . 
`` There be a protective effect for breast cancer for woman who have child earlier and then breast feed for long period of time , '' he say . 

Cherry research , development levy increase 
Australia 's cherry grower have vote to increase their research and development levy by three cent . 
They will now contribute four cent per kilogram , with the industry expect to raise about $ 280,000 a year . 
The secretary of the Cherry Growers Association , Trevor Ranford , say the rise be long overdue . 

Cattle , sheep export death rise 
The number of cattle and sheep death in export shipment have rise slightly in the first six month of this year , compare to the same period last year . 
Department of Agriculture report table in the Senate say cattle death rise from 1.3 in 1,000 to 1.4 . 
Sheep death rise from six in 1,000 to eight . 
Deaths of goat rise from 11 in 1,000 to 13 . 
But the federal Agriculture Minister , Peter McGauran , say animal management measure at port and on live export ship have improve dramatically . 
`` Especially the inspection at the feedlot and also before the stock board the ship , in transit where there 's a requirement for a vet , report daily back to AQIS , with the oversight of an experienced stockman , the improved feed and water system [ and ] the best ship in the world , '' he say . 

Uranium industry heavily regulate : ERA chief 
The head of the Ranger uranium mine in the Northern Territory say new entrant to the uranium industry should prepare themselves for zealous government regulation . 
Harry Kenyon-Slaney , the CEO of Energy Resources Australia ( ERA ) which run Ranger , say his mine be one of the most stringently regulate in the world . 
He say the red tape come at a price and be definitely not for mine company who want to cut corner . 
`` Frankly , uranium mining be just like any other mining , '' he say . 
`` It have some specific issue that need to be manage , just a ... other different mining operation do . 

Drought may affect dairy food supply , exporter say 
A Victorian-based exporter and processor of dairy food have tell a conference in Sydney that Japan be concern about Australia 's capacity to ensure long-term supply because of the drought . 
Burra Foods say Australia export nearly $ 23 billion of food and beverages a year , with Japan take 20 per cent of that . 
But chief executive Grant Crothers say while Japan have be a loyal customer of Australia for two decade , it be now worry about the continue dry condition . 
`` Security of supply for any country that ca n't fee themselves be a big issue and their self-sufficiency on food be down to about 40 per cent and they know they need to buy food outside Japan , '' he say . 

Senate committee back guest worker scheme rejection 
A Senate inquiry have reject farmer ' argument that Pacific islands guest worker should be allow in to ease a national shortage of harvest labour . 
The Senate committee 's report support the Federal Government 's view that a new visa be not need for seasonal farm worker . 
Inquiry chairwoman Judith Troeth say extensive hearing suggest farmer could find Australian harvest labour if they pay good wage and offer adequate working condition and accommodation . 
`` The guarantee that we be give that there would be suitable accommodation and enough work for labourer come in Australia - the confidence there be probably misplace , '' the Victorian Liberal Senator say . 
`` Experienced picker who be Australian tell u that it be often quite difficult to get a good wage on the present piece rate that exist . '' 
The body represent fruit and vegetable grower in north-west Australia be furious about the inquiry 's finding . 
David McKerrell from the Kimberley Primary Industries Association say it be not pay and condition that be put worker off in Kununurra in north-west Western Australia , it be the heat . 
He say many farmer in the district already pay above award wage but it be not help . 
Mr McKerrell want the Federal Government to make exception to allow Pacific Islanders to work in hotter climate like the Kimberley . 
`` Up in Kununurra at present , when it 's 38 degree everyday , it 's not pleasant working , '' he say . 
`` And if these people be around that Senator Troth say there be , surely they would be here . 
`` There 's mango here drop on the ground . 
`` There 's no one available and they 're not here , and the reason they 're not here be because it 's too hot . 
`` They 're not acclimatise to it and that 's the end of the story . '' 
Isis Shire Mayor Bill Trevor give evidence to the Senate Committee when it visit Queensland 's fruit and vegetable grow Bundaberg and Childers region early this year . 
He say the inquiry have hardly look at the many barrier that farmer face in get worker . 
`` There be a need within the farm community to be able to access labour and it 's very , very difficult at time , especially in peak production period , for farmer to pick up that extra labour , '' he say . 
Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) have launch a national advertising campaign to lift domestic beef sale by $ 300 million over the next three year . 
The $ 2.8 million promotion will involve television , radio , newspaper and magazine advertisement start from this Sunday . 
MLA spokesman David Palmer say it have be seven year since beef have be promote and it be important to keep consumer think about it . 
`` The ambition over a lengthy period through until 2009/2010 be to to increase the frequency of beef consumption from 2.3 meal to 2.6 meal per week , '' he say . 
`` There 's a TV advertisement which be a bit quirky , a little bit of humour , that take up back to the beginning of Australia , the beginning of white settlement in Australia . 
`` You know it 's just a good story about beef and summer , and barbeque . '' 
And a part of a new marketing plan for King Island beef , the product be now be use in gourmet meat pie sell at the supermarket . 
Traditionally , only cut such a eye fillet and porter house have attract a premium price for the King Island brand . 
Tasman Group marketing manager Lydia Horsburgh say the pie will open up the product to a wider group of shopper . 

Young cattle price slip 
Young cattle value in eastern Australia have slip to their low level in three year . 
The eastern young cattle indicator fell 29.5 cent in the past week to finish yesterday on 267 cent per kilogram carcase weight . 
That mean the indicator have fall 28 per cent since January . 
Southern Queensland livestock agent Noel Grant say he be not surprised a beef producer run out of feed and water . 
`` It 's something we expect to happen , '' he say . 
`` The confidence have go out of the store market generally .

The Deputy Prime Minister , Mark Vaile , be expect to announce another major drought relief package next week , extend assistance to more farmer , their family and rural business . 
The package be expect to bring Federal Government drought spend to more than $ 2 billion . 
The Federal Government say further change to it drought relief package will mean thousand more farmer in more region will become eligible for exceptional circumstance drought assistance . 
It be already encourage the South and Western Australian state government to apply for EC status . 
It have also listen to call from Coalition backbencher for help for farm-related business , extra measure to combat rural depression and more emergency assistance for rural family . 

Locusts threaten Nullarbor crop 
It have appear that crop near the Nullarbor in South Australia 's far west look like be some of the best in the nation because they have receive reasonable rain . 
But now they be under threat from locust and local farmer say they be not get the help they need from the State Government . 
Brian Smith from Coorabie , west of Ceduna , say newly hatch locust be wreak havoc on crop . 
`` For the last week at least we 've be flat out try to keep them out the crop a they ripen , '' he say . 
`` A lot of the crop in the district now have sort of ripen , but any crop that be a bit later have take a fair old hammering . 
`` One farmer I think be probably go to give up on a 400 or 500 acre paddock of barley . 

South-west NSW resident pray for rain 
Residents of south-west New South Wales have turn to prayer to break the drought . 
Farmers and town folk have be unite at ecumenical church service . 
More than 100 people come together in Wagga to call for rain , while another inter-faith prayer service take place in Leeton . 
Pastor Michael Skewes say aside from the spiritual value of prayer , it be a strong show of support for those on the land . 
`` I think for the farmer that be here - we saw a number of hand go up and say 'yeah , we 're farmer ' - for them to know that the Wagga community , we in the city really do care for what they 're go through I think that 's get enormous value as well , '' he say . 
In complete contrast , land clear fire rag across Kalimantan and Sumatra could be prompt increased rain across the Top End . 
Over the past 50 year , some station rainfall have increase by up to 300 millimetre . 
Climatologist Sam Cleland say rainfall in part of the Victoria River district and Kimberley be increase by 50 millimetre per decade 
`` It 's potentially that it 's not a direct result of greenhouse gas , '' he say . 
`` It might even be due to increase pollution over South East Asia change the temperature structure of the atmosphere and the temperature gradient between northern Australia and South East Asia in our summer season . 

Grain president resigns after single desk comment 
Wrangling over the single desk 's future in the nation 's large grain grow state have claim a scalp . 
Earlier this week , the Western Australian Farmers Federation 's grain president , Ray Marshall , release a new and alternative policy position , urge the single desk be maintain . 
But , at least for this season , he urge that the power of veto be remove from AWB and transfer to the Wheat Export Authority . 
The statement have divide group member . 

Calls for Biosecurity Aust to be independent authority 'out of line ' 
A war have break out over change to the controversial import risk assessment process . 
The federal Agriculture Minister , Peter McGaruan , announce this week that from next year there will be great scientific scrutiny of the import risk assessment , a regulated time frame and more regular consultation with farmer . 
While the National Farmers Federation say the bulk of it member support the new protocol , chief executive Ben Fargher say call by NSW farmer for Biosecurity Australia to be make into an independent statutory authority be totally out of line . 
`` It be always so important to have unity when talk to government , '' he say . 
`` Disunity when deal with government be death .

Farmers and small business have welcome the passing of amendment to the Trade Practices Act , which simplify collective bargaining .

Chief executive Mike Stone say grower will now be able to genuinely negotiate with winery . 
`` Usually grape buyer give grower a price in say January and unless there 's a dispute resolution provision that allow grower to dispute those price they be take a a give , '' he say . 
`` It 's a take it or leave it proposition often . 

CSIRO NT plant research division close 
The Northern Territory will no longer host a division of CSIRO 's plant industry research . 
That be despite increased interest in northern agriculture with it good water supply , and $ 1 million from the Territory Government to improve the laboratory . 

Darwin resident encourage to save water 
People live across tropical northern Australia be also be urge to conserve water . 
Darwin resident use more than twice the national average amount of water , but it be hop convert garden to suit the dry tropic will help reduce water use . 
Some politician , like independent Gerry Wood , be also call for small dam to be develop in the Daly region , south-west of Darwin . 
`` I think we have to look at thing differently , whether you collect water in off farm dam during the wet season , to pump out in the dry , '' Mr Wood say . 
`` There be certainly potential on the Daly to increase the amount of food . 

Drought fail to deter bank from lending 
Despite the drought , the bank be still keen to lend to farmer . 
Queensland property valuer Kerry Herron say he believe the property market will come back due to the poor seasonal condition . 
He say the boom in recent year have increase landholder ' equity and the bank be particularly willing to lend to buyer in the wetter northern region . 
`` Cattle be still the flavour of the month and they 're still offer very big term , '' Mr Herron say . 
`` We have hear instance of up to 30 year interest only payment , certainly 10 and 15 year interest only be common . 

Climate Institute urge more action on greenhouse emission 
The farmer-funded Climate Institute have launch a national advertising campaign , call on the Federal Government to do more to reduce Australia 's greenhouse gas emission . 
The organisation say the drought have be intensify by climate change and a national carbon trading scheme and increase mandatory renewable energy use target be need . 
In his weekly online radio message the Prime Minister , John Howard , say the Government be spend $ 2 billion on reduce climate change . 
But the Climate Institute 's founder , beef and sheep farmer Mark Wootton , say these measure be not work because greenhouse emission be increase . 
`` Under what be put forward at the moment our greenhouse , the Australian government 's current policy , increase emission by 10 per cent over the last decade and it will increase them by a further 17 per cent by 2020 unless we change what we be do , '' Mr Wootton say . 

Analyst promote forest a answer to energy supply 
An Australian analyst have dismiss the push for more ethanol and biodiesel production , say Australia 's energy future lie in wood . 
Barney Foran , a visit fellow at the Australian National University , say plant 60 million hectare of forest could provide up to 90 per cent of future transport fuel , and 20 per cent of future electricity need . 
He say many different specie of wood could be use , include native tree , and this could provide another source of income for farmer in tough time . 
Mr Foran say fuel processing plant should be build in regional area . 
`` The key here be that we do n't cart wood long distance or else we lose both the economic advantage or more importantly the energy advantage , '' he say . 

Farm Institute report urge rethink on marketing 
An independent farm think tank say the Australian farmer 's share of world agriculture export have fall by almost $ 3 billion in a decade . 
An Australian Farm Institute report , release today , show Chile and Brazil 's agriculture export double in the 10 year to 2004 , while Australia 's export grow by only half that amount . 
Report author Selwyn Helibron say farmer must focus on how to market their product to their customer , or continue to lose market share . 

Crews battle fire near Bathurst 
Fire authority in New South Wales be still try to control a bushfire north-west of Bathurst . 
The fire have burn 1,400 hectare of grazing and scrub country , threaten a number of house . 
The fire jump containment line over the weekend , but be quickly bring back within the line , by ground crew . 

Suspension of WTO talk hamper US effort to fight AWB 
The suspension of World Trade Organisation ( WTO ) talk be make it hard for US farmer and trade official to take action to try to end AWB 's monopoly for export Australian wheat . 
The last Doha round draft call for banning or phase out single-desk monopoly , like AWB , by 2013 . 
But with WTO talk suspend since July , American Farm Bureau trade adviser Dave Salonsen say there be no way for the US to fight AWB . 
`` If they be operate accord to WTO rule , a they exist now and you ca n't see that they 're somehow not follow them , there 's not much opportunity , potentially , to go through a dispute settlement , '' Mr Salonsen say . 
Australia agree in it bilateral free trade deal with the US to address single desk trading in the WTO round . 

30,000 cattle import to Indonesia for Ramadan 
At least 30,000 import cattle have be sell across Indonesia for the Islamic festival of Ramadan . 
The last fast will be break this evening and the food festivity begin with prayer tomorrow morning . 
Greg Pankhurst from Agrogiri Perkasa , the large importer of Australian cattle , say he expect 20,000 cattle will be sell in the coming day . 
But he say feedlot sale have still be slow this year . 
`` We have n't be run off our foot in any way , '' Mr Pankhurst say . 
`` We have go from our traditional 100 a day to 200 a day , which be normal . 
`` So I have 100 per cent increase in sale but the next three or four day we wo n't sell anything because most people have their meat stock in hand . 
`` Traditionally after Labaran , which be tomorrow and Wednesday we will see a little bit of an increase over and above our normal sale . So we will probably sell about 120 to 140 a day . '' 

Livestock price slump 
Sheep and cattle price have slump across the nation , a farmer offload stock they can not fee . 
Sheep have lose nearly 75 per cent of their value in the past four week . 
Yardings in all state have increase substantially , with the southern state hit hard . 
Travis Parsci , from the National Livestock Reporting Service , say the fall be drastic . 
`` In the last fortnight we 've probably see 20 to 30 cent shave off a lot of average price . We have see a lot of the plainer grade suffer even large fall , '' he say . 
`` It 's be cause by the large number of cattle come onto the market , a everyone 's aware , by the dry condtions , the lack of water in particular and also a lack of feed that a lot of producer be face with at the moment . '' 
The drought be also push wool price up . 
News of Australia 's plight be prompt wool buyer to stock up for fear that supply will run out . 
The southern market indicator rise by up to 18 cent at last week 's national sale , the big weekly rise since January . 
Tony Kidman from Quality Wool in south Australia , say buyer also want to avoid buy drought-effected wool , which be less strong than other wool .

Campdrafting official say they be hopeful a bid to have their sport recognise by the Australian Sports Commission will be successful . 
The National Campdraft Council of Australia say while the sport be develop in Australia , it still need to go through the process to become a national sporting organisation .

`` It 's give campdrafting credibility , to have thing such a a code of conduct for animal welfare , member protection policy for the protection of our member and their committee and thing like that , '' Mr Cookson say . 

Testing find Aust wildlife free of bird flu 
Ongoing test across Australia 's most susceptible region have find no evidence of the new lethal strain of bird flu in wildlife . 
Last year the H5N1 strain kill thousand of water fowl in China and this year it spread from bird to human in Indonesia . 
Dr John Curran , from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service , say continue trap and test of wild bird across northern Australia have so far fail to isolate any live influenza virus . 
`` But by the same token we 're still concern that the global epidemic be continue and that this have actually come closer to , the epidemic have come closer to Australia through Indonesia , '' Dr Curran say . 

$ 5m study to determine Gippsland groundwater decline 
The Federal Government have provide $ 5 million for a study to find out once and for all what be cause decline groundwater level in Victoria 's south Gippsland . 
A study by the CSIRO two year ago find subsidence of the Latrobe aquifer be cause mostly by offshore oil and gas production . 
Now the Department of Sustainability will conduct far research to see if irrigators should be compensate . 
Bill Bodman Senior , from the Victorian Farmers Federation , say the aquifer have be drop at the rate of one-metre a year for the last 40 year cost farmer thousand of dollar . 
`` The huge extra cost of lift the water up the extra distance , that 's the major cost in bring water to the surface , '' Mr Bodman say .

The Australian Oilseeds Federation say canola yield forecast for 2007 be the low for a decade . 
The estimate for this year 's crop be just 561,000 tonne , due to the failure of many crop across the nation .

Graincorp be prepare to ship 1 million tonne of wheat from Western Australia to the eastern state , a harvest fail in New South Wales , Victoria and Queensland .

The country 's large private irrigation company , Murray Irrigation , expect to lose several million dollar this financial year because of the drought . 
The company will introduce a four day week from mid-November , reduce it weed control program and defer maintenance in a bid to cut cost . 
General manager George Warne say director ' fee will also be reduce by 20 per cent . 

New drought relief package not enough : irrigators 
Irrigators say new Victorian Government drought relief do not go far enough . 
The Victorian Government have announce a $ 5,000 rebate for farmer who receive less than 50 per cent of their water allocation . 
Farmers still pay water authority even when they do not receive water , due to the cost of maintain irrigation channel . 
Chair of the Northern Victorian Irrigators , Dudley Bryant , say with most large dairy and cropping farm pay bill around $ 30,000 , the Government 's offer will only make a small difference . 
`` They have recognise there 's a problem there , '' he say . 
`` They have actually say now that they 'll pick up the cost of water even though there may be a lot of small hobby farmer and whatever , and I 'm not try to say they should or should n't be in it but they be . 

NSW irrigators fight for water fee relief 
Irrigators in New South Wales be currently have no joy in receive assistance for their fixed water charge . 
Only one inland valley have receive a general security allocation this season and there be demand for fee relief across the state . 
Chairman of Jemalong Irrigation Ted Morgan say the New South Wales Government must develop it own assistance package for irrigators . 
`` What we 're really look for be where a set of rule be set up for the valley where , when you have zero allocation some sort of principle kick in like exceptional circumstance , '' he say .

The wool industry 's grower-funded marketing arm have post a $ 316,000 annual loss . 
Australian Wool Services ' ( AWS ) chairman Barry Walker say the company 's Woolmark brand and market research division both return profit . 
But it processing section , Andar , return a deficit and the company 's substantial debt to a UK pension fund drain $ 1.3 million from the business . 
Mr Walker say the organisation be battle the effect of the drought and would be deeper in debt if it have not cut cost earlier in the year . 
`` I think the management do a huge job to reduce the cost against decreased income to actually get u to a loss factor in the finish of $ 300,000 , '' he say . 
`` We 're find that the whole wool chain , from farm right through to retail , be extremely difficult .

He say tree be less susceptible to drought than other crop and the wood thinning would be a valuable source of biofuel .

A technical issue be delay the resumption of US beef export to Korea .

`` The producer segment in Korea 's be very oppose to reopen the market , so there be a lot of political pressure in opposition to reopen the market , but the agreement have be that we would open for boneless beef , '' he say . 
But the Koreans have say they will have zero tolerance for bone chip .

A South Australian company say it could duplicate Australia 's entire wild catch of more than 5,000 tonne of tuna within a decade through captive breeding . 
This follow the successful airlift of nine southern bluefin tuna from offshore sea cage into a $ 6 million tank build by Clean Seas Tuna at Arno Bay . 
The fish will be use to spawn million of egg for harvest in the world 's first captive breeding program for the specie . 
Chairman Hagen Stehr say he could not put a price on the brood stock . 

Hobby farmer work on solve sheep shearing problem 
It be hard to find a shearer if you be a hobby farmer and perhaps have just half a dozen pet sheep . 
But the grow number of hobby farmer in Western Australia 's south-west be work on the problem . 
The local community of Manjimup have it sheep shorn , drench and de-loused for a small fee , with all proceeds to be donate back into the community . 
Local shearer Ron Nivon say it be the best way to handle the region 's increase number of pet sheep . 
`` This be the best thing that ever happen . I think we 've be do it for over 20 year . It 's a great cause , '' he say . 
`` You do n't have that phone ringing and nuisance phone call ask for five or six sheep shorn when you should be out do three or 4,000 sheep . 

CBH set to launch wheat export pool 
Australia 's troubled wheat exporter AWB have another force to deal with today with Western Australia 's large grain bulk handler , CBH , attempt to launch a wheat export pool of it own this harvest . 
As Western Australian grower consider how they will sell their wheat crop this season , the company today have launch an export licence to test the power of veto that AWB have over it single desk licence . 
A previous attempt and subsequent appeal by CBH last December be lose . 
CBH chief executive Imre Mencshelyi say the new move will not undermine the single desk and will put more money into grower pocket this season . 
`` We 've agonise over that decision for sometime and today we 're launch the CBH wheat pool for 2 million tonne volume for West Australian grain grower , '' he say . 
`` At the end of the day we recognise there 'll be divide opinion on what we 'll be put out in the market place but the grower will have this opportunity to deliver and they 'll vote by their action . '' 
AWB 's Ian Donges say that the export application be an attack on the single desk , and will not necessarily result in grower be pay a high price over the life of the propose CBH pool . 
Meanwhile , AWB have increase it new season pool return for premium wheat to $ 245 a tonne , up $ 5 . 

Gold mine operator agree to provide water to farmer 
Farmers have have a breakthrough in their dispute with the new Lake Cowal gold mine in the central west of New South Wales , which have have a dramatic impact on local bore water level . 
The water level have drop from 20 metre to 50 metre below ground level .

`` One of the requirement be that if those trigger level be approach , you have to continue to supply the impacted stock and domestic , '' she say . 
`` So while there be water there I guess stock and domestic will be maintain . 

Anger over late drought assistance

Lower canola yield a boost return 
The huge drop in canola production have send price up as high a $ 555 a tonne at east coast port , almost double last year 's return . 
Canola yield forecast for 2007 be the low for a decade due to the drought , down to just 561,000 tonne , a third of the size of last year 's crop . 
Australian Wheat Forecasters analyst Ron Storey say canola will have to be transport from coast to coast to meet crushing requirement . 
`` Most of the canola crop this year will be in Western Australia , we look like have you know something under half a million tonne of canola in total and more than half of that be go to be in WA , '' he say .

Seaweed fertiliser help farmer battle frost 
Farmers be use seaweed fertiliser a a way to protect horticultural crop from frost . 
Victoria have have several frost in the past month , with cherry , grape , stone fruit and apple crop be damage . 
Scientists believe the liquid fertiliser work by harden the plant cell , so the frost can not pull the moisture out of the fruit . 
Consultant Dr Colin Young , a former Melbourne University chemistry professor , say there be limitation to the seaweed 's effect . 
`` It take 12 hour to kick in and then give you reasonable protection for two week then it start to decrease , '' he say .

Tasmanians John and Diana Lord have be declare Australia 's top tree farmer . 
The Lords , from Longford in the state 's north , win the title from among six other state finalist at the Australian Forest Growers international conference in Launceston last night . 
The family start tree farming in the 1980s and now manage three forest property and a 1,200-hectare mixed farm .

Rain prospect improve 
There be an improved prospect of rain for some part of Australia over summer . 
The National Climate Centre 's late climate outlook still predict some of the country 's most drought affected land will stay dry than normal over the next three month . 
South-east Queensland and much of New South Wales will only have a 30 to 40 per cent chance of receive above average rainfall . 
And a hot summer be still forecast for most of eastern Australia , with the confirmation of the El Nino weather pattern . 
But meteorologist Grant Beard say it be not all bad news , a some area could get above average rainfall . 
`` It 's more encouraging for northern and north-west Queensland , '' he say . 
`` There 's an increased likelihood of wet than average condition there and it 's not quite as discourage a it be in the south-east of the country as well where the probability have rise from around about 40 per cent or a bit lower last outlook .

But Brisbane wholesaler Tony Joseph say while banana price have go through the roof , there have only be 10 per cent of normal supply on the market .

Consumers in the US may see meat and dairy product from clone animal on their supermarket shelf next year .

Vets in Tasmania be conduct an audit of a wildlife park in the north of the State after the discovery this week of two devil with the devastate facial tumour disease . 
It be the first time the disease have be find within a captive population . 
It have already wipe out half the wild devil population .
