That , couple with rise cost of feed grain , be put the squeeze on farm finance . 
Mr Howard be also expect to meet with local community leader later this afternoon . 
Meanwhile , young farmer , harvester and other farm contractor say the drought assistance package probably will not be enough to keep many of them on the land . 
Western NSW crop spray contractor , Andrew Oliver , who speak to Mr Howard yesterday , say he and his friend be sick of watch their business run down . 

Frost devastates Clare Valley vineyard 
Another of South Australia 's premium wine region have be devastate by frost . 
The Barossa Valley , Coonawarra and Padthway have experience crop loss range from 20 and 90 per cent . 
Now the Clare Valley , north of Adelaide , have also be hit . 
Trelawney Vineyard manager Tracey Sandow estimate last weekend 's big freeze ruin hundred of tonne of grape . 
`` The frost come in Saturday morning and anything on the low lie area of the vineyard be basically blacken off completely , '' she say . 

Storms bring good and bad to mid-west farmer 
It have be a mix of pain and good fortune for Western Australia 's farmer and pastoralists , after wild storm tear through the Gascoyne , Murchison and part of the mid-west and northern wheatbelt . 
Strong wind and rainfall of 60 to 90 millimetre destroy some farm crop and damage fence . 
But far north , pastoralists have welcome the rain after such a dry winter . 
Geoff Pilkington from Kirkalocka Station , south of Mt Magnet , say strong wind and hail create a fierce storm . 
`` Dark sky and threaten for most of the morning and then the heaven just open and it be just amazing , '' he say . 
`` At the mine site and in Mt Magnet town site , there be huge hail stone and apparently they be the size of golf ball and two or three inch thick on the ground , so it 's just an amazing event . '' 

Tobacco grower vote to accept exit package 
Australia no longer have a legal tobacco grow industry . 
Tobacco be grow in Queensland and Victoria , but British American Tobacco and Phillip Morris have now announce they will be withdraw from Australia by 2008 because overseas crop be cheap . 
Growers in both state yesterday vote to accept an exit package make up of $ 15 million from the tobacco company and $ 17 million from the Federal Government . 
That amount to a maximum payment of $ 150,000 per grower , which producer say be an offer too good to refuse . 
Queensland Nationals Senator Ron Boswell say the Government hop the tobacco farmer will be able to find alternative crop , but admit it will be difficult . 
`` In the case of Merribra it 's a long way from the market so it 's difficult to find something they can grow commercially , but some of the farm may go over to sugar which be do okay at the moment , '' he say .

The Office of the Gene Technology Regulator have approve the commercial release of genetically modify ( GM ) cotton for northern Australia . 
It be satisfied that five variety of GM cotton design to be herbicide and insect resistant will have minimum impact on tropical environment . 
The decision be unlikely to benefit Western Australia 's Kimberley region , since the State Government have a moratorium on all GM crop until 2008 . 
But Cotton Australia 's Philip Russell say there be now nothing stop farmer in north Queensland grow it commercially when price pick up . 
`` In Queensland there 's no moratorium and we certainly have some interested people up in the Burdekin area of north Queensland who potentially could grow cotton , '' he say .

It be a record profit year , despite the drought , for New South Wales base dairy business Bega Cheese . 
It post a $ 10.5 million profit on a $ 280 million turnover . 
The Bega Dairy Co-op employ more than 500 people , export to 50 country and produce Australia 's top-selling domestic cheese brand . 
Chairman Barry Irvin say all the Co-op profit be return to the 100 farmer owner , to help see them through the bad drought in a century .

Underground miner at Australia 's new nickel mine have intersect the first of a number of a high grade nickel sulphide ore body . 
The Flying Fox mine at Forestania , 400 kilometre east of Perth , host one of the high grade nickel deposit in the world . 
The price of nickel be currently at a record high .

`` Initially that ore will be toll treat at a nearby treatment plant to produce a nickel concentrate which will end up be export to Canada , '' he say .

`` So for those who be able to produce grain we do n't want to suppress their price and in any event I do n't think the amount be able to be import will amount to a flood . ''

A shipment of US beef have arrive in South Korea for the first time in nearly three year but exporter appear nervous about the future of the market .

But other company be wait to see how it be receive in a market now dominate by Australia .

`` The reluctance to ship have be by the US industry , relate to concern about how Korea might handle finding of small piece of bone , or bone chip . We have have one company who have elect to test the system , '' he say . 
Mr Lambert be still wait on Seoul for a response to his letter , ask the Koreans for more flexibility in how they deal with bone chip , cartilage and muscle membrane . 
Korea 's major retailer be not place order for the U-S beef . 
Quarantine authority will take the next 10 day to inspect the first shipment for bone fragment .

Natural gas sector push for role in greenhouse gas fight 
Australia 's natural gas sector want to know why it be not play a great role in the push to reduce greenhouse gas emission . 
The Federal Government be fund two research project in Queensland to extract methane from coal , with any carbon dioxide emission to be bury underground . 
But the Australian Pipeline Industry Association have question the continued reliance on coal while renewable energy source come on line . 
Chief executive Cheryl Cartwright say there be enough known natural gas reserve in Australia to last 100 year and it would make good environmental sense to start use it . 
`` Instead of rely on coal fire generation in the immediate term and the medium term , we can start to reduce greenhouse gas emission , '' she say . 
`` Certainly not to the level that renewable energy provide , which be almost zero but natural gas greenhouse emission in energy generation be far low than coal . '' 
Federal Resources Minister Ian Macfarlane say coal will remain a feature of global energy generation for the next century . 
Mr Macfarlane say Australia be lead the research into clean burning and emission technology , and the natural gas sector should see itself a a part of that . 
`` They 're promote their side of the industry , the Government be promote a broad mix , we need to make sure a we announce that mix we get it right , '' he say .

Meanwhile one of Australia 's big cattle producer have be fin for fail to electronically ear-tag his cattle .

Spokesman Charles Lund believe the $ 800 fine and conviction be unfair 
`` The meatworks will tell you over 30 year we 've never have a question come back from them and our cattlework and our paperwork 's be always spot on and they could n't find anything wrong with any of our paperwork or the traceability of our stock , '' he say . 
`` What annoy me the most , that we 've help the DPI , we 've help the police , we 've catch quite a lot of steal cattle and that , and we 're all for cattle be correctly designate , but if you ca n't get a product to put in them in the ear , you ca n't put it in the ear . '' 

Canadian GM canola may be in Aust by year 's end 
Genetically-modified ( GM ) canola from Canada could be import into Australia by the end of the year . 
It be one of 40 application to import grain and oilseed to address feed shortage . 
Peter Liehne from the Australian Quarantine Service have tell the Senate Estimates Agriculture Committee that if the canola application succeed , the oilseed will have to be crush near the port of entry . 
He say the applicant plan to make the remain meal into livestock feed . 

AWI court action cost woolgrowers 
The Federal Court have hear the Australian Wool Innovation 's legal action against the animal right group , People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals ( PETA ) , have cost woolgrowers $ 5 million . 
The two-year-old case be a result of PETA 's campaign against mulesing . 
But at today 's hearing in Sydney , Justice Rares have ask how woolgrowers can claim indirect economic loss , when AWI have $ 100 million in the bank . 
The startling figure come out after PETA file a strike-out motion against the woolgrowers ' damage . 
Rod Smith SC tell Justice Rares AWI and it co-applicants have make a series of `` forensic u-turns '' . 
Mr Smith say he be intrigue to know how the 101 woolgrowers could prove they have suffer a loss of benefit in their levy when AWI have $ 100 million in it account last financial year . 
Mr Smith add the 2 per cent levy be a Commonwealth statutory figure determine in November 2003 before the court action begin . 
Mr Bannon SC for AWI and the woolgrowers argue the strike-out motion be a shemozzle , say if AWI have spend it legal fee in the PETA campaign on other thing woolgrowers would be in a good position today . 
Justice Rares order that AWI and the woolgrowers provide within seven day detailed particular of the loss . 

City resident rally around drought-stricken counterpart 
Charities say there be grow support from city people want to help rural Australia through the drought . 
Queensland-based Aussie Helpers say people and business from all along the east coast have offer free holiday accommodation , while some Brisbane resident have drive into outback Queensland to donate grocery . 
Beverly Kerr from St Vincent de Paul have start a rural task force to coordinate support in the ACT and New South Wales and say she only realise how bad it be when she visit rural Australia . 
`` When I be ask to form this task force I think what be I go to do , I do n't know anything about this drought , I live in Wollongong near the beach , '' she say . 
`` So I drive to Broken Hill for their 100th anniversary , instead of fly I drive . 
`` You can read it in the paper and you can think 'oh that 's really bad ' but actually see it and talk to people . 
`` I mean some people on those farm have be there for generation and generation , what do they do ? '' 
Meanwhile farm worker be urge their boss to be honest about the future of their job during the drought . 
Victorian dairy farm worker Nat Watson say employee who be keep in the dark can become anxious about their job security . 
`` They 're come home stress and it affect their family life because they do n't know if there be go to be on food on the table tomorrow , '' he say . 

Record October temp record in NSW 
New South Wales have record it hot , dry October on record , follow it hot and dry September . 
The consequence have be devastate for the rural sector , with crop failure and feed , and water shortage force a huge sell off of stock . 
Mike Logan from the Bureau of Meteorology have the bad news . 
`` Right across NSW temperature be just more than three degree above the historical average of 24.5 degree and the rainfall 's unbelievably low , '' he say . 
`` On average we only receive 6.6 mm compare to the state average for October of 48.9 . 

Price rise to help potato grower 
Tasmanian potato grower have receive their first price rise in six year . 
Processor McCain will pay grower $ 10 a tonne more for russet burbank variety and $ 6 a tonne extra for other variety . 
Grower representative Phillip Beswick say the rise will help farmer face a difficult season ahead . 
`` It 's pretty significant , the company have recognise the hardship grower be go to be in this year with the problem with water and acquire it , and the high cost that we 've have in the last 12 month , '' he say . 

Robotic system to hasten grape vine prune 
University student in Adelaide have a design a robotic system which can hand prune grape vine four time faster than a human . 
Although many grape be mechanically prune , premium variety still need some hand pruning . 
Through GPS and computer imaging , the software can be program to tell a machine with a mechanical arm , where and at what angle to make the cut . 
One of the designer , Damien Mavroudis , say it have the potential to save grower time and money .

Glen Riethmuller from the Department of Agriculture say farmer in the reliable cropping area be not use to have such light crop . 
He say grower be experiment with different way to set up their harvester , so they can reduce loss . 
`` People have certainly be look at that knife and particularly change to the double density knife guard if they have n't already get them , '' he say .

In an effort to break the drought , a woman in South Australia who describe herself a an Aboriginal spiritual adviser , be plan to travel the country host rain dance .

`` I do n't sit down here and think this be all fun and game .

Frost hit apple crop 
A quarter of the apple crop in central western New South Wales have be lose , a a result of weekend frost . 
The cold snap hit the Orange region , damage apple , apricot and cherry . 
Batlow producer have also lose around 5 per cent of their crop . 
Orange district apple grower Adam Roweth say he lose about half his crop , when the temperature plummet to minus two . 
`` I think I have a problem in one of the block , '' he say . 
`` The fruit be n't see to be grow , but it be n't because it be n't grow , it be because it be frost . 
`` I have never see frost that way , in that condition and that bad in my time which be n't very old but I can assure you that I do n't think my father would have see it like that either . 

AWB cut wheat pool management cost 
Wheat exporter AWB have slash it cost for manage the national wheat pool this financial year . 
The company say it be an attempt to maximise return to grain grower during the drought and reduce administrative cost . 
The base fee AWB charge for manage the pool will be cut by 40 per cent to $ 39.5 million . 
Chairman of AWB International Ian Donges say the new business model will benefit grower . 
`` It mean the cost per tonne will come under $ 10 , provide we get four million tonne , '' he say . 
`` I think that 's a very good result give that in the last drought in 2002 that $ 10 per tonne be around about the base rate that grower pay as well .

`` Circumstances have be present to u where there be directly agricultural-related small business , like harvest contractor , spray contractor , that be be significantly affect in many EC [ exceptional circumstance ] area , '' he say .

Australia 's big fruit can company be offer extra drought assistance to grower to shore up supply for the summer .

`` Secondly , be subsidy on fruit deliver to u and that 'll be for fruit and tomato . 

Patchy rainfall welcome across NSW 
Inland New South Wales have receive it most widespread rainfall in more than three month . 
Falls over the past 24 hour have be patchy , with 50 millimetre in the state 's north but nothing in some central and western district . 
But farmer in the central west say any rain be welcome . 
`` We have 26 millimetre in two storm . One yesterday afternoon and one sometime early this morning , '' one farmer say . 
`` Certainly some of our later paddock , which we be save for seed , it will help them . It wo n't help the yield but it will help the grain size . '' 
Another farmer say : `` Two storm , one yesterday afternoon , 24 millimetre in 15 minute and do n't it come down . '' 
`` Two storm , one yesterday afternoon with five millimetre and then another one about 4:00am ( AEDT ) , and we pick up 16 millimetre . A little bit of heavy stuff in it , '' a third farmer say . 
`` [ We get ] about half a millimetre , we ca n't measure anything under that , '' a fourth farmer say . 

Speed limit cap punish remote family : resident 
Remote resident in the Northern Territory be outrage at Government plan to cap open speed limit . 
By the end of next year , all traveller on the Stuart , Arnhem , Barkly and Victoria Highways will have to stick to a 130 kilometre an hour limit . 
All other road will have a 110 kilometre per hour cap . 
Jo Coulthard from Orange Creek Station , south of Alice Springs , say the change punish remote family . 
`` I do n't think it 's go to be upheld because how be they go to police it ? '' she say . 
`` We would have to take more time to do the travelling , which of course when you be work or live on a station you do n't have a lot of time to be do that sort of stuff . 
`` I think that 's go to have a huge impact on u . Instead of just be an overnight trip ... now it will have to be a couple of night . 

Scientist pessimistic about alternative fuel in Aust 
Australia 's chief scientist do not think alternative fuel have a big future in the country because of a shortage of available production land . 
Dr Jim Peacock make the comment ahead of the Australian Farm Institute 's strategic round table meeting on agriculture in Sydney today . 
The conference be examine how science will assist agriculture over the next decade , especially in the area of climate change , GM technology and strengthen international market . 
Dr Peacock say people must be realistic about the potential offer by the alternative energy source . 
`` There 's a lot of talk about agriculture and biofuels , I personally do n't think that 's go to be of very much significance in Australia , '' he say . 
`` It 's just a question of available land , production land . 
`` There 's no doubt that ethanol be useful a a blend et cetera , but they 'll be part of the portfolio .

The National Centre of Science and Maths say country pupils fall further behind city student , the further they live from a major city .

TV station operator push for rural channel 
The operator of a rural community television station say the Federal Government be ignore request for a new digital TV station dedicate to rural Australia . 
South Australian-based BushVision say in a national survey of 250 people , more than 90 per cent believe rural issue be not cover adequately by mainstream TV network and almost all support a dedicated rural channel . 
The Federal Government want digital technology to replace the current analogue network within six year . 
BushVision station manager Leon Ashby there be good reason for a rural channel . 
`` For many year , our information and our news have either be sensationalised and it put a picture of rural Australians always whingeing , always get a flood or a fire , or some catastrophe , '' he say . 
`` But it do n't give the overall picture that there 's a lot of good thing happen . 
`` We talk about good communication for the bush but television have be leave completely out of the picture . ''

South Australia 's peak irrigators body say some farmer may not survive the late cut in water allocation .

`` I 'm sure that this be go to create real problem for a lot of irrigators , '' he say .

New South Wales have have an early start to the anthrax season , with two property already suffer stock loss . 
The state normally see about four case of stock loss from anthrax each year .

Dry force cattle sell-off 
One of the big cattle station in the world have be force to sell 12,000 head a the dry continue . 
Anna Creek Station in South Australia 's far north have reduce it stock level from 16,000 head to 4,000 since late last year . 
Manager Randall Crozier say most of the cattle have be sell or send to feedlot . 
`` We 've be destocking pretty well since November last year and we 're pretty well in full swing now we 're down , '' he say . 
`` We 're down to approximately less than a quarter of our stock rate at the moment and if it do n't rain soon , there 'll be even less than that .

Higher price have lead soybean producer on the New South Wales north coast to plan their big crop planting in year . 
Growers be be offer an opening price of $ 380 a tonne for bean for the crush market .

`` I think that 's start to put a bit of a surge in everything , '' he say . 
`` They can use the oil in a biodiesel situation because the soybean produce 20 per cent of it mass in oil . 
`` And also our food chain be get away from solid fat into oil to do their cooking for health reason .

Today be the last chance for wool grower to vote on the level of their industry levy . 
Wool Poll be run every three year to determine funding level for research and development , marketing and grower service . 
Growers currently pay a levy of 2 per cent of the value of their wool sale , value at around $ 60 million .

`` But we get a good spread of rain over about three day and that really get them go then .

Cattle price have make a slight recovery a supply tightens across the country . 
But there be a big discrepancy between livestock yardings and the number of both cattle and sheep be slaughter at abattoir .

`` We 're see yardings about 30 per cent up year on year both for cattle and for lamb at the moment , '' he say . 
`` And yet the slaughter side only up about 5 per cent for both . 

Rain boost cotton plant area 
More cotton will be plant in south-east Queensland after some of the best rain all year . 
A band of rain and isolated thunderstorm cross the region over the weekend with 102 millimetre record at Warwick , 64 at Kingaroy and 51 at Warra . 
While some of the state 's most drought-affected area miss out , Darling Downs cotton grower Ian Speed say he can now double his crop planting . 
`` We 'll be able to plant some dryland cotton now , we 'd only have about a hundred hectare of cotton that we 'd pre-watered and now we 'll put in probably another 200 hectare of cotton , '' he say .

`` The adult locust will survive well now , '' he say . 
`` They 'll move probably large distance than they normally would if they do n't have any rainfall and there definitely be the possibility of an air glade .

The drought be expect to cut rice production in southern New South Wales by 80 per cent to 200,000 tonne .

`` There 's not many business out there that could say if they lose 95 per cent of their work they 'd be in a very financial position , '' he say . 

Stud breeder seek govt assistance 
Stud breeder in the cattle industry say they be worried about the loss of valuable genetics , unless they receive drought assistance . 
Many do not qualify for Federal Government support because of high off-farm income . 
The industry say most of that income be be use to support stud property during the drought . 
Central Victorian murray grey breeder Marilyn Pell say she be go into serious debt but do n't want to have to sell cow to abattoir . 
`` I 've pay up to $ 2,500 just for one cow because she be a well breed cow with her genetics , '' she say . 
`` If I be to send her in now to get her head cut off you know I 'd be lucky to get $ 400 . 

Govt play catch-up on water policy , say Labor 
Labor have attack the Federal Government for not do enough to prepare the country for drought . 
The Prime Minister will hold a water crisis meeting with four state government tomorrow to look at critical storage level in the Murray Darling River system and the implication for irrigators . 
The Murray Darling Basin receive just 3.2 millimetre of rain last month , the low rainfall since record begin . 
Opposition agriculture and fishery spokesman Gavan O'Connor say the Coalition be play catch-up on policy . 
`` Labor propose a summit on climate change and water some two year ago and that suggestion be meet with derision by the Government , '' he say . 
`` Now with the Murray Darling Basin in a state of stress , system not have enough water to meet farmer need and some farmer allocation down to 30 per cent some not at all , the Government have decide to act . It 's simply not good enough . '' 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGuaran say the current dry condition be no-one 's fault and step have be take to manage low water level . 
Irrigators from the Murray Darling Basin say environmental flow should be use to boost city water shortage . 
The lobby group , Irrigators Australia Limited , have put forward a five point plan to the Federal Government look at how to deal with the water crisis . 
Chairman Barry Croke say government should reduce water flow for the environment , instead of buy water off farmer . 
`` Irrigators ' water be need to fee people and we think that 's very , very important but urban use when it start compete with irrigation water in this time of real scarcity , it 's create an enormous problem to produce food , '' he say . 
`` So environmental water be there and normally the gum tree would n't be get environmental water in this situation and we just believe urbans ought to be supplement by environmental water . '' 

Pumping water 
Calls to pump water from northern Australia to the south have receive support from a US scientist , who say similar project have solve water shortage there . 
Professor Scott Bassett from the Desert Research Institute in Nevada say water in river and underground basin be worth big money . 
He say in the US water be be pip from farm area to city because population growth be outstrip water supply . 
`` Water move uphill and it move uphill to money . Big city will pay for their water supply in such a way a $ 3 billion canal from Phoenix to the Colorado River so they 'll ship the water from the Colorado River to city like Phoenix which have the base to supply the economic drive to get the water up there , '' he say . 
But former Californian farmer Spike Dessert , who now live in the Kimberley , say the distance water be pip in the US do not compare with Australia . 
He say some pumping scheme be just 300 kilometre long , nothing compare to the thousand of kilometre of pipeline that would be need here . 

Expert want dingo control relax 
There have be a call to relax control on dingo and even reintroduce them in some part of Australia . 
In a new book , Professor Chris Johnson of James Cook University say it be important to conserve the pure-bred dingo . 
He say he understand the damage wild dog cause to livestock but argue the dingo be a natural predator of other ferals .

The men of north-west Tasmania have prove a dab hand in the kitchen , whip up frenzied competition at a weekend sponge cake cook-off . 
Fourteen cook line up for the men-only competition at the Ulverstone Show on Saturday .

Rural Aust fairly protect from interest rate rise : NAB 
Rural Australia be expect to ride out any further interest rate rise well than most . 
The National Australia Bank ( NAB ) say many farmer have lock their loan into fix rate to guard against a rise . 
It be widely tip the Reserve Bank will announce an increase of a quarter of a per cent tomorrow .

`` Of our agricultural loan book there be something in excess of 70 per cent of that manage on fixed rate or cap rate , or with interest rate risk management tool if you like apply to assist , '' he say . 

WA export hold yard breach standard : RSPCA 
The RSPCA say most live export hold yard in Western Australia breach new national quarantine standard . 
The animal welfare body be investigate what it say be a lack of shelter at one of the state 's big port at Wyndham . 
It say cattle , goat and pig be force to stand in temperature of more than 40 degree for up to three day without shade . 
Since the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service ( AQIS ) standard be not enforceable , the RSPCA want the owner of the yard , the Ord River District Co-operative , to provide shelter . 
But spokesman Jim Hughes say that be unlikely to happen . 
Mr Hughes say the facility be not part of their core business and they do not receive enough rent to warrant upgrade the 80-year-old yard . 
`` What we get for those cattle yard be no more than a donation , '' he say . 
`` In those circumstance why on earth would we want to spend a lot of money on facility at the yard ? '' 
The new AQIS export standard state register premise must provide animal with protection from extreme climatic condition . 
But RSPCA prosecutor Robin Moore say he be tell the standard be not enforceable . 

Japan pressure to lift age limit on beef import 
The US Government be pressure Japan to lift it age limit on beef import . 
Japan have agree to accept beef from animal under the age of 20 month in the wake of the outbreak of mad cow disease in the US in 2003 . 
But US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns say the 20 month limit be too restrictive and not the international standard . 

Uranium price expect to rise 
The price of uranium continue to climb steadily , with prediction it could hit $ US100 a pound by next year . 
It be currently sit at $ US60 , up from just $ US10 five year ago . 
ANZ Bank commodity analyst Andrew Harrington do not think the price will go quite so high but say demand be far outstripping supply . 
He say there be 50 nuclear power reactor be plan around the world and the supply of uranium from old nuclear weapon be dry up . 
`` Nuclear weapon , the linchpin in supply for a long time but recycle nuclear bomb be few and few between in the old Soviet Union and the United States , '' he say . 

Dairy co-op lift milk price 
A dairy co-operative on the north coast of New South Wales be lift milk price to help farmer pay high cost for grain to fee their cow . 
The Norco Dairy Co-op will pay producer just over four cent a litre extra from January . 
Chairman Greg McNamara say there be likely to be a major shortage of milk by autumn if farmer be not give support to maintain their herd . 
`` We 're extremely concerned about the cost impact of grain on farmer and how that 's actually see ( a ) farmer actually leave and ( b ) the current farming supply leave be use less grain and get less milk , '' he say . 

Irrigators await summit decision on Murray Darling 
The Federal Government say it will decide in the next few week what action will be take to help the ail Murray Darling Basin . 
It have be meet with four state government this morning to thrash out way to salvage river system . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say if there be a repeat of this year 's dry condition there will be an extreme water crisis across the basin . 
But he say the government have not yet decide whether they will compulsorily buy back water right from irrigators to shore up town water supply . 
`` Those be the hard decision that we will prepare for next year , '' he say . 
`` We still hope obviously the drought will break but if it do n't then there be go to be difficult decision and people need to be reassure that all government be work together on this . 
`` We 're go to take action on contingency planning , we 'll commission a survey of town and city ' water supply situation , what option be available to u . '' 
The National Farmers Federation say rural town should be make a priority when it come to water distribution . 
But chief executive Ben Fargher be worry the decision-makers will not take into consideration the huge investment irrigators make in their water allocation . 
`` We do want a process set up to make sure that we can protect our core breeding stock , which be our productive base , '' he say . 
`` How do we protect those permanent planting , those crop like orchard and other planting that take a long-long time to establish . '' 
Meanwhile irrigators in southern New South Wales be anxiously wait to hear if there will be further cut to their current water allocation . 
The New South Wales Department of Natural Resources have suspend trade in the Murray and Murrumbidgee valley to assess how much water there be for irrigators . 
The department 's David Harriss say the review have be prompt by record low inflow into storage in the Snowy Mountains . 
`` That give Snowy Hydro the capacity to reduce what they call the required release into the Murray and Murrumbidgee valley , '' he say . 

NT fruit grower bemoan lose Cup sale 
Northern Territory fruit grower be hop to have good luck on the horse today after miss out on lucrative sale for the Cup carnival . 
The star fruit , also know a carambola , command up to $ 60 a tray at this time of year . 
That be more than double the price receive outside of the racing calendar . 
Darwin grower like Cheryl be hop to get the crop back on track for Christmas . 
`` It 's use a lot in garnish and in salad , '' she say . 
`` We have a problem earlier on in the year with late rain , early cool temperature and it just delay everything - we be about three week late with the season for this time of year .

A Tasmanian company be develop a biological fungicide to control grey mould in vineyard . 
Biocontrol Australia have win a Federal Government grant to commercialise the fungicide . 
Dr Dean Metcalf say field trial have reduce the amount of grape lose to the disease by 80 per cent . 
He say the biological fungicide work with the help of a micro-organism that be native to Tasmania . 

Good rain benefit Kangaroo Is beekeeper 
Beekeepers on South Australia 's Kangaroo Island be have one of the best honey season they have experience in year . 
Local apiarist Peter Davis say the large volume of honey be the result of good rain in autumn and early winter which help set the flower bud . 
He also say the dry mild winter keep the bee healthy and active . 

Muswellbrook race cancel because of heavy track 
Racegoers in the heart of thoroughbred breeding industry , the Hunter Valley of New South Wales , do not know whether to laugh or cry today . 
Despite be drought-stricken , the local track be soak by rain earlier this week , cause the traditional cup day race meeting to be cancel . 
It be normally the big event of the year . 
The Muswellbrook Races be as well know to the race industry a the Melbourne Cup and attract some of the best race horse from across New South Wales . 
Conditions be so dry in September and October however , that the club fertilise and water the track to soften it up but recent heavy fall have now make it too heavy for race . 

Drought hit horse racing stud 
Horse race stud in Victoria say they be be hard hit by the drought . 
A lack of spring rain have mean stud owner be buy in feed early this year instead of usually hold off until summer . 
Fiona Smith from Nagambie , in central Victoria , say stud be be force to pass the cost on to customer . 
`` We 've have an increase in feed , feed price be astronomical at the moment and be affect u quite badly in regard to the cost of everything , '' she say . 
`` Unfortunately we 've have to increase a drought levy fee onto our agistment so therefore owner be incur extra cost . '' 
Meanwhile country race club in New South Wales be concern about their future viability . 
Orange-based trainer Brian Cornish say low prizemoney , increase feed cost and high fuel price be hurt . 
`` We 're try to get more money here . Everyone be work hard to try and get it for u , '' he say . 
`` That be the only way we will survive on the cost of living here today and training horse . 
`` The expense of it be get astronomical now . The thing of it be they want all the money to go to Sydney . That 's where they want the money for them down there , they 're not worry about u very much here . 

Calicivirus have an impact around Alice 
Research be show that a re-release of the rabbit kill calicivirus be have an effect near Alice Springs . 
Rabbit number have increase dramatically in recent year , amid fear the disease be lose it effectiveness . 
Kym Schwartzkopff from Parks and Wildlife say a number of rabbit have die since the re-release , but the disease have not spread as far a hop . 
`` The main stop of the spread be usually cause through weather , it do seem to work a lot well within a mild climate where it 's a lot cooler and a bit more humidity around and a bit more moisture around and the high temperature that we have in the centre of Australia and also through the desert region make it go dormant . 

Giant Qld dam fall to record low 
One of Queensland 's large dam have now fall to it low level yet . 
Fairbairn Dam at Emerald supply 200,000 megalitres of water each year for irrigation , industrial and urban need . 
When full the dam hold 1.3 million megalitres , but today it be at just 14 per cent of capacity . 
Nev Wogand from Sunwater say it would take an exceptional wet season to fill the dam . 

Drought prompt call for seed law change 
A South Australian farmer want the rule on Plant Breeders Rights ( PBR ) to be relax , so grower can donate seed to struggle colleague . 
New grain variety be subject to the rule , which prohibit grower from sell or even give away the seed . 
Chris Lawrie from Tumby Bay say the seed company should waive the ban this year , give the magnitude of the drought . 
`` Why ca n't they come out publicly and say well okay , if we either give or sell seed to somebody that we notify them of the amount of tonne we 've sell , who we 've sell it to , then they 've get a record of it all , '' he say . 

Grain-fed cattle number down 
The number of grain-fed cattle in Australia fell by nearly 60,000 head in the last quarter , due to skyrocket grain price and the worsening drought . 
Figures from the Australian Lot Feeders Associations show a drop in total number from 940,000 to just over 880,000 , with the big drop in Queensland . 
Association president Malcolm Foster say South Australia be the only state to buck the trend , with number jump 10,000 to 27,000 . 
`` There 's a lot of cattle that have come out of feedlot that have go to profitable market . Not all of them have be replace , '' he say . 
`` If feedlot ca n't make the sum work between the price they can get for the cattle when they 're turn off , and the price they 've get to pay for the cattle come in with the current grain price , then they 'll just slow up their purchase of cattle and so you 'll see reduced demand and the ultimate outcome of that be fall cattle price . '' 
Meanwhile , Tasmania 's only feedlot be look to import two third of it grain this year due to the poor grow season . 
The Powranna feedlot usually buy more than 20,000 tonne of grain from Tasmanian grower , but after frost and a dry season less than half that amount be available . 
Managing director Andrew Thompson say the company be look to the mainland to make up the shortfall . 

Supply shortage felt in pig meat industry 
Competition between pig meat processor be heat up in the lead up to Christmas because of supply shortage . 
As a result the market have rise to record high this week , with liveweight price as high a $ 3.20 per kilogram . 
Greg Richter from Primo Meats at Port Wakefield , in South Australia , say the shortage have be cause by hot condition last summer . 
`` There 's be a bit of a general infertility problem that happen earlier in the year and that 's just start to come through now , it always show up about nine month after they have the problem , '' he say . 

US wheat industry face export problem 
Despite a boost from Australia 's drought , the US wheat industry be face widespread export problem due to quality and disease issue . 
India be buy wheat again for the first time in seven year , but mostly from Australia and the Black Sea region , not the US . 
`` It 's because their phytosanitary requirement just ca n't be meet . It just create an impossible barrier to trade , '' say US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns , 
USDA be work with US Wheat Associaties to reduce these barrier . 
But the group 's Rebecca Coleman say quality and disease issue be `` crop up '' elsewhere . 
`` We 're have trouble in the EU , we 're have trouble in Japan , I 'm sure we 're go to have trouble in Korea . We 're have trouble right now in Kenya , '' she say . 
Ms Coleman say sanitary barrier be now threaten to become more of a problem for US wheat in some place than tariff . 
Meanwhile , the Grains Council of Australia say a national survey of grain quality show it be almost 100 per cent clean . 
The National Residue Survey of Australian grain , a joint government and industry project , reveal that 99.9 per cent of grain for export comply with Australian Food Standards . 

Funding shortage kill weed research centre 
The Co-operative Research Centre for Weeds will close by 2008 , after fail to win further Federal Government funding . 
The national research and development body have seek an additional $ 30 million funding over seven year , but fail to meet three out of the four necessary criterion . 
Chief executive Rachel Mcfadyen say it be a disastrous result because climate change will bring on fresh weed invasion . 
`` Some of the northern weed will move south , a the temperature heat up so in particular for example prickly acacia , mesquite in the grazing land will extend their range southward to western New South Wales and possibly even in Western Australia , '' she say . 
`` Things like lantana along the coast will extend it range southward and we do offer advice a to how best manage those weed and how to limit their spread . '' 

New smut fear in Qld 
Tests be underway to confirm whether the disease sugar cane smut have escape from a quarantine zone in Queensland . 
The State Government be expect to announce today that scientist be test what 's be call `` suspicious substance '' , a smut inspection team survey 600 farm around Mackay . 
Smut be first find near Bundaberg in June , and authorites have think it be contain . 
The Canegrowers Organisation be refuse to confirm that the disease have escape quarantine , but have confirm testing be underway . 

Mixed reaction to drought aid 
There have be a mixed reaction to the Federal Government 's announcement of drought aid for small business reliant on the farm sector . 
Businesses which receive 70 per cent of their income from farm in drought-declared area will be eligible for income support and interest rate subsidy . 
The Australian Grain Harvest Association say it will help contractor struggle to make repayment on machinery . 
But spokesman Rob Gribble be now urge the government to help contractor prepare for future drought , by set up a version of the Farm Management Deposit ( FMD ) scheme . 
`` In the long term what we request from the Federal Government be some sort of FMD facility so we can deposit money in good time and draw them out in bad and hopefully self manage our way through these thing , '' he say . 
Farm machinery dealer say they have be unfairly exclude from the new drought assistance package . 
Vin Delahunty from the Tractor and Machinery Association say most dealer will not be eligible for aid , because they employ more than 20 people . 
`` Once again the significant employer in the regional area , the people who employ the most significant number of skill in those community , have be leave out and to be honest , we do n't understand why the Government have take this action . '' 
Irrigators say they be skeptical of plan to speed up interstate water trading to address critical water shortage in drought-hit state . 
The federal and state government have agree that interstate buying and selling of permanent water right will begin on January 1 . 
But George Warne from Australia 's big irrigation company , Murray Irrigation , say there be little water available to ease shortage , because farmer allocation be so low . 
`` I think it be good they get together , but I 'm a a bit of a loss to understand how permanent water trading be go to help the drought , '' he say . 

New family day care system help outback NT family 
Outback family in the Northern Territory be take advantage of a new system of family day care . 
The Federal Government lift the cap on family day care position earlier this year . 
It have result in more opportunity for approved carers , and parent can claim a child care benefit . 
In the Douglas Daly , south-west of Darwin , mother like Sarah , say it be become easy to juggle the farm and small child . 
`` We do claim the CCB ( Child Care Benefit ) , which be a fantastic help , '' she say . 

CCC investigate further misconduct 
Western Australia 's Corruption and Crime Commission ( CCC ) have reveal it have further evidence of serious misconduct and abuse of power by public officer . 
The revelation follow yesterday 's startling evidence at the CCC of secretly record phone conversation between the former minister Norm Marlborough and the former premier Brian Burke . 
The CCC inquiry be originally set up to investigate the handling of a proposal to build a tourist resort at Smiths Beach , near Yallingup . 
But the uncovering of secret phone conversation between Mr Marlborough and Mr Burke have now change the nature and course of the inquiry . 
Yesterday CCC lawyer Stephen Hall SC reveal the commission have for some time be undertake broad investigation . 
He say the investigation support the proposition that serious misconduct by public officer have , may have , or be occur . 
Mr Hall say the investigation have be give the high priority because of the need to protect the integrity of government in Western Australia . 

AWB 's wheat export decision 'disgraceful ' 
There have be an angry reaction to AWB 's decision to block 12 application to export more than 3 million tonne of wheat . 
The application be by several company look to export to eight country but AWB have use it veto power under the Wheat Marketing Act to prevent the move . 
Chairman of AWB International Ian Donges say the decision will protect the financial interest of wheat grower deliver grain to the National Pool . 
`` Quite clearly , if we be to accept the permit that total 3 million tonne this year we would be derelict in our duty , '' he say . 
`` We be now look at a potential harvest or a pool delivery of 4 million tonne so it 's very important to maximise those pool return that we have every tonne available to service the international market place . '' 
But WA-based grain handler CBH have describe AWB 's decision a disgraceful . 
The co-operative want to export wheat to it South-East Asian flour mill . 
It be the second time CBH have be knock back and chief executive Imre Mencshely say AWB have again jeopardise the future of grower in the west . 
`` We can not understand how an organisation can hide behind legislation to make a decision of this nature , '' he say . 
`` We 've come out and we 've say that we can do this on a regular basis and we 've say we 'll be out there for five year . 
`` To deny the grower of Western Australian $ 40 million to $ 50 million in a year of drought , we just can not comprehend an organisation come out in that way . '' 
The Federal Government say it will not be pressure into change the single desk wheat export system before the outcome of the oil-for-food inquiry . 
Some Coalition MPs be call for AWB 's veto power to be remove but Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say that will not happen yet . 
`` AWB and other bulk handler and other interested party all know that , '' he say .

The trucking industry say new law to reduce driver fatigue must be accompany by major government spending on road . 
The National Transport Commission have release the final version of it plan to reduce driving hour and increase penalty in a bid to improve safety . 
While many concern with the commission 's initial recommendation have be address , the transport sector say good infrastructure be need . 
Stuart St Clair from the Australian Trucking Association say driver can not meet new rest break requirement unless 21,000 new rest area be build . 
`` It 's very difficult to put an onus on the trucking industry and it driver to perform to the necessary regulation , that 's one thing and we accept that responsibility , '' he say .

`` I think the change of his get that approval be pretty remote now . I mean , why would the Democrats in the House want to give the President a victory on a trade issue ... effectively , 18 month before the next election , '' Mr Drazek say .

Victoria 's fruit grower be cut their watering time by half to ensure water supply will last the season .

`` Peaches respond very well to regulate deficit irrigation ( RDI ) it 's a matter of just irrigate those peach a you would on the normal interval , say once a week but cut the irrigation time in half , '' he say .

Livestock price lower in WA 
A new report in Western Australia have show significant difference in livestock price between the eastern state and the west . 
The Department of Agriculture report say saleyard price for all stock class except porker be well below those on the eastern seaboard .

Tim D'arcy from the Pastoralists and Graziers Association say it be a dramatic difference . 
`` It probably average 50 cent a kilo year in and year out , but it vary anywhere between about 20 or 30 cent up to $ 1.28 a kilo and we 're always that far behind , '' he say .

The Queensland Government have concede that it be unable to contain the devastating disease , sugar cane smut . 
It be confirm late yesterday that smut have reach the Mackay area after it be first find near Bundaberg in June . 
The industry have now turn it focus to limit the economic impact on the billion dollar sector . 
Eion Wallace , from the industry 's research and development arm , BSES , say smut may have be in Mackay for some time . 
`` The evidence at the moment would suggest that it 's an incursion that occur certainly before harvest and probably before this season , probably , '' he say . 
`` Which mean that it be not a failure of containment from Bundaberg and Childers but a separate incursion either at the same time a Bundaberg and Childers , or subsequent to it . '' 
South of the border , the sugar industry have launch a new round of crop surveillance . 
Rick Beattie , from the New South Wales Sugar Milling Co-operative , believe the disease may have be spread for at least a year but not be detect . 
He be ask farmer to check crop , so the disease can be detect early if it be there .

Sheep genome map nearly complete 
Science be one step closer to provide farmer with a complete genetic map of the sheep . 
The 'virtual sheep genome ' project have map 98 per cent of the sheep 's genetic make-up . 
That be enough to fast track the identification of the crucial gene for wool and meat quality , and even parasite resistance . 
Dr Robert Forage , who be lead the joint Australian Wool Innovation/Meat and Livestock Australia project , say the sheep 's genetic jigsaw be still not quite complete . 
`` It 's put together use bit and piece of information not only from the sheep but also from the cow and from the human as well , '' he say . 
`` So we do n't have all the information we need from the sheep . 
`` We 've put some piece of the jigsaw puzzle together but there be still hole in it - we think we know where everything fit but we do n't have the complete sequence yet . ''

The Government be move away from try to contain the disease . 
The Government have appoint an independent economist to head up a team to assess the impact and identify measure to manage the problem , and facilitate economic recovery . 
The team will report by December 18 . 
A stakeholder meeting on Friday be tell replant with resistant variety over the next five year will cost an estimated $ 800 million , with an additional burden of a 10 per cent reduction in yield .

The state have argue the Commonwealth 's use of the Corporations Act to underpin it new workplace reform be not constitutionally valid . 
The High Court 's ruling today say it be . 
Tim Kennedy from the National Union of Workers say the decision crush the award system and leave low pay rural worker in a vulnerable position . 
`` Essentially for many many year a lot of rural and regional worker who work for small employer have rely on a state award system and arbitration system to set minimum term and condition , '' he say . 
`` They basically have ensure the public interest of people get pay that can support a family if you like . 

Chicken death blame on chemical in feed 
The death of almost 50,000 chicken on two farm near Brisbane have be attribute to an accident involve a load of feed . 
The food contain high level of Nicarbazin which be use to control parasite . 
The farm and the feed supplier have not be identify by Queensland Health or food safety authority . 
Dr Andreas Dubs from the Australian Chicken Meat Federation say the 150,000 chicken that recover from last week 's overdose have be clear for human consumption . 
`` The chemical be one which be use a medication quite frequently , '' he say . 
`` But in this instance it should n't have be there and it be present in the feed at a much high dose than it would normally be use . 

Wheat price fall a panic buying eas 
After a bullish run , wheat price have fall around $ 50 a tonne on the domestic market . 
Widespread panic buying by miller and feedlotters have ease , with the market fall heavily a more of the nation 's crop be harvest . 
Chairman of AWB International Ian Donges say there have be a reduction in tender activity and the cash price . 
`` I notice back when the harvest start in southern Queensland the market be roughly between $ 300 and $ 330- $ 340 a tonne , '' he say .

The big bank say they be find it hard to attract branch manager to country town .

Australia 's 6,000 dairy farmer will go to the poll early next March to vote on how much they be willing to contribute to research and development . 
Farmers pay 0.32 cent per litre of milk sell which , couple with Federal Government support , generate around $ 50 million a year .

Long range forecaster look to autumn rainfall 
The Bureau of Meteorology and other long range weather forecaster be predict a good outlook for drought-hit area by autumn next year . 
But there be still some debate about how much good . 
Most long range forecaster agree it be not yet an exact science and they be use different system . 
But David Stephens from the WA Department of Agriculture be predict an 80 per cent chance of a good autumn break . 
In Victoria , independent forecaster John Moore say there be 90 per cent chance of an average year start with heavy fall in February or March . 
Queensland Sunspot observer Owen Beneict expect the dry to continue .

Rockmelon grower in Western Australia 's Ord Valley have receive price that be up to 10 per cent higher this year . 
Rockmelons be the big horticulture crop grow in the region , worth $ 7 million a year .

But transport woe continue to plague grower , who be compete with other crop for truck . 
`` Our major issue be that Perth be a relatively small market but that 's where the transport be available so a lot of fruit go to Perth that would probably would n't have if we have other option and depressed price there , '' Mr Menzell say .

`` We be look at about $ 400 a hectare for the chemical and application and we be look at do ten to fifteen hectare . ''

`` I do n't want to see the power grid fail we 've get to have power but a little bit of power rationing because we 're short of the water to generate the electricity with , be that too much to ask ? '' he say . 
The NSW Minister for Natural Resources , Ian Macdonald say release the water would jeopardise electricity contract . 
`` Snowy Hydro have enormous contract that it be bind to abide by and if those contract be break then taxpayer will pay hundred of million of dollar , '' he say . 
Snowy Hydro have refuse to comment . 
Meanwhile the Victorian Government be plan to resume environmental flow into the Hattah Lakes in the state 's north-west .

`` It be just a principle in a time of drought .

`` I mean it 's important in nutrition research to see it in context .

A Federal Court judge have tell lawyer for Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) and People for Ethical Treatment of Animals ( PETA ) that their case have chew up too much time and a trial date will be set .

He order all party to appear before him on December 14 for what he describe a a `` substantive case management debate '' . 
The judge say the time have come to bring some order to the case , in which AWI and 101 wool grower be sue PETA for it campaign aim at get international retailer to boycott Australian wool . 
Justice Rares tell lawyer they must present all evidence and full witness list , and ask them to consider if they want a jury trial . 

Mining company sign carbon trading deal with grazier 
A major mining company have sign a carbon trading agreement with Queensland grazier , pay them to keep their tree for the environment . 
In a landmark deal , Rio Tinto will pay three landholder in the Charleville area well over a million dollar to offset the release of greenhouse gas . 
Broker Mark Jackson from the Carbon Pool company say it do not mean the land be off limit . 
`` They continue their current management of the land , which be to say leave the current vegetation intact , continue with sustainable grazing activity so that the land be not lock up and do n't become infested with weed and feral animal , and they 're relinquish their right to clear , '' Mr Jackson say .

Several hundred harvester in New South Wales might have to be fit with a safety device after the settlement of a high profile court case . 
WorkCover be withdraw it prosecution of machinery manufacturer CNH Australia and a New South Wales dealer over a 2003 farm accident , where a worker lose his leg while try to clear a blockage in a combine harvester . 
CNH Australia 's Stuart Redman say the company have agree to design , test and fit a device to make the particular model of header safer . 
`` It 's probably go to be like an interlock device on the ladder access the top of the combine and once the farmer pull down the ladder then it will cut off the machine . It 's still very much in design and test phase at this stage but that 's what we will be look at , '' Mr Redman say . 
The agreement only apply to the case IH 2388 header in use in New South Wales .

The decision bring SA into line with the crop ban in Victoria and New South Wales .

The Federal Government be in talk with Israel to try to lift a ban on live sheep export from Australia . 
The ban be impose after six sheep be find to have scabby mouth disease on a shipment last month . 
Israel buy just 1 per cent of Australia 's live sheep export and 6 per cent of live cattle .

Frosts may halve crop production 
Unseasonal frost in Queensland 's crop region could halve production for some broadacre farmer . 
Below average temperature on Friday bring frost and even snow to some part of the Granite Belt in the state 's south . 
Crop specialist Paul McIntosh say while they 're still assess the damage , it already appear significant . 
`` There 's sorghum , grain sorghum , corn , forage sorghum and even the feed value like Dolichos lablab , and some of those soft crop they be absolutely black , and the Eastern Downs be definitely the big area that 's be hit , '' Mr McIntosh say . 

Grain audit under consideration 
The Federal Agriculture Minister say he will consider an annual national audit of grain stock . 
The Grains Council have call for the audit to address uncertainty about the level of grain hold in storage . 
The Australian Bureau of Statistics be currently investigate this year 's dramatically drought-reduced stock . 
Peter McGauran say with ongoing uncertainty over how much grain will be available for export or domestic livestock feed this year , the Government be continue to process 40 application to import grain . 

Chaff cart trialled in weed fight 
Grain grower in Victoria be try to find way to tackle herbicide resistance , especially a the big dry drag on . 
Farmers be trialling chaff cart , large enclose trailer that be tow behind header and collect screening , and small seed that would normally be leave in the paddock . 
Bernard Noonan from the Wimmera Conservation Farmers Association say they have be use successfully in South Australia . 

Hunt under way for Australia 's best young truckie 
The trucking industry have launch a national campaign to find Australia 's safe and most skilled young driver to try to change public perception about the sector . 
The winner will receive a $ 220,000 prime mover . 
The competition have never before be hold in Australia but have be a big hit in more than 30 country . 
Stuart St Clair from the Australian Trucking Association say the competition be an attempt to tackle any negative image of truck driving . 
`` The whole purpose of this be to show to the general public and to the industry itself about the professionalism of the industry and the fact that we 're look to attract young people into this business a driver and other support people , '' Mr St Clair say . 

SA investigate wine partnership with Chile 
The Chilean Government be look at a partnership with the wine industry in South Australia 's Barossa Valley . 
Chile 's Foreign Minister and Ambassador have make a fly visit to the region to talk about a joint effort to sell wine to Asia . 
State MP Ivan Venning say although Chile be a major competitor , it be worth investigate . 
`` I be initially quite cautious because why would you want to do a deal with an international competitor , a Chile be with u , in the world of wine but I think the Australian wine , particularly our Barossa wine and the Chilean wine do complement each other because they do n't have the premium red like we have , '' Mr Venning say . 

Farmers may look to cooperative for protection 
Agricultural cooperative could be about to make a comeback , accord to new research . 
Author Gary Lewis have be look at farm cooperative in Australia and say by allow many to be corporatised , farmer have lose an important weapon . 
He say farmer need to look after their own interest when it come to drought , water and politics , and form new cooperative be one way of do that . 

City folk urge to 'sponsor a cow ' to support dairy farmer 
Citysiders be be encourage to `` sponsor a cow '' to help a group of Victorian dairy farmer fee their livestock . 
The Stanhope and District Development Committee have come up with the plan to help the district survive the drought . 
Chairman Bob Holschier say the campaign will benefit the farmer but also help sponsor to learn about the farm sector . 

'Functional food ' may help prevent disease 
There be a grow trend in Europe to produce so-called 'functional food ' . 
The food be say to help prevent life threaten disease or curb potential health problem like obesity , heart disease and high blood pressure . 
Visiting food scientist Charles Daly , from University College Cork in Ireland , say there be also a trend to match individual human genetics to different food group to improve health . 
`` We have different genetic make-up and so that mean that we can have different susceptibility to some of the disease that we mention , and that mean that by look at the genetic make-up of sub population we can target food to those group , '' Mr Daly say . 

Watchdog call for accurate labelling of GM import 
Australia 's consumer watchdog have call for any genetically modify ( GM ) import to be label accurately . 
Choice , formerly know a the Australian Consumers Association , have raise the concern amid speculation that a major grain handler be expect a consignment of GM canola from Canada within the next month . 
Domestic canola supply be tight this season due to the drought . 
Choice spokeswoman Claire Hughes say consumer will not know they be eat GM canola oil . 
`` If we do start to see a large amount of genetically modify canola come into Australia , if it 's go to be process and use a oil , consumer would n't necessarily know if a product they 're purchase have be genetically modify or do contain genetically modify canola oil , '' she say . 
`` Because our GM labelling law do n't require a product that have be highly refine , those product do n't have to be label and canola oil be a good example of that . '' 
Federal Minister for Agriculture Peter McGauran say he be aware of the import , which be intend for use in oil for human consumption and meal for stockfeed . 
He say the consignment have be independently sample and test before load to confirm that only GM line approve by the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator be allow in . 

Doctors call for rural health community service obligation 
The Rural Doctors Association ( RDA ) claim the Federal Government be more concerned with ensure people have a phone rather than a doctor or hospital . 
It be call for a community service obligation for rural health , much like the one which force Telstra to provide service . 
New president Dr Peter Rischbieth from Murray Bridge in South Australia say million of taxpayer ' dollar pour out of rural community to subsidise metropolitan health service . 
`` They have the ethos that everyone should have a telephone and access to telephone repair , '' he say . 
`` [ The ] Rural Doctors Association believe they should have access to timely medical service . 

Sugar cane smut find on third cane farm 
A third Mackay cane farm have be find to have sugar cane smut , confirm fear that the fungal disease be widespread . 
The disease have be find on a property , 20 kilometre from the original find near Mackay , which have be discover on Melbourne Cup day . 
Mackay Area Productivity Service spokesman Alan Royal say smut now look to be well-established in central Queensland . 
`` It 's very , very sad but it 's right across the other side of town and the whip be reasonably advance but they 're certainly not big whip like we 've be see , '' he say . 
`` What do frighten me be on the weekend in one row at the initial farm , you know we be see whip that be four , five foot long , so it 's get a hold there but let 's hope we can get on top of it . '' 
Meanwhile sugar cane farmer in Western Australia 's Ord Valley be look for new variety , because some which be once resistant to cane smut be not any more . 
The disease be first find in WA 's north-west in 1998 . 
CJ Ord River Sugar spokesman Wayne Paul say 100 variety have be try in the past five year but only a handful have show promise . 
He say smut be also expect to reduce next year 's crop . 
`` Q95 be probably the bad . It 's get a bit of smut now whereas it do n't have early on , so that will probably be mostly plough out over the next couple of year , '' he say . 

Vegie grower tell to change 
Tasmania 's vegetable grower have be tell to change or be prepare to go out of business . 
A strategic plan have be release for the sector , raise a number of area to be address , like improve marketing and good relationship with food processor . 
Consultant Euan Laird , who help produce the report , say the change will see some grower leave the industry . 
`` Only the strong will survive , '' he say . 
`` It 's a really tough market out there and those that change and adapt , and modify , and meet the demand of consumer will survive so I 'll put an estimate that only 50 to 60 per cent of exist grower will survive in the long term and they be go to be those that be adaptable . '' 
Tasmania 's grower agree with the plan but most feel the hard work be still ahead . 
`` We 've get to start somewhere to get the vegetable industry off the ground or to stop it go back into the ground I suppose , '' one grower say . 

NSW Govt urge to allow grazier access to forest , national park 
The New South Wales Farmers Association want grazier to be give access to state forest and national park to help fee hungry livestock . 
The association say feed be become scarce a the drought intensifies . 
President Jock Laurie be urge the NSW Government to consider the proposal , which he say would help farmer hold onto core breeding stock . 
`` As far a we 're concerned it would be a good tool for the feeding of core breeding stock throughout this drought period , especially when feed reserve be so low , '' he say . 
`` You do n't need a long bureaucratic process to go through here , so get in and make a decision so that people can then plan well into the next few month about how they 're go to fee stock . '' 

Starlings attack cherry orchard 
Cherry orchard in central New South Wales be suffer major bird damage this year . 
Large number of starling be attack crop much early than normal , which grower believe be due to the drought and a lack of food . 
Cherry grower Guy Gaeta say he have never see so much damage . 
`` They be get to the cherry when they be still green , '' he say . 
`` Whether it be because they be hungry because of the drought . 
`` I have never seem them before and everybody in the district be have the same problem . They be not eat the cherry , they be just chop them off . 
`` They go to taste them and then they be sour . They pull it off the tree and then they go to another one hop it be a bit sweeter . 

Company offer incentive to encourage truckies to stay 
A major trucking company be plan to pay incentive to it driver to encourage them to stay in the industry . 
Road Trains of Australia say it be hard to find staff with many driver be lure into the mining sector . 
While a national campaign be under way to attract more young people towards a career in transport , Mike Bailey from Road Trains ' Mount Isa branch , say the company need to make an effort to ease the skill shortage . 
`` We 're try to start a scheme where - just within ourselves - that they get reward if they stay in the industry , in our employment , for a number of year , '' he say . 
`` At the end of that time they 'll get a bonus or whatever for hang in there , it 'll be like a miniature long service leave sort of thing . '' 

Increased pay help retain mango picker 
Improved wage have help to secure picker for the Northern Territory 's mango season . 
The NT Mango Association have set a recommended minimum wage of $ 16.50 this year , more than a dollar above the national award . 
President Peter Marks say there be not many picker around but the incentive have help to keep worker on for the whole season . 
`` We have the union involve , we have Aboriginal organisation involve and all the labour provider , '' he say . 
`` We ask their opinion how we should manage this situation because we could see it be not go to be good . 

Drought set to bring live export trade growth 
The Australian live export trade be tip to grow because of the drought . 
Lower price for sheep and cattle have prompt international market to step up demand for livestock which fell away after the Cormo Express incident in 2003 and more expensive livestock cost . 
Meat and Livestock Australia spokesman Mike Hayward say despite low price the trade do give producer another alternative during the dry time . 
`` It be really noticeable in the west when they really get hit with the drought early in the year , '' he say . 
`` A lot of livestock would have probably die on property if they have n't have the live trade . 

Wool bale fetch seasonal record price 
A super ultra-fine bale of have fetch a seasonal record of 70,000 cent a kilogram in Victoria . 
The 12.4 micron bale be the fine yet produce by Brockville grower Andrew and Annie Gardner , who have a farm at Penshurst , in the western district . 
The same buyer also pay 67,000 cent a kilogram for a 12.5 micron bale from Pyrenees Park in central Victoria . 

EC farmer assistance require rethink , expert say 
An environmental and climatic change risk analyst say the Federal Government need to rethink it exceptional circumstance ( EC ) assistance to farmer . 
The University of Canberra 's Dr Brian Button say he be oppose to EC funding because flood and drought be a natural occurrence and not exceptional . 
He say the Government should look at other way of help . 
`` Now in Canada the Federal Government sponsor to the tune of about $ 2 billion Canadian a year a crop insurance scheme , '' he say . 

New tree planting fail to secure farm biodiversity : research 
New research say offset the clearing of native vegetation with new tree planting be not an effective way to maintain biodiversity on farm . 
The Australian National University research suggest it take up to 300 year for newly-planted vegetation to provide the same food and shelter to animal and bird . 
Ecology Professor David Lindenmayer say the finding show a need to preserve remnant vegetation . 
`` We 've find this from our data on the south-west slope of New South Wales and it 's for reptile , it 's for possum and gilder , arboreal marsupial and also for bird , '' he say . 

Scientists claim new water filter halve purification cost 
Scientists in Italy say they have develop new way of filter water that should halve the cost of purification . 
The water membrane technology be already be use in other country to recycle waste , make bore water palatable and desalinate salty water . 
Professor Enrico Drioli from the University of Calabria say the membrane , which look like plastic wrap , mirror the natural filtering membrane in our body . 
`` Just a film that the one you can use for package your sandwich sometimes , so this film be able to be selective , '' he say . 

AWB 's profit drop 
Wheat exporter AWB have announce a 68 per cent cent fall in annual net profit to $ 58.1million . 
The company say it will pay a reduced final dividend of 4 cent , with the drought cut the harvest and less domestic grain trading . 
The oil-for-food inquiry have cost the company almost $ 24 million , while redundancy and restructuring have take $ 10 million off the bottom line . 
Managing director Gordon Davis say AWB will remain viable if it lose control of the single desk for wheat export in the wake of the Cole inquiry . 
`` AWB have be pursue a strategy of diversify it income away from pool management . We 've get strong and grow business in our international trading in Geneva , Brazil and India , '' Mr Davis say . 

Grain grower wo n't oppose removal of AWB 's wheat veto 
The Grains Council say it would not oppose any move by the Federal Government to remove AWB 's veto on wheat export application . 
There be a push from within the Government to take away the veto to allow other grain company to export wheat . 
But chairman of the peak body , Murray Jones , say grower must be consult before any major structural change be make to the single desk . 
`` We do n't know what the Government 's reaction will be and I 'm leave it open to them to make their reaction , '' Mr Jones say . 
`` We 've consult regularly and continuously during the course of the last few month and we 'll continue to do so , and continue to put forward the grower ' position , which be they wish to retain a single desk and they want to be consult if there be to be any change . '' 
The Grains Council say it want grower to have control of the export system . 
But the Australian Grain Exporters Association be push the Federal Government to remove the single desk . 
The association of bulk grain handler want an interim licensing system put in place to smooth the way for deregulation .

Federal Labor leader Kim Beazley have begin a tour of central New South Wales to hear first hand how the drought be hurt rural family . 
Mr Beazley have use the trip to make his first announcement on drought policy , 
He visit three property near Forbes in the central west of New South Wales and will be show the Jemmalong Irrigation Scheme , which this year have a zero water allocation . 
Young farmer highlight the difficulty they be encounter in remain viable and tell Mr Beazley about their failed crop , many of which be to be irrigate . 
The Labor leader tell the producer if his party be elect , it would set up a series of research institute to help commercialise technology to good manage the drought . 

Live export trade inhumane , say RSPCA 
The RSCPA say it have proof that a majority of Australians believe the live export trade be inhumane . 
An national phone survey of 600 people by Roy Morgan Research have find almost 60 per cent believe the trade be cruel .

The livestock industry 's peak national body , Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) , be hold it annual general meeting in Adelaide today . 
Around 250 producer and industry representative have finish the producer forum which cover the current and future direction of the red meat industry . 
Many apology be receive from farmer , both local and interstate , who have be affect by bushfires and could not attend . 
Four resolution will be vote on at the AGM regard the election of MLA director , follow by a question period where the recent NLIS poll scandal and the process of register voter from levy pay producer be expect to be raise . 
At the same time , more than 150 cattle producer have rally on the Western Downs in Queensland , in a direct boycott of the MLA meeting .

The rally have see producer travel from as far a Western Australia to attend the Queensland rally and chairwoman Linda Hewitt say she be go to call on the Australian Government to undertake a full review of Meat and Livestock Australia . 
The rally have already see a group of grazier hear from expert on depression and a psychiatrist who be highlight the need for help at the farm gate . 
Speaker Danny Beer from the US cattle produce organisation R-Calf have speak about it support for country of origin label in the United States .

Uncontracted winegrape grower might have more luck sell their fruit this year . 
A lack of water and frost damage in some part of Australia mean that remain grape be likely to be in demand .

Biofuels industry face grain cost challenge 
A new report say the big challenge for the fledgling biofuels industry be to keep down the cost of grain for alternative energy production . 
The independent report predict Australia will almost double it production target of 350 million litre of biofuel by 2010 . 
But report author Graeme Bethune say cost be the big problem and eventually grain which be currently export may be in demand by manufacturer . 

Nuclear power report wo n't help uranium industry in short term 
Australia 's uranium sector say yesterday 's positive review into nuclear power will make little difference to the industry in the short term . 
Although share price in uranium explorer rise on the back of the Switkowski report , the Association of Mining and Exploration say Australia 's uranium reserve be still under-utilised . 
Spokesman Ian Loftus say the public tend to confuse nuclear energy with uranium mining . 
`` We have some of the world 's great resource in term of uranium in the ground and we have the ability here and now , subject to government approval of course , to dig up that uranium and use it to provide fuel for clean electricity for other part of the world , '' Mr Loftus say .

The rapidly rise humidity and heat in the Northern Territory be prove good news for crocodile farm . 
Many be busy grade baby saltwater crocodile , accord to size . 
At Noonamah on the outskirt of Darwin , Mick Burns be sort 12,000 baby reptile , which be more than one-metre long . 
`` The animal get very dominant and territorial and they 'll blue with any small animal , '' he say . 
`` No loss of finger but certainly there would be a few little nip . 
`` This year have be pretty slow because we have have such a cold dry season , it 's the third or fourth large number of day that have be below a certain temperature so that certainly slow down the animal .
