With debate about the future of drought-stressed river in the headline , Canberra student have launch plan for an International Conference on River Health . 
The conference , set for October next year , will bring more than 600 student from across Australia and around the world to Canberra to share knowledge about their environment . 
Founder and convener Arron Wood say it be important to let our future leader explore river issue now , so they have a head start . 
`` To have kid from small town like Mildura and Renmark , and those sort of thing , talk to someone in the Amazon about the issue that they 're face , '' he say . 

Cities urge to consider buy water from irrigators 
A report commission by the Federal Government say city will need to consider buy water from irrigators to address major urban shortage . 
Report author John Marsden say buying water from irrigators be a possibility for Melbourne , Adelaide , Perth and Canberra . 
He say community must consider the option . 
`` In general there 's be a reluctance by government to put this issue firmly on the table because of fear of upset rural electorate , '' he say . 
`` But of course , the rural waterholders trade water all the time , between themselves and there 's no reason why the trade ca n't be with other party , include with the city . '' 
Meanwhile the National Water Commission have confirm it be conduct a feasibility study into pip water from so-called `` water rich '' area of northern New South Wales , to drought-affected south-east Queensland . 
The study , which will go to the Federal Government , be look at river include the Wilson , Brunswick , Richmond , Tweed and Clarence . 
Although the region have high rainfall , Wayne Franklin from Rous Water say there be not enough water to pipe across the border . 
`` When you look at the Clarence and the Clarence be the one below u so we 're centre on the Richmond Valley , '' he say . 
`` If you look at either of our valley and the amount of water we have we 're really small fry compare to Queensland . 

ABARE chief to take on climate change role 
The nation 's new chief commodity forecaster say predict the effect of climate change on agriculture will have to become part of his work . 
Phillip Glyde have be appoint executive director of the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) after work in the Departments of Prime Minister , Industry and Agriculture . 
He say the agency need to be responsive to industry and farmer need but say provide economic analysis on climate change will be difficult . 
`` I think it be something that we will be do more on , I hesitate to say when , '' he say . 
`` Really the issue there be the quality of the science and really the economic analysis flow from the science . 
`` One of the problem we 've get at the moment be that impact of climate change at a regional level or on a particular industry be n't really that well know . '' 
Meanwhile grain farmer be be urge to factor in climate change when planning for the future . 
Dr Peter Hayman from the South Australian Research and Development Institute have win a 'Seed of Light ' award from the Grains Research and Development Corporation for his effort to make farmer aware of climate change . 
He say many grain grower be now wonder how to adapt . 
`` Certainly , no longer be people say - what be climate change , be this something my grandchild have to worry about ? '' he say . 
`` They 're concern about it and want to know more information about it now and what it mean for their decision-making and planning .

Tasmania be move to manage water use by the timber plantation sector a part of a review of it Water Management Act . 
The review be recommend a study of water right security and tenure , change to the dam approval process and a risk management strategy for water use by large scale land use change . 
Alan Harradine from the Department of Primary Industries and Water say catchment model need to be refine .

Cattle producer urge to audit livestock record 
The Australian Beef Association ( ABA ) want cattle producer to audit their livestock record list on the database of the National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) . 
The system , which be design to track every animal through electronic ear tag in case of a disease outbreak , have be heavily criticise by the breakaway group . 
New president Brad Bellinger from New South Wales say the ABA 's own research show only 30 per cent of NLIS producer record be accurate . 
`` Now their own audit be the matter of match what their actual property sale be to what be actually register on the NLIS database account , '' Mr Bellinger say . 
`` We want to point out to the regulator and the Minister how bad the situation , how inaccurate the NLIS system be . '' 
The Federal Government have commission an official audit of the database . 
Meanwhile the peak national body , Meat and Livestock Australia ( MLA ) , be call for unity within the cattle industry . 
The ABA boycott MLA 's annual general meeting in Adelaide yesterday and stag a rally in Queensland . 
MLA chairman Don Heatley say cattle producer need to resolve NLIS issue by work together . 
`` Yes , there be criticism , and I do n't resile from the criticism , '' he say . 
`` At the end of the day we 've develop a new system and NLIS be new and it 's not perfect at this stage but we will continue to work on it . 

Pig tracing may go high-tech 
The pig industry be consider launch an electronic system to trace animal . 
The industry have already set up a traceability system call Pig Pass , where producer who export pig fill out national vendor declaration form . 
But Bill Salter from producer group Australian Pork Limited ( APL ) say they be now look at a paperless system with swipe card instead of individual animal tag . 
`` The system would work on the basis of have everyone involve in Pig Pass actually be register on the APL database , '' Mr Salter say .

Native flower export wilt 
Australia 's native flower sector expect to lose about 30 per cent of it export flower crop this year . 
Drought , frost and hot weather have decimate crop , with some grower report bud loss of 50 per cent and hundred of thousand of flower which be unsaleable . 
Tony Kosky from the Australian Flower Export Council say low production level will affect Australia 's international reputation a a reliable flower supplier .

Cane toad help reduce mosquito number 
If you dread summer because of the mosquito , you might need to start hang around cane toad . 
As part of a study into the effect toad be have on native fauna , a team of scientist have find cane toad tadpole be reduce mosquito number . 
Professor of ecological biology at the University of Sydney Rick Shine say the toad could be contribute to good human health . 
`` We 've simply set out bowl of water with and without cane toad tadpole , we 've put mosquito larva in there and we 've see whether or not the mosquito larva do survive and what size mozzie actually fly out at the end , '' Prof Shine say . 

Prospect for rain improves 
The National Climate Centre say a duel between sea temperature in the Pacific and Indian ocean could bring slightly high rainfall to much of Australia . 
Indian Ocean temperature be rise off Western Australia and up to Indonesia , cancel out a worsen El Nino effect in the Pacific Ocean . 
There be now a 50 per cent chance of average rainfall across most of Australia in the next three month , although north Queensland could be dry . 
Senior climatologist Lyn Bettio say the prospect of rain certainly have not get any bad . 
`` It 's actually look good than what it be last month , '' she say . 

Merino price plummet 
Prices for top merino sheep have plummet at the annual Yass circuit sale , in New South Wales , once a stronghold for fine and superfine wool . 
With a large offering than last year , merino sheep and cross breed lamb be be offload a the drought bite deep , with ewes be pass in for $ 1.50 each . 
The average price for Roseville ewe of the Merryville line be $ 10 , down from a height of $ 70 in previous year . 
Richard Buckmaster say the low price will hurt farmer . 
`` It 's very disappointing . I know we 've get bad season and everything but I think this be the bad we 've have in 17 year of circuit sale , '' Mr Buckmaster say . 
In general , the wool market have ease this week , fall 2 per cent at sale in Sydney , Fremantle and Melbourne . 
The eastern market indicator ( EMI ) fell 18 cent , to finish the week at 826 cent a kilogram . 

Stronger quarantine condition for import prawn recommend 
Biosecurity Australia have recommend tougher quarantine restriction on prawn import , which could effectively end the trade . 
The domestic industry have call for an end to import due to disease concern , although importer oppose any tough restriction . 
Federal Fisheries Minister Eric Abetz say if the draft recommendation be adopt , most of the country which currently send prawn to Australia will not be able to prove they be free of disease . 

ACCC clamp down on misleading label 
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ( ACCC ) be clamp down on mislead claim be make about food and drink . 
It have publish new guideline on what can be label organic , free range , natural and fresh . 
Commissioner John Martin say producer and processor of everything from egg to fruit juice be increasingly flout the law but will not be able to get away with it for long . 

Legislation block grasslands clear 
After three year of wrangling , Tasmania have pass legislation to protect remnant grassland from land clearing . 
The controversial legislation be only pass yesterday in Tasmania 's Upper House after a number of modification be make to the Bill . 
Tasmania be oblige under a federal agreement sign in 2003 to protect non-forest native vegetation . 
President of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association , Roger Swain , say the legislation be restrictive but at least provide certainty . 

Govt contribute to WA carbon trial 
The Federal Government will contribute $ 60 million towards the world 's big carbon capture and storage trial in Western Australia . 
The money will go to the Gorgon natural gas project off the Pilbara coast , which be still wait for the final go ahead . 
If it proceed , 125 million tonne of excess carbon dioxide will be liquefy and bury 2.5 kilometre under the sea bed in saline aquifer . 
Environment Minister Ian Campbell say it be imperative the project get off the ground . 
`` The Gorgon project , be the big one of it type anywhere in the world , in fact big than all of the other project in the rest of the world put together , will help u demonstrate that it can be do safely , that you can put in place a regulatory environment around it , put the risk management technique around it , '' Senator Campbell say . 

Irrigators discuss compensation with Premier 
New South Wales farmer have meet with Premier Morris Iemma to ask for compensation for their cut water allocation . 
The Government have slash carry over water allocation for Murray River irrigators by half . 
What water be available will only be give to customer near the major supply channel to reduce evaporation . 
Chairman of Southern Riverina Irrigators Ted Hatty say the Government have not offer any immediate help . 
`` The Premier have say that he will look at what he can do , he say we 're talk week not month , so I suppose that be a positive , '' he say .

Dairy Australia say it will not ask farmer to support an increased service levy next year . 
A poll on the levy will be hold in February and March , with farmer to be offer three option .

The thoroughbred horse industry say new research could protect hundred of foal from the disease know a rattle . 
The debilitate bacterial infection be believe to be bring on by dry and dusty weather , and cost the industry million of dollar a year . 
Researcher David Hodgson say good livestock management could prevent the disease spreading .

Australia 's peak sheepmeat body have appoint a new president .

Top drop go down well with National Wine Show judge 
The 2004 and 2005 vintage have prove popular with the judge at this week 's National Wine Show in Canberra . 
Only premium wine that have win other award can enter , with the main award go to wine from Margaret River , the Hunter Valley and the Yarra Valley . 
Chairman of judge James Halliday say top drop be cheap because of the wine glut . 
`` 2004 , 2005 , 2006 which be the three vintage which have bring the oversupply issue right onto the front page , happen to have be three very good vintage , '' he say . 
`` So if you 're go to have too much wine it 's rather a good thing to have too much good wine , or very good wine , rather than too much bad wine . '' 
Meanwhile drought , frost damage and low water allocation be draw down Australia 's wine stock glut faster than anticipate . 
The wine industry have revise down it estimate for next season from 900-million litre to 460-million litre . 
Predictions for another extreme drought season next year be expect to bring yield down by 20 per cent . 
Lawrie Stanford from the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation say the excess stock be certainly drop and that be good news . 
`` The late estimate that the industry have be that stock above a desirable level would rate at something like 460 million litre , '' he say . 

Far north Qld fruit wine in demand 
The maker of tropical fruit wine in far north Queensland say they be struggle to keep up with demand . 
The wine be make from fruit include passionfruit , native tropical berry , banana , lychee , rambutan and black sapote . 
Tony Woodall from the Tropical North Queensland Wineries Association say the region have become the world 's leading commercial fruit wine producer . 
`` Some of the fruit be quite bland like grape and do n't make a particularly nice wine , '' he say . 
`` Not say grape do n't , they do of course . 

Cole inquiry report finalise 
After nearly a year of public hearing , 7,500 page of court transcript and more than 70 witness , the final report of the Cole inquiry be finish . 
Commissioner Terence Cole be today hand the document to Australia 's Governor-General Michael Jeffery in a brief ceremony at Admiralty House , the official Sydney residence of the Governor-General , 
It will advise the Federal Government on the action it should take against monopoly wheat exporter AWB and two other Australian company for kickback payment they make to the Iraqi regime in breach of UN sanction . 
AWB be by far the large contributor , pay more than $ 290 million . 
Huge secrecy surround the content of the report , which will be table in Federal Parliament next week . 
It be widely predict Commissioner Cole will recommend the laying of criminal charge against some AWB executive . 
The report 's content will also have a bearing on the future of the single desk . 
Meanwhile the author of an AWB commission report into wheat export say change to the single desk be inevitable . 
But the report say any change should take place gradually , to minimise the impact on wheat grower . 
Former world trade commissioner and report author , Alan Oxley , have warn that any immediate change could hurt 12,000 grain grower from marginal area . 
`` These tend to be farmer who be not in upper income group who be solely dependent on grain in area where there be variability , '' Mr Oxley say . 
`` So as far a we be concern they be concentrate in the eastern wheatbelt of Western Australia , and on the Eyre Peninsula ( in SA ) , and in western NSW . They be the one who tend to rely on the collective marketing of their crop . '' 
But independent grain analyst Malcolm Bartholomaeus disagree . 
He say most farmer would take advantage of an open market . 
`` I 'm not sure that we hold back the entire industry for a small group who may have a little more trouble adjust . Farmers be n't silly , you change the rule and they rapidly adapt , '' Mr Bartholomaeus say . 

Dry condition to blame for slump in farmer ' confidence 
The confidence of Australian farmer have slump to it low level in six year . 
The state of mind in rural Australia be reveal in the late Rabobank Rural Confidence Survey . 
Just 15 per cent of farmer expect the rural economy to pick up over the come 12 month compare with 19 per cent last quarter . 
The state hardest hit be Victoria , New South Wales and South Australia . 
Rabobank 's head of rural banking , Neil Dobbin , say ongoing dry condition be largely to blame . 
`` This be the low confidence farmer have have since the survey start , which be six year ago . Sixty-five per cent of the farmer think that income would worsen over the next 12 month , '' Mr Dobbin say . 

Tasmania struggle with drought 
Conditions continue to deteriorate in Tasmania after record low rainfall and river flow . 
The president of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association , Roger Swain , say the State be experience one of it bad season in 100 year . 
He say while pocket of the State be have a reasonable year , the extended dry and heavy frost be make the season tough . 
`` It 's quite clearly a drought , you only have to look around and see , '' he say . 
`` We 're look at the ground now almost a if it be February here in Tasmania . 
The National party 's resurgence in country Victoria be continue , with more vote count in the state election . 
Labor have concede defeat in the Gippsland seat of Morwell with the seat go to Russell Northe from the Nationals , with the help of Liberal preference . 
The Nationals also take the seat of Mildura from independent MP , Russell Savage , in a swing influence by Labor 's proposal for a toxic waste dump in the electorate . 
The Nationals have increase their Lower House number by two to nine member in a poll where they fear they would be nearly wipe out by preference deal . 

German company buy wool directly through producer 
One of the world 's major wool spinner have start buy greasy wool directly from merino producer because of high level of dark fibre contamination in wool be sell through Australian auction room . 
German company Sudwolle process 200,000 bale a year at mill in China , Germany and Poland - the equivalent of 10 per cent of the Australian wool clip . 
It have be trialing buying wool through an Adelaide firm , which source bale from a small group of fine wool grower . 
Director of purchase Gotz Giebel blame the high contamination rate on a trend by grower towards sheep which produce both meat and wool , which have more black fibre in their fleece . 
`` We have initiate that because we notice a lot of quality problem and due to our size and our market situation we think we have to do something in the industry , '' he say . 
`` Also to encourage grower and that 's very important . 
`` We also want to reward the grower for good quality . '' 
But wool broker and buyer in South Australia believe local producer have grow one of the best clip of the past five season . 
Landmark 's state wool manager Trevor James say the quality have hold up despite the lack of rain . 
`` Probably that early rain in March put a bit of feed on the ground and that early rain make a big difference , so we 've get a lot of really good length , good sound wool , probably be the best we 've see for five year and we 've have some really fantastic wool come through , '' he say . 

Lamb feedlot shed open for business 
One of eastern Australia 's big lamb feedlot shed have open . 
Based in Goondiwindi , in southern Queensland , it will house more than 3,500 sheep undercover . 
Owner Kerry Corish say they originally expect to sell around 15,000 fat lamb a year but that number have significantly increase due to the drought 
`` I think at the moment the way it look and the drought condition , and because we 've buy far more sheep than what we anticipate we would be able to buy , and that 's simply drive by the drought and because ( of ) the large number available down south and the price drop in sheep , that we probably will go 20,000 plus , I would imagine , '' Mrs Corish say .

Mr Roberts say $ 57 million in levy money be spend last year to help farmer survive the drought and fight for their right . 
`` Our leadership role be [ to ensure ] the farmer have good information and water again be another good example a the dairy industry be probably the big single user in agriculture of water , '' he say . 
`` We 've get to be able to defend our position and make sure our argument be good and sound because there 's a lot of competition for that water . '' 
Farmers will be ask to vote on three levy option early next year . 
Because of the drought , Dairy Australia be ask them to maintain the current levy rate rather than increase it . 
Mr Rowley represent dairy farmer at a state , national and international level for more than 30 year . 
He also help create the peak body five year ago and say he be sorry to be leave at such a testing time . 
`` I 'm sure the industry will no doubt get through this drought and it always rain at the end of a drought , but there will be some people who will struggle very hard and that be sad to me a I go , but it would n't matter when I decide to go , there would be some challenge somewhere , '' Mr Rowley say . 

Court close chapter on native title claim 
Members of the Federal Court have don heavy black robe in 40 degree heat to close a chapter on a series of long-running native title claim in north Western Australia . 
At a small community outside of Kununurra , the court grant native title to almost 7,000 square kilometre of the East Kimberley , bring the total land under native title in the region to 35 per cent . 
Edna O'Malley from the Miriuwung Gajerrong Corporation say the ruling not only allow access to country but will bring economic benefit in the future .

`` With about 70 per cent of wheat grower in Western Australia engage in harvest , withhold their wheat from the statutory marketing single desk operator , I think it 's a crisis and I think it 's a crisis that need to be address now , '' Senator Johnston say .

The Federal Government have start consider the future of the wheat export system follow the Cole inquiry report .

South Korea reject US beef shipment 
South Korea have reject a US beef shipment over a tiny bone fragment , deal a major blow to US effort to recapture the market . 
US beef be first ban in Korea after mad cow disease be detect in Washington state in 2003 . 
US Agriculture Department Deputy Under-Secretary Chuck Lambert be upset , not just that Korea will not accept any bone in US beef , which could transmit mad cow disease , but by the way it handle the initial post-mad cow US shipment . 
`` It 's disappoint that they 've go to the length that they have to identify this small , very small piece of bone in more than nine tonne of product , '' he say . 
The US have ask an international standard set body to assign the US a mad cow-risk classification but insist US beef meet exist safety guideline . 

Quarantine protocol impose on NZ avocado 
Biosecurity Australia have impose new quarantine protocol on avocado import from New Zealand . 
The disease avocado scab have be find in New Zealand and be not know to be in Australia . 
The new rule will require fruit to be spray before harvest and dip in copper after harvest .

`` You 'd expect a fall in profit and we 've allude to that . 

VFF demand end to Goulburn-Murray water trading 
The Victorian Farmers Federation ( VFF ) want the State Government to stop water be permanently trade between the Goulburn and Murray River system . 
Currently irrigators on the Goulburn system only have access to a quarter of their annual water allocation , while Victorian irrigators on the Murray can use 95 per cent . 
When a water allocation be trade from the Goulburn to the Murray , it be automatically increase from 23 to 95 per cent . 
VFF water resource committee spokesman Richard Anderson say a a result , Murray irrigators be now worry their allocation be at risk . 
`` Once it 's transfer down on to the Murray system , the person buy that megalitre of water actually get to use 95 per cent , be the current allocation on the Murray system , '' he say .

Northern Territory hay producer be take advantage of the drought across the rest of the country to meet export demand .

Ancient drought blame for megafauna destruction 
A group of researcher say a series of massive drought 40,000 year ago wipe out Australia 's megafauna . 
It have be previously think that over-hunting be to blame . 
Palaeontologist Dr Gilbert Price have dig up the fossil of giant kangaroo , emu and wombats the size of car in south-east Queensland . 
He say the remains show the population have be under stress because of dry condition , which could provide clue to help small wildlife specie today . 
`` There 's so many interesting ecological event that have occur in the past and these event be record in place like the Darling Downs in the fossil record , '' he say . 

Task force to examine AWB charge 
A day after Commissioner Terence Cole have hand down his final report into the activity of AWB in Iraq , 12 people be consult lawyer about their future . 
A special task force will investigate whether they should face criminal prosecution . 
Former chairman Trevor Flugge be among a group of people who Commissioner Cole have find should be far investigate for possible breach of the Crimes and Corporations Act . 
He be join by former manage director Murray Rogers and former chief financial officer Paul Ingleby . 
Also name be whistleblower Mark Emons and Dominic Hogan , executive Peter Geary , Michael Long , Nigel Officer and Michael Watson , and former in-house lawyer Jim Cooper . 
Charles Stott have be single out for his involvement in the smelly Tigris affair , involve BHP and a 20,000 tonne wheat shipment . 
Commissioner Cole have also recommend the Wheat Export Authority be give more power and more money to regulate AWB but he have leave AWB 's veto right and the future of the single desk to be sort by the Federal Government . 
Former AWB manage director Andrew Lindberg say he be relieve that the Cole inquiry have clear him of any wrongdoing . 
But he say it be a matter of great regret that kickback be pay to Iraq and he hop it do not lead to the dismantling of the single desk for export Australian wheat . 
`` Personally , I think that would be a great shame because I do believe it do provide a great benefit to Australia against heavily subsidise competition , particularly from the US and Europe , '' he say . 
`` I think it 's very important that we do n't throw the baby out with the bath water . '' 

Grains Council 
The Grains Council have warn the Federal Government not to use the Cole finding a an excuse to abolish the single desk for wheat export .

`` We 've come out with six basic principle that be there and the key of that be ownership and control by grower , and I guess security of payment for pool participant , '' he say . 
`` There be six thing and they 're on our website . They be quite clear and the government 's very well aware of that .

Govt accuse of mishandle response to Cole report 
Two former diplomat say the Federal Government have mishandle it response to the kickback scandal , give an advantage to Australia 's international wheat trade competitor . 
Andrew Farran , now a trade policy consultant living in Victoria , say the damage to the monopoly wheat trader cause by the Cole inquiry have already cause farmer to lose wheat contract . 
Former Middle East diplomat Bruce Haigh , now farm in New South Wales , say wheat grower will be angry if they lose the single desk a a result of the inquiry . 
`` I mean the drought be already a huge burden that they 're have to cope with and if the single desk get lose , it 'll be an even big blow , '' he say . 
`` I can say from my conversation with wheat grower , that they 're very apprehensive and the potential there be for a lot of anger . '' 
Prime Minister John Howard say the Federal Government be still consider a range of option for the future of the wheat export marketing system but because of the Cole inquiry find the status quo can not remain . 
Mr Howard acknowledge there be division within Government , with the Nationals push to keep the single desk and some Liberals demand the removal of AWB 's monopoly . 
He say he will put forward recommendation to MPs next week but the solution decide on will be the best one for farmer . 
`` Any changed arrangement have to be one that work and have wide acceptability among Australian wheat grower , '' he say . 
`` Our main concern be to protect the interest of Australian wheat grower and I be determine that whatever arrangement come out of the discussion will protect the interest of Australian wheat grower . '' 
Meanwhile United States Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns have direct his department to again consider ban AWB 's United States subsidiary from his country 's export program in the wake of the Cole report . 
Mr Johanns acknowledge that the AWB have voluntarily agree last year to not participate in the US Department of Agriculture 's ( USDA ) export credit program but add that be pending the outcome of the Cole inquiry . 
Top USDA lawyer Marc Kesselman say Mr Johanns have order him to resume debarment proceeding against AWB . 
`` The Government can choose who it do business with and the Government usually choose to do business with people whom it think be trustworthy , who be not go to commit fraud with federal dollar , '' he say . 

Agriculture sector remain large water user 
The Australian Bureau of Statistics say agriculture be still the big sector user of water in Australia but consumption have fall by 23 per cent since 2001 . 
The new water report say farmer and the domestic sector have both respond to the drought , with householder reduce their water consumption by 8 per cent . 
Michael Vardon from the bureau say farmer have be particularly responsive to reduce water supply by plant less demand crop . 
`` Certainly cotton and rice be large user in 2002 to 2001 and they continue to be in 2004-2005 but the water use have decline , water use have decline substantially in those industry , '' he say . 

Goulburn win water-saving award 
The resident of one of Australia 's dry city have be recognise for their effort to conserve water . 
Goulburn in southern New South Wales have halve it domestic water usage under stage five water restriction over the past 18 month . 
Now the council have win a National Water Conservation Award for Excellence , ahead of 700 council from around the country . 
Goulburn-Mulwaree Mayor Paul Stephenson say the council be now apply for state funding to install a cover for the Pejar dam to reduce evaporation . 
`` It still allow the ultra-violet ray to get through to do the normal purification of your water , it reflect a lot of the heat , '' he say . 
`` Your blue-green algae problem start to dissipate and you stop all the wind action because these thing be moor up reasonably close together .

New figure show the National Livestock Identification System ( NLIS ) be work 99 per cent of the time at two of Queensland 's major saleyards at Roma and Dalby .

AWB to split 
AWB be plan to split the company in the wake of the Cole inquiry report . 
Chairman Brendan Stewart have also announce he will stand down , once the split be approve by shareholder . 
As expect , the embattled wheat exporter have propose to separate AWB International , which own the single desk licence and service provider AWB Limited to independent company . 
AWBi will be wholly grower-owned and manage the national pool , while AWBl will be list on the stock exchange and it service to AWBi will be decide in a new agreement to be vote on by shareholder at a February annual general meeting . 
Managing director Gordon Davis will also introduce a new executive team to run the company and AWBl 's Mr Stewart will stand down in a bid to improve the company 's governance . 
Meanwhile , BHP Billiton say an internal review into it involvement in the oil-for-food scandal have exonerate the company . 
The mining giant be implicate when the Cole Commission hear that BHP Petroleum have deliver a shipload of wheat to Iraq in 1996 , worth million of dollar . 
Chief executive Chip Goodyear say the internal review have reflect the Cole report find that there be no basis for adverse finding against the company . 
`` BHP and BHP Billiton act consistently with the UN sanction and Australian law , '' he say . 

AWB plan 'not a permanent solution ' 
The US wheat industry have reject AWB 's plan to split the company into two separate business . 
US Wheat Associates claim the AWB split into a grower-owned operator control export and a commercial agribusiness firm do not get rid of the single desk monopoly target by the US . 
`` We believe that any solution that leave a monopoly in place in Australia , Canada , wherever it be , no matter how you shuffle the box around or shift responsibility from one organisation to another , a monopoly be not a permanent solution , '' spokesman Steve Mercer say . 
Mr Mercer say if the new arrangement leave in place veto power over private export with a new organisation or Australia 's Wheat Export Authority it be still a monopoly and must be end . 
The Australian Grains Exporters Association be also critical of the split because it will not make the market contestable until next harvest . 
AWB will seek the approval of shareholder after it annual general meeting in February . 
But association spokesperson Alick Osborne say that be not good enough . 
`` If this get up at all , it wo n't be until the middle of next year which be far too late for grower , particularly those grower in Western Australia , who be try to make marketing decision for the wheat they produce this harvest and be not comfortable with the lack of choice be provide to them today , '' Mr Osborne say .

Eastern Australian bulk grain handler Graincorp have announce a full year after-tax profit of $ 39.5 million . 
The result be a whopping 193 per cent high than last year 's result .

`` As part of our strategy to manage this we continue to reduce our cost and focus on revenue improvement in a number of our business unit . ''

El Nino may be benefit fishing , aquaculture 
El Nino weather system may have a bad name for bring drought to Australia but they might bring benefit for fishing and aquaculture . 
The interaction between weather system and the ocean will soon be track more closely , with the installation of high-tech monitoring equipment along the Australian coast . 
South Australian base oceanographer Dr John Middleton say the equipment will give a more accurate picture of the impact of El Nino system on marine life . 
`` The research I 've do to date suggest they can actually lead to more nutrient available to the food web and thus more productivity , '' he say .

Gary Riggs almost hit the animal while he be out on a bore run and say it be the first time he have ever see a deer in the bush . 
`` I think jingo I wish I have a camera , '' he say . 
`` Anyway I get home and I call a meeting , and it be all the kid and everyone who 's here and I say 'Santa 's in a bit of a flap at the moment , he 's a bit hot and bother ' . 

Govt seek to strike balance over chemical restriction 
The Federal Government be ask the public whether there should be tight restriction on around 80 chemical widely use in agriculture to try to prevent them be use by terrorist . 
Attorney-General Philip Ruddock say the Bali bombing show that terrorist be look for readily accessible chemical which be easy to use . 
Farmers be oppose the change regard chemical use in fertiliser , spray , grain fumigant and livestock production , say there be already industry restriction in place . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say the Government will try to strike a balance between security concern and the impact on farmer . 
`` High risk chemical be not so freely available a the public might think at present anyway , '' he say . 

Growers to fight import of NZ apple 
Australian apple grower will appeal against Biosecurity Australia 's decision to allow import from New Zealand . 
Under the recommendation , tough quarantine measure will be impose on import to stop the disease fire blight enter Australia . 
But the peak industry body say it 400 page submission on the plan be largely ignore . 
Apples and Pears Australia chairman Daryl Ashton say there should be additional inspection of orchard in New Zealand because the disease risk be too great . 
`` The level of protection , that 's the Government 's responsibility and we 'll be start to call on the Minister and in fact all parliamentarian to ensure that Australia 's level of protection be what it should be and not what Biosecurity Australia want it to be , '' Mr Ashton say . 
Under the new rule , apple import will still be ban in WA and the Tasmanian Government be consider impose it own ban . 
Primary Industry Minister David Llewellyn say import pose a serious risk to the Tasmanian industry . 
He say state quarantine regulation could be tighten in response to the import risk analysis . 
Meanwhile the New Zealand Government be consider take action through the World Trade Organisation if the new import risk analysis for apple becomes law . 
New Zealand Agriculture Minister Jim Anderton say the propose quarantine regime will be too expensive for grower and be base on trade protectionism rather than science . 
`` If we ca n't get the fact in the way of others ' prejudice , we 'll have to look at other action , and the WTO be the last resort , '' he say .

`` That 's where we 've be for the last six month . Supply of the vaccine be run out and it have be ration , so theoretically people who should be receive it may not be receive it . '' 
Hunter Valley farmer Bev Adams , who have suffer from the disease , say the announcement be great news .

November have be the fifth consecutive month of record low flow into the Murray River system .

It have now be sell to the Macquarie Goodman Group .

`` In a big pastoral situation I find the economy of scale be not there .

Barley single desk marketing system abolish in SA 
After 10 year of operation , South Australia 's single desk marketing system for barley will be abolish . 
Despite a majority of South Australian grower support a single desk in a open ballot conduct earlier this year , the decision have be overturn . 
Barley marketing will be oversee by an independent authority know a the Essential Services Commission over the next three year . 
After that , the market will be completely deregulate . 
This have be the result of a four month review , push by the State Government which have be deny national competition payment of up to $ 9 million in the last three year due to lack of competition . 

Winter crop harvest down 60pc : ABARE 
The late prediction from the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) show the nation 's winter crop harvest be 60 per cent down on last year . 
With the driest August to October period since 1900 , ABARE be also warn summer planting will suffer , particularly rice and cotton . 
Chief commodity analyst Dr Terry Sheals say any grain and fodder stock hold on farm will become increasingly important . 
`` I would expect the winter grain harvest , a lot of that harvest will be hold on farm in those area worst affect by the drought , '' he say . 
`` The report confirm the seriousness of the situation . 
`` We be look at the low winter grain crop in 10 year , since the 1994-95 drought to be precise . 
`` The crop 's estimate to be about 15.5 million tonne . '' 
Meanwhile a expect , drought condition have intensify across eastern and southern Australia . 
The National Climate Centre say there have be a distinct turn for the bad since August , due to the lack of late winter and spring rain .

`` We 've actually put special control area in there to stop vine and bin , and machinery move in there without cleaning , '' he say . 
`` That , along with the soil type which be not conducive to the spread of phylloxera , have help keep those vineyard free .

Professor Young say the move would drive up water price during drought reduce shortage and generate more money for water infrastructure , desalination and recycle project . 
`` If we start have high price in urban area then they 'll start actually make the water that they need themselves and actually recycle and do all those other thing , '' he say .

A bushfire researcher say slot or super dry air which reach the earth 's surface from a high altitude may have accelerate some of Australia 's bad fire . 
Dr Graham Mills be investigate the phenomenon in relation to the fatal bushfire on South Australia 's Eyre Peninsula in 2005 and the Canberra fire of 2003 . 
He say satellite imagery have reveal a dry slot move towards Canberra on the day the blaze hit the city . 
`` My hope would be that we would have some hour of warn for at least some of these event , '' he say .

Wheat export change may compromise national pool : AWB 
Wheat exporter AWB say a lack of clarity in the Federal Government 's change to the wheat export system could compromise the national pool . 
In the wake of the Cole inquiry , the Government will take control of AWB 's veto power over wheat export for six month while it discuss the future of the single desk . 
AWB say the change will prevent the company from forecast future earnings . 
Managing director Gordon Davis say he will meet with Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran to discuss the impact on grower who have already deliver wheat to the national pool . 
`` Under the previous obligation , AWBI have the ability to veto export if it consider they be n't in the interest of the national pool , '' he say . 
`` In these transitional arrangement , the Minister will have an obligation to make decision in the public interest . 
`` The arrangement be very complex a they currently be and there 's a range of interest that need to be satisfy in any discussion . '' 

Vaile 
Deputy Prime Minister Mark Vaile say the Government will not allow Australian wheat export to compete against each other in overseas market . 
The Government will decide which company be allow to export wheat for the next six month , but AWB will not have to apply for an export permit . 
Mr Vaile want the Government to gauge the view of grain grower organisation and wheat farmer before any decision be make on the future of the export system . 
`` We initially need to have a discussion with those group to draw together the point of view to probably develop an option paper go forward , then that need to be broadly discuss across the industry , '' he say . 
`` I think that at a point in this process the best thing that we can do a a Government be communicate directly with grower . '' 

WA grower 
Meanwhile the decision to remove AWB 's veto be expect to have the big impact on Western Australian grower , with many warehouse their wheat this harvest . 
But grower in the west have mix feeling . 
`` I think it be a good decision because there be a stalemate and I think it 'll be beneficial to WA wheat grower , the one that have warehouse their wheat , '' one grower say . 
`` It also give protection to the farmer who have deliver into the pool . '' 
`` Stripping the right of veto from the AWB this year , in an exceptional drought year and give to Mr McGauran could be fraught with danger , '' another grower say . 
`` Before I allocate my wheat I want to know that CBH ( Co-operative Bulk Handling ) have get a realistic chance of extract a $ 20 or $ 30 a tonne premium , '' a third wheat grower say . 
`` If they have , well then that 's probably where the wheat will go . 
`` It 's just on a price thing , there 's no loyalty leave , I do n't think . ''

NFF back call for climate change action 
The National Farmers Federation ( NFF ) have join call for early action to tackle climate change . 
Members of the NFF 's policy council have vote to become part of the Australian Business Roundtable on Climate Change . 
President David Crombie say the nation 's farming body need to involve in effort to address climate change because of the impact it will have on agriculture . 
His call come a the Federal Government confirm that Australia 's greenhouse gas emission be set to rise by 22 per cent by 2020 . 
The bleak news be contain in it State of the Environment report , release today in Canberra . 
The report also confirm there have be five year of low than average rainfall across most of eastern Australia and that Perth 's water supply catchment be yield half a much water a they do in the 70 . 
Committee chairman Associate Professor Bob Beeton say thing will get bad before they get well . 
`` Some of the heritage property may decline , some biodiversity may decline , river health may continue at a very low level and the CO2 level obviously continue to increase , '' he say . 
`` The amount of energy use in Australia be still increase and we need to figure out what we 're go to do about that . '' 
Meanwhile , the energy sector say managing climate change will be it great challenge for the next few decade . 
The Energy Futures Forum have release a report which say future investment will hinge of the industry 's response to climate change . 
But forum member Tony Wood say develop country will have to make an effort as well . 
`` No-one would suggest that Australia should act unilaterally forever , '' he say . 
`` ( A ) we would just damage our own economy and ( b ) , we would n't solve the problem of climate change anyway , so there 's no doubt we require a global solution .

The small plant be process 2,500 sheep and 2,000 lamb a week and Mr Oliver say there be at least a month-long wait to get stock through . 
`` We be just struggle to keep in front , we be work six day a week and we be just look at put in an afternoon shift in the boning room to try and move some more number , '' he say .

Centenarian maintains enthusiasm for farm life 
She may be about to celebrate her 100th birthday but the Hunter Valley 's Harriet Madden have not lose her enthusiasm for farm life . 
For most of her life , Mrs Madden have be a dairy farmer with her late brother Len . 
Despite endure tough time and drought , Mrs Madden say she be now enviously eye off a farm that be for sale next door . 
`` And if I have my way , if I have the money , I 'd buy that now , '' she say . 
`` They only want $ 3,000 for it , it 's a bit much when you 're on the pension . 

NASA see evidence suggest liquid water on Mars 
Images take by NASA 's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft suggest the presence of liquid water on the Martian surface . 
It be a tantalising find for scientist wonder if the Red Planet ever have harbour life . 
The orbit US spacecraft allow scientist to detect change in the wall of two Martian crater that may have be cause by the recent flow of water , a team of researcher say in a paper appear in the journal Science . 
Scientists previously have establish that two form of water - ice at the pole and water vapour - exist on Mars , but liquid water be crucial to nurture life . 
The scientist compare image of the Martian surface take seven year apart and find the existence of 20 newly form crater cause by impact from space debris as well a the evidence suggest liquid water trickle down crater wall . 
`` These observation give the strong evidence to date that water still flow occasionally on the surface of Mars , '' Michael Meyer , lead scientist for NASA 's Mars Exploration Program , say in a statement . 
The paper say water seem to have flow down two gully in the past few year , even though liquid water can not remain long on the planet 's frigid , nearly airless surface because it would rapidly freeze or evaporate . 
This seem to support the notion that liquid water may exist close enough to the planet 's surface in some place that it can seep out from time to time . 
The scientist propose that water could remain in liquid form long enough on the surface to transport debris before freezing . 
The two bright new deposit be each several hundred metre long . 
They cite a possible alternative explanation that these feature be cause by movement of dry dust down a slope . 

Life on Mars ? 
Scientists long have wonder whether life ever exist on Mars . 
Liquid water be an important part of the equation . On Earth , all form of life require water to survive . 
Among the planet in our solar system , only Earth have a more hospitable climate than Mars , and some scientist suspect Mars once shelter primitive , bacteria-like organism . 
Previous mission find evidence the Red Planet at one time boast ample quantity of water , and the question be whether liquid water be still present . 
`` As with many discovery , the possibility that liquid water may be come to the surface of Mars today pose many question , '' the scientist say . 
`` Where be the water come from ? How be it be maintain in liquid form give the present and most likely past environment ? How widespread be the water ? '' 
They also wonder whether the water could be use a a resource for future mission to explore Mars . 
The two site be inside crater in the Terra Sirenum and the Centauri Montes region of southern Mars . 
`` The shape of these deposit be what you would expect to see if the material be carry by flow water , '' Michael Malin , lead author of the paper , say . 
`` They have finger-like branch at the downhill end and easily divert around small obstacle . '' 
The researcher first report the discovery of the gully in 2000 , but this be the first time they have reveal the presence of newly deposit material seemingly carry by liquid water . 
Last month , NASA say the Mars Global Surveyor mission appear to be at an end , say it have lose contact after a decade-long mission in which it map the surface of Mars , track it climate and search for evidence of water . 

WA fisher welcome new illegal fishing law 
The fishing industry in Western Australia have welcome new law to toughen the nation 's defence against illegal fishing . 
The Royal Australian Navy have be give permission to shoot at uncooperative illegal fishing vessel to disable engine or rudder but not sink them . 
Kimberley Professional Fishing Association spokesman Alan Fraser believe it will be a good deterrent . 
`` There 's be a lot of talk of action be take and money and resource be expend on try to solve this problem , but really up until now our effort have be pretty dismal , '' he say . 

Core cattle breed stock number fall 
The New South Wales Opposition say core cattle breed stock level have fall by 65 per cent due to the drought . 
Opposition primary industry spokesman Duncan Gay claim it could take five year to rebuild stock level . 
North-west stock agent Dick Cameron say some producer have already lose all of their breeding stock and may never recover . 
`` Some people have run out of heart , some have run out of money and some have run out of both , '' he say . 

US citrus export price skyrocket 
Citrus export to the United States this year have attract some of their high price in year . 
Exports of navel orange be down 33 per cent on the initial forecast due to severe frost damage , with 1.4 million carton ship . 
Greg Nelson from DNE World Fruit Sales say quality have be a factor in the good price . 
`` We really applaud the effort of the grower , the packer , the quality control inspector in Australia because the condition of the fruit be excellent , '' he say . 

Chiquita takeover stall 
A takeover bid for the major food processor and wholesaler Chiquita Brands South Pacific have be stall . 
Tradefresh , a joint venture between Timbercorp and the Cost Group , have manage to acquire control of the company with 78 per cent ownership . 
But plan to de-list the company from the stock exchange can not go ahead because investment company MMC Contrarian be not likely to sell it 12 per cent stake . 
Tradefresh and Chiquita chairman Robert Costa say he be disappoint at MMC 's stance . 
`` Our original intention be to secure 100 per cent of the company , that 's still our intention , '' he say . 
`` Now we know that 's not go to happen in the short term because we have a significant shareholder in MMC , who at this stage be not sell and that 's their prerogative . '' 
Chiquita have interest in the blueberry , banana , mushroom and citrus sector . 

US beef industry suspicious about bone chip find 
The US Agriculture Department want to examine bone chip that South Korea claim it find in two reject shipment of American beef . 
The US industry be suspicious about where the fragment come from . 
US beef industry source argue the tiny bone the Koreans claim they find , which cause them to reject the US shipment , may not have be from animal the same age a the beef . 
United States Department of Agriculture Deputy Under-Secretary Chuck Lambert be not ignore the possibility that the shipment may have be tamper with . 
`` We 've ask to have the bone chip return , some people have suggest DNA sampling or other mean of try to determine the origin of those bone chip , '' he say . 
The late suspicion threaten to raise the US-Korea beef dispute to a new level after Korea earlier this year agree to reopen it market follow a 2003 US mad cow case . 

Study to investigate irrigation scheme 
The Tasmanian Government be look at build the state 's big irrigation scheme . 
A study will look at the possibility of divert water use for hydro electricity to farmer in some of the dry part of the state . 
Farmer Richard Gardiner say power generation should no longer be the only use for the water . 
`` If you look at the state of water availability in the whole country and you look at the fact that there 's 2,000 odd megalitres a day earn $ 10 a megalitres , I think there be no other way we can go into the future , '' he say . 

Company defend GM canola import 
The importer of Australia 's first shipment of genetically modify ( GM ) canola say it have no choice but to buy in grain because of fall domestic production . 
Three Greenpeace protester have be arrest at the Port of Newcastle yesterday a they try to block 57,000 tonne of Canadian canola be offload . 
The grain will be process in Newcastle and sell to unnamed buyer in the oilseed and biodiesel industry . 
Cargill Australia importer Robert Green say crop level in the eastern state have be dramatically reduce . 
`` The current industry estimate that the crop 's only be an odd 160,000 tonne in the eastern state , versus an east coast demand of over 500,000 tonne of seed , '' he say . 

Milk production expect to drop 
The dairy industry be expect a big drop in milk production next year a farmer struggle to meet high feed price , particularly in non drought-declared area . 
Although milk processor be negotiate well farm gate price and offer interest free loan , farmer be have major problem secure reliable feed delivery . 
Dairy consultant Bill Naughtin say some farmer be not milk as much . 
`` I have hear on the grapevine that some people have decide to go once a day in an effort to reduce water use , but most people I have speak to have a plan in place to fee their animal , '' he say . 
`` The principal concern at the moment be where be they go to get the money to pay for the feed and how be they go to access feed that 's reasonable quality and reliable . '' 

Pressure 
Dry condition in Tasmania be put pressure on farmer who have be agisting dairy cow for their Victorian colleague .

`` When we agree to take an extra 100 or so heifer that be some six week ago because there be quite a bit of rough weather on Bass Strait it take some time to get them over , '' he say . 

Drought to impact on farm income 
The Australian Bureau of Statistics ( ABS ) say farm income be predict to fall this financial year because of the drought . 
It say farm GDP be to drop by 16 per cent and agricultural export be likely to fall 14 per cent . 
The ABS figure be confirm what farmer be see in the paddock a their income be drop , while the cost of their input be stay the same or rise if they be feed expensive grain to animal . 
Meanwhile peak farm group in the eastern state have form a Recovery Alliance to look at how the agriculture sector will rebuild after the drought . 
The group will chase further funding from the Federal Government to help farmer buy seed , fertiliser and maintain core breeding stock . 
New South Wales Farmers president Jock Laurie say the situation be dire for all rural community , not just farmer . 
`` If we get into a situation where people out there actually reduce their cropping by half , then obviously that 's the income halve for a lot of those small business , '' he say . 
`` In circumstance like these , what we 're aim to do be to try to make sure we get as much money flow through agriculture , which then flow straight back in through those small community - that will keep those small community go , business go . 
`` The thing about this be that it 's a way to help the whole region , the whole community , not just individual farmer . '' 

Local community lose out 
The economic impact of the drought be hit home in one small community in southern New South Wales . 
The Temora Shire Council say many local grain grower have not harvest a crop this year , cost the region about $ 100 million in lost income . 
Mayor Peter Speirs say when farmer stop spending , the whole town suffers . 
`` It will be very hard for some of our business , there will probably be rationalisation of staff in some area , '' he say . 

Fires begin to merge a wind shift 
Fire authority in Victoria be warn that 600,000 hectare of Alpine country in the state 's north and south-east could be on fire by the weekend . 
Fires spark by lightning strike earlier this week be merge a wind shift . 
Temperatures be set to climb into the high 30 on Saturday , along with predicted hot northerly wind . 
Bairnsdale district cattle grazier Frank O'Connor say all farmer can do be renew fire break , check water supply and pack personal belonging . 
`` We 've go through our family photograph and thing that connect you to your ancestor and so forth , they 've all be put in a bag , '' he say .

`` Secondly , a change in government policy that will allow the commercial harvest of wild crocodile egg , of course under strict guideline . '' 

GM canola shipment contaminate : AQIS 
The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service ( AQIS ) have confirm a 57,000 tonne shipment of import genetically-modified ( GM ) canola be contaminate with Canadian barley and weed . 
The shipment arrive at the Port of Newcastle this week . 
It will be process in Newcastle into protein meal and vegetable oil , and sell to the food and biodiesel industry . 
National manager for Plant Programs at AQIS Peter Liehne say it be common for bulk commodity to contain other material . 
`` In this case we find that there be some seed present in the shipment which have sufficient concern for u to look at the management of the product to ensure there be no risk to the environment result from these weed seed , '' he say . 

ABS revise grain storage figure 
The Australian Bureau of Statistics ( ABS ) have be force to re-release figure on the amount of grain in storage after the industry question the statistic . 
Earlier this week , the ABS say bulk grain handle company have more than 13 million tonne of grain in stock , include 10 million tonne of wheat . 
The revised figure show a drop to 10 million tonne in storage overall , with wheat make up around 7 million . 
The bureau 's Karen Connaughton say there be a number of reason for the change . 
`` We have n't undertake this collection since December 2004 so it be quite difficult for u to verify the benchmark figure , '' she say . 
`` We do make some effort to verify the figure and we get some broad parameter from people , and it appear that the estimate we provide be too high . ''

The volume of Australian wine export have reach a record 749 million litre this year , up 8 per cent .

`` So normally our peak season be around at the moment but we 've have a couple of quiet month and November be a a great catch up for u . ''

Efforts have begin to send another shipment of trained buffalo from the Northern Territory to the Indonesian province of Aceh . 
Seven water buffalo be send to remote rural village earlier this year to help resident recover from the 2004 Boxing Day tsunami . 
Buffalo whisperer Graham Heffernan say the villager have be frustrate by delay in replace their important beast of burden . 
He be hop the Federal Government will support plan to send another 50 by April . 
`` One of the first thing one of the farmer say to me be , 'why so long ' ? '' Mr Heffernan say . 
`` He be n't have a go at me ... take so long to get the buffalo there , it be like , 'all this other aid have happen here in Aceh , why have it take so long for someone to bring buffalo to u , because that 's what we really need ' . 
`` And that 's just the beginning you know . Like hopefully in 12-18 month we may be send them in hundred per month . '' 
The first Australian aid donation of trained water buffalo be the result of an unlikely alliance between a buffalo whisperer , a private benefactor , Newcastle surfer , the live export industry , shipping , fodder , trucking and quarantine authority .

Meanwhile Wheat Australia , the consortium of grain handler ABB , CBH and Graincorp , have re-submitted it export application for 500,000 tonne of wheat to Iraq . 
It follow the decision last week by the Federal Government to shift the veto power over wheat export from AWB to Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran . 
East coast grain handler Graincorp have also make four application to export wheat to Japan , Europe , Indonesia and Malaysia , total more than 200,000 tonne . 
In another development , grain analyst be predict global stock to fall to the low level in 20 year next season , a drought condition hit most wheat-producing country . 
The United States Department of Agriculture predict global wheat stock will drop to 119 million tonne next year , the low level see in two decade , thanks to drought and difficult planting condition around the world . 
As a result , this year 's high price be likely to continue into 2007 , with the competition between fuel industry and food add to the pressure . 
Grains analyst Lloyd George say the so-called food versus fuel factor be significant . 
`` The big surprise factor that 's happen on a long term basis , the emergence of biofuels would be right up there , '' he say . 
`` There 's strong incentive to use these biofuels in a number of different country and I 'd expect that to continue . ''

Farmers on Eyre Peninsula in South Australia may have to shoot their sheep in the next few month because they can not afford to fee them or send them to market .

He say the glut of sheep and lambs from interstate make it difficult to even book sheep and lamb into abattoir . 
`` In the next few month you might see quite a few sheep from Eyre Peninsula that will just have to be slaughter and bury if the number keep come out of Victoria , '' he say . 
`` It 's get to the stage this week that unless they be very good sheep , you 'll get a bill if you send them to Adelaide .

Some wine grape grower in South Australia 's Riverland could run out of irrigation water as early a next month .

`` A lot of grower have already go over 30 per cent of their total allocation for the year , '' he say . 

Dept hop sediment flow into Lake Argyle will decrease 
Authorities hope they have slow down the amount of soil run into Australia 's large inland sea , Lake Argyle , in the Kimberley region of Western Australia . 
A decade ago , scientist estimate the Ord River Irrigation Scheme 's main reservoir would lose 30 per cent of it storage capacity in the next 100 year . 
But sediment level have recently be survey again and Duncan Palmer from the Department of Water hop they show a slow-down of nutrient build up from wet season run-off .

`` Farmers do have it within their capacity to contribute to reduce emission , which be one of the major cause of greenhouse gas change and be link with climate change , '' Mr Crombie say . 
`` If farmer have a role to play there , which I believe they do , then it 's important that they be part of any long term plan go forward . '' 
Meanwhile a national emission trade summit in Sydney have be tell agriculture be pay the price for a century of pollution generate by the coal and resource sector .

US committee chief to let Senate decide on AWB probe 
The new chairman of the US House Agriculture Committee say he will leave it up to the US Senate to probe the AWB scandal , but will look at way to prevent problem in the future . 
Collin Petersen say he be not interested in `` assigning blame '' base on `` past history '' , but in deal with the monopoly practice of the AWB and the Canadian Wheat Board for the future : `` We 're not happy about the Australian Wheat Board , we think that have this kind of a system be not fair and not right , and we 've be try to get rid of it for a long time , some of u , '' he say . 
`` So we will be watch to see how this be reconstitute and whether it be go to be do in a way that be transparent , or whether it 's go to be utilise to undercut u when we 're try to go into other market . '' 
Mr Petersen expect the Senate , under new democratic leadership , to look at why the just-ended Republican Congress drop any plan to probe the oil for food scandal . 
Meanwhile wheat exporter AWB have drop price for the 2006/07 national pool by $ 8 a tonne . 
The company blame a weak international market for the decline , with the benchmark premium white wheat now return $ 242 a tonne . 

Rice crop expect to drop 
This year 's rice crop will be one of the small in more than 50 year due to cut to water allocation in southern New South Wales . 
The Department of Primary Industries estimate less than 12,000 hectare of rice have be sow , only 10 per cent of average planting . 
Other industry source say the figure be more like 15,000 hectare , which will yield around 130,000 tonne of rice . 
Griffith district rice grower Glen Andreazza say the late reduction in water allocation mean he have have to abandon his rice crop . 
`` I have sow 80 acre of rice and have to de-water all of it , '' he say . 
`` It be to the point where all I have to do be to keep water on it and watch it grow . 

Bass Coast applies for EC assistance 
One of the green part of southern Australia be now put it hand up for exceptional circumstance ( EC ) drought assistance . 
Farmers on the Bass Coast in southern Victoria say they be suffer one of the bad season on record . 
Stephanie Symes from the Bass Coast Shire Council say district farmer be use to much wetter condition . 
`` It 's the first time we 've ever have stage four water restriction apply , '' she say . 

Extra fund allocate for Qld sugar industry reform 
The Federal Government have announce another $ 33 million to reform the sugar industry in Queensland . 
One of the plan be to generate a third of Mackay 's energy need from nearby cane field . 
Under a $ 95 million project , the Mackay Sugar Co-operative will transform one it mill to convert sugar cane waste into steam and then electricity . 
Chief executive John Pollock say the funding will kickstart the plant . 
`` We 're really pleased that $ 12 million that the Government have see the value of the project and we presume that it 's fund the early stage of that project rather then the latter stage , '' he say . 

Camels sell a weed eater in Qld 
Prices have fall at Australia 's third commercial camel sale but organiser say there be a grow market for use the animal a weed eater . 
Camel breeder Paddy McHugh have sell 67 camel under the hammer at the Gracemere saleyards in central Queensland . 
He say while a few camel be buy to boost breeding number , most will have new job manage weed . 
`` That 's probably the most predominant use of them at the moment , be to eat the parkinsonia and prickly acacia and all the wattle regrowth , '' he say . 
`` They do a great job and they coexist with cattle - they 've get all sort of funny little thing , the ruminant bug they pass on . 

Drought force vegetable price up 
Shoppers be be warn that vegetable price could rise by 30 per cent before Christmas , and even double in January , a the drought continue to hurt production . 
But grower group be worried that price hike at the retail level be not be pass back to farmer , with many lock into contract that do not recognise high cost . 
AusVeg chairman Mike Badcock say some grower have raise concern about profiteer during the drought . 
`` I think while we can keep spread the word that we 'll be look very hard at margin and the return to grower , hopefully that keep everybody honest . There 's an opportunity here to reward grower who have do the right thing , drought proof their farm and they do need some reward for that , '' he say . 
The Australian Consumer and Competition Commission be review price in the meat industry as well , with a report due next week . 
And it be not just the drought that be set to hurt price . 
Fruit and vegetable grower in southern Queensland be count the cost of devastate hail storm which sweep through the region late yesterday . 
While up to 90 millimetre of rain be record in gauge on the Darling Downs , the hail have leave a multi-million dollar damage bill . 
Growers have report damage to crop of cabbage , strawberry , plum , table grape , tomato , mango and avocadoes and Stanthorpe lettuce grower Dean Radin say that could mean a price rise at the supermarket . 

Wholesalers not happy with fruit and veg code 
The controversial regulatory code of conduct for the fruit and vegetable industry be expect to be sign off by the Governor-General today . 
But section of the industry still be not happy with it . 
The code specify how wholesaler and grower must deal with each other in the future , but exclude supermarket , the big retailer and processor . 
Wholesaler Andrew Young , from the Central Markets Association of Australia , say the code he have see will be a cost burden for everyone . 
`` It add significant administration cost . There 's legal requirement that have be introduce , which grower must obtain legal advice prior to execute an agreement with a wholesaler . There 's much more prescription in term of how wholesaler can and can not act and virtually require in excess 90 per cent of the industry to totally change how they 've do business for many many year , '' he say . 

Zinifex and Umicore link for zinc 
Australia 's large lead and zinc miner will combine it smelt asset with a Belgian company to become the world 's big producer of zinc alloy . 
Zinifex have sign a memorandum of understand with Umicore to form a global company to produce 1.2 million tonne of zinc and alloy a year . 
Zinifex say it want to concentrate on mining , but spokesman Martin MacFarlane say exist smelter operation in Hobart and Port Pirie will not be affect . 
`` Those business tomorrow will continue on much a they have today , there 's no change to any of the employee term and condition for the short to medium term future - we see the business will be very much a it be today , '' he say . 
`` Longer term , however , it may create and open opportunity that may not have be otherwise available just from the fact that Zinifex do not wish to develop that side of the business . '' 

Japan agree to export talk 
Despite concern over the impact on it agriculture sector , Japan have agree to discuss good access for Australian farm export under a possible free trade agreement . 
Formal talk on the trade deal will start early next year , which the Federal Government believe could be worth $ 39 billion to Australia over 20 year . 
Trade Minister Warren Truss say Japan might push for more opportunity to sell niche product to Australia , but farmer here should receive the big gain . 
`` We be export a lot of beef into Japan at the present time , but all of it be pay 40 per cent or more tariff , '' he say . 

Deadline for potential wheat exporter loom 
The Federal Government want potential wheat exporter to submit their application by Friday , to give certainty to grain grower during the harvest . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran now have the power of veto over export application , after it removal from AWB in the wake of the Cole inquiry . 
Mr McGauran say application will be assess on public interest ground to maximise return to the industry .

Prime Minister John Howard have visit firefighter in north-east Victoria , a they continue to battle bushfires which have now burn 400,000 hectare . 
Thick smoke cover Whitfield a resident and Country Fire Authority ( CFA ) volunteer meet with the Prime Minister today . 
Made up of beef property and vineyard , the Whitfield area in the north-east of Victoria have be threaten by fire since lightning strike hit there a week and a half ago . 
John Howard have thank firefighter for their work , and get a briefing on the fire condition which be expect to last many week . 
He also speak with local , mostly woman , who be busy make cup of tea and sandwich for the crew . 
He will visit the fire ground before fly to Tasmania , where he be expect to make a funding announcement . 
Meanwhile cooler weather on Tasmania 's east coast be help firefighter control a bushfire which have burnt more than 11,500 hectare and destroy 17 home . 
Firefighters be work to contain the fire ahead of forecast hotter and winder condition tomorrow . 
Farmer Stephen Woods , whose two farm near Scamander be already hit by drought , have save his livestock , but lose more than 100,000 of pasture and another 700 hectare of bush .

The WA Government have give the environmental nod to the development of the Gorgon gas field on Barrow Island . 
The island , off the Pilbara Coast , be a reserve that be home to the rare flatback turtle and other endangered specie . 

Drought stall dairy-based manage investment scheme 
The development of the nation 's first dairy-based manage investment scheme have stall due to the drought . 
Carilla Dairy at Tintinara in South Australia 's south-east have fail to find enough cow because of a lack of feed . 
The company need 2,000 head before it can issue a prospectus , but only have 1,200 . 
Peter Doman from Dairy Management Australia say despite the delay , he be confident the scheme will be successful . 
`` We 're go to try and keep on track , but obviously this year have present it problem for u , '' he say . 
`` We 've just get to work towards what we 're go to do over the next 12 month . As you say , it 's the first dairy farm that 's go to be involve in a scheme , we think it 'll be sell next year and we think it 'll go very very well . 
The drought be hit the dairy sector in general , with milk production drop below the past two season . 

EMS accreditation do n't attract premium price : study 
A study have find consumer will not pay extra for food just because it have environmental credential . 
Increasingly farm be adopt environment management system ( EMS ) , which can cost up to $ 10,000 to implement . 
The Australian Farm Institute have find product stamp with an EMS accreditation do not attract premium , because consumer expect farmer to be environmentally responsible . 
But spokesman Mick Keogh say the EMS system be useful to win new market . 

Aquifers be badly mismanage : letter 
Australia 's underground water supply be in crisis , accord to a letter that have be send to all level of government . 
Written by seven of the country 's lead hydro-geologists from the public and private sector , the document say Australia 's aquifer be be badly mismanage . 
Spokesman Dr Rick Evans say on every level , from policy to education , effort be aim at repair river , instead of restore groundwater .

An anonymous Sydney businessman have donate $ 150,000 to buy Christmas hamper for drought affected family in western New South Wales . 
The donor say he want to let struggle family know that people in the city do care about them . 
Jamie Simmons from Broken Hill 's Christian City Church hop it will make a little difference . 

Saleyards industry worry about livestock dumping 
With sheep selling for as little a 10 cent a head in some part of the country , the New South Wales Shires Association be call on saleyards to waive their fee . 
But the industry be worry that saleyards could become a dumping ground for livestock in poor condition . 
David Pollock from the Livestock Saleyards Association of Victoria say farmer must consider the welfare of their animal . 
`` People should consider whether the animal be fit to load and to be transport , and go through the rigour of the saleyard process before it 's send there , '' he say . 
`` And if it 's not in that condition , well then it should n't come to the saleyard . '' 
And the RSPCA be urge grazier to look after their livestock follow the conviction of a 54-year-old farmer from southern New South Wales . 
Llewellyn Mark Doulman be convict on 77 breach of the Cruelty to Animals Act for his treatment of 2,500 sheep . 

Court ask to streamline AWI case 
Australian Wool Innovation ( AWI ) have ask the Federal Court to streamline it case against the animal right group PETA . 
The peak wool body want the claim of 101 woolgrowers heard separately , leave AWI , Elders Limited and BWK Elders Australia to go to trial against PETA and Animal Liberation New South Wales . 
AWI start it case against PETA in November 2004 and join the woolgrowers to the action in March , 2005 . 
AWI 's counsel tell Justice Rares his client propose corral the woolgrowers separately for efficiency reason to streamline the case . 
But PETA 's barrister Michael Jones say this would prejudice his client because PETA want access to the farmer ' contract for sale of wool , financial record and mulesing information .

Hot and windy weather this afternoon be expect to test firefighter battle a large fire near Tumut , in southern New South Wales . 
The fire have burn 13,000 hectare - mainly pine plantation . 
Landholders in the Argalong and Goobruhgandra valley have be on high alert since yesterday afternoon , when the fire breach containment line . 
A handful of people have be relocate . 
Last night firefighter be able to put in new containment line but with hot north-westerly wind forecast for this afternoon there be concern there might be spot-overs . 
Rural Fire Service Commissioner Phil Koperberg be tour the region and an extra 70 fire brigade have be bring in . 
A sky crane helicopter be also add to the aerial attack . 
Forests New South Wales will attempt to salvage timber from the burnt pine plantation near Tumut . 
At least 10,000 hectare of pine have be burn so far . 
Spokesman Bob Almond say tree that have be blacken can still be salvage , but there be a time limit .

Key US farm state senator be demand the Bush Administration end free trade talk with South Korea , until Seoul end a defacto ban on import of US beef .

Agriculture committee spokesman Keith Williams say the law-makers just run out of patience . 
`` Unless the export of US beef resume and both country be able to agree on a reasonable and fair bone tolerance level for future shipment , then , anything less than that , would result in the opposition of the senator that sign this letter , '' he say .
