The administrator of a fruit grower ' cooperative in southern New South Wales have tell grower creditor that they will only get around a quarter of their money back .

Win for avocado grower in blight fight 
Avocado grower have win their fight for tough restriction to protect the industry from the fungal disease , avocado blight . 
Biosecurity Australia have impose strong rule for import New Zealand avocado , include a ban on any fruit with windrub , which look the same a blight . 
Avocadoes Australia 's Chris Nelson say the new protocol could lead to a rise in the cost of fruit for consumer . 
`` Because there will be less fruit export to Australia there will be a change in that supply and demand balance and inevitably I guess the price may rise to a certain extent so they 're look towards probably a good return for the fruit they do send over , '' he say . 
Random inspection will be conduct on Australian fruit orchard this summer to ensure grower be not breach plant breeder ' right .

Western Australia 's commercial fishing sector be angry that be have not be consult about new marine park plan for the state 's north-west . 
The State Government will create the park , a part of an attempt to protect the environment , once the $ 15 billion Gorgon gas field be develop on Barrow Island .

`` It 's just point to I think that we be n't consult more closely in term of the Government 's intention .

Wool price have end on a positive note at the final Sydney auction for 2006 . 

The northern wool market indicator have finish on 858 cent a kilo , up 11 cent on last week .

Drought expect to drive more from farm 
Demographers and farm organisation say the severity of the drought be likely to accelerate the trend of primary producer leave the land . 
The National Farmers Federation say it do not expect an exodus , but the drought will continue the trend of few farmer run big property . 
Social researcher for the Victorian Department of Primary Industries , Dr Neil Barr , say history suggest few young people will become farmer . 
`` In the census period before the 1983 drought there be 10,000 people age in their late 20 , 25-30 that enter farming in the five year before it , and then in the late 1980s that have drop to 6,000 , '' he say .

Firefighters continue to battle large bushfires threaten the township of St Mary 's and Irish Town in Tasmania 's north-east . 
The fire front be about a kilometre north of the town , near the German Town Road , and fan by north-easterly wind . 
Tasmanian Fire Service district officer Steve Lowe say crew be work on control burn while condition allow , but be brace for an unfavourable weather change tomorrow , 
`` It 's still move quite slowly at this time however the forecast be not favourable for firefighting at all , '' he say . 

Pressure mount for quick wheat export decision 
Pressure be build on the Federal Government to make a quick decision on wheat export , with at least half a dozen company lodge application . 
Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran now have the final say on who should be allow to export wheat after the removal of AWB 's veto in the wake of the Cole inquiry . 
Sources say Brooks Grain , Cargill , Ozepulse and Louis Dreyfus be among several exporter who have lodge the late bid for around 3 million tonne . 
But Peter Howard from Ozepulse say it be still unclear if the new system will make it easy for AWB 's rival to export wheat . 
`` It 's new so there be a lack of clarity , I mean we 're guess what 's go to happen , '' he say . 
`` I would hardly consider it would have any adverse effect on the national pool . 
`` I ca n't see if you grant another competitor an approval they 've still get to buy the wheat , presumably you ca n't buy it for any less than what AWB be offer you 've get to pay more .

The Northern Territory 's outback community be rally around a severely injured campdrafter . 
Quita Docking be recover from a head injury she receive four year ago , when she be crush by her horse . 
In a miraculous recovery , she have leave her wheelchair and learnt to walk , and ride again . 
Mother Gladys Docking say she be grateful for local support which help to send Quita to Germany for stem cell therapy . 
She also want to encourage all rider to wear hard hat . 
`` Quita be always against it , a a teenager . I be always , always try to get her to wear it , '' she say . 
`` [ She ] never would , but [ I continue to encourage use ] , now more so than ever . Quita would still have suffer injury , but they would have be minimise . 
`` It do n't take much to have a bit of a hot head for a couple of hour , you can take it off when you be off the horse .

The wool market have end the year strongly , with the eastern market indicator up 14 cent to 839 cent a kilogram .

Buyers from China have dominate sale this year but a pick up in demand from other country have be a major factor in lift the market . 

Court date set for AWI case 
A trial date have finally be set for Australian Wool Innovation 's ( AWI ) long-running case against the animal right group , PETA . 
The Federal Court will hear the case over two month from October next year . 
Legal action be launch against PETA in 2004 after it mount an international campaign to boycott Australian wool , over the practice of mulesing and live export . 
Les Targ from AWI say the peak body plan to call more than 30 witness . 
`` I wo n't be specific about name but obviously we 'll be talk people who be expert in the area of fly control and expert in the geographic region , and the effect of fly in those region , so we 'll be call on a range of expert , '' he say . 

Roma saleyards for sale 
Australia 's big saleyard complex be on the market . 
The council-owned Roma saleyards in southern Queensland will most likely be put out to tender in the New Year . 
But yard manager be already deny a possible sale will squeeze out small independent agent in favour of big company like Elders and Landmark . 
Chairman of the Roma saleyards board Rob Loughnan say it be early day in the tender process and a sale would have to benefit all party . 
`` I want to hear from people about whether they think it would be good in private or public ownership , '' he say . 
`` Its not just he money we 're talk about , if someone want to buy it just to shut it down in favour of another centre somewhere , you know , away from Roma , so Roma lose the benefit of 400,000 cattle throughput a year , that 's not go to be of interest to u , '' he say . 
Major livestock agent Elders have deny it be behind the possible sale of Roma . 
Queensland livestock manager , Tony Gooden be reject speculation that his company be either interested in buy the yard , or set up it own facility in competition to the council-run centre .

Tasmania 's bushfires have destroy plantation timber worth an estimated $ 50 million . 
About 17,000 hectare of bush have be burn on the north-east coast since the fire begin last weekend .

Government inspector be assess stock loss after bushfires in eastern Victoria , which have destroy about 20 house .

A 48-year-old man die when he fell off a trailer while fight a fire near Heyfield in Gippsland . 
There have be significant stock loss around Dargo , and Angus Hume , from Victoria 's Department of Primary Industries , say farmer need to be ready for more fire front in coming day . 
`` You really must make sure that you have water provide for stock and feed if you have them in containment area and just those general thing that be about plan beforehand , '' he say . 

Climate change to worsen fire situation : report 
The farmer-funded Climate Institute say high bushfire danger day will increase by up to a third in the next 30 year , a a result of climate change . 
The lobby group have analyse data from the Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO , which suggest Australia be likely to heat up and become drier . 
Climate scientist Graham Pearman say government need to decide whether they invest in measure to mitigate climate change now , or boost firefighting resource later .

A new report back farmer claim that they be under pressure to cut cost to remain competitive in global trade . 
The Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics ( ABARE ) say while food export have grow at 10 per cent a year , it be get hard to make a profit in both export and domestic market . 
ABARE 's Lisa Elliston say manufacturer and processor be also under pressure . 

Farmers turn to Malaysia for cheap fodder 
Dairy processor Murray Goulburn be look to our northern neighbour for fodder to help farmer fee their cow . 
The first shipment of palm kernel extract from Malaysia be due in mid-January . 
The extract be a by-product of the palm oil industry , and be make up of ground and dry skin , and the flesh of the palm kernel . 
Ross Greenaway from Murray Goulburn say the rise price of grain make the extract a cheap option for farmer . 
`` This first load of palm kernel be $ 220 plus GST plus freight . That be very cost effective compare to the current price of grain , '' he say .

Riverina irrigators call for compensation 
Riverina irrigators have rally to voice their anger at New South Wales Government cut to their water allocation , and be call for compensation . 
Rice farmer , dairy farmer and cropper , already have zero water allocation this season , but since October the NSW Government have cut 52 per cent of farmer 's carry over water . 
This be water farmer have save in the previous year , to use in the current drought . 
So today farmer be rally in the street , to show their anger at the State Government 's decision . 
Farmers also say a number of town and 1,500 farm family now could run out of household water and water for stock .

He say there be huge growth opportunity for farm and harvest skin , and meat .

`` All we can really do be present the opportunity and make sure that we have the infrastructure and the training , and the like , and then it 's really up to the community . 
`` So whether they be ex-prisoners or they be not , a lot of it be just about create an opportunity and we be pretty happy to be do that . 

Wheat export issue divide grower 
Wheat grower across Australia be divide on whether Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran should allow AWB 's rival to export wheat . 
Mr McGauran now hold the wheat export veto and be consider 44 bid to export wheat to 20 country after call on trader to submit their application . 
Farmers disagree on what Mr McGauran should do , but believe open the market would be the end of the single desk . 
`` It 's too detrimental for the whole grain industry to allow those to take place , it would effectively destroy the single desk a we know it , '' one farmer say . 
`` As far a we 're concern a grower , the single desk have run it day . 
`` To think that you be just go to chuck all that out in one year I think be extremely dangerous , we need to have this debate first and then decide how our wheat be go to be handle . ''

Meanwhile Victorian grain grower be debate how they would like their wheat market overseas at a major forum in Bendigo today .

Qld storm crush fruit and cane crop 
Severe storm which lash south-east Queensland over the weekend have flatten young sugar cane crop and destroy fruit in the Childers district , near Bundaberg . 
Strong wind have bring down tree and power line , while hail stone describe a half the size of cricket ball have damage crop . 
Cane , mango and lychee grower John Muller be set to harvest fruit in coming week , but say his crop have be almost completely wipe out . 
`` There 's probably less than 1 per cent of the mango hang on the tree and every one of them have five or six chop out of them , '' he say .

`` If they 're talk to a farmer or a farmer 's wife or whoever , then they will be able to have the skill to be able to recognise those sign and symptom , '' he say . 
`` They 'll also be able to offer some help and advice a to where people can get help to see them through the problem that they 're experience . ''

For the first time , farmer in the central west of New South Wales have be fin for stop state authority from investigate claim of illegal land clearing . 
Farmers have blockade two property at Tottenham at the weekend .

One infringement notice for an $ 1,100 fine have be serve , with another two to be hand out this week .

As bushfires continue to rage in eastern Victoria , some farmer have have a chance to survey the damage cause by the blaze . 
Stock , shed and house have be lose so far and landholder be gear up to protect their property again a temperature rise this week .

Both be wheelchair-bound and Mr Bond say it be go to take a long time to rebuild . 

Cane smut find near Townsville 
The crippling fungal disease sugar cane smut have be discover even far north in Queensland , in the Herbert River region near Townsville . 
The disease , which cut crop yield , have be first find in the Isis and Bundaberg area in June , and more recently in the central region near Mackay . 
A two kilometre quarantine zone have be impose around the late discovery in the Lannacost area . 
Canegrowers chairman Alf Cristaudo say find the disease in the wetter northern region have be unexpected but grower be prepared . 
`` We would ask everyone now to be even more vigilant than they have be , it 's disappointing and a surprise that we be find it anywhere , '' she say . 

Apple and pear planting drop 
New planting of apple and pear tree have fall by up to 6 per cent . 
The late Bureau of Statistics figure for 2005-2006 also show apple production be down more than 15 per cent on the previous year . 

SA Govt accuse of mismanage fish stock 
A long-term prawn fisher in South Australia be concern about stock level , accuse the State Government of mismanagement . 
An official report in SA have find the prawn catch be only one third what it be in the 1970s . 
Commercial fisher Maurice Corigliano say the Government have allow overfishing in Gulf St Vincent and want boat number reduce . 
The Government have have meeting with the fisherman and tell them it be their responsibility to ensure the fishery be manage sustainably . 
Mr Corigliano say the Minister for Fisheries , Rory McEwen , be dodge the issue . 
`` It 's the Government 's responsibility to manage that fishery , they have the power to say how many vessel come in , how many vessel go out , when they can fish , where they can fish , what size prawn they can take , what size vessel they can use , '' he say . 
`` Regrettably , he be simply not do so and be simply dodge the issue . '' 
The Prawn Boat Owners Association disagree , say number have not deplete and there be no need to reduce licence . 
Currently there be only 10 license boat . 

Govt finalise revamped horticulture code 
The code of conduct for Australia 's horticulture sector have be finalise by the Federal Government . 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran say any new agreement and wholesaler sign after December 15 will be subject to the code . 
It be expect to be table in Parliament in February and will then become law .

Tasmanian farmer be export live dairy cow to Pakistan for the first time . 
About 1,000 cow be send to China from Tasmania each year but that trade have slow this season . 
Livestock agent Craig Waldron say the new market look promise , with Pakistan pay $ 800 a head for cross-bred heifer . 
`` Given the season on the current return of what you can expect to buy replacement stock for , it 's pretty reasonable to buy a female that be only just recently join , '' he say .

More than 100 horse have be grant a reprieve in the Guyra region of New South Wales after a campaign to stop them be send to the knackery .

`` People have call from a far away a Tasmania and I 'm actually get email even from overseas , '' she say . 

Economists call for independent national water body 
There be call today for an independent , national body to control Australia 's water resource . 
Two water economist have put together the plan to remove political tension between state and federal government . 
One of the plan 's author , CSIRO Professor Mike Young , say a more responsive and consistent system be need to decide water allocation , trading rule and entitlement . 
Professor Young say there be widespread concern that the current system be hamstring by politics . 
`` People be very frustrated with what 's happen , there 's a lot of frustration around the rule over water trading and thing like exit fee , '' he say . 
`` Every state be take subtly different approach , if you have a structure like this it would all be resolve in a unified way , so there 'd be no opportunity for arbitrage from one state to another . '' 
But there be concern from irrigators that the proposal would leave agriculture out of the water reform process . 
National Farmers Federation irrigation task force spokesman Laurie Arthur say farmer need to be represent . 
`` I have real concern that agriculture will not be front and centre of the debate , '' he say . 
`` I 'm a little bit concern at the moment that expertise within agriculture for example , within our irrigation company , be a bit remote from the decision-making process . '' 

Working together 
Meanwhile , peak farm , water , environment and business organisation have agree to work together to push for improvement in water security for farmer and urban user . 
The National Water Commission ( NWC ) stakeholder group have agree on priority , include well water accounting and reporting , and address over-allocation of river . 
Commission chairman Peter Corish say the group realise that body outside government can contribute to find solution to Australia 's water problem . 

Vets urge livestock check in bushfire region 
Vets be urge farmer in bushfire-affected district to check their livestock once fire have pass through . 
In Victoria 's Central Gippsland area , 530 beef cattle , 62 sheep and goat and 120 chicken have be lose . 
Department of Primary Industries vet Liz Parker say damage from the fire might not show for some day . 
`` They can look really bad , they can be cover in black and look terrible , but actually they really do n't have much damage at all , '' she say . 
`` Other animal can look fine but the burn can be in the respiratory tract and sometimes the evidence of that do n't come up for a couple of day as well , and they can be really life-threatening and the animal might need to be put to sleep . ''

Recycled water blame for lettuce damage 
Lettuce grower in Victoria fear their crop be be damage by recycled effluent water from the Werribee Sewage Farm , near Melbourne . 
More than half of Australia 's iceberg lettuce be grow at Werribee . 
The farmer have be use the recycled water since last year , when the State Government ban the use of underground water due to the drought . 
Southern Rural Water spokesman Clinton Rodda say an investigation be under way to find out what have cause stunt growth and discolouration of lettuce . 
`` Certainly the salinity be high than ideal and this be an interim scheme until , hopefully , the salt reduction program will move to low salt in the long-term , '' he say . 
`` But I think these farmer in Werribee south be very effective in the way they manage their crop , they 're aware of the high salinity . 
Some of them have deal with high salinity bore for many , many year in the past , so they learn how to deal with those high salinity level . ''

Vegetable grower say Australia be import far more produce than it export . 
Most of the surge have be for frozen and processed vegetable , particularly potato .

`` But there have also be some substantial increase in import come from the European Union as well . '' 

Emergency service fail to tackle fire : report 
An investigation into the 2003 Canberra bushfires have highlight a failure to attack fire early and a failure to warn the public of impend danger . 
Four people be kill and 500 home destroy in the blaze , which start in the mountain , west of Canberra . 
The coronial report make more than 70 recommendation , but there be concern over how the ACT Government will respond . 
ACT coroner Maria Doogan have hand down 15 finding on the cause of the fire . 
Among them , the ACT Emergency Services Bureau have fail to aggressively attack the fire . 
They withdraw crew on the night they start , fire trail be overgrow , and there be heavy fuel load . 
She also find that in the face of drought and extreme fire condition , the bureau have inadequate map , planning , bulldozer and other support for fire crew . 
The coroner have acknowledge that the ACT Government have already give more statutory power to emergency service , but have since return the fire control to answer to bureaucrats with no special emergency management knowledge .

A lack of student want to study agriculture and science be cause concern . 
Universities and scientific body say the shortage could hurt Australia 's ability to cope with issue like climate change and natural resource management .

The Federal Court have give Fortescue Metals Group open access to BHP Billiton 's iron ore rail line in Western Australia 's Pilbara region . 
The decision mean BHP Billiton can no longer stop other company from use the Mount Newman and Goldsworthy rail line , despite claim them a part of it own production process . 
Foretescue have successfully argue that the line be a 'service ' , under the Trade Practices Act and should be available to all company who need them . 
Fortescue spokesman Graeme Rowley say the court have uphold a right to fair competition . 
`` We not only now have achieve success for ourselves , but we 've also achieve success for Australia , '' he say . 
`` We now go to the Australian Competition Tribunal to ask them to approve effectively our access to that infrastructure . 
`` That overturn the Treasurer 's decision that we could not have that access . ''

AWB payment to Saddam regime not bribe : ATO 
There have be a strong surge in AWB 's share price today after the Australian Taxation Office ( ATO ) clear the company of any wrongdoing in an investigation of payment make under the oil-for-food program . 
Findings from the Cole inquiry say AWB write off payment under the oil-for-food program a tax deduction , include those to truck company Alia . 
It have be think the company may have be liable for up to $ 450 million in penalty and unpaid tax . 
But in a statement to the stock exchange , AWB say the tax office have find the payment do not constitute bribe to foreign public official under the Income Tax Assessment Act . 
The stock market have react favourably , with AWB share gain more than 7 per cent this morning , trading at $ 2.81 shortly before 10:00am AEDT . 
Meanwhile AWB 's rival be be ask for detail on their price , return to grower and the effect their application might have on the national pool . 
The condition be set out in a letter from the Department of Agriculture send this week to all the company that want to export wheat . 
The letter say the Government want more information a it try to establish the 'public interest ' value of each application . 
Exporter Peter Howard from Ozepulse say some of condition be surprising . 
`` I think it 's unusual - we 've always think and argue in the past that any application approve would n't really have any effect to the detriment of the pool , '' he say . 
`` But I guess it 's a point in question look at what the cost might be to those pool participant , would they increase if these application be grant . 
`` Perhaps they would , but our answer be that surely AWB should be reduce those fee to those pool participant . ''

In another development , New South Wales grain grower have step up the battle to save the single desk wheat export system at a rally in the Riverina .

Local farmer Hugh Hart say it maximise return to grower in a corrupt world market . 
`` Give the power of veto back to the company , '' he say . 
`` Let them get on with the job and let 's all look forward , so when it start to rain we can make a quid again and cut all this rubbish out . 
`` We 've have enough - no more inquiry , no more consultation , just get on with the job . '' 
Nationals MP Kay Hull say farmer need to voice their support for the single desk to silence a noisy minority in the Federal Government .

In Western Australia , 200 grower have also back the single desk at a public meeting in the Wheatbelt town of Mingenew .

US TAKES ACTION AGAINST AWB 
US Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns have temporarily ban wheat exporter AWB from use his department 's program , in the wake of the Cole Inquiry . 
Johanns act follow his directive last month that USDA resume debarment proceeding against AWB . 
He say he 's suspended AWB , several individual and a Minnesota commodity firm from USDA program or purchase . 
`` The extent of our ability to act here be debarment . 
`` Now , Congress may look at this and say there 's a need for a legislative approach . They certainly have a right to do that . 
The suspension do not prevent Australian wheat from be sell in the US or affect AWB 's ability to trade on commodity exchange . 
AWB spokesman Peter McBride say the program have only ever be a small part of the business . 
They include US government subsidy and loan guarantee for sell US crop overseas . 
He say the company voluntarily withdraw from the program , when the UN inquiry into the Oil for Food program begin . 
`` We have not use this export subsidy program since early 2004 and we inform the USDA earlier this year that we would voluntarily stand aside from use the program in the foreseeable future . 
`` So we 'll continue discussion with the USDA go forward , but we have n't use the program in a long time and we do n't envisage use itÂ '' . 
AWB 's share continue to trade strongly after yesterday 's clearance by the Australian Tax Office . 
The ATO have accept that payment make under the Oil-for-Food program do not constitute bribe to foreign public official , under the Income Tax Assessment Act . 
Austock analyst Paul Jensz say the ruling be worth around 50 cent to the share price . 
`` It 's one of the first bit of positive news to come out of what have be a fairly devastating year . 
`` This do help the momentum inside the company and the renewal and the change that they 're do on a cultural level and a cost levelÂ '' .

Beekeepers in eastern Australia be have mixed fortune . 
The eucalypt be burst with flower and nectar in southern New South Wales , but low world price , bushfires and drought be hurt . 
Seventy per cent of Australian honey come from eucalypt , and right now the gum in the Southern Tablelands be full of flower . 
Doug Sommerville with the NSW Department of Primary Industries say it 's in response to a break after the last drought and the intensity of this one : `` The fella be make good honey right now , off snow gum , yellow box , red gum , all in the nice quality honey '' . 
But he say disaster be imminent with the drought continue and beekeeper Greg Roberts say the fire of 2001 and now be devastate . 
`` It take many , many year for specie such a stringybark to come back after fire . '' 
With low world honey price , Australian beekeeper be switch from export honey to export live bee to the US , under the free trade agreement .

An abattoir in central western New South Wales , at the centre of a row over the Federal Government 's workplace reform , have a new owner . 
The previous owner of the Cowra abattoir sack 28 staff under the WorkChoices legislation and then offer to reinstate them at a low rate . 
The plant be hand over to adminstrators in August this year and then close .

`` Obviously we will have a reduction in staff , '' he say . 
`` The place fail before because it be over-manned . 
`` For a start there will be work an eight hour day , which be n't the case before . 
`` All the chain will be wind back . 
`` We will have a pretty good product come out of there , probably a good a product a anywhere on New South Wales will come out of there . 
`` It 's a good plant and need a little bit of money spending on it , it be in a great position .

Christmas have arrive early for at least one lucky farmer in central New South Wales .

`` Almost every dam be empty and almost every dam be full to overflow , '' he say . 
`` It be beautiful to watch because we have absolutely no chance of get away at all with worry about trough and pump water from here to the stock , but we wo n't have to worry about that now . '' 
The weather bureau be forecast possible isolated shower and storm late today and tomorrow over most of New South Wales . 
A rain band be move in from the south-west and rain be forecast this weekend right across the state . 

Thunderstorms bring welcome rain to Eyre Peninsula 
There have be a wide range of rainfall total record in South Australia , a a result of large thunderstorm which cross the state overnight . 
While the rain barely settle the dust in some area , dam be fill on the eastern Eyre Peninsula and through the state 's mid-north . 
Jan Girdham , who farm between Kimba and Cleve , have one of the high total with 52 millimetre . 

MIS plantation forestry tax incentive to stay 
The Federal Government have decide not to remove tax advantage for investor in plantation forestry under manage investment scheme ( MIS ) . 
But under new change it will change the law , to ensure that at least 70 per cent of investor 's money be spend on tree , instead of other project . 
Farmers believe the scheme create unfair competition for land and water , but assistant treasurer Peter Dutton say the farm sector also receive help . 
`` The Government have put in place a deliberate strategy to make sure that we support the forestry industry , '' he say . 
`` At the same time we have provide many other tax incentive and support through the tax system and government policy and otherwise for traditional farming measure such a the Farm Management Deposit Account so it 's about provide a balance . '' 
The Government have also launch a three-month review of the taxation of non-forestry MIS for crop such a grape and tomato . 
But there be criticism from the investment and the farm sector over the continuation of the timber tax deduction . 
Former rural banker and agricultural business consultant David Cornish say the Government have do nothing to address community concern over the impact of plantation . 
He say traditional farm enterprise be be overlook . 
`` These be just massive tax distortion or subsidy which be lead to distortion of capital into rural Australia , '' he say . 

Govt to buy back more scallop fishing licence 
The Federal Government will buy back another 150 fishing licence a part of it program to reduce over-fishing in Australian water . 
The new scheme include one third of the scallop fisher in the northern prawn fishery and 14 per cent of Bass Strait scallop fisher . 
Their early application for buyout be not consider good value by the Government . 

McGauran approve non-AWB wheat export contract 
Federal Agriculture Minister Peter McGauran have approve two wheat export contract for company other than AWB . 
One of the contract be for 300,000 tonne for Wheat Australia to ship wheat to Iraq , where AWB have be ban from trading and one for Western Australian-based CBH of 500,000 tonne to Indonesia . 
Mr McGauran say of the 46 application receive they be the only two consider to be in the public interest . 
He say AWB have give assurance the two application will not have an impact on national pool return . 
As a condition of the export permit , both Wheat Australia and CBH must contribute $ 4 a tonne to the national pool up to a total of 800,000 tonne . 
Meanwhile , the head of AWB International have warn the Federal Government he will have no other choice than to wind up the company , if it veto over wheat export be remove permanently . 
AWB International chairman Ian Donges say the Government must be careful in what it decide . 
`` I think a lot of commentary have be around , '' he say . 
`` We can have the the bulk veto power with someone else and have a permit system along side a single desk system . 
`` Quite clearly you ca n't do that . 
`` If the single desk close down or in fact change to the point where we do n't have a future for the say [ in ] the 2007 pool then we will phase out of business . 

Early grain harvest see farmer enjoy pre-Christmas activity 
Victorian grain farmer be be rope into Christmas preparation by their family , with harvest finish early . 
Usually most cropper be strip paddock right up to and after Christmas day , but the drought have have a drastic impact on yield . 
Grain grower say the extra time this year be a mixed blessing . 
`` I actually do n't sow a crop this year , so maybe I 'll have an early Christmas , a nice early Christmas , '' one grower say . 
`` Had a bit more Christmas shopping time , so it 's good to get that do instead of at the last minute , '' another say .
